John S. Lee wrote:

>  ( a heckuva lot of stuff...)

Ok.  So.

So John and Noah are at each other's virtual throats on this.  Noah
threw down some rather weird defensive "logic" for which John proceeded
to verbally bash his head in.  I'd have done the same, I'm sure.

BUT:  
	o Noah is a good guy who made a dumb mistake
	  and is now acting defensively.  
	o John is a good guy teaching Noah the hard 
	  penalty for racist remarks in this forum.

SO, let's just calm down a bit, ok?  You guys kiss and make up, alright?

Some observations:

1. JOHN: Rather than go around and around about whether the "joke" Noah
sent was Ebonics or slang, why not give examples of both so we, the poor
uneducated melanin-challenged folk ;) , can make the distinction in the
future?

2. For some, the difference between being funny and being racist is
whether or not you're the underdog.  I personally find Russell Simmons
"Def Comedy Jam" to be one of the most amazingly racist programs on TV
today.  Open, vitriolic characterizations of whites typifies most of the
routines.  I find it patently offensive and unacceptable, but it's
hysterically funny if you're on the "black" side of the fence, no?

3. So Noah is Native American.  Fine.  Well, that really plays no part
in whether or not the humor was acceptable.  If a little green man
stepped out of a spaceship and started delivering a comedy routine
smattered with the "N" word, I'd personally walk up and shut off the
mike.  There's never a good excuse for racial remarks, period.

4. So I'm a brownish shade of pink (popularly referred to as "white"). 
Fine.  That doesn't mean I can't be just as offended by a racist
statement that disrespects a dark brown (popularly referred to as
"black") friend.  We are all here together, and we're all family.

5. THE COLOR DOESN'T MATTER.  If this had a been a list of jokes that
slandered ANYONE based on their skin color, I, and I'm sure most of the
people on this list, would have a very real problem with it.

6. IMPORTANT: The joke was dumb, Noah apologized for it, and I think the
whole incident made an important point, that "jokes" of that nature just
aren't appropriate.

Much love and phat hugz,

S

Ok.... Someone posts the following rumor:

>><<From a friend of Thomas Troubles, I hear that he was stabbed 13(?) times in
>>the face and chest, by 4 black dudes who broke into his home in Berkeley and
>>were stealing his equipment.  Apparently he tried to keep them from taking
>>the stuff, and fought hard, putting two of them in Intensive Care, and 
>>actually kept his stuff!

>Can anyone tell me why mentioning the race of the alleged assailants is
>crucial in the (above) text? I can see why it's important in the context of
>the rest of the paragraph. I can't wait to hear your responses....  
>--Monty

>I was just reading a post about TT and him catching a buglar in his home and
>them stabbing him. It is very interesting how people are quick to point out
>nationality, cause had they been WHITE guys like they were no one mentions that
>but if it is a person of color they are quick to say "some BLACK DUDES did it"

>ONE DAY WE WILL ALL BE COLOR BLIND...

I believe that the only reason that race was mentioned was that, at the time
it was assumed that certain Russians had attacked TT. If the persons who
attacked TT had an excess of melanin then it stands to reason they also were
lacking in russian-ness. Something like; If black then not russian....Most
of the time....

For yer info ... i happened to be at the BC College of Pharmacists the 
other day and grabbed a book called Drugs and Drug Abuse off the shelf.  
it was a 1996 edition, but stupidly i didn't get the authors' names etc. 
so this isn't the most organized post but i thought someone might find it 
interesting ...

KETAMINE
Drug Class: Disassociative Anesthetic

Ketamine (Katalar) is a sythetically manufactured disassociative(1) 
anesthetic with potent hallucinogenic and analgesic features similar to 
those produced by phencyclidine (PCP).  It occurs as a white crystalline 
powder, freely soluble in water and soluble in alcohol.  When it is 
injected intravenously over a period of one minute, disassociative 
feelings are experienced very rapidly and unconsciousness may be achieved 
almost immediately.  The therapeutic intravenous dose is between 1 and 2 
mg per kilogram of body weight; the dose range for intramuscular 
injection is approximately three times as great.  A therapeutic dose 
causes increased heart rate and elevated blood pressure.

Unconsciousness lasts for only 10 - 15 minutes(2); for this reason, 
ketaime is useful only in short surgical procedures (usually those 
involving the head and neck where the use of an anesthetic mask is 
inconvenient) and for induction of anesthesia before switching to 
another anesthetic.  A number of problems associated with its use can 
further limit its therapeutic value: unsatisfactory muscle relaxation; 
increased muscle tone; unpredictable and sometimes violent jerking and 
twitching (which can be precipitated by otherwise relatively innocuous 
stimuli); vivid and unpleasant dreams during and after surgery; and slow 
recovery from anesthesia (up to several hours).  During the period of 
recovery, patients may experience headache, nausea and vomiting, 
hallucinations, feelings of unreality, confusion, and sensations of 
heaviness or floating.  Irrational behaviour may also occur.  
Hyperexcitablity (and sometimes convulsions) may be precipitated by mild 
stimuli for up to several hours after surgery.  These adverse effects are 
particularly common in patients over the age of 30; nonetheless, some 
patients find the hallucinogenic effects to be pleasant.  The incidence 
of adverse effects is low among children.

Ketamine has been subject to some abuse in both the United States and 
Canada.  Street preparations include powders, capsules, tablets, crystals 
and solutions.  Nonmedical users inject (estimated) doses of 50 mg or 
sniff between 60 and 100 mg.  At such levels, consciousness is usually 
maintained.  The main desired effects are euphoria and "mystical" 
revelations, as well as hallucinations and pleasant sensations of both 
floating and stimulation.  Users generally experience impairment of 
cognitive processes, dizziness, motor incoordination, slurred speech, and 
confusion.  Severe adverse episodes sometimes occur and resemble the toxic 
psychotic state caused by PCP.  The principle hazardous effect of high 
doses is respiratory depression.

There has been little research on the protracted nonmedical use of 
ketamine, and it is not known whether tolerance or dependance develops 
with regular use.  However, a number of regular users do experience 
"flashbacks".  In fact, there are reliable reports of some patients' 
experiencing recurrent hallucinations after ketamine anesthesia.


(1) In this context, disassociative means producing feelings in the user 
of disassociation from the external environment.

(2) Intense analgesia lasts for up to 40 minutes.


. . . 

pounce

Nuggles the Whump-Whump bird flew quietly above the wonderful greenness of
Happy-Tree Meadow, eagerly awaiting the cheerful humming that always
signalled the beginning of the Gubbywub Parade and Picnic, which annually
provided the Whump-Whumps with enough Gubbywub fur and flesh to last the
entire winter.
                                         - Bruce K. MacDonald
                                           Scarborough, Ont.

> As far as I'm concerned you're all racist ...

        I'll go along with that. Racism is a particular flavor of
"ethnocentrism". Ethnocentrism is the *universal human tendency* to
believe that whatever group you are a member of is the "best" group,
that your group does things "right", that other groups that are different
from you are at best "wrong" or "stupid" or if they oppose you are perhaps
"evil".

        To get past my own racism (ageism, nationalism, speciesism,
raverism, ...) I have to first acknowledge that it exists. Then I can
*start* to work on a little self-reprogramming. Yes, I'm a racist. But
at least I'm working on that.

> > Thumper Thumped.....
> >
> > >>>>>
> > Does anyone have any good healty suggestions on how I can keep my energy
> > and vibe going past 3:00 am without drugs? Somebody send me a magic
> > recipe please.

FOOD.  Otherwise your body just runs out of calories and dies.

However, anything heavy will divert energy towards digestion and away
from dancing; same problem.

Fruit is a good solution.  Bananas are nice and mushy and easy to
digest.  Fruit juice is good but too much on an empty stomach gets
acidic.  A big bunch of bananas and a quart of your favorite thick soupy
Odwalla admixture will keep you going for a LONG time.

Plus, make sure to have eaten well before you go, and drink lots of
water whilst there.  Borderline dehydration shows up as tiredness too.

// grigsbeast

happy monday night everyone! :)
	I went to koinonea expecting a phat party, and my mind was 
blown! I agree that the sobriety level was incredible there, but 
sober or not, most EVERYONE had smile buzz ON.. not only smiles but 
LOVE too! 
	Everything was perfectly harmonious.. The drumming, the music 
being downstairs and the whole upstairs just a nice big chillin' vibe 
thing goin on.. I felt like I was with family, and for once didn't 
experience any negative vibes (i was lucky enough to avoid some of 
the negative guys but was disappointed to see tagging).. 
	Massive props to ALL the djs who spun, it was HARD to tear 
myself from the speakers but it must be done once in awhile :)) you 
guys are turning a junglist into a trancer ya know! :P 
	The Chai and water were perfect, no lines for either of these 
(which was great) and so was the fruit (i especially want to say 
THANX! to the guy who was running around slicing oranges!)! The 
location, I was surprised it didnt get busted but with no in/out 
privelages iI guess not as surprised.. I almost didn't get in after 
taking a dangerously lightheaded (cuz of the HEAT not drugs, mind 
ya'all) person outside.. =o but thanks for letting us back in whoever 
you are! :)
	All in all, the best party in a LONG time. Big BIG BIG props 
to the wonderful beautiful Koinonea kru for everything they did to 
make the night as spectacular as it was :) ANYWAYYY take care 
everyone and hope you have great weeks!
love hugs and a whole lotta smiles,
lara

called the cops or not. Stabbing people is in a whole different

fucking Mafia code-of-silence talk-to-the-cops-and-you-deserve-
to-die. Bullshit! Go join a gang and deal crack if that's your
attitude.

that one might use melanin rich, and conversley melanin chalenged.  Now,
THAT has a better ring to it.

scientific PROOF POSITIVE, I present the following as evidence, article 1:

"...I don't know, yeah, I'm just a rhyme sayer, skins proctected 'gainst
the ozone layer, breakdown 2001 it might be best to be black or just borwn,
COUNTDOWN!" - Public Enemy, Fear Of A Black Planet

article 2:

"...black man, black woman , black baby...white man, white woman, white
baby...black man , white woman, black baby...white man, black woman, black
baby...check it out!..." - Public Enemy, Fear Of A Black Planet

known Black Russians.  Then again, I thought a black russian was a drink.

someone who is bi-racial and Russian.  I hear that's been going around
these days. Or it could be the fabled minstrel russian.  You know, they put

promoter. Mammy!

and listen to samples? What about tracker files .XM and =
.XI...etc...sounds and loops and songs? Would you submit files if you =
were given the opportunity to share? (given proper credit of course)

art people care to see.  Would you care to see art? Would you send us =
art..digitally or by mail..if you were given the ability? Does this =
interest anyone? Let me know what you think.

you were able to add in any text you wanted...such as give your own =
angle on record reviews, articles, and what not? Any other ideas?

the monday night dinner has passed through many iterations, and since my
monday night schedule has had some changes, i can no longer sponsor any
monday night dinners!

your favorite restaurant, wherever you wish to sponsor it.

so, get out and sponsor your own!

Subject: Love Is In The Air

The following post contains views and subject mater that might not be suitable for all readers.  
Open mindedness is suggested.

I was not sure I was going to post any information about this party on the net.  I always get my 
head chewed of every time I go out of my way to try and inform the people on this list about my 
events.   I debated for some time whether I was going to subject myself to the aggravation of 
having people misinterpret my intentions and actions and inevitably blow things completely out 
of proportion.  But because of my open mindedness, I decided to go with the benefit of the doubt 
and tell everyone who cares about our event.

The event on Feb 15th is going to be unlike any event we have ever produced.

It is our 5 year anniversary event.  We are going to take everything that we have learned in the 
past 5 years and apply a very generous application of PLUR into making an incredible party.  In 
my opinion, there is no substitute for experience, and there is no excuse for ignorance.   We 
are not holding anything back, this event will break new ground.

This event is all about love.  It is about giving, and sharing.   

It is really hard for me to put my feeling into words when it comes to something as passionate 
an meaningful as this.  All I can say is that this event is going to be like non before, and 
will hopefully set the pattern for other promoters to follow.   If you want to understand what I 
mean, you will just have to experience it for yourself.

The event is a benefit for the environment.  At the party will be tables set up by several non 
profit environmental activity organizations that will receive monetary donations from a portion 
of the proceeds from this party.  Yes StarChild, I said a portion, and NO I will not open up my 
books for anyone to review.  Please lets not start that discussion all over again. 
The better the party does, the more money we will donate.  Your support of this event will be 
directly reflected in our contribution the save our planet and aid in education about 
environmental problems.  It is something that we call - "Edutainment:  Educational 
Entertainment"  This is the direction that We will be focusing all our future events on.

I know that some of you have this certain stigma about "massive" and large parties in general 
for whatever reasons.  That is fine.  I respect your views, and would prefer that you kept them 
to yourselves, or e-mailed me privately.  But for those of you who have always wanted to 
experience a large party with the small party vibe, than don't miss this event.

A party is not measured by its size.  Size has become a barrier that is insinuated to be 
inversely proportional to the vibe of the party.  I can't understand how so many of you got 
suckered into believing this BS.   I believe that the problem lies in the fact that it takes a 
lot of very very very hard work and determination to create a large party with a good vibe.  And 
because it does take so much work, most promoters are more willing to perpetuate the mentality 
that you cannot have a good vibe at a large party, so therefore large parties do not have a good 
vibe.  This to me is the epitomy of laziness, and ignorance.  I don not only believe that large 
party can have a great vibe, I am going to prove it.
  
You see, the vibe is something that is created far before the party takes place.  It is a 
combination of: belief, attitude, motivation, concern, effort, and most of all; inspiration and 
vision.  When these factors collimate with good intentions, the vibe is created.  This is the 
vibe that people take with them to the party.  Vibe is not created by an event at all, it is 
expressed there.  The promoters job is to manifest to expectations that people bring with them 
into reality.  If this is done, then the vibe at the event will be better than good, it will be 
extraordinary.

You can not please everybody.  I used to think you could, and at one time it was possible, but 
the scene is very dynamic, and changes all the time.  Over the past 5 years of throwing parties 
and being involved in the scene, I have seen many changes and I have come up with many of my own 
conclusions as to what is needed to make a good party.  These beliefs will be self evident in 
our anniversary party on the 15th.    

I hope to get a chance to see everybody out there, sharing love, and rejoicing in the goodness 
created by our culture, spirituality, and energy. 

For all the info and DJ lineups and directions, check the SF Raves calendar, and dial the info 
numbers.  Leave me a message if you like or e-mail me.  I would love to hear your opinion or 
suggestions.

Attached is a copy of the Global Party Network News Letter that we sent out.  For those of you 
who do not understand what we are doing at Feel Good Entertainment, maybe this will bring you up 
to speed.

PLUR
Vlad, Feel Good Entertainment,  Executive Producer , aka: Ray Vonie


Global Party Network News Letter                  Issue #  2          Page # 1

Introduction

Dear Global Party Network Members, it is a new year and it looks like it is going to be a 
wonderful and positive year in all respects.  The purpose of this newsletter is to keep 
everybody informed about our upcoming plans as well as sharing information about topics that 
concern our scene and our culture.

The Past Five Years Were Just The Beginning 

It was a Thursday night on Valentine's Day, in 1992, when 200 people crowded into a small 
basement for the first event promoted by Feel Good Productions.  The name has now become Feel 
Good Entertainment, but the vision has not changed, and our mission is still to create positive 
events that make people FEEL GOOD.  Our parties are now safer, legal, more culturally 
diversified, always original, and virtually hassle free.
People often ask me, "What is FGE all about?"  Well, the answer is very simple.  We want to 
create a cohesive medium that culminates  Music, Dance, Spirituality, Expression, and Awareness, 
so that it promotes Peace, Love, Unity, and Respect for everything.  It means more than just 
throwing outrageous parties, it's producing incredible dance collectives for meaningful reasons.  
We are a dynamic organization with real concerns about our community, our culture, and the 
direction of the rave scene.  We work year-round on creating this cohesive medium that we called 
the Global Party Network.  By networking everyone's resources, we want to create a powerful 
organization that will maintain the integrity of the reason why we 'RAVE'.  This is what FGE is 
all about.   We are all the Rave Generation.  Lets keep it REAL.   

97 and Beyond 

The GPN (Global Party Network) has many aspects.  These include; The  Buzz-Line, Global Party 
Productions, The GPN News, GlobalParty.Com., the Membership Card Program, and YOU.  These are 
just some of the things that make up the GPN and much more is being worked on daily.  The 
following will hopefully bring everybody up to speed on the past, present, and future of  the 
GPN.   
Three years ago, we started the Buzz-Line.  This information resource is to help ALL promoters 
pass on their event info, and to help ALL ravers find out about all the parties and clubs.  We 
provide this service to spread the word about positive parties going on and to keep people 
informed and aware of our culture.  This service is free to you, but for us, it is expensive and 
time consuming to operate and maintain.  Sometimes 'Shit Happens' and it breaks down,  but we 
are still doing our best to make it even more reliable and dependable.   In the event that there 
are problems with the new number, 415-569-3300,  then please call the FGE info line @ 415-568-
1338 for updates or changes.   We plan on expanding the Buzz-Line with many surprises this 
year, so keep calling.
Global Party Productions is the engine that creates FGE events.  You are all members of the GPN, 
therefore Global Party Productions are parties for you.  Every one of our events is a growth 
experience.  With each party, we learn and improve the way we do things.  As always, we make 
sure that all of our events are positive for you, the community, and our culture.   We 
have always made some form of  donation to non-profit organizations, whether the event made a 
profit or not.  It is our ultimate goal to eventually expand Global Party Productions into a 
'Benefactory' collective, producing 100% beneficial events for our community.  This might still 
be a ways down the road but we plan on setting up our events so that each time we are able to 
contribute more, until we reach our goal.   This will give all of our events a method of 
channeling the positive vibe created at the parties into a meaningful direction.   Makes me FEEL 
GOOD just thinking about it.
What you are reading now is our second issue of the Global Party Network News.  We hope that 
this grows and becomes something informative and meaningful as a regular periodical of the 
network.  In future issues, we would like to see articles contributed by some members of the 
GPN.   Your comments, views, and questions are always welcome.  Please feel 
free to submit any articles, stories, poems, or artwork to us anytime.  If you have something 
you want to share with us, please fax it to 415-654-9354, or send it to Feel Good Entertainment,  
951 Old County Rd.  Suite # 217, Belmont, CA.  94404.
By summertime, the GPN will be online.  Our domain is registered @ WWW.GlobalParty.Com.   We 
will let you know as soon as it is ready.   If you want to contribute to our website, please 
leave a message on our voice mail. 
The GPN is like a support mechanism for our rave community.   Many of you already have the 
membership card, most of you don't.  If you did not pick yours up at Megga-Buzz, they will be 
available at the GPN booth at Love A-Fair on Feb 15th.   The card program will get you discounts 
at clubs, parties, food, merchandise, and other services that support the GPN.  It is just 
our way of saying thanks for your support.  Keep calling the Buzz-Line for updates.  
This is just the beginning of the GPN.  We have a lot of incredible ideas on how to create our 
network.  It will take a lot of hard work and a great deal of support.  By working together we 
can accomplish more than our wildest dreams.  Lets show the world the power of  RAVING. 

A Very Special Celebration of Unconditional Love.

How much do you love raving?  Does raving love you back?  What does it mean to you?   What do 
you get out of it?  Is it about the music, the dancing, the energy, the spirituality, the 
people, or the whole scene?  Why do you do it?  The answers to these questions are the reasons 
for this party.    In our own individual ways, we all have an intimate love affair 
with raving.  It means a lot more to us than just partying or dancing, it is the ritualistic 
devotion and dedication that makes us all feel good about ourselves when we know that our 
partying has a positive message, that it has a purpose,  a deeper meaning, and a direction.  
That is what creates our love affair with raving. 	
Valentine's is a reason to express love and affection.  This Valentine's, lets share our 
unconditional love.  Our five year birthday party is a festival dedicated to environmental 
awareness and consciousness.  A portion of our proceeds will be donated to several non-profit 
environmental activity programs.  Lets show our love for Mother Earth by helping to 
conserve our natural resources and  to protect our only planet. 
This party will be set up like a small festival, or like a FAIR (get it??)    We do not want to 
give away all the surprises, but I'll put it like this -  we are putting a lot of passion into 
this party.  It is our five year anniversary and we aren't going to do anything short of 
spectacular to celebrate this event.  We have a wonderful, fully permitted, centrally located, 
indoor and outdoor, Bay Area location.  Take a look at the flyer and read it carefully - this 
party is going to break new 
ground.  As always, we are going to do our best to create a large party with the small party 
feel.  We will do our part and set up the event, but you are the one that will set the vibe, so 
please come prepared to share your love with everybody, and it will turn out to be a very 
memorable night full of fun, excitement, and absolutely excellent music.
	We have enclosed a special gift for all GPN members.  It is a cutaway coupon on the bottom 
of the flyer.  This is just a small way to show you our love and appreciation for your support.  
We look forward to seeing you all on Feb 15th.  Get there early, or you might miss some of the 
incredible surprises that we have in store for you, and please recycle the flyer by sharing it 
with a friend. 

Tagging - Its Not Cool At All !!!! 

Graffiti is Art, but Tagging is Vandalism.  It's destroying our scene.  Here is a list of 
locations that will never again be used for raves because of tagging; Cow Palace, Richmond 
Civic, Henry J. Kaiser, Vallejo & Sonoma County Fairgrounds, Fashion Center, Concourse, 
Galleria, Santa Cruz Civic, and many more.  It costs the rave scene money by making raves 
more expensive, and gives us a bad image by giving society the wrong impression.  Please protect 
and respect our scene, as well as the art form of graffiti  by  putting an end to tagging before 
we run out of places to have raves.   Please spread the word.

Editorial  (Just My View on Things) 
 
Music is has a special way of distinguishing people and separating generations.  The 60's gave 
us Hippies.  In the 70's it was Disco.  The 80's brought us Rock and Roll, and now it's the 
90's, and everybody is raving to house music.   Raving is becoming  more and more accepted every 
day.  What started as underground music and parties has grown to become a major influence in our 
lifestyles and attitudes.  Some things, such as the spread of  Peace, Love, Unity, and Respect 
(PLUR) are good for society, and we feel proud about this positive contribution from our 
culture.  Other things, such as the exploitation of the culture by mainstream capitalization, 
are less appealing.  We can't sit around and wish for things to get better, because they won't.  
However, our attitudes, participation, and behavior can influence the expansion of raving 
in a more positive direction, bettering society.  We have a very unique heritage, and it would 
be a shame if it was forgotten or misunderstood.  It is up to each one of us to figure out what 
we can do to influence society's perception of our generation.  It's no longer 'Just Do It', 
it's about doing it the right way for all the right reasons.  Lets show our pride.  This is our 
time.  We are the Rave Generation.

* * * * * Please re-post where appropriate * * * * *

Dear Friends,

NetAction, the Institute for Global Communication, and Media Alliance are
co-sponsoring a four-week workshop on how to be a Virtual Activist.

The workshop will be held in San Francisco, beginning March 3, for activists
interested in learning how to use the Internet effectively for organizing,
advocacy, and outreach.  Classes are scheduled for four consecutive Mondays,
March 3, 10, 17, and 24, from 6:30-9:30 p.m. at Media Alliance, 814 Mission
Street, Suite 205.

The workshop is designed specifically for people who want to learn how to
make better use of the Internet for organizing, advocacy, media outreach,
building membership, education, and fund raising.  Participants should have
some experience using a computer, but previous online experience is not
required.

The first two sessions will be an overview of the basics of the Internet,
including selecting an Internet service provider, using E-mail and Web
browsers, and more advanced tools.  The last two sessions will focus on how
to make use of these tools for activism, including fund raising and
membership building, with examples of successful strategies.

Online homework will be assigned and temporary Internet access accounts may
be available on a case-by-case basis for students who need them.

NetAction, the Institute for Global Communication, and Media Alliance are
co-sponsoring a four-week workshop on how to be a Virtual Activist.

The workshop will be held in San Francisco, beginning March 3, for activists
interested in learning how to use the Internet effectively for organizing,
advocacy, and outreach.  Classes are scheduled for four consecutive Mondays,
March 3, 10, 17, and 24, from 6:30-9:30 p.m. at Media Alliance, 814 Mission
Street, Suite 205.

The workshop is designed specifically for people who want to learn how to
make better use of the Internet for organizing, advocacy, media outreach,
building membership, education, and fund raising.  Participants should have
some experience using a computer, but previous online experience is not
required.

The first two sessions will be an overview of the basics of the Internet,
including selecting an Internet service provider, using E-mail and Web
browsers, and more advanced tools.  The last two sessions will focus on how
to make use of these tools for activism, including fund raising and
membership building, with examples of successful strategies.

Online homework will be assigned and temporary Internet access accounts may
be available on a case-by-case basis for students who need them.

To register, phone 415-546-6491.  Cost is $95 for members of Media Alliance,
NetAction, and IGC; $125 for non-members.

Activists and organizations interested in co-sponsoring Virtual Activist
Workshops in communities outside the San Francisco Bay Area should contact
Audrie Krause at NetAction, by phone: 415-775-8674, or by E-mail:
akrause@igc.org.


--
Audrie Krause  <<NetAction>>  E-MAIL: akrause@igc.org
601 Van Ness Ave., No. 631    San Francisco, CA 94102
TELEPHONE: (415) 775-8674     FAX: (415) 673-3813
* * *       WEB: http://www.netaction.org      * * *

From: Anthony E <tymat@community.net>
Subject: Re: odyssey
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This was a really neat party considering it was the first rave thrown by US
Eternal Ent.  The lighting was superb, the sounds were very nice, and
everyone had their best smile on.  The few problems that I noticed was the
VMB which didn't give the right directions to the map point and the map
point which didn't give the right directions to the party, good thing I've
been to that place before so I really didn't get lost.  Then there was the
girl who had too much LSD and was supposedly raped and started freaking out
which abruptly ended the party at around 5:00am.  No matter what we do
there are going to be assholes in our scene.  I can deal with the drunks,
the gangsters, the snobs, but I CAN NEVER DEAL WITH RAPISTS!  A RAVE ISN'T
A PLACE TO GET LAID PEOPLE!  That person is guilty of either 2 kinds of
rape statutory(sp?) rape and raping someone who is intoxicated...  Oh well,
 I feel sorry for the girl but I also believe that she has to take
responsibility for her actions and she should have at least known a little
better before putting any substances in her body.  The other bad part to
this was her friends abandoned her when she started getting attention from
everyone.  SOME FRIENDS THEY ARE!  People, if you know that your friend is
on drugs please, please be sure to watch over them for their 6-12 hour trip
if you are their real friend.  I have guided a lot of people throughout
their trips on LSD and E and a lot of other drugs and I make sure I am
there for them whenever they need help be it getting a drink of water or
just giving a warm hug to give that fuzzy E feeling.  Anyway,  I'm done
bitching for now.  I hope that this becomes a learning experience for
everyone for years to come.  

Have a nice day!

Anthony E


-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
      Anthony Eufemio
 Professional Computer Geek
       800-981-5465
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Feb  4 09:34:16 1997

Dear Mr. NStuff,


> Any proof of rape?

Please read below so that I can correct your ignorance.  If I were ever
raped, I certainly would not want to have a friend with your cavalier
attitude about the subject.

> 
>   I don't know man..   I could understand how this could happen at Home
> Base or something..   But at a little house.    The way I see it, just my
> opinion. In this little house, the only place you would get away w/ raping
> someone, would have to be in the promoters private little room.  Know what
> I mean?  I don't think everyone is just going to stand around and let this
> shit happen. 

I'd just like to inform you that a rape can occur in a large room, in a
small room, outside, inside.  The size of the place does not matter.
Especially when people are VERY unwilling to get involved with
interactions between other people.  For your information women are taught
to scream fire instead of rape in order to get help. And why is it so
unbelievable that this would happen at a small rave when a certain aspect
of raves is a tolerance of more expressed sexuality.  This just makes it
more likely that people won't get involved.


>   But hey, sounds like no one knows for sure if this really happened..  So
> some girls said she got raped, who knows, they were probably frying there
> asses off too. They might of just thought she was raped.
>   If it is true.  How did it happen? And why does no one in this little
> house know who did it?

That is the typical excuse that has been used for decades, "She was too
_________(insert varying intoxicants here) to know what she was doing,
therefore she couldn't have been raped."  Or, "She deserved it due to
________ (1-dressing sexy, 2-I know she wanted it).  The only thing I can
imagine worse than being raped would be being raped on acid.  And I don't
really think someone would imagine a trauma like that.  

Of course, women have responsibity too, and I am not a supporter of "we're
all victims."  But, Mr. NStuff, your attitude is the purveyor of a larger
ignorance about this crime, and I think you should do some intelligent
re-thinking.

And, I'd like to remind you, MEN can be raped as well as women, and it is
NOT as rare as you might think.  And, most people are raped by
acquaintances whom they trust.  And, yes, rape can be hard to prove, but
I"d like to give people the benefit of the doubt.  And, people do cry
wolf, which is really terrible and makes you not want to give people the
benefit of the doubt.  

Just, please, don't be so cavalier about such a serious topic.  The girl
was only 15.  That's sure a nice way to grow up.  Shit like this happens
and then we bitch about all the negative media raves get.  Well, rave have
a seriously shady side, don't you think??  I personally feel really sorry
for that girl, and especially her parents.  What a terrible thing to have
happen.  My worst nightmare is about being raped.  

That's all I have to say on the topic.  I cc'd this to the list because it
is a problem that needs to be addressed in the rave scene, but moreso in
society in general.

-KaySEE

Coming to your Frequency Modulation dial somewhere between 87 and 107
Megahertz is MRAU, the latest radio fad... [Rave Alternative-Underground
radio, the music formerly known as techno]

That's right, we are determined to challenge the commerical "alternative"
scene with a whole bunch of commercial "underground" material. You ask,
"how can it be underground if it's commercial"? Our investors asked the
same question and we answered, "Who would have ever thought that
"alternative" would be commercialized? We don't want to miss out on the
oppurtunity of commercializing the underground and we want your help"...

So, after receiving hundreds of millions of dollars from companies and
individuals, whose ethics and moral practices reflect absolutely nothing of
the ideals of the rave sub-culture from whence the majority of music comes
from, we feel we are now fully prepared to bring the underground to the
mainstream...

Flip around on your FM dial until you find us... Then listen to all of our
wonderful adverstisements for products and services which are intended to
fully take advantage of the "average" american consumer and transmutate
them from normal less than productive americans into full blown candy-raver
slackers. Also keep your ears peeled for our new radio endeavors:

WRCU Rave-Country Underground (formerly known as gabber)
WRSU Rave-Soul Underground (currently "dance music format radio")
WRRU Rave-Rock Underground (also includes some not so well known
"industrial" acts like Nitzer Ebb, Front 242, Ministry and NIN)
WRGU Rave-Gospel Underground (our biggest risk, religous rave music)
WRCU Rave-Classical Underground (formerly experimental)
WRPU Rave-Pillow Underground (formerly known as ambient)
WREU Rave-Elavator Underground Musak (formerly known as house music)
WRJU Rave-Jazz Underground (formerly known as acid jazz)

The possibilities are endless. Stay tuned for more details...

m

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Feb  4 11:14:19 1997

Date: Tue, 4 Feb 1997 11:14:12 -0800 (PST)
From: KC <scarab@value.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: An Observation
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.970204110315.28925I-100000@value.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

With the spate of recent busts, do we think it is wise to go about listing
the address and detailed descriptions about available spaces.  This is
a public forum, anyone can read it easily enough.  The lack of
spaces is problem enough without advertising "Here's our address, come
bust us!!"   Information is good, but there is such a thing as TOO
much of a good thing in this case.  Secrecy isn't all bad. :\  

I dunno, just my thought.

-KaySEE

p.s. My advice is probably the same on the recent influx of "I did E at
this party and my friend did it at this party."  Think about who you
are advertising too.  On sfraves we feel like we can trust one
another, and I like to think of it that way.  But, one should still be
careful.  Email *is* considered written evidence, and it is starting to 
find it's way into more court cases.  I'm not being paranoid, just 
realistic.  Until we reach legalization, sometimes the best thing
said is unsaid. :)  Please, don't consider this admonishment, just a few
thoughts and advice.  I am personally not bothered by such talk, sometimes
rather interested in fact.

> In response to the following:

        Any proof of rape?
>
>
>       But hey, sounds like no one knows for sure if this really happened..

        there asses off too. They might of just thought she was raped.
        If it is true.  How did it happen? And why does no one in this little
        house know who did it?

I can't believe you are questioning her.  You know when you have been
raped.  Especially if you are on a psychedelic.  Psychedelics make you more
aware rather than numb.  I hardly think this 15 year old girl is making
this up.  This is very serious to the rave community,  especially if she
goes to her parents with this information.

What was a 15 year old girl doing at a party in the first place.  I thought
parties were a space for adults 18 and up to rave and be children.  People
wonder why the older crowd is not interested in coming to raves anymore.
Well personally I love to rave and although I look very young, I feel very
uncomfortable taking drugs with 15 year old little girls around.

The other thing I wanted to comment on was I have personally oberserved
promoters and dj's using their "status" to convince little girls in high
school to come to the "promoters room" or car and give blow jobs.  I have
listened to the dj/promoters brag about it and the little girls talk about
doing it and then disappointed later in the way their relationship is with
the male.  This isn't rape but it certainly is taking advantage of one's
role in the scene to prey on girls under the age of 18.  Little girls who
are allowed to come to these parties idolize these older players and with
the ideals in mind for throwing a party should be treated with respect
When they are used as objects of play for their fascination for the evening
they are struck with a different view of PLUR than most people get from the
parties.

This is the behavior that the media and cops are looking for and someday
when one girl screams rape... the rave scene is going to fall fast.

Hmm,

	Yes, there are stipulations and factors as to who can do what to
whom...  Ravers are younger nowadays, I see many @ the age of  fifteen
to seventeen...  One of my friends got "snagged" by a gal who said she
was nineteen.  Allthough mature and a very nice person, deception was
conveied (she is sixteen)...  So it can be a double edge sword...
	If your young and doing drugs, please be responsible.. Your
carelessness is what will cause this scene to disintergrate into a
swirling mass of negativity and confusion.  People have to take in
consideration that drugs, which loosen inhibitions, can also cause you
to lose control... Please keep control when on whatever.  Or at least
have someone around to act as your common sense when you're "out there".
	And to those who take advantage of these children... If I were to run
across someone forcing themselves onto a female...  Well, let's just say
I defend my scene.  An act of aggresson like that (and that's all rape
is, an act of hostile aggression) would make U an enemy in my book. 

 And I don't _have_ enemies.

I'm saddened to hear about what happened @ Odyssey, and cautious as my
little sister will become more involved in the scene (after HS
graduation)...  But at the same time I am releived to hear about such
positive corispondence in regards to making proactive measures so such a
incident does not occur in our scene again...

---_Adam

The story in a nutshell:

The girl was 15.  It was at a dance studio, not at someone's house.

It's my understanding, having chatted with someone who just spoke to 
someone connected with the promoters and then getting confirmation
from one of the promoters, that the girl was freaking on 2.5 hits of 
acid, had gotten into the room where people were allowed to toss 
their backpacks and stuff, and had decided to turn into Nature Girl 
by removing all her clothes except her bra, and then proceeded to 
scream her head off.  She was completely out of her mind, and no one 
could restrain or help her.  The promoters tried to get her under 
control but could not approach her.  She would alternate between
inviting them to do various things to her, and then attacking anyone 
that got within a few feet of her.  The cops showed up at some point 
and called an ambulance for the girl.  The EMT had a helluva time 
getting the girl's clothes back on.  She had to be restrained, loaded 
into the ambulance, and taken to the psych ward at the hospital.  The 
whole question of rape came from the fact that some schmo left a used 
condom in the same room, but there's no proof of rape - yet.  As for 
the promoters, they were in a bind because they couldn't locate the 
girl's friends or anyone to take responsibility for the girl.

So that's the story.  Ignoring the possibility of rape for a moment, 
may I state an opinion?

Where the hell were the 15 year old girl's parents?  What the hell 
was a LITTLE GIRL doing at a party?  Perhaps it behooves the more 
responsible promoters to start throwing parties where there is
an age limit.  At 15, you're hardly able to recognize the virtues of
moderation.  At 15, you'll trust anyone, believe anything, put just
about any kind of crap into your system, and all the while thinking
it'll just be a fun ride the whole way, that you're invincible, that
all the bad things you hear about can't happen to you.  Fast forward
to the hospital where your stomach is being pumped, your parents 
are sitting nearby in tears, and your friends are being questioned or 
even arrested by the police.

I won't assume even for a moment that I'll get total consensus on
this, but if I were her father, I wouldn't have given her permission
to go to such a party.  I would want to know where the hell she 
got acid, who gave it to her, and where they live [flash to scene
of large man grabbing scrawny punk by the neck and threatening
to break him in half if he ever got near his daughter again], and
then I'd ground her until she was 50, with her first chance at 
parole in about a month.

I'm a 32 year old man, and I know enough at this age that, IF I
take a substance, then when I take a substance, be it anything 
between caffiene all the way up to E, I take only enough to get
the desired effect.  I assure you that freaking out naked at a 
large party is NEVER the desired effect.  At 18 you *might* 
start having some idea that sometimes less is more.  At 15 you 
can barely wipe your butt and keep your room clean at the same 
time.

		WHERE WERE HER PARENTS?

S

Wayne posted today:

>Otherwise, call KCSM-60 in San Mateo... They have it on tape.

The episode is TIC 105, "Electronic Communities" -- call 1-800-916-PCTV (I
didn't make that up), and it can be yours for $24.95.

When I first saw the Internet Cafe show on Friday, I somehow presumed that
others knew about it or that it would be shown again (most PBS affiliates
repeat shows often).

But, as I posted on Friday night:

>my VCR worked

Depending on interest level, I'll have a "formal" showing at my place in
Berkeley sometime within a week or so, and can lend it out to people.

The context of the show was this -- a half-hour program on virtual
communities in cyberspace, featuring a women's community, some other
on-line group I can't remember, and Ethan talking about Fnf, sfraves, the
hyperreal web-site & raving for about 4 1/2 minutes (with interspersed
shots of the Fnf & hyperreal web-sites).

leftjab

        More people should explore the rhythmic pleasure you receive from
dancing to drum and bass at parties..I think the real reason people haven't
caught on yet, is because they still think that it's just really fast,
frantic breakbeat music, when they never really, really actually listened to
it before..The stepping and rolling blends are the new funk breakbeat sound
of the 90's, and if you actually listen to how the music breaks, then you
will see that it is also very danceable....Food 4 Thought:)

Peace...

On Mon, 3 Feb 1997, michal migurski wrote:
> ...so I went to my first Bagok Tribe party on saturday. I was curious since
> I've heard so many bad things about BT on this list and from friends, and I
> wanted to check it out for myself to confirm/deny my suspicions.

Since I am way beyond green to the atmosphere out here I will REFRAIN from
commenting on any parties that I have no clue about but I do want to say
that the experience given here is just what I am trying to avoid when I
manage to get out.  Its why I always ask the wonderful people on this list
before I go to some event.  Im sure Everyone on this list (including me)
has a horror story to tell about how they were clueless and ended up at
some shitty party with 2 people dancing and everyone else staring.  Isnt
there something we can do about this?  I was going to go real
philosophical on this but instead Id like to hear what other people have
to say about the subject.  Im bringing a number of new people to raves
lately and we have a good time cause I know how to find events that wont
be disasters.  But many people (including me a few years back) dont have
the benefit of help in choosing.  How do we keep the good people from
getting discouraged by bad raves?

- David

who just cant believe some of the things he's heard about the scene here
lately.  Sheesh.

The cloud house party last Sat. in Oaktown went off!!!

I was happy to see all of the good posts about the _Koinonea_Sp? party. 
Because the Cloud House party was on the same level.  Absolutely amazing
energy flowed through this rather small party of about 200 ppl.  My
cheeks were actually sore from smiling too much, and this is not an
exaggeration.  It is really good to see that there is still a lot of
good left in the scene: whether it be the people, promoters or dj's.

Free water and lotsa toilet paper.  BUST FREE! and happy people.  No bad
vibes or fights.....well actually there was one...but it had nothin to
do with the party. ;) for those that know what i'm talking about.  :P 
It was just a warm and cozy party.  There were even two impromptu
circles where everyone held hands and danced around together.

The cloud factory group, like others, have gotten it right.  Anyone who
hasn't been to a Cloud Factory party should definitely check one out and
see what it is all about.

I truly love the scene and am quite happy to see it survive through all
of the BS that goes on, because there will always be BS.

:)
Micron

Subject: Re: Rape
In-Reply-To: <v01540b02af1c08e1bd1c@[206.79.223.150]>

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

the whole idea of the relative danger for kids under eighteen going to
parties and being taken advantage of is very distressing to me, as i
started partying at fourteen, and have only fairly recently turned
eighteen. if you see someone young who seems to be an inexperienced raver
who may attract the kind of {evil} people who would take advantege of
her/him, then keep an eye out!! nothing has ever happened to me, though
several people have tried to take advantage of me when they thought i was
too high to handle myself. fortunately, that has never been the case,
and i was able to stop those encounters from becoming far more serious. 
it concerns me that inexperienced partiers may not know enough about the
drugs they take to ensure their own safety. this stems from a lack of
easily available information, and though i don't have a solution to that
problem aside from more responsible drug education in scholls or through
parent/ community relationships, it is possible for those of us who have
more experience and knowledge to look out for those that seem to be in
a potentially dangerous place.
with love often comes responsibility.
love as always,
****allegra****

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The issue of age limits at parties has come up several times today.

Where do we set the cutoff 16? 18? 21???

At times I almost wish there was a limit, but this would most definitely
change the scene. Our scene is based on FAMILY, young and old alike. When I
started partying at age 15, there were people who always watched out for
everyone (i.e. giving out candy, helping people through a bad trip,
whatever.). Now at age 22, I try to do the same for the younger kids on the
scene. Unfortunately, the kids seem different than all the kids I partied
with when I was young.

Its kinda sad that I took it for granted, but part of that family vibe is
gone. Now we are trying to keep the younger kids out of the scene, which
may be good for us now, but what happens in a few years when we start
dropping out of the scene and there's no one left.

The moral of this stupid story is... keep an eye out for the kids. I think
that all of us have had someone watch over US at one time or another. Keep
the circle going. Show the kids what the vibe is and just maybe they'll
pass it along.

Anyways,

dnns

C ya at Strawberry Sundaes (we're working on some special guests... i'll
keep ya informed)

> did the robbing the guys said it was some "black dudes" and they were
> white jewish guys on the program. This type of attitude gets me so
> upset cause I am a

If you're so concerned about this, then you should check yourself on
your own usage as well. Why did you need to say they were "white jewish
guys" -- didn't "white" suffice? perhaps you just thought they were
jewish because they had "new york" accents? Or were they wearing
yarmulke's and tvilin and peyes (i.e. orthodox jewish garb) so that it
was clear that they were jewish, rather than, say eastern european or
italian or whatever other nationality/races people sometimes confuse
with "jewish"... Did you know there are chinese, hispanic, "arabic" and
black jews? What's "white" have to do with it?

Other than this, i'd have to agree with the points you made -- I see
often that the media loves to portray people of color as "criminals",
to the extent that they go out of their way to show pictures of the
suspects, especially if they're "of color". For example in the
chronicle and/or SJ Mercury  article about the guys that have been
apprehended for blowing up the solano county courthouse -- they just
had to put a small picture of the suspect on the front page, just so
you know what color he is.

	So I just don't need yo comment bout the size o' my nose!

Don't you all know that all mailing lists turn into a blatant
Race/Sex/Religion discussion?  It's really annoying. So are these brand
new subjects for y'all that you think you need to enlighten us with your

actually there (thank you to those few who told us the real stories)

as being "black" "jewish" "gay" don't get offended.  You belong to
groups of people no matter what. Be proud and quit obsessing on it.

please bring a couple bucks and support the cafe, they need it! =)

>From the minds of Charity and Discovery.......


Saturday, February 15, 1997

South Bay Underground presents:


Euphonic Genesis


Dj's Shilo Maggi, Gerlando, Li (harmony), Indigo, Lucas, Sol, and
special guests.


there will only be 300 tickets available

posted to the sfr calander, so this may be your only notice of it.

Tickets will be available as of this Friday, at K&K music in San Jose.
They are $8 presale, $10 @ the mappoint.

The space for this party is absoulutely incredible, and there are many
people working very hard to make this one of the most special
underground events of the year.  

Chai will be provided by the generous folx at nub circus, and there will
be fruit and other goodies too.

The chill zone is gunu be unbelievable; the same people that made the 
10 ft. mushroom @ Charity are at work again....

This event is planned with the cooperation of the SJPD, and we will not
have to worry about our event ending early.

On Tue, 4 Feb 1997, Dan Capriles wrote:

> The cloud house party last Sat. in Oaktown went off!!!
> 
> I was happy to see all of the good posts about the _Koinonea_Sp? party. 
> Because the Cloud House party was on the same level.  Absolutely amazing
> energy flowed through this rather small party of about 200 ppl.  My
> cheeks were actually sore from smiling too much, and this is not an
> exaggeration.  It is really good to see that there is still a lot of
> good left in the scene: whether it be the people, promoters or dj's.
> 
> Free water and lotsa toilet paper.  BUST FREE! and happy people.  No bad
> vibes or fights.....well actually there was one...but it had nothin to
> do with the party. ;) for those that know what i'm talking about.  :P 
> It was just a warm and cozy party.  There were even two impromptu
> circles where everyone held hands and danced around together.
> 
> The cloud factory group, like others, have gotten it right.  Anyone who
> hasn't been to a Cloud Factory party should definitely check one out and
> see what it is all about.
> 
> I truly love the scene and am quite happy to see it survive through all
> of the BS that goes on, because there will always be BS.
> 
> :)
> Micron

I dunno if any of y'all have been down south lately, but in the Santa =
Monica area there is a redio station that plays house, techno, jungle, =
trance, and trip-hop 24 hrs. a day...

And it's not any of the "Wild 107 type" cheesy, commercialized stuff =
either...=20

They call themselves "Groove Radio", and they're at 103.1FM, next time =
you're anywhere near there...  and they have a website where you can =
listen to them through real audio..

http://www.grooveradio.com

If anyone here does listen to Wild 107, you may have heard about their =
newest mixing DJ who calls herself "The Mixstress"...  this is where =
they "found" her...

I would really like to know what you guys feel about having a radio =
station committed strictly to our scene...  Can this be considered =
"commercialization" when the top priority is to get the message of PLUR =
out to as many people as possible?  After all, to run a radio station, =
you need money; and to make money, you have to sacrifice a little (in =
this case- keeping it underground).

much hugs,
doughboy

Totally agree. My hat is off to all who made it an absolutely amazing
event!!!

On Sun, 2 Feb 1997, Nancy Shaw wrote:

> 
> An awe-struck THANK YOU to Koinonea for that beautiful, beautiful party 
> last night.  _Clean_ space, amazing artwork everywhere, Chai tea hut 
> (ummm!), bananas-and-oranges just when I needed them, many grooving 
> drummers, a random flutist, people melting on massage tables, the dance 
> floor pounding all night with the boundless soul-energy of goa trance, and 
> even a breathtaking contortionist, gracefully bending to the music like a 
> moving meditation.  And of course, all the people...
> 
> It was rejuevenation to me.  Last I danced was two weeks ago, but somehow 
> it felt like it had been too long, and the night passed in a daze and I 
> came out of it wrung through with sweat and exhaustion...a 4-hour 
> work-out in a sauna...a deep body experience to restore me to myself. 
> 
> Sober raving meant our night ended when our bodies could go on no more, 
> around 4AM.  But this time I actually _remember_ the names of those I 
> met, and, though the sober experience is different, it is just as fulfilling.
> 
> Til next time!
> Love,
> n
>

Received: from #shawna- (ala-ca17-18.ix.netcom.com [204.32.168.178]) by dfw-ix5.ix.netcom.com (8.6.13/8.6.12) with SMTP id UAA03304 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 4 Feb 1997 20:31:52 -0800

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (Frisco Freaks)
From: The Laffin Happy Trip Farmer <shawna-@ix.netcom.com>
Subject: Back on SFRaves:  Ack!!
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey all!

Shawna here, back from the dead, for those of you who noticed.  Boy what a
long strange trip it's been.  I signed off of sfraves a month or two ago,
finally got my ass back on again to see what's up.  I've finally gotten
myself out of Concordland, Fabled Land of Circle Dancers ;) and closer to an
area I want to live in, and also got a new computer in the process which
took a while to get going, and an SO magically fell in to my lap, so I've
really been out of the loop for a long time.  So now I'm pretty much settled
in, and have my new computer up & running, and said SO is off doing SO-ish
things, so time to come back to sfraves & see what goes on.  Hello to all
you old people who are still here (those oldsters who're still here speak
up!) (SDream, you still out there hon?) (Steve Simitzis I miss you!!)
(Wayne, you're just exactly as Crusty as when I left, and thank you for
dragging me out to play that very first time, definitely got the ball
rolling!) (Matt L, I have a picture of us from the church rave and we look
beautiful! :) (knucklehead I'm pleased as hell to see the BBQ & Beats
campout, count me in for help!) (Burger King I miss you too!!) (Tom L. I'm
such a GODDAMNED flake I SWEAR I'll make it up to you) (Amy S. you've been
there from the start) (Reagan, Stan told me you say hello, so HELLO BACK!
:):),  and hello too to all you gnu fokes who are on the list too.  

Wow is all I can say!  I can't tell yet if it's a good wow or a bad wow.  It
feels bad right now.  I scrolled thru all the info numbers of all my
favorite promoters and found pretty much nothing there when I dialed them to
see what's going on lately.  Either there was a recorded message from
parties that occured ages ago, or the number doesn't even exist any more, or
something.  Seems like everybody's just up & vanished, all those beautiful
parties that hold so many memories for me, Harmony, Beautiful People,
Chrysalis, Light, Friends & Family, and all the ones that just seemed to be
everywhere, never had a free weekend cuz there was almost *always* something
really great being planned by all those beautiful people (I now regret
throwing out my 1996 calendar with all those wonderful days written in it).
Those parties were just exactly what I needed at exactly the time I needed
them, an amazing supportive environment for me to begin growing into the
kind of person I still work at becoming, and so it saddens me to see neither
hide nor hair of these people and parties of course.  (god I feel so
nostalgic I'm bout ta cry!)  But I'm hoping that what I'm seeing is not a
loss of these people & parties that meant so much to me, but rather an
evolution of them into new and beautiful things awaiting on the horizon.
It's a little difficult for me to look at it this way, it's very easy for me
to simply lament the loss of what once was and is no more, but I really do
have to begin looking again for the hidden beauty that I'm sure is still
there and just needs to be found, just like it was before.  Also, perhaps it
is possible that these parties have simply gone further underground, rather
than actually dying out, so again that would require further looking.  One
party that really gives me hope of evolution is the Koinonea party, reading
the couple reviews that have trickled in since I subbed back on really makes
me feel like there is new growth on the old tree.  And poor Tom knows I have
yet to make it to one of those parties, but I know they must be beautiful
cuz Tom is there pouring his amazing energy and intent into them along with
the rest of his group, how could it be otherwise?  Tom has some of the most
beautiful energy and pure intent of anybody I've met in the rave scene,
everybody please support him and his group, they really deserve it, I know
I'm happy to see those parties occurring when all else appears to have dried
up. :)  And so perhaps the scene is evolving as it should, and so maybe it's
a good wow rather than a bad wow.  But that remains to be seen, only the
future will tell.

So people, regale me with tales of the amazing parties that have been
happening in the past two months or so, what new things are appearing on the
horizon of our scene?  What new groups have started up and show promise?
And I really am curious, did anybody attend Coolworld Planet New Years?  I
am *very* curious about that one (and please no flamewars, I just want to
hear descriptions).  Course, prolly everyone's afraid to even admit to
attending massive, eh, Wayne "Crusty the Raver" Correia will run out & lop
off their heads! ;)  

So that's all that's new in Shawnaland, hope everybody is well.

Much love,
Shawna

            
                   
         Do not go gentle into that good night.
       Rave! Rave into the dawning of the light!

To: *B* <branka@sirius.com>
From: Aryck <mxman@illuminati.heald.edu>
Subject: Re: E & possible problems
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        I just thought I'd ad that on theat night of Karma, (Lara & Leslie
know). I got some E from some little ass guy who I was told to of had some
really good E. I got 2 for me, and one for Laycee. I was told that it was
really strong and it made a lot of people sick really quickly. But I'm a
strong guy so it didn't make any diffirence to me.
        I took one hit on the way home. I felt it a little about 10 mins
away from my house. I noticed that things were melting (a trait which mdma
doesn't posess). Me and laycee took the rest when we got home and then went
to take a shower. . . it started hitting me pretty hard and shit just
started going haywire, all melting and jumping around, It was pretty obvious
that this wasn't only MDMA. Me and laycee just started talking and massaging
each other and I started sweating like some kind of oversoaked sponge. The
feelings we had were super intense, and the next thing we knew, it was 3
hours later and we were still sitting there in front of each other. I guess
the acid like effects and the e lasted through the next 2 days, gradually
diminishing to nothing.

        But to make my point, yep, my temperature must have been at least
105-110 degrees F that night. And that certainly wasn't just E.

        Me and about 14 other friends had an E party one night. I had about
4 hits. After a while, I noticed weird little neon  colored shapes on
everyones faces, and after the fourth hit really hit, I couldn't sit still
if I had a gun to my head. But other than that, it was a killer little get
together and we're doin it again soon.

        So MDMA IS hallucinogenic in larger amounts. But that other stuff in
the beginning wasn't all mdma.

Guess there really was no point. . . 

who cares. . . 


Aryck

I recently discovered that nothing makes the rhythm inside me flow more
than drumming along to jungle breakbeats.  I had pretty much ignored
jungle until my first out-of-body experience at Gaiamind.  I felt it
again when I tranced out at Koinonea.  The breakbeats keep the rhythm
jumping, while the speed makes it all flow so smoothly.  I'm all eyes &
ears now for any jungle event that will welcome an enthusiastic drummer.

As for dancing, it might be harder to capture the rhythm inside your
body.. I think letting it flow naturally instead of trying for a
robot-breakdance is the best bet.  Then, there's no telling what you'll
do.. =)

Living the beat,

Leonardo

SDream wrote:

Please, this isn't a flame.

> The story in a nutshell:
> 
> The girl was 15.  It was at a dance studio, not at someone's house.

Okay, anyone remember the post I made about my concern for kids at
raves? The general (but thankfully kind :) response was that we need to
educate young people about the substances they take at a rave.

> that the girl was freaking on 2.5 hits of
> acid, had gotten into the room where people were allowed to toss
> their backpacks and stuff, and had decided to turn into Nature Girl
> by removing all her clothes except her bra, and then proceeded to
> scream her head off.  She was completely out of her mind, and no one
> could restrain or help her.

Was *this* a good time to educate her about the characteristics of LCD?
I'm being sarcastic.

> Where the hell were the 15 year old girl's parents?  What the hell
> was a LITTLE GIRL doing at a party?  Perhaps it behooves the more

Whoa Whoa Whoa. So 20/20 tells the parents and others that "The Raves"
are to blame for over drug use and it's dangers like the example at
oddyssey. So WE blame the parents. Okay, I'm glad everyone is taking
responsibility.


> I won't assume even for a moment that I'll get total consensus on
> this, but if I were her father, I wouldn't have given her permission
> to go to such a party.  

 Rise your hand if youve ever sneaked out of your house from your
parents to go to a Rave. If we have a problem withthe age of some people
at parites, then a few collectives may need to trim down their rosters.
Because people this age are are helping to throw parties.

>I would want to know where the hell she
> got acid, who gave it to her, and where they live [flash to scene
> of large man grabbing scrawny punk by the neck and threatening
> to break him in half if he ever got near his daughter again], and
> then I'd ground her until she was 50, with her first chance at
> parole in about a month.

  And in the 20/20 story the young girls mother basicly did all that AND
shut down the site permanently. So I guess we can say goodbye to that
site, huh?

> I'm a 32 year old man, and I know enough at this age that, IF I
> take a substance, then when I take a substance, be it anything
> between caffiene all the way up to E, I take only enough to get
> the desired effect.  I assure you that freaking out naked at a
> large party is NEVER the desired effect.  At 18 you *might*
> start having some idea that sometimes less is more.  At 15 you
> can barely wipe your butt and keep your room clean at the same
> time.
> 
>                 WHERE WERE HER PARENTS?

Please do not push the blame on her parents. This is whats going to
happen at an underground party and it must be accepted. Yoda would say
that this is the "Dark Side" of the Rave. This and the Thomas Trouble/GT
incident.

Flame away...

>On Tue, 4 Feb 1997, eros wrote:
>
>> $$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$
>ok...I figured that...what are the operational costs? besides the obvious
>things like staff and records...

Very little actually...
>
>also...there seems to be lots of space on the dial for another station in
>the bay...what does it take to get a number?

Lots of space?    Come one man....  get real....   The FM band in the Bay
Area is saturated.     I'm sure you might find something below 92 Mhz.
>
>How about pirate radio?...

If you get no complaints of interference,  or from the programming,   you
might be able to go on the air without getting molested by the FCC.   You're
range will be small (1- 5 miles radius) but Berkeley Free Radio has been on
the air for a long time,  although they are fighting the FCC on Civil Liberty
issues.

>how much can you get away with?

Depends on the quality of your signal.   If you over-modulate,  or the audio
is crappy,   you won't get away with it at all.     If your audio is clean
and you don't interfere or cause problems,   you MIGHT get away with it.

>
>what kind of crap are you going to get from the fcc?
>
Usually the first "offence" they will warn you,   or possibly confisgate your
equipment.    Or they would file criminal charges.   5 yrs jail or 5 years
probation at worst case.

Getting a license is next to impossible,  again,  Steve Dunnifer is fighting
the FCC for this reason.

Crunchman



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Feb  4 23:29:07 1997

Received: from [206.173.194.39] (cnc012039.concentric.net [206.173.194.39]) by user.host.net (8.7.5/8.7.3) with SMTP id CAA21606; Wed, 5 Feb 1997 02:28:46 -0500

Subject: Re: crack dream: rave radio!
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>How about a discussion on what it would take to get a radio station on the
>air?

I would certainly like to participate in that....   For starters,  assuming
that a frequency is available (which there is NOT in the Bay Area),   it
takes a Minimum of about $200,000.   FCC requires a radio station to be
able to run in the "red" for 2 years without making money.

You're best bet is to buy an existing radio station,   assuming one is for
sale.    Average costs run from 2 - $10 million.

There is talk of trying to pursuade the FCC to permit low power licenses
for neighborhood stations with ranges from 1 - 5 mile radius,  but the
FCC is dragging their feet on this.

In Berkeley,  there is Steve Dunnifer,  fighting the FCC on these issues,
trying to get them to ease up license restrictions to permit neighborhood
radio.   It might be important to get behind Steve and supporting him.

Crunchman

this whole oddyssey rape thing is giving me a bad taste in my mouth for 
a ton of reasons.. first off, i'm really concerned with how apathetic 
certain posts seem to be about this.. not just this poor girl, but 
about rape in general.. speaking from experience, rape is the most 
devestating thing that can happen to a girl... so regardless of how 
fucked upo she was, if she said no, that's what it meant.. she didn't 
invite this... there's been an influx of negative people coming into 
the scene with all the media publicity, and unfortunately, many of 
these people think they can take advantage of others there.. she was 
only 15, and maybe hadn't fryed before, so her friends should have been 
there for her... but blaming this violent act on her age (as well as 
the promoters for letting her in) is lame... i've been partying since i 
was 14, and i've just turned 18 now... it wasn't until recently that 
i've had to deal with guys trying to take advantage of me while i'm 
"too fucked up" to notice... fortunately, i have good friends, and 
never let myself get to the point where i'm out of control of what's 
being done to me...another thing that made me sad was to hear the way 
it sounded like everyone was coming down on the promoters... they put 
on a good party, and it wasn't their fault that something like this had 
to happen... i think they did their best to control the situation, but 
it just was beyond their hands.. instead of all of us fighting about 
what is rape and what isn't, we should be sticking together to help 
this girl and preventing tragedies like this from happening in the 
future.. i'm sorry this was so long, but as you can tell, i feel 
strongly about this subject...

                             much love,
                               anissa...

Funny you should mention 'Legs' since there have been at least two fairly
big releases over the last few months that included samples from
Legs...X-Calibur's Retriculan Groove and U.K. Science's Mainline

that Prodigy used samples from Beat Box (Diversion One) in Firestarter
or....


:)

I agree, the AoN 'sound' is very stuck in the 80's.  That's part of what I
like about it, though!  I helps me remember those days gone by.  I think
was ahead of their time, though, as they were experimenting with methods
of synthesis and sampling produciton techniques that other groups were not
trying.

Subject: Groove Radio and such
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.970205000719.21678G-100000@boris.ucdavis.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0

Precedence: bulk


When Groove Radio 103.1 in LA (broadcasts out of Santa Monica, repeater
station is in Newport Beach) went on the air in the summer, it was really
really funny.  No DJs, no real programming cycle, just all of a sudden
this message ont eh air that said "Have you ever been to a rave...?" and
then all this clubby-housey music.  

Now, after a while, they got their programs together, got the DJs on board
and such and it's all good.  During the daytime they spin mostly
commercially available club/house/Hi-NRG stuff, but they also spin a good
amount of Drum&Bass and various techno.  Now, everybody has to pay their
bills, so you really can't condemn Groove Radio for spinning commercial
discs during the day.  
Noghttime, though, sees a bit of a difference.  Continuous mix shows
dominate, including special guest DJs from all around the country.  Doc
Martin has a weekly show, and there is also a weekly International
countdown continuous mix program.  Last week they broadcast the Future
Sound of London live via an ISDN hookup.  
I've heard everything from Troi Amos to Fatboy Slim, Josh Wink to
Uberzone, Fluke to Everything But the Girl on Groove Radio.  The diversity
in the programming is quite impressive for a commercial station.  But, if
you only listen at lunch time or on your drive home from work, you're only
going to hear the heavy rotation tracks.

Just my thoughts.  Viva Groove Radio!

 Maybe somone can offer some advice here...
I started out throwing the party Osmosis with a partner.
After my personal bullshit with a mutual friend (which was all my
fault), he decided to support our friend and decided to cancel the
party.  He took 4 of the 10 dj's and decided to throw another party...
It was decided that neither of us would use the name Osmosis.  Wanting
to make a clean break I decided to name my make-up party Begin Again.
(seemed appropriate to me at the time)
What I didn't realise was that this name had been used a couple of times
previously.  So my question is this: Do I stick with the name which I
feel is appropriate, or do I change it again out of respect?

Hi all!

 No smiley faces. This subject is WAY too serious.

 I would like to propose a raver "escort" service to help prevent 
situations like this. Many promoters do this with their crew on an 
informal level but I feel an organised system might be helpful.

 This would be similar, in some respects, to escort services offered by 
volunteers working at colleges and university.

 A general outline for operating could go like this;

	A bunch of folks agree to volunteer to help.
	
	These folks coordinate with each other before each party (as many 
	parties as possible) so everyone knows who is going to what party 
	(know your support group!) A mailing list for this group maybe?

	This group should be in touch with the promoters and staff so 
	that everyone knows each other and can call on each other for help if 
	needed.

	If a person looks messed up a volunteer can either hang with them 
	or just keep a discreet eye on them. Also, folks can let the 
	volunteers know if someone looks out of it.
 
	This could help prevent unwanted run ins between loaded folks and 
	event security/cops/media/whatever.

	This could include escorts to ones car in scarey neighborhoods.

 	Ideally most escort members would know basic first aid.

	Out of the spirit of giving, I feel the escorts should still be 
	paying party goers. Guest lists are too huge!
 
 

 There is strength in numbers and I believe there are enough of us that 
care to watch out for one another and our scene.

 Intelligant and compassionate responses invited.


peace y'all
 


Ran D.Dreams

Doughboy <bigjaydog@earthlink.net> wrote:
>I dunno if any of y'all have been down south lately, but in the Santa
>Monica area there is a redio station that plays house, techno, jungle,
>trance, and trip-hop 24 hrs. a day...

On the general topic of rave radio and the mainstreaming of rave music, I'm
fascinated to hear how much more dance and electronic music there is on
KZSC (88.1), UCSC's station, this year compared to last.  Last year it was
very rare, and now I can hardly get away from it.  There seems to be more
every term.  Three nights in a row now I've switched it on and there it
was.  It shows up in the daytime, too.  I haven't seen their current
schedule, but most of what I've been hearing is along the lines of jungle,
drum-n-bass, trip-hop, dub, ambient/experimental sounds.  Some house, very
little techno, trance, hardcore, breakbeat.  I'm not sure what it means,
but it's interesting.

For those who can receive it, next Tuesday night Hollipop, from Moontribe
in LA, will be a guest DJ in the midnight to 3 slot.

anarch@scruznet.com

randy's got a pretty good idea, if i understand it correctly.  if i did 
get this correctly, when someone looks lost, this guide sort of stays 
there with them.  

kind of reminds me what the shamen does with all of his "guidees" 
(theres' prolly a better word, just can't think right now) 

the only difference though is that like real shamen in say peru the 
shamen-shamenee relationship is established BEFORE the trip starts.  

this is the problem with these substances being illegal.  there ought to 
be people who have had more experience with psychedelics guiding the 
younger (or less experienced people) through the trip.  so they have 
someone they know they can rely on.  but there's a risk for taking that 
role in the united states of clinton/gingrich [applause banner 
please]...it's called...

"contributing to the delinquency of a minor"

gotta go snooze--->fog
