hello everyone...

i don't know if this will help anyone...but Vlad and I have known each 
other for years.  I remember when his /Honda/ was new and I was cleaning 
his windshield.  That was October 17, 1989 at 5:03 PM.  Remember what 
happened after that?  why was i cleaning his windshield?  well, that's a 
long story.  

so we've known each other like 10 years now.  from even before raving.  
in fact, i remember when our mutual friend took him to his first party.  
he's a cool guy, really.  we haven't really hung out a whole lot, but 
that doesn't matter.  

i guess what i'm trying to say is what i like most about him is he's at 
least making a contribution to our music community.  it's ok to make 
money doing this, contrary to popular belief, and promoters take on a lot 
of responsiblity.  but vlad seems to enjoy it.  

yeah, i know.  i've seen posts about what happens at some of these big 
massives.  but i'm just here to say that the vladster isn't someone from 
out of town in for the weekend type of guy.  if we keep on positively 
reinforcing each other, instead of taking a little toothpick and finding 
out what's wrong, you know some of you guys are like that.  oh, look 
there's a problem!  quick!  focus on that problem!  look, let CNN and 
Geraldo and Oprah Windbag focus on the problems.  Any idiot can tell you 
what's wrong with something.  What we need here is a mastermind group 
that can start blending ideas so we all throw better parties, have better 
trips, and have more fun!

this doesn't mean don't express your opinion, by the way.  

fog
(ps, vlad...call me!)

At 08:07 AM 2/5/97 -0800, you wrote:
>Thus spake Deepfog:
>>this is the problem with these substances being illegal.  there ought to
>>be people who have had more experience with psychedelics guiding the
>>younger (or less experienced people) through the trip.  so they have
>>someone they know they can rely on.
>
>Is this really possible?  Can one person relate to another's trip
sufficiently
>to be of help?  My curiosity forcuses on LSD, as I have no experience
>with it, but would like to know how to help someone who is having an
>unpleasant experience.  I know that, with some organic psychedelics,
>there's still that control if you wish to utilize it.
>Peace,
>Eric
>

LSD trips are really too complicated to be documented since different
amounts will have different pleasant and unpleasnt effects.  The best way
to help someone with a bad trip in my experience is to have a few people
hang around the person.  Sing songs, dance, share candy, and tell stories
(even tho it will not really make sense to the person at all).  I realize
that most of my bad-trips happen when no one is around me to give me
assurance that it's going to be over in a few hours.  

Another cause of a bad trip would be an event that may be traumatic to the
person right before taking acid (breaking up with someone, etc...)  So you
also have to make sure that the person is in a pleasant mood before dosing
and if not suggest that the person stay sober or try a weaker dose.

As far as Ran's suggestion, I think I'm up for it.....

Much love,
Anthony E

"[Oo]" wrote:

> > If Youz really had a temp of 105 to 110 degrees ....You would have
> >been very dead I'm afraid. I think the brain starts to cook at 105 to
> >107 death can occur as low as 104 as high as 108 at the most. Please,
> 
> He didn't say he took his temperature and thats what it was.
> come on now...
> he's a raver... and we all know how ravers exaggerate.

Oh, heck yeah, I once had a temp of 212.  Had steam shooting out my
ears, which of course made my ears shrivel up.  My head swelled, my
eyes turned all black and got huge, and all my hair just >poof!<
fell out.  All my clothes burned off.  And with all the moisture
escaping, my body shrunk down from 6'1" to about 3".  So if you saw
a little guy with a big head and large black eyes jamming in front
of the decks, it wasn't an alien, it was me!

S

Pengo wrote:

> Was *this* a good time to educate her about the characteristics of LCD?
>
> > Where the hell were the 15 year old girl's parents?  What the hell
> > was a LITTLE GIRL doing at a party?  Perhaps it behooves the more
> 
> Whoa Whoa Whoa. So 20/20 tells the parents and others that "The Raves"
> are to blame for over drug use and it's dangers like the example at
> oddyssey. So WE blame the parents. Okay, I'm glad everyone is taking
> responsibility.

Yes, in part we blame the parents.  Just because we can't put all the 
blame on one person doesn't mean no one gets some part of the blame.
Her parents were at fault.  The promoter was at fault.  The GIRL was
at fault.  Her friends were at fault.  You're absolutely right that
I focused quite a lot on one point, but the truth is we are all in
this together, and when it comes to our young people, we ALL have a
responsibility to look out for them.  She was too young to be at a
party that goes all night.  She was too young to be doing LSD (or 
LCD for you electronics freaks ;) )

> > I won't assume even for a moment that I'll get total consensus on
> > this, but if I were her father, I wouldn't have given her permission
> > to go to such a party.
> 
>  Rise your hand if youve ever sneaked out of your house from your
> parents to go to a Rave.

We all have, but that doesn't mean parents should just throw up 
their hands a say, "Geez, I guess I should just condone it, cause
I sure can't stop it."  *That* would be one helluva a lousy parent.

> If we have a problem withthe age of some people
> at parites, then a few collectives may need to trim down their rosters.
> Because people this age are are helping to throw parties.

You are absolutely right.  Some of the collectives *should* trim
their rosters, and they should check IDs at the door.  People wouldn't
have a problem with raves if ADULTS were attending.  The reason raves
get SO much flak is because, at the mids to massives and at a lot
of the small raves, a large portion of the population are KIDS.  
Kids that parents are worried are thrashing themselves near to 
death with  drugs.  Hell, who cares if kids (beyond a certain age)
go out all night and DANCE?  It's the DRUGS that parents are pissed 
off about, and this girl is a prime example of why.

> >I would want to know where the hell she
> > got acid, who gave it to her, and where they live [flash to scene
> > of large man grabbing scrawny punk by the neck and threatening
> > to break him in half if he ever got near his daughter again], and
> > then I'd ground her until she was 50, with her first chance at
> > parole in about a month.
> 
>   And in the 20/20 story the young girls mother basicly did all that AND
> shut down the site permanently. So I guess we can say goodbye to that
> site, huh?

Yup.  And if a bar was serving minors it would get shut down as 
well.  Too bad for the bar, too bad for the site, too bad for the
promoters.  And WAY too bad for the mother whose daughter had to
die before someone DID something about it.

> >                 WHERE WERE HER PARENTS?
> Please do not push the blame on her parents. This is whats going to
> happen at an underground party and it must be accepted. 

No, it does not have to be accepted.  It has to be changed or 
parents will continue to attempt to *stop* it.  And that's life 
in the social contract.

S

I'm really sorry to bring the OJ Simpson saga onto this list, but there 
is something that is really bothering me about this fine country that we 
live in.

Last night I flip on the TV at around 6PM to see a Live camera shot from 
a Hellicopter hovering over OJ's House.  Then they cut to a live camera 
shot from a hellicoter hovering over the Santa Monica Court Room.  
Appaerntly the OJ Verdict was about to come in.  

At the same time, on the other side of the country in Washington DC, 
President Clinton was about to give his State of the Nation Address.  
However, the media decided that the OJ Verdict was more important, and 
that they would air the Presidents Address on tape delay.

To be honest, I could really care less about politics or the OJ Trial.  
But me, as a citezen of this Country, feels that what our president has 
to say is much more important then the fate of OJ.  It just goes to show 
you that the state of our nation is controlled by the media, and that the 
mass majority of the people in this country want to know what is going on 
in OJ's life more than what the President has to say.

Its sickning.

sort of unique. yeah, go ahead.  flame my post.  doesnt' matter. i just

This reminds me of a story I uh....heard.  
A couple of years ago a group of fairly inexperienced ravers journeyed out
to a party (Thunderground). They had cut their teeth on small family type
parties (Chrysalis, where did you go!!) and intimate house parties,
thunderground was a different scene altogether for them. 

 There was no E to be found, but there was a lot of acid to be had. One of
the more chemically inexperienced of the group ended up with about a 1.5
inch long strip of paper in his possession, and not knowing any better,
I...er...I mean he ate it. Stupid eh?  Anyway, in about an hour this guy is
on a couch in the chill room, completely motionless, experiencing his own
personal hell.  Bad trip is way too mild a description.  All night long this
poor, stupid guy watches groups of friends come into the chill room and
ignore his motionless, agonizing form glued to the couch totaly unable to
communicate.  This story would not have been nearly so sad if someone,
anyone had hung out and talked/interacted with the poor bloke.  

Moral of the story?  If someone looks lost at a party, you might want to
check on'em and give some assistance. Talk to the person, hold their hand,
find their friends, It could mean a lot.

Oh, the very next night, on thanksgiving, the poor shmuck in this story had
a religious experience (went to heaven/saw god/was god) at Tribal Funk, this
time mescaline was the culprit.  This person has learned his lesson and no
longer indulges in "Hard" psychedelics in public.

!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!DISCLAIMER!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
!!!!!!!!!!!!
This is a made up story, the events depicted never happen.  Drugs are not
sold at raves.  Mind expanding drugs are illegal and never consumed at
raves.  No minors had their delinquency contributed to during the making of
this story. (The group of, now very experienced ravers, was 22-23 years of
age at the time of filming)
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------

A bunch of ravers wrote:

>Thus spake Deepfog:
>this is the problem with these substances being illegal.  there ought to
>be people who have had more experience with psychedelics guiding the
>younger (or less experienced people) through the trip.  so they have
>someone they know they can rely on.

>Is this really possible?  Can one person relate to another's trip
>sufficiently
>to be of help?  My curiosity forcuses on LSD, as I have no experience
>with it, but would like to know how to help someone who is having an
>unpleasant experience.  I know that, with some organic psychedelics,
>there's still that control if you wish to utilize it.
>Peace,
>Eric


>LSD trips are really too complicated to be documented since different
>amounts will have different pleasant and unpleasnt effects.  The best way
>to help someone with a bad trip in my experience is to have a few people
>>hang around the person.  Sing songs, dance, share candy, and tell stories
>>(even tho it will not really make sense to the person at all).  I realize
>>that most of my bad-trips happen when no one is around me to give me
>>assurance that it's going to be over in a few hours.  
>>
>>Another cause of a bad trip would be an event that may be traumatic to the
>>person right before taking acid (breaking up with someone, etc...)  So you
>>also have to make sure that the person is in a pleasant mood before dosing
>>and if not suggest that the person stay sober or try a weaker dose.
>>
>>As far as Ran's suggestion, I think I'm up for it.....
>>
>>Much love,
>>Anthony E

... **Thumper**... wrote:
> Also I forget who suggested it but what exactly is Thermodrean and
> 
> Cytomax? I know what Rip fuel is though. Once again Thanx everyone,

I don't know what Thermodrean is but Cytomax is a sustained energy
drink used by endurance atheletes (runners, bikers, swimmers,....
ravers) It accomplishes this mainly via complex carbohydrates and
other natural fuels...I can't remember exactly the other stuff on the
label. It also contains a nutrient which helps prevent lactose (sp?)
buildup in your muscles. This buildup is what causes your muscles to
feel sore during and after strenuous exercise. I've tried it a few 
times and I was able to run a whole lot longer at a faster pace. It's
also caffeine and ephedra (ephedrine) free!!! Try buying it at your
local healthfood store before going to GNC which charges premium $$$.
The fruit punch flavor tastes best too!

Peace,
John K.

SDream wrote:

Okay. I think we are for the most part on the same wavelength so I'll
cut right to it:

> >  Rise your hand if youve ever sneaked out of your house from your
> > parents to go to a Rave.
> 
> We all have, but that doesn't mean parents should just throw up
> their hands a say, "Geez, I guess I should just condone it, cause
> I sure can't stop it."  *That* would be one helluva a lousy parent.

This is true. But I don't think her or any parents would condone it
simply because they cannot stop it. This really is a seperate matter
though, because we are not the parents here. I just want to make the
point that we should not focus so much on the faults of others when as
promoters there is room for improvment on our part.

> > If we have a problem withthe age of some people
> > at parites, then a few collectives may need to trim down their rosters.
> > Because people this age are are helping to throw parties.
> 
> You are absolutely right.  Some of the collectives *should* trim
> their rosters, and they should check IDs at the door. 

 You highlight *should* because, I assume, you mean that promoters
probably won't exclude kids from their collectives anytime soon. A
promoter who has kids on their staff will probably not start IDing
people. This is what I mean by having to accept it unless promoters want
to change. And right now few are interested in doing that. Underground
basicly means no rules exept thoes that people voluntiarly follow. 

> > Please do not push the blame on her parents. This is whats going to
> > happen at an underground party and it must be accepted.
> 
> No, it does not have to be accepted.  It has to be changed or
> parents will continue to attempt to *stop* it.  And that's life
> in the social contract.

Aye, here's the rub. So it must be changed, yes? While we can blame
parents or friends the only thing we have any sort of control over is
the party itself. Therefore this must be the focus.

I challenge each and every promoter that is concerned for the well being
of the people that attent the parties to START CHECKING I.D.s AT THE MAP
POINT _AND_ AT THE SPACE. If we fail to do this, then it is not our
place to blame any other individual (child) or group (friends or
parents). Unless I'm forgeting some other option, this is the only way
we as promoters can help prevent these problems. And if promoters won't
check I.D.s, then yes, these problems must be accepted as part of
underground parties.

A couple of weeks ago, at a party called "First Contact", there was a dj who
was absolutely runnin' things in the main room...Who was he?..He played a
combination of hard trance and goa, and he was wearing some hannah barbara
cartoon character on his shirt...Anyways, I had never really been exposed to
music like that before...His whole set had the crowd freaking out, and I
watched many people come to the front of the decks, and tell him how much
they loved it...To me, that's what it's all about...Good music, good crowd,
equals good vibes and good times...Also, just wanted all the anti-trancers
to know, that proper trance and goa, can be just as funky as anything
else...Nuff' respect to the dj (whoever he is), and to all the trancers who
were havin' it...

Peace:)-~

Reverting back to my original e-mail...

Checking IDs and such at parties would kill the whole spirit of the party.
Ask yourself how old you were when you went to your first party. What if
they ID'd you? I stick to my same argument in that putting an age on
parties puts a damper on the scene.

Its no different than mocking the commercial scene or anything else
associated with raving. What we are saying is that we want to make the
environment better for ourselves by keeping the people who MIGHT make us
have a bad time out of the scene. 

I'm sure that we all have our self-centered attitudes about younger ravers
but they are still part of the FAMILY, (or maybe what's left of it.)

-dnns

You know what peoples....

This is rediculious.  This is sooooo sad it's laughable.  I see postings
from
some of you saying "when I was sixteen", and "Yeah I just turned 
eighteen" blah, blah.  When did you all grow up?  Do you remember raving
in your younger days?  And now some of you are looking to cut off raving
to the younger generation?  

I _KNOW_ even if an age limit is imposed there will be *exceptions* when
 it comes to the promoters, DJ's, sound and light crews and friends.
Will
 it become a type of "exclusive socieity" as to who gets in where?  I 
played this game in the club circut.  When I was 16-17 yrs old I was
going 
to The Edge, (come to think of it, they still play the same music there
too...), Catcus Club, and a few other 21 and up venues cos my brother
and his friends were the DJ's...

The answer isn't in the age, but in watching our own and watching
ourselves.  Has anyone notice how much more 'relaxed' people are at a
CCC or F'n'F (or Harmony, F-8, FMR for that matter, the list goes on..)
then say, Ghost Tribe, Gathering or other massives...  What I percieve
is our smaller parties gaining a more massive party additude.  How do we
change that?  
>I have my answer...  And you, out there, must find yours.



----_Adam
"Stay Connected"

Pengo wrote:

> Aye, here's the rub. So it must be changed, yes? While we can blame
> parents or friends the only thing we have any sort of control over is
> the party itself. Therefore this must be the focus.

Agreed.  Absolutely.

> I challenge each and every promoter that is concerned for the well being
> of the people that attent the parties to START CHECKING I.D.s AT THE MAP
> POINT _AND_ AT THE SPACE. If we fail to do this, then it is not our
> place to blame any other individual (child) or group (friends or
> parents). 

RIGHT ON!

> Unless I'm forgeting some other option, this is the only way
> we as promoters can help prevent these problems. And if promoters won't
> check I.D.s, then yes, these problems must be accepted as part of
> underground parties.

Actually, I was discussing this with someone and they suggested that
promoters have a responsibility to the people that pay to get into the
party to have some kind of staff on hand to watch over everyone. 
A bar has bouncers, and the clientele there are adults.  By the very
virtue of the "vibe", I don't think a rave needs bouncers per se, but I 
do think there should be a handful, say 1-to-50 ratio, of people that 
are paid (or get in free?) that are part of the staff and are tasked 
with staying sober and just keeping an eye out for any trouble, even 
folks that are just tripping way too hard.

This is a solution that can be applied regardless of the target
audience or age group for the rave.

Just another $.02.

S

> 
> You know what peoples....
> 
> This is rediculious.  This is sooooo sad it's laughable.  I see postings
> from
> some of you saying "when I was sixteen", and "Yeah I just turned 
> eighteen" blah, blah.  When did you all grow up?  Do you remember raving

Exactly - I think drawing an artificial age-limit, be it 14 or 16 or 18
is just that - artificial. There are some very mature and responsible
14-year-old's and some very immature and irresponsible 21-year-old's.
Excluding someone from a scene as (generally) positive as ours on the
basis of age is going to force them back into a less healthy scene.

[some snippage]

> The answer isn't in the age, but in watching our own and watching
> ourselves.  

Precisely - we should all be looking out for each other, and especially
for the younger kids, not trying to exclude them. We can teach them a
lot about caring and responsibility.

- Martin

hell, causing the authorities to be called kills the spirit of the party
a lot more. Don't you think?

  Yes I know, we all love our family members, no matter what age. But
having no age control over who goes to a party for the sake of keeping
the vibe alive or because they are FAMILY members does not justitfy
allowing tragedies like this weekends or any other to happen.  This is
not something that MIGHT happen. IT WILL HAPPEN. Sooner or later, you
know it will happen again. And I'm not talking about keeping kids out
for our sake. It's for their sake.

You're right massives are (arguably) bad, having to turn away people
from parties is bad, lots of things in the scence are bad but NOTHING
compares to having a kid get so fucked up she has to be put under
restraint. Short of death maybe.

Sorry everyone for getting so rilled up over this topic. But it's one I
feel passonate about. =)

Adam Guevara wrote:

> The answer isn't in the age, but in watching our own and watching
> ourselves.

Damn it, you've converted me, Adam!  No more age discrimination!  Why,
this should extend to everything!  Let's take it to some extremes,
whatdya say?

The Draft: Put a gun in the little buggers hands and let them duke
it out with the rest of us.  Most of them are carrying guns anyway,
right?  We'll just watch our own on the battle field.  They'd be
ok, right?

Drinking: What the hell, as long as they're young enough to die, 
they're young enough to throw back a few stiff ones at the end of
a hard day in of eighth grade math and English.

Driving: Who cares if they can't hardly reach the pedals?  Everyone
has a right to transportation so they can get to and from the raves,
right?

Voting: So some of the kids in today's high schools wouldn't know
an issue from a tissue, but if we can catch them at a moment when
they're not drunk, shooting someone, or out of their minds on
acid and naked as a jaybird, they should be able to wander into a 
voting booth with the rest of us.  Of course they wouldn't know
who the hell was on the ballot or what they various initiative
numbers meant, but then who does?

Cigarettes: Light up, kiddies!  Cancer - the game the whole family
can die from!

Porn: Pop that stupid Barney tape out of the VCR and throw in 
"Debbie Does [fill in blank with name of major city or sports team]".
Then grab the baby oil and a towel and get bizzee!

Jobs: Hey!  It shouldn't be my responsibility to provide everything
these little sh*ts need -- let them get off their duffs and work
a full day like the rest of us.  Janitorial services would clean up!

Taxes: Great!  Now that everyone can do anything anybody else can
do, regardless of their age, including getting gainful employment,
let's tax the little rug-rats.  How about taxing comic books?  Or 
pacifier disposal?  Or padded bras?  Make kids generate the funds
to implement the programs they use the most.  Tax peechees and
jock straps.  No more free bus rides to the school -- charge them!
Charge for school lunches, books, crayons, etc.

-	-	-	-	-	-	-	-	-

Have I made a point yet?  There are a LOT of things that HAVE to
have an age limit.  Anyone can stagger through the door of a rave,
but do they belong in an environment known for it's availability
of drugs, where the clientele are known for their consumption of
any and all combinations of just about any substance that will
alter reality?  Do you want your kids going into the environment?
I know I don't want mine to until they're old enough to handle
what goes on there.  I'm thinking 17, but I'm sure that number
will cause an uproar.  

Either way, Pengo had it right, the promoters have to decide how
responsible they're going to be and whether they want to deal 
with a bunch of kiddies barely out of diapers that probably will
not know how to handle their drugs.  The responsible promoters
will stick with people who are mature enough, or should be,
to handle whatever entertainment they choose to partake of while
at partying and let the less responsible promoters field the 
babies in the bunch.  They'll also, hopefully, provide some kind
of staff to watch out for people that are in trouble, people
with the training to handle situations like the one that occurred
at Odyssey.

Let's see... that must have been at least a $1.25...

S

Received: from localhost (scarab@localhost) by value.net (8.8.4/8.7.3) with SMTP id QAA02483 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 5 Feb 1997 16:00:16 -0800 (PST)
Date: Wed, 5 Feb 1997 16:00:16 -0800 (PST)
From: KC <scarab@value.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Age-Limits (long)
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.970205152632.28432C-100000@value.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


My opinion on age-limits varies.  On one hand I am very disturbed by the
amount of young people doing lots of drugs at parties.  I also don't
always like the attitudes that teenagers exhibit.  It is too exclusionary 
for me, and that's why *I* stopped being a teenager.  It had nothing to
do with getting older! :P hehehe  And the older I get, the more I realize
how young teenagers actually are. And then I get selfish and think,
"Teenagers should be banned from all the things I was banned from when I
was a teenager."  But, then I get a flash and remember what it is like to
be a teenager.  It sucks to be treated like a child because you aren't
actually that, but you aren't actually an adult either.  However, this
society spends so much time not respecting children that you end up being
really resentful against this as a teenager.  I remember the few people
that treated me with respect as a teenager, and I listened to them a lot
more than I listened to people who just told me what I could and could not
do.

I honestly don't think that as a society we provide enough things for
teenagers to do.  I would not want to exclude teenagers from dancing and
some of the joys of raving.  It is fun, provides a social outlet, and
provides a sense of community.  Being at social gatherings is fun for all
of us, and is not something that should be limited to certain ages.  For
example, I don't support the age limit on drinking.  I think that, in
itself, promotes excessive drinking.  Because it is forbidden and "adult",
you want to do it more.  I lived in a country that had no age limit on
drinking, and teenagers were more resonsible about drinking.  This was
because there was open communication in this family oriented society. I
feel that the larger problems are how un-family oriented we are as
Americans.  Americans are materialistic and seek instant gratification.
This is reflected in the youth and raving is a prime target in which to
seek instant gratification via drugs and be materialistic via clothing and
other goods.

Age limits may be the answer to keeping kids away, but I don't know if it
is the right one.  I think the right one is more familial communication.
When I started raving 2 years ago at 22, the people I went with did drugs
every damn weekend.  I was a bit worried by that, and myself did not
partake in such excess.  The people with me weren't teenagers, but
their drug use concerned me.  Part of me always looks towards the future
and is always careful about what I do.  That's how I've always been.  When
I was a teenager I certainly drank and got drunk with my friends at
parties, but I knew when enough was enough.  But, I also remember being a
teenager and having *nothing* social to do.  I would hate to cut off 
social outlets to teenagers when we don't provide them with alternatives.
We also force them to grow up too quickly and then tell them they are too
young.  It's ridiculous.

My crazy solution to the kid/drug problem is raising the legal driving age
to 18.  I don't think teenagers need cars as much as they think they do.
It is part of a larger materialism.  Not being able to have licenses and
cars would probably do a lot to curb the drug/drinking problem because
you would wipe out the accessibility.  Also, it would get a lot of cars
off the highway which is good environmentally.  I know it sounds strange,
but I think it is a legitimate point.

I've noticed from a number of posts that quite a few of you *are*
teenagers.  What do you have to say about this??  How do you feel you are
being treated?  HOw do you feel about yourselves, your peers, and all the
drugs at raves?

-KaySEE

One more question.  All of you out there who say, "I began raving at
14 and now I'm 18, or whatever", how did you do this?? I can understand
sneaking out once or twice, but *all the time.*  My parents would have
never let me do this.  Plus I had a lot of other responsibilities
including school work and sports.  You can't do that when you are burnt
out and exhausted from raving.  Did your parents allow you to go out all
the time?  Did they know?  What did they think?

I have wondered about this forever.  I still don't understand *how* so
many teenagers go in the first place.  It amazes me.  Parental ignorance?

> One more question.  All of you out there who say, "I began raving at
> 14 and now I'm 18, or whatever", how did you do this?? I can understand
> sneaking out once or twice, but *all the time.*  My parents would have
> never let me do this.  Plus I had a lot of other responsibilities
> including school work and sports.  You can't do that when you are burnt
> out and exhausted from raving.  Did your parents allow you to go out all
> the time?  Did they know?  What did they think?
> 
> I have wondered about this forever.  I still don't understand *how* so
> many teenagers go in the first place.  It amazes me.  Parental ignorance?
> 
> -KC

The few "kids" I've met, one 19, and two 16, are high school dropouts. 
They all seem very wise for their years, some travellers who stay on the
street, and one of the 16 year olds has his own apartment.  These people
are sober ravers and very cool.  But, I really advocate the fact that
they should go back to school and get GED's.  Maybe they will listen to
a "cool" old schooler (no pun intended) like me.  I seriously doubt that
all teenagers at rave are dropouts, becuase I seem to attract an element
of homeless and hippy dready teenagers because of what I look like--so
that's who I meet, I guess.

I am not saying that raves causes teenage delinquency (but, they may
attract them to some degree)  When I was a teen, I regularly went to
dance parties in Canada (this was ten years ago) and it really shaped me
into the music-loving adult that I am now.  Dancing keeps kids out of
other kinds of trouble and gives them something to look forward to!  I
remember being in school and counting the hours 'till the next time I
was dancing my butt off in Quebec.  If it wasn't for those nights, I
wouldn't have started trying to make my own dance music, learned how to
use a computer, become a computer programmer, become a music producer,
become a drummer, etc. etc. etc.

As far as my mother goes, she hated the fact that I went out all the
time.  I used to say, "But, Ma!  I don't drink, I don't break the law, I
get good excercise, please, please can I stay out 'til four AM??  She
begrudgingly let me go because she knew how much I loved it.  

So, let teens be teens and don't turn into the adult that you once hated
when you were a teen.

-Goldilox

Adam and I are discussing this topic offline at this point, but I wanted
to make this much clear:

On the topic of looking out for our own, I'm in total agreement, but I'd
rather keep the gun out of a kid's hand than let him play with it and
hope he doesn't blow his brains out with it.  I do not condone giving
drugs to kids.  I absolutely believe that up to a certain age most kids
do NOT have the mental tools to deal with the drugs that are prevalent
at a rave.

Most of Adam's last post ticked me off because it was just disingenuous
or so completely off the wall that it seemed to be time to take my
response offline, but this I want to post here:

Adam wrote:
> Maybe SDreams parties may be 18+

Like I said, I was thinking 17+ and up.  I would try to arrange to 
have some "designated straights" who would not get stoned and would
watch out for the others.  And I'd keep the number of people down around
300 to 500, the better to keep control of the venue.  And y'know what? 
I'm willing to bet my events would be the ones less likely to get
busted, less likely to have crisis situations occur.  People would have
a better time at events where they could have fun with other, at least
somewhat, mature individuals.

From: Rob Rayle <robertr@autodesk.com>

> I absolutely believe that up to a certain age most kids
> do NOT have the mental tools to deal with the drugs that are prevalent
> at a rave. 
 
        One of the reasons I feel very strongly that *all* drugs
should be legal *for adults*, is that this would give us a fighting
chance to keep drugs out of the hands of those who are way too young
to handle them. If we kill off the black market with legalization,
but keep draconian penalties in place for those who provide drugs to
minors, I think things would change for the better. Yes, some minors
would still get drugs. But it would be more difficult for them. Right
now, it's not significantly more difficult for a 12 year old to get
LSD than it is for a 25 year old. Dealers don't have any incentive to
check ID. 

        Now, how does this relate to age limits at parties?

	If these parties were really drug-free, I wouldn't have any
problem with letting anybody in regardless of age. Bring in the 
5-year-olds, who cares. If it's really just about music, dance and 
community then we should include all ages. That's not really the case, 
though, is it?

When I originally proposed that promoters ID people at their parties in
an attempt to keep accidents like this weekends at the Dance Studio from
happening, it was as an answer to SDreams statement that these accidents
are not to be just accepted as a 'Side Effect' of parties and that
something has to change. I guess I worded it wrong when I said "I
challenge...". I know that IDing would never work for many reasons. Adam
G. covered them well.

My only real point in this whole thing was that: When something like
this happens at a party, I don't want to hear people blaming the persons
parents, or their friends, or the dealer, or whatever when there was an
opportunity by the promoters to keep people this age out of the party.
Yes I know, people can tweak off of drugs at any age. But when youre 15
a bad acid trip is going to affect you mentally for a while (if not
longer). A lot worse than if the same thing happened to an adult.

I believe that while continuing to educate young ravers as much as
possible is definitely a big help, a situation like this weekends was
unacceptable. We collectively AS A FAMILY FAILED to educate this girl
ahead of time before she took her acid. Which was obviously beyond her
limit. If we cannot ensure a young persons safety at a party, then what
the hell are we doing? Do you find it acceptable?

We talk about a LOT of different things of SFR. So why do I feel like
I'm the only one screaming bloody murder about this? Has a little girls
bad acid trip become that pass? I didn't know that girl, I wasn't a
promoter at that party, yet because I feel for ALL ravers I feel
especially guilty that this happened. We lost a member of the family
forever and probably gained two hateful parents and a girl who will know
she striped down in front of her peers and went berserk. Thats quite a
mental scar. If we are FAMILY, then cmon gang let's act like it and
each in our own way accept responsibility. Or are we still blaming 'the
other guy'?

-=Pengo=-

Adam: "The woman made me do it"
Eve: "The snake tricked me to do it"

At 9:35 AM -0800 2/5/97, meclay@ix.netcom.com wrote:
>Deepfog wrote:
>>
>> hello everyone...
>
>  Just a comment:  From my perspective the people who don't like Feel Good
>Prod.
>don't mind people making money from the scene as much as the line of BULL SHIT
>that comes from them.... Martin for example exemplifies the commercial rave
>scene and most people get along with him... but then he doesn't spam sfraves
>with pleading messages about how all he's concerned with is the "togetherness
>and sharing of the oneness of the scene and how much we love blah, blah
>blah...
>and btw check your money with me at the door"
>
>  If the message about how concerned Feel Good was about sharing and vibe had
>included btw  - all sfravers get in for $5 just give your account info at the
>door the message would have made more sense....
>
>  but I suspect that the motive behind the contact of sfraves was more
>along the
>lines of.... well there's 600 of 'em out there... if I compose a message
>and am
>able to get 100 to bring one or two friends then that'll be 200-300 more
>and at
>$20 ... that's $4000 to $6000 more income in my pocket.... not bad for sending
>a message to the net plus it's free advertising........
>
>  But then maybe I'm more cynical than I should be ;-)

Mike, You are not extra cynical. You are *right on*. But then we all know
how Mike and I feel about the PLUR-spouting marketing gimmick commercial
rave swine like Feel Good Entertainment and Nomad Interactive, don't we? :-)

When I saw 16k of "hugs and love and plur and sharing and caring" from Feel
Good E. (inplied drug references to lure the 15 year old kids out to
'play') I just wanted to throw up.

Maybe it would have been more appropriate of Feel Good E. to write
something like:

----
"I'm having a big commercial party that I hope to make a lot of money at.
Although I am spouting PLUR and Sharing and Caring out my ass I am not
going to let any of you in for free -- but I really hope all you vibey SF
ravers from the underground will come, drop your hard earned $20 to get in
so that you can unknowingly help me make my tagger-fest move vibey!

Then my party, having a new-found vibey reputation will have an even bigger
turnout next time, making me many suitcases of cash! Then I can have an
even bigger party, make even more money whilst fooling the public with my
reputation of legitimacy that I swindled from my unknowing accomplices in
the underground!

By then it will be too late for any of you to detract from me because my
parties will have the hugest marketing budget that even if all of your
collective voices in the undergorund attempt to detract from me you won't
have a hope of countering me and my 100,000 rave flyers -- which will be
spread around every square inch of every related store and gas station in
northern california! And the the biggest joke will be on all those Eco
groups that think they're getting money from me cuz I printed it on all my
100,000 non-recycleable wax coated rave flyers! Hell, I will be Cool World
II !!!
----

With that in mind, I am a very compassionate person, but, without regret, I
must absolutely, positively maintain a hard line 100% against the breed of
promoter that spouts "MARKETING BUZZWORDS" like "PLUR" and "LOVE" and
"SHARING" and "CARING" because when it's heard by those of us who actually
attach meaning, emotion, passion and purpose to those words, it's just
disgusting.

I hope to see Feel Good Entertainment & _Love-A-Fair_ on a Leeza, Hard
Copy, 20/20 or the local TV news soon. It seems to be the only way to keep
exploitation in check in the land of raving.

And if after reading all of this you (the sf raves community) are not in
doubt that this party will suck, ((1)) judge the size and complexity of the
flyer (inverse rule applies), ((2)) the number of DJ's on the lineup
(inverse rule applies), or ((3)) the number of different area codes and
info lines (inverse rule applies). [Remember, this is *no* disrespect to
the DJ's.]

Three strikes, cash-boy, and you're out!

   ---------------------------------------------------------------------

more real than this.

Subject: why i get knocked on at raves
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-id: <01IF2DK3O57M9JDFDO@SONOMA.EDU>
X-VMS-To: SMTP%"sfraves@hyperreal.com"

KaySEE wanted to know how teenagers are treated like at parties by 
people they don't know..
	I am 19 years old and technically still a teen but i look 
about 16 when i go to parties. I wear my short hair in pigtails and 
put kiddie hair thingies in them, and i have a pacifier, and i wear 
glitter and lots of bracelets made of beads not unlike the bracelets a 
child would wear. (i hand them out too, so look out!!)
and many of you may ask why? well i have my various 
reasons. but this isnt why i am posting. 
	I can remember many a time I attend a party and get looked at 
(and this aint the massive scene) with almost disdain because i look 
young. I was actually preached to by a guy on E the other night about 
how i shouldnt be doing drugs (i was sober.)at such a young age. why 
does age matter? maturity is the key here, and i think you're all 
forgetting this when you're saying "people 18 and under shouldnt go 
to parties." I would hate to be carded at an event where we are 
supposed to all be coming together and celebrating our differences 
AND our similarities. 
	I can understand all your anger about "those damn kids" and 
their damn drugs. so can i say "damn you oldies and your 
discriminating elitist vibes?" :) no, because i know tons of older 
ravers who welcome the younger kids into the scene, and vice versa. 
the scene isn't OWNED by any of us. it's CREATED by ALL of us, 
every single one. you all crow PLUR! PLUR! but yet, you ignore the 
Unity part of it by discriminating against younger ravers. we are ALL 
individuals, not all of the kids in the scene are drug addicts, and i 
know that not all the older ravers are sobriety addicts. may i repeat 
again, iTS NOT ABOUT AGE. its about maturity.
	i tend to LIKE younger ravers alot, because they have a fresh 
outlook on the scene and don't get all caught up on "well IM better 
because I think THIS and IM better because I know THAT DJ and I got 
into SUCH and SUCH party for FREE". plus, I enjoy feeling younger at 
parties, and i know that some of you (come on admit it) feel like a 
child at a party, no matter how old you are, because you are so 
happy. admit it. youth is an incredible contribution in the scene. i 
agree that a 15 year old girl tweaking on acid is not much fun to 
see, hear about, or even BE, but ANYONE tweaking on acid is not much 
fun to see, hear about or BE. I thought that in this scene, you were 
accepted for who you are, and now we are saying "you can't come to a 
party.. 
not because of your bad vibes, or your drugs, but something you can't 
even control -- your AGE" since when is being 15 a crime? because you 
KNOW that even if you DO card at parties, bad vibers who are 18+ will 
come in, and one of THEM will overdose. then will we say "well we 
might as well just call off parties, except for me and my best 
friend, because everyone else has the probability of giving me bad 
vibes and overdosing on something". if we start discrimination with 
age, what's next? no ADIDAS allowed at parties ?? Glostix contain 
toxic stuff, are glostick masters gonna be banned too because they 
MIGHT break and get in someone's eye? how would you older ravers like 
it if us younger ones said "we don't like the <insert whatever 
generalization about older ravers here> you bring to the parties we 
go to, we're gonna make it a 21 and under party!" you'd be shouting 
discrimination all over the place. 
	It sounds like some of you just want to have some parties 
where all these older ravers get together and talk about the good old 
rave days, and talk about whats wrong with the rave scene today. 
that's fine and dandy, you can do that.
 but while you are 
discriminating against the younger rave genre, you are also missing 
the chance to get to know and befriend some of the most unique and 
beautiful people in the world. we are ALL beautiful people, no matter 
what year we were born in. 
peace love hugs and smilin' loud,
lara

On Wed, 5 Feb 1997, SDream wrote:

> Actually, I was discussing this with someone and they suggested that
> promoters have a responsibility to the people that pay to get into the
> party to have some kind of staff on hand to watch over everyone. 
> A bar has bouncers, and the clientele there are adults.  By the very
> virtue of the "vibe", I don't think a rave needs bouncers per se, but I 
> do think there should be a handful, say 1-to-50 ratio, of people that 
> are paid (or get in free?) that are part of the staff and are tasked 
> with staying sober and just keeping an eye out for any trouble, even 
> folks that are just tripping way too hard.

	Whoa! Since when did small raves become consumer events? When did 
we institute such a division between promoter and party goer? When did 
people forget what a community consists of? All this talk of promoters 
are responsible for this and that, where does it end? Aren't each of us 
responsible for >ourselves<?

	I have recently made a fool of myself in private and may be doing
it here in public, but this is moving from what I view a community to be,
toward a consumer event. Everyone is throwing responsiblity on to everyone
else's shoulders, no? "I paid good money for this so I should be taken
care of"? How does that fit into a community? Maybe my idea of community
is a little off from everyone elses, and maybe that is due to the time I
spent going between festivals... I dunno. I had a belief that the rave
scene had some ties to people DIYing things and finding certain things out
in the process. What is next? Promoters responsible for provibing a vibe?
If I sound somewhat beside myself, I am so please look at what I am trying
to get say: I have another suggestion - if you see something which you
feel is lacking, why not fill the gap...
	You want medically trained people at raves, go get trained in
first aid, then CPR, then maybe as an EMT. Maybe scout around the net and
try to find some other courses than those offered by the Red Cross (their
courses are shit now, don't tell you anything except call 911). Keep
badgering groups until they respond (yes I am still try to get those
wilderness first aid courses for those of you who were interested. And I
finally found out why I haven't gotten a response to any of the emails I
was sending out, I was sending them to the old listserver which crashed -
but it still eats my mail without sending out a delivery failed notice). 
Granted big commerical parties are commerical and they are "providing" 
for party goers so maybe they have such a responsiblity, but small 
parties?

dave

now sEE that's one DAMN good idea. 
instead of sitting on your asses complaining about how awful some 
aspects of raving are, why not try to improve it? by providing  a 
shoulder to lean on and a hug and a smile and a conversation to 
someone having a bad trip, it's not CONDONING drug use. The person 
took the drug, if they're having a bad time, then they're obivously 
learning a lesson. I should hope though, that the escorts do not 
become people who lecture trippers. Maybe inform them why/how their brain 
is reacting to the chemicals they ingested.. Educate them while 
making them feel more comfortable with themselves and their trip. 
It's a natural instinct for me to go up to someone leaning against 
the wall with a frown/crying/not looking so hot and sit down and 
smile and ask them if they're ok. If they lost someone/something, i 
stay with them until they find it. If they want to talk, I want to 
listen. I'm all for this escort service, sign me up! And for those of 
you who oppose the idea, try and think of a time at a party, sober OR 
not, when you felt (even for an instant) that you needed a hug, or 
some sort of reassurance that things are going to be ok. If you've 
ever felt this way, then you'd know that having escorts is a good idea..
	I'm not so sure about wearing glostix on your head though. I 
mean, I think that people won't know to go to the person or what the 
glostick headband really means. Unless the map point people tell 
everyone in advance "if you have a problem go to a glostick head 
person" hehe :) 
	anyway, happy wednesday all!
love hugs and smilin loud,
lara

---------- Forwarded message ----------
This was posted in early December by "LiQUiD 7" from UCSC about sober 
raving.  I foward it to the sfraves list again for the person that asked 
about sober raving.   Peace! Bill


Well obviously there is an art to sober raving, and to keep up with all 
those who are 'not' sober can sometimes be a challenge ;)

But there are tons of ways to stay alive throughout the night.  
*	Firstly and most importantly is **BAD-ASS** music (without i almost 
	always die)

*	Then Id say people and their vibes are number two...

---> but from here the rest is up to yooooou!  & theres lots of options

*	ok, theres 'Vivarin' & NoDoze, they're great for some mild tweaking,
	haha, just kidding, but they DO keep you 'UP'.  Then again they
	are very hard on your stomache, so never take too much.  It isnt
	something you should take for a long time...  theres other the ways!

*	now theres 'herbal power' stuff.  i have recently begun experiment
	ing with this and it's great!  a medium sized bottle of red ginseng
	right before a party TOTALLY energized me!  im looking further 
	into other herbal 'upers'.  SOMETHING NOT TO TRY: MaHuang
	Its as addictive as speed, and quite harmful.  DONT GO THERE :!

*	and then there are many *smart* things to do.
	- resting before partying
	- eating high protein food, some good carbos too!
	- like someone said before, lots of water & juice (ESSENTIAL)
	- take something to munch on. i remember once when i took a couple
	  of pb&j sandwiches, and i ate them when i tought i was pooped.
	  those little badboys perked me up like mad!  Try it!

*	and finally there are "energy boosters" that are available. i dont
	know much about the products that are out there, like at GNC, but
	i sell nutritional products that are sponsored by the US Olympic 
	Licensee comitee, and about 20 olympic atheletes, not to mention 
	ive tried their energy booster, its great!  cheaper than a hit 
	of E, better for you than "psuedo-amphedamines", and works well.

	e-mail me if you want more info on this, they have many other 
	awsome supplements as well. (its worth looking into if youre
		---sick'n'tired of being SICK & TIRED---- haha

RAVE ON !!!!!
Peace,   LiQuiD

Just an observation, but I dont think I saw anyone say "get wired on
sugar".  I kinda thought this was convention, no?  I try to bring massive
amounts of sugar and cold water (w/o, you will VERY quickly get dehydrated
even if you DONT dance).  The fact that the water is cold aids the
digestive process (eeewww! :-) and speeds the absorption of the sugar to
the blood stream.  And sugar is way less harmful than caffeine (tho
neither are very dangerous if you behave at all reasonably).

- David

who is just glad to be able to contribute to conversation :-)

(Sorry, this got kinda long...)

> 
> On Wed, 5 Feb 1997, KC wrote:
> 
> > 
> > 
> > I've noticed from a number of posts that quite a few of you *are*
> > teenagers.  What do you have to say about this??  How do you feel you are
> > being treated?  HOw do you feel about yourselves, your peers, and all the
> > drugs at raves?
> > 
> 
> One more question.  All of you out there who say, "I began raving at
> 14 and now I'm 18, or whatever", how did you do this?? I can understand
> sneaking out once or twice, but *all the time.*  My parents would have
> never let me do this.  Plus I had a lot of other responsibilities
> including school work and sports.  You can't do that when you are burnt
> out and exhausted from raving.  Did your parents allow you to go out all
> the time?  Did they know?  What did they think?


OK - time for me to wade into this one - it's a subject close to my heart
and I've kept quiet for long enough. I have a 14 year-old son who I'd 
hesitated to take with me to raves for the very reason that most parents 
would - the pretty free acceptance of drug use. Well, it turns out that 
the drug scene in schools and on the street these days is so bad that 
kids are actually exposed to a lot more than you'd think. All the things 
I was worried about him seeing at a rave, he'd already seen in a much 
more negative context. 

I'd always had this dilemma - on the one hand raves are such incredibly
positive events with an amazing vibe and a spirit of.. uh... PLUR (you 
know what I mean) that I was aching to show my kid. On the other hand 
there is undeniable drug use to a greater or lesser extent which I'd just
as soon not expose my kid to. When I found out the exposure to drugs he'd 
already had at school and on the street, my dilemma was solved. The kids 
are ALREADY exposed to this!

The first rave I took him to was Karma 4 which was pretty heavy on the
drug use, and he *loved* it. Even though there were a lot of drugs there,
he actually felt peer-pressure to stay off drugs, and I think seeing drugs
used in a "responsible" context was really good. He's not interested in
doing drugs himself - and no, I don't think I'm just being naive here -
he, like a lot of people who have posted on this subject (including
myself), likes to rave sober! It's not a cop or a bunch of republicans
telling him to "just say no", it's a bunch of wacky ravers who he respects
MUCH more!

And the positive aspects of raving have totally changed his life. Don't
underestimate the impact of such a positive, loving environment - kids
these days often get lost in the negativity of the world that surrounds
them. All I can say is that raving is the most positive influence in his 
life and his outlook and attitudes have changed literally overnight. Oh,
and he doesn't go on weeknights and it doesn't interfere with school, so 
the other parental concerns are taken care of. 

> 
> I have wondered about this forever.  I still don't understand *how* so
> many teenagers go in the first place.  It amazes me.  Parental ignorance?

Hey, if more parents took their kids raving *responsibly*, the world 
would be a better place! Yeah - I realize this story is probably about 
as untypical as they come, but it goes to show that raves CAN be an 
incredibly positive influence on kids, and I'd be sad to see them excluded
automatically because of their age (well, maybe the REALLY young ones -
14 is probably about as young as I'd be comfortable with, and only then
with "adult supervision" for all-nighters). (Maybe we should have PG-14 
raves where you can go if you're accompanied by an adult!)

Hugs y'all....

- Martin  =]

dear lara.  

that is a fascinating story.  for the life of me i've never understood 
that type of mentality, but I know that it does exist, and I'm pretty 
sure it's never going to change, because we constantly have new people 
entering the dance scene and we constantly have new people turning into 
old people.  are you with me?  =]  

I've always thought that most people are like cows.  They sit around,
complain about what's wrong with the world [cows moo and chew their cud]
instead of trying to focus on how we can make the world a better place. 
Of course it's easy to pick on kids, because they're there, a lot of them
are nervous because they haven't gone out that much, and they handle it in
different ways.

I'm going to make this kind of short.  But I'll just leave you with one 
of my favorite quotes:

"Everyone has a flock of opinions waiting to be had upon anyone that will 
take them."

Ok, folx those of you that aren't young and think i'm seeing only one 
side of the coin, there are a lot of kids that do cause trouble at 
raves.  some of you circle dancers need to respect the dance floor as a 
community dance floor for instance.  but telling kids they shouldn't be 
doing e is hypocritical, especially if they've ever done it in their 
life.  It's hypocritical, and the kids can sense that.  Those of you that 
have kids, have you ever noticed that they do what you do and not what 
you say?  Don't always pay attention to what people say.  Watch what they 
do.  

I've just about always enjoyed hanging out with younger people.  I mean, 
sometimes they're going through something i went through years ago, but 
hey that's life.  deal with it.  smile and let others be right.  you 
won't be hanging out with them forever anyway.    

Sorry folx I broke that I/we thingy rule in all English books.  So just 
say aaaauuuummmmmmm and drink some Nub Chai <nubcircus@cruzio.com>( no 
purchase necessary but donations are appreciated i have no financial 
interest in this plug) and the answers will come naturally...

ahh.  the borg is on in an hour.  gotta go--->fog

Hi!  ]=)

 I'm really happy to see this thread rolling a bit more now. I'll collect 
all the mail and create a huge cc list for us involved.

On Wed, 5 Feb 1997 ZINTSMAS@SONOMA.EDU wrote:

> I should hope though, that the escorts do not 
> become people who lecture trippers. Maybe inform them why/how their brain 
> is reacting to the chemicals they ingested.. Educate them while 
> making them feel more comfortable with themselves and their trip. 

 I don't think the time to educate/brainwash someone is when they're 
high. I prefer instead to help them (if I'm talking with them) by giving 
tips on relaxation techniques. Breathing, focusing on words/images tend 
to help. I hate to say this but I have a lot of high dosage trip 
experience and experience in helping folks through rough moments. It 
doesn't always work, but having someone take a deep breath does wonders 
sometimes (especially if they are panicking/hyperventilating). Sometimes 
knowing someone is suffering from low blood sugar is helpful (you find 
out by talking to them of course, focusing on something as ordinary as 
breakfast can sometimes help), as you can give them a bannana or orange.


> It's a natural instinct for me to go up to someone leaning against 
> the wall with a frown/crying/not looking so hot and sit down and 
> smile and ask them if they're ok.

 Or if they would like a drink of water or some candy.

 It is by teaching through example that you reach deep.

 
peas,


Ran D.Dreams

>Mike, You are not extra cynical. You are *right on*. But then we all know
>how Mike and I feel about the PLUR-spouting marketing gimmick commercial
>rave swine like Feel Good Entertainment and Nomad Interactive, don't we? :-)
>
>When I saw 16k of "hugs and love and plur and sharing and caring" from Feel
>Good E. (inplied drug references to lure the 15 year old kids out to
>'play') I just wanted to throw up.
>
>Maybe it would have been more appropriate of Feel Good E. to write
>something like:
>
>----
>"I'm having a big commercial party that I hope to make a lot of money at.
>Although I am spouting PLUR and Sharing and Caring out my ass I am not
>going to let any of you in for free -- but I really hope all you vibey SF
>ravers from the underground will come, drop your hard earned $20 to get in
>so that you can unknowingly help me make my tagger-fest move vibey!
>
>Then my party, having a new-found vibey reputation will have an even bigger
>turnout next time, making me many suitcases of cash! Then I can have an
>even bigger party, make even more money whilst fooling the public with my
>reputation of legitimacy that I swindled from my unknowing accomplices in
>the underground!
>
>By then it will be too late for any of you to detract from me because my
>parties will have the hugest marketing budget that even if all of your
>collective voices in the undergorund attempt to detract from me you won't
>have a hope of countering me and my 100,000 rave flyers -- which will be
>spread around every square inch of every related store and gas station in
>northern california! And the the biggest joke will be on all those Eco
>groups that think they're getting money from me cuz I printed it on all my
>100,000 non-recycleable wax coated rave flyers! Hell, I will be Cool World
>II !!!
>----
>
>With that in mind, I am a very compassionate person, but, without regret, I
>must absolutely, positively maintain a hard line 100% against the breed of
>promoter that spouts "MARKETING BUZZWORDS" like "PLUR" and "LOVE" and
>"SHARING" and "CARING" because when it's heard by those of us who actually
>attach meaning, emotion, passion and purpose to those words, it's just
>disgusting.

>exploitation in check in the land of raving.

>flyer (inverse rule applies), ((2)) the number of DJ's on the lineup
>(inverse rule applies), or ((3)) the number of different area codes and
>info lines (inverse rule applies). [Remember, this is *no* disrespect to
>the DJ's.]

Date: Tue, 04 Feb 1997 12:50:14 -0700
From: Collectively Unconscious <swarm@doitnow.com>
To: Goa List <goa@party.net>, az-raves <az-raves@gn5.getnet.com>,
    mtn-raves <mtn-raves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: [GOA] Re: cyber fun

> > This is your cyberlife -- nothing in it works
> >
> > BY JAMES LILEKS
> >
> > YOU WAKE up late, wondering why the alarm didn't go off. After
> > all, you programmed your alarm to dial up the Atomic Clock
> > during the night and set your alarm within a nanosecond of the
> > proper time. Isn't technology wonderful? Unfortunately, the
> > connection crashed your alarm, and not only does it just keep
> > blinking 12:00-12:00-12:00, but all the DJs on the radio
> > stations are muttering nonsense syllables. You reboot the clock
> > and head to the shower.
> >
> > Ah, the water's hot, the water pressure is strong. You have a
> > good connection this morning. Lucky you. In the middle of
> > lathering your head, however, the shower head goes dry, and the
> > indicator reads: ``BROKEN PIPE. TRY AGAIN LATER.''
> >
> > Well, it happens. You sit on the edge of the tub and turn the
> > tap on and off until the water starts again. It comes out slow
> > and cold. Of course! This is the time of day when everyone on
> > the West Coast is hitting the showers. Slows everything down.
> >
> > You go to fetch the newspaper from the porch. It's thick today.
> > But a couple of pictures are missing from the front page, with
> > little question-mark icons where there should be a picture of a
> > car wreck -- but hey, that happens. When you turn the page, it
> > takes one minute for the words to appear. While you wait for
> > the paper to become legible, turn on the TV and catch the news.
> >
> > The TV has fancy plug-ins that enable it to display words,
> > pictures and video -- imagine that! There's a RealAudio WebCast
> > on flooding conditions in your neighborhood, so you pay
> > particular attention. Unfortunately, too many people are trying
> > to watch the same program, so the audio's a little sketchy.
> >
> > `` . . . -lood -ater SKRCRR eaded toward SKRCHRR esidents
> > advised to evacuatSKRCHRCHC efore certain deat SKROSSSH orrible
> > loss of . . . ''
> >
> > Hmm. Doesn't sound good. Maybe you'd better catch a cab for
> > work before the disaster strikes. On the way outside, you
> > remember that you have to mail a letter; it absolutely has to
> > have today's postmark. Hmmm. The mailman is slumped on the
> > ground unconscious. The mail slot is welded shut. A little sign
> > says, ``Mail is currently unavailable; try again in 15  minutes.''
> >
> > The cab ride is speedy, but the driver keeps telling you that
> > your address is not valid. You keep repeating the address:
> > day.work.office/cubicle/mychair.html, NOT cubicle.mychair.
> > Eventually he gets it. Stupid driver. He tells you to go to
> > hell/sulferouspit.com.
> >
> > After a productive morning working with pen and paper, it's
> > time for lunch. Perhaps you should try America Out to Lunch --
> > a fabulous restaurant with food from every culture on earth,
> > and AOL has an all-you-can-eat buffet for $19.95. Why not give
> > it a try? After all, you've already paid for it. They sent you
> > dozens of free menus until you signed up, and since they're
> > charging your credit card, you might as well have a bite.
> >
> > There are 300,000 inside the cafe, and thousands waiting to go
> > in. After you bang on the door for 10 minutes, it creaks open.
> > You give the maitre d' your password. WELCOME! he says. YOU'VE
> > GOT MAIL! (You still have the letter in your hand; all the
> > mailboxes are still welded shut.) You step up to the buffet.
> >
> > Just as you have loaded your plate with a delicious repast and
> > are ready to download the food into your stomach, a bouncer
> > appears, grabs you by the back of your jacket and hurls you
> > outside. A handbill flutters beside you. ``For some reason,''
> > it says, ``you have been thrown out of the restaurant. If this
> > problem persists, please call Customer Relations, and listen to
> > some nice on-hold music for 40 minutes.'' Yet there's a man on
> > the corner handing out free menus to the restaurant. You're
> > still hungry.
> >
> > Later you read in the paper that the restaurant is adding
> > tables as fast as they can, and as long as you don't intend to
> > eat for the next few weeks, you'll be fine.
> >
> > That night, you recount the day's frustrations, and wonder when
> > enough things will work enough times to make the day feel easy
> > and seamless. Well, that's the future, and the future's not
> > available. That's what makes it the future. All you can do now
> > is dream. You close your eyes, initialize your id and prepare
> > to handshake with your subconscious.
> >
> > Three hours later, you're still staring at the ceiling, waiting
> > for dreams. The busy signal is starting to sound like a lullaby.
> >
> > ----------------------------------------------------------------
> > James Lileks is a Newhouse News Service columnist.
> >
> > Published Monday, February 3, 1997, in the San Jose Mercury
> > News.  Copied with permission.

> Doesn't work too well with alcohol now does it?

	The penalties for giving alcohol to minors are not draconian.
	There's a general atmosphere of social tolerance for alcohol.
	But I agree, it might not work out that way. Still, my 
	experience at a young looking age 14 when I returned to
	the US from Greece (where there is no drinking age, and
	I used to get alcohol quite easily) was that it was easier
	to get marijuana than beer.

	Assuming an age limit of 18, 16 & 17 year olds will probably
	have fairly easy access. 12 year olds won't.

Mime-Version: 1.0

Date: Thu, 6 Feb 1997 01:13:20 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: anarch@scruznet.com (Anarch)
Subject: Re: why i get knocked on at raves
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

ZINTSMAS@SONOMA.EDU wrote:
>why
>does age matter? maturity is the key here, and i think you're all
>forgetting this when you're saying "people 18 and under shouldnt go
>to parties."

and:
>may i repeat again, iTS NOT ABOUT AGE. its about maturity.

I think everyone knows this.  Fundamentally, the qualities that people
would like to be restrictive about are things like maturity,
responsibility, respectfulness, and such.  But there's no easy way to
measure these qualities, so once you've decided to expand what you're doing
(raves, or anything) beyond the people you know intimately, you have to
give up some degree of control over them.  But not necessarily all--there's
a lot of ways to regulate indirectly.  Some are very simple and have only
minor drawbacks--taking care who you tell or how you advertise, for
example--but are correspondingly weak guarantees of the sort of person
you'll attract.  And if you feel that certain risks are too great or
certain costs are too high, you may want a stronger guarantee.  If you can
come up with some sort of statistical connection between an easy-to-measure
quality--say, age--and your hard-to-measure target-- "maturity" --then you
can get that stronger guarantee by testing people on the easy one.  And
yes, it will be unfair; you're bound to get false positives and negatives
both.  But maybe the tradeoff's acceptable.

It's matter of judgement on all counts, of course: weighing the risks and
costs, establishing correspondences, evaluating the tradeoffs.  But these
are things that can be reasonably discussed or argued about without this
sort of "it IS"/"it ISN'T" yammering, crying discrimination, and so on.

anarch@scruznet.com

I was just watching Late Night w/ Conan O'Brian and they were talking
with the actor John Frank Lezamo, and Conan asks him about his "dancing
hobby". "Oh yea!" Frank says, he's "totaly into the rave scene". "First"
he says, "you gotta get some E!" Then procedes to grab this big canister
of capsules with that big RX symbol on it. Conan's sidekick-dude  starts
to dig on em and pops one after another into his mouth. "*Then yew hav
two git into this british accent and be real violent" John says as he
jumps behind the chairs and throws on a black sweater and runs over to
this... well it can only be described as a one/two person rave area,
with some strobes and cool colors. Some cool trance breaks out full on.

"ARE YOU GOING TO RAVE WITH ME?!?" Yells John.

"Uhh.. you rave first then I'll jump in."

And you know, this guy can dance pretty good! Even though he funky/dumb
sometimes. Then Conan starts busting in trying to do some break dancing.

I have a tape if anyone whats to check it out.

Subject: Young ravers
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey all!

	All the talk I've heard and all the posts I've read regarding young
ravers (or candy ravers, or teeny-boppers, or whatever) has been most
discouraging, and it got me to thinking: how 'bout we more experienced
ravers try to show some of the younglings the aspects of the scene that
attract us?  Find out where their raving interest lies, and use that as a
springboard for exploration.  We were young once, too, just maybe not going
to parties.  These young people need to understand that it's not about
hanging out in some big tripper's den, but rather that it's about people
joining together through music and dance.  Beyond that, there are plenty of
additional spins people could put on the concept of the rave scene.
	I challenge each of you to someday make an effort to school at
least one young raver.  The more of them who spread the "good news," the
more of their friends might check in for good reasons, and the less we
might see of clueless kids just out of their minds.
Do you hear the bell ringing?  Class is about to start ;)
Love and peace,
Eric

groove radio and kcrw in los angeles saved me when i was down in los
angeles for a break.  i got to hear an interview with juan atkins.  i also
bobbed my head to carl cox spinning on the radio and at a sunday weekly
called logic.  groove radio is a cool station for the most part.

if anyone's every down in la, also check out metropolis hosted by jason
bentley, on kcrw 89.9 fm.  jason bentley was the editor of urb for years
and has been heavily involved in the l.a. scene.



>When Groove Radio 103.1 in LA (broadcasts out of Santa Monica, repeater
>station is in Newport Beach) went on the air in the summer, it was really
>really funny.  No DJs, no real programming cycle, just all of a sudden
>this message ont eh air that said "Have you ever been to a rave...?" and
>then all this clubby-housey music.
>
>Now, after a while, they got their programs together, got the DJs on board
>and such and it's all good.  During the daytime they spin mostly
>commercially available club/house/Hi-NRG stuff, but they also spin a good
>amount of Drum&Bass and various techno.  Now, everybody has to pay their
>bills, so you really can't condemn Groove Radio for spinning commercial
>discs during the day.
>Noghttime, though, sees a bit of a difference.  Continuous mix shows
>dominate, including special guest DJs from all around the country.  Doc
>Martin has a weekly show, and there is also a weekly International
>countdown continuous mix program.  Last week they broadcast the Future
>Sound of London live via an ISDN hookup.
>I've heard everything from Troi Amos to Fatboy Slim, Josh Wink to
>Uberzone, Fluke to Everything But the Girl on Groove Radio.  The diversity
>in the programming is quite impressive for a commercial station.  But, if
>you only listen at lunch time or on your drive home from work, you're only
>going to hear the heavy rotation tracks.
>
>Just my thoughts.  Viva Groove Radio!

On Thu, 6 Feb 1997, Anarch wrote:

> certain costs are too high, you may want a stronger guarantee.  If you can
> come up with some sort of statistical connection between an easy-to-measure
> quality--say, age--and your hard-to-measure target-- "maturity" --then you
> can get that stronger guarantee by testing people on the easy one.  And
> yes, it will be unfair; you're bound to get false positives and negatives
> both.  But maybe the tradeoff's acceptable.

Really? Let's look at a similar situation. As others have pointed out a
very disproportionate number of people in prison are people of color. So
it could be argued that statistically, people of color commit more crimes.
(actually more likely that they can't afford to buy justice.) 

Now, do you think it would be an "acceptable tradeoff" to say, limit the
number of people of color in a store at a given time because statistically
the store could show that people of color commit more crime? This is done
every day with young people. We are criminalizing a whole group in our
society based on their age alone. It is no more right than the above
senario. The only difference is that young people have no rights in this
society. What kind of message do you send to young people when you treat
them like criminals until the age of 18? How do you expect them to act?

Finally, I think that many people are making a big, possibly false
assumption here: Anyone under 18 who comes to a party is going to do
drugs, and therefore should not be at the party.  

					Black Adder

I was happenning to listin to the radio this morning (BTW is rare for me)
but I heard what the radio had to say. They started there little news cast with
sound bytes from the 20/20 fiasco and they just totally made the "rave" scene
look so negative. Then the stupid DJ's went on to say how they have done "E"
and the dangers that it possess. But he went on to say how he liked it and
loved the feeling. Yet enticing young listners to possibly consider taking the
drug and at the same time he is saying how bad it is. He made his self sound
like a total hypocrit. Then some of the listners called in and said that 2 out
of hundreed people that try E die there first time. I Find these stats a little
hard to beleive seeing how I have been going to partys for 4 or 5 years and
have been to countless massives. with tens of thousands of people and never had
heard of any deaths. I was not trying to find any however either but I have
just not heard of two many "rave ecstacy" realated deaths in my time in the
scene. That is not to say that there have not been any cause I bet there have
but 2 out of 100 those facts are wrong or else we would have seen a lot of
people dead at partys. They would have been dropping like flys? I wonder where
these "experts" get there stats from? Sorry but that was my $0.02

On Wed, 5 Feb 1997 rayvonie@ix.netcom.com wrote:

> I raed your post and would like to ask you something........
> 
> DO YOU KNOW ME????  HAVE YOU EVER TALKED TO ME???  I HAVE NO IDEA WHO YOU ARE, BUT YOU SEEM TO 
> THINK YOU KNOW ALL ABOUT ME.  DO YOU KNOW HOW TO READ???  

I suppose one could ask you if you know how to write.

> DO YOU MAKE IT A HABIT TO INSULT STRANGERS AND TELLING THEM WHAT THEY ARE SUPOSABLY THINKING 
> WITHOUT EVEN LISTENING TO WHAT THEY SAID?????

I listened to what you said. Pretty much sounds like bullshit to me. 

What you said(possible paraphrasing):

"This party is a benefit for the enviroment."
"This party is about sharing and giving." 
"I am not opening up my books." 

When someone says something is a benefit, I take that to mean that most,
if not all profits are going to the cause. For example, Gaimind springs to
mind as a true benefit(and a really diverse crowd too which was cool.) 

Now, you claim that your party is a benefit for the enviroment, but you
refuse to tell us how much money is going to this cause, who the money is
going to, what percentange of the profits are going to this cause or any
meaningful information. All you say is: "The more you give, the more will 
go to the cause." And from your post that cause seems to be primarily your
pocket book. 

> DO YOU CONSIDER THIS RESPECTFULL?  

I consider your post an insult to my intelligence. Apparently a couple
others felt the same way, which is why you received the responses you did.

> WHAT IS YOUR DEFENITION OF PLUR??  

Something that doesn't cost $20, and you can't sell, which is what you are
doing.

> Anyways, I am not going to indulge you by trying to defend myself or my position.  I make it a 
> habit not to have conversations with closed minded, opinionated, negative egomaniacs. I have 
> been in this scene for way to long, and taken way to much shit from the like of you.  And you 
> know what, I'm still here.  And you know what else, I'm not going anywhere.

Then why did you respond in the first place, screaming all the way?

> Mabee you should read my initial post, with an open mind this time, and see if you understand me 
> any better.  If not call me, and get to know me.  415-593-3664.  Atleast then you won't be 
> insulting a complete stranger.  

Hmm. Nope, still seems like bullshit to me. 

You know, I don't think anyone would object if you said "Hey, I am going
to throw a kick-ass party and it is $20." But when you say your party is
the benefit for something, and then are ambigious and defensive about
exact amounts, and start making new-agey, feel-good brotherhood
of man and PLUR statements, it all rings very, very, hollow. This party is
about making *you* money first, and everything else is second. If you were
to just level with people, perhaps you would have some more credibility.

                                         Black Adder
