	Right on... spring is nearly here, and all of us experienced
ravers have to spread that *pure* underground vibe which is so fantastic--
since the mainstream always eventually adopts a somewhat diluted version
of whatever is going on underground, I think it's all the more important
that we increase the 'PLUR density level', if you will--that way, the
lessons of raving will carry more impact as they spread everywhere (given
that this year looks like it will be the 'year raves blow up' for better
or worse).  If it can be shown to as many people as possible that DIY is 
the way to go, then DIY will set the standard... (sorry to sound like some 
quasi-prophet or something there ;)
Anyways, I guess you can never overdo it on PLUR, so more more more!
best,
Timothy 


On Thu, 6 Feb 1997, Eric P. Peterson wrote:

> Hey all!
> 
> 	All the talk I've heard and all the posts I've read regarding young
> ravers (or candy ravers, or teeny-boppers, or whatever) has been most
> discouraging, and it got me to thinking: how 'bout we more experienced
> ravers try to show some of the younglings the aspects of the scene that
> attract us?  Find out where their raving interest lies, and use that as a
> springboard for exploration.  We were young once, too, just maybe not going
> to parties.  These young people need to understand that it's not about
> hanging out in some big tripper's den, but rather that it's about people
> joining together through music and dance.  Beyond that, there are plenty of
> additional spins people could put on the concept of the rave scene.
> 	I challenge each of you to someday make an effort to school at
> least one young raver.  The more of them who spread the "good news," the
> more of their friends might check in for good reasons, and the less we
> might see of clueless kids just out of their minds.
> Do you hear the bell ringing?  Class is about to start ;)
> Love and peace,
> Eric
> 
> 
>

WAIT!

No no no no please don't say you don't care about politics!!
NEVER say that, however tempting it may be!  Politics *matter*.
Did you hear President Clinton's proposal?  A 10,000 dollar tax credit
for college tuition!!!  A pledge to make education "The number one 
priority for the next four years."  I know I always stick up for Clinton, 
but believe me the guy knows what's up.  A lot of his ideals match up
with the traditional set of raver ideologies: more education, more
knowledge, and greater global community through advancements in
technology.  
Anyways, I would just love to see ravers more involved in politics,
especially because we have so many great ideas and could actually bring
about some real change.  
And if anyone wants to get good, accurate political coverage, click on
www.washingtonpost.com.   (And no, all you silly SF "the media brainwashes
us and controls the news" people ;) --sorry couldn't resist, I'm a DC
boy--the post can be trusted --remember, they toppled Nixon!)
Local political coverage here sucks, basically because no one at the 
Chronicle can write, but the post is a great read.
Anyway, I've rambled enough I think, but remember--your voice counts
as much as anyone's, so don't be afraid to use it!

"The biggest enemy today is inaction." -Bill Clinton

peace and love,
Timothy

Dear ravers, 

	What can I say, I tried to get out a positive message about a positve event, and insted I 
was made to feel like shit for trying.  But That doesn't matter.  A lot of people posted me 
privately suporting what I am doing.  That made me feel good.  Thank you everybody.  

	There is way to much anamosity and politics.  This is the underground......Why can't we 
all just get along??  Isn't that the reason why we went underground to get away from things like 
this???  I don't think there is anythin I will be able to say that will change peoples minds, 
and that is hardly what I wanted anyways.  All I wanted to do was to share my information about, 
what I believe, to be a positive event for a good pursose.  I do not have the luxury or the 
convenience of time to respond to everyones questions.  I am sorry, but I have important work to 
take care of for the party.

For those of you who care enough, and realy want to get to know me, just give ma a call, @ 415-
593-3664.  I will be glad to talk to you, answer all your questions, and get to know you.  I 
hope you do call.  The only thing you may loose by talking to me is your asumtions.

It would be nice to talk to some of you in person, And answer all your questions.  I will try to 
make it to the FnF party this weekend,  If you realy want to talk....find me.  I won't be hard 
to miss.  I will be the guy wearing a t-shirt that says "Money Grubin Sell-Out rave promoter"  
walking around throwing flyers on the ground, and trying to steal money ot of peoples bags. just 
kiding.

I will once again try to leave a copy of my original post, for those of you that missed it the 
first time.  Thank you for you time and bandwidth.

PLUR
Vlad,  415-593-3664  FGE
bad spelling is my trademark.


Original post:
	
From: rayvonie
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: 02/04/95 01:04:00
Subject: Love Is In The Air


The following post contains views and subject mater that might not be suitable for all readers.  
Open mindedness is suggested.

I was not sure I was going to post any information about this party on the net.  I always get my 
head chewed of every time I go out of my way to try and inform the people on this list about my 
events.   I debated for some time whether I was going to subject myself to the aggravation of 
having people misinterpret my intentions and actions and inevitably blow things completely out 
of proportion.  But because of my open mindedness, I decided to go with the benefit of the doubt 
and tell everyone who cares about our event.

The event on Feb 15th is going to be unlike any event we have ever produced.

It is our 5 year anniversary event.  We are going to take everything that we have learned in the 
past 5 years and apply a very generous application of PLUR into making an incredible party.  In 
my opinion, there is no substitute for experience, and there is no excuse for ignorance.   We 
are not holding anything back, this event will break new ground.

This event is all about love.  It is about giving, and sharing.   

It is really hard for me to put my feeling into words when it comes to something as passionate 
an meaningful as this.  All I can say is that this event is going to be like non before, and 
will hopefully set the pattern for other promoters to follow.   If you want to understand what I 
mean, you will just have to experience it for yourself.

The event is a benefit for the environment.  At the party will be tables set up by several non 
profit environmental activity organizations that will receive monetary donations from a portion 
of the proceeds from this party.  Yes StarChild, I said a portion, and NO I will not open up my 
books for anyone to review.  Please lets not start that discussion all over again. 
The better the party does, the more money we will donate.  Your support of this event will be 
directly reflected in our contribution the save our planet and aid in education about 
environmental problems.  It is something that we call - "Edutainment:  Educational 
Entertainment"  This is the direction that We will be focusing all our future events on.

I know that some of you have this certain stigma about "massive" and large parties in general 
for whatever reasons.  That is fine.  I respect your views, and would prefer that you kept them 
to yourselves, or e-mailed me privately.  But for those of you who have always wanted to 
experience a large party with the small party vibe, than don't miss this event.

A party is not measured by its size.  Size has become a barrier that is insinuated to be 
inversely proportional to the vibe of the party.  I can't understand how so many of you got 
suckered into believing this BS.   I believe that the problem lies in the fact that it takes a 
lot of very very very hard work and determination to create a large party with a good vibe.  And 
because it does take so much work, most promoters are more willing to perpetuate the mentality 
that you cannot have a good vibe at a large party, so therefore large parties do not have a good 
vibe.  This to me is the epitomy of laziness, and ignorance.  I don not only believe that large 
party can have a great vibe, I am going to prove it.
  
You see, the vibe is something that is created far before the party takes place.  It is a 
combination of: belief, attitude, motivation, concern, effort, and most of all; inspiration and 
vision.  When these factors collimate with good intentions, the vibe is created.  This is the 
vibe that people take with them to the party.  Vibe is not created by an event at all, it is 
expressed there.  The promoters job is to manifest to expectations that people bring with them 
into reality.  If this is done, then the vibe at the event will be better than good, it will be 
extraordinary.

You can not please everybody.  I used to think you could, and at one time it was possible, but 
the scene is very dynamic, and changes all the time.  Over the past 5 years of throwing parties 
and being involved in the scene, I have seen many changes and I have come up with many of my own 
conclusions as to what is needed to make a good party.  These beliefs will be self evident in 
our anniversary party on the 15th.    

I hope to get a chance to see everybody out there, sharing love, and rejoicing in the goodness 
created by our culture, spirituality, and energy. 

For all the info and DJ lineups and directions, check the SF Raves calendar, and dial the info 
numbers.  Leave me a message if you like or e-mail me.  I would love to hear your opinion or 
suggestions.

Attached is a copy of the Global Party Network News Letter that we sent out.  For those of you 
who do not understand what we are doing at Feel Good Entertainment, maybe this will bring you up 
to speed.

PLUR
Vlad, Feel Good Entertainment,  Executive Producer , aka: Ray Vonie


Global Party Network News Letter                  Issue #  2         

Introduction

Dear Global Party Network Members, it is a new year and it looks like it is going to be a 
wonderful and positive year in all respects.  The purpose of this newsletter is to keep 
everybody informed about our upcoming plans as well as sharing information about topics that 
concern our scene and our culture.

The Past Five Years Were Just The Beginning 

It was a Thursday night on Valentine's Day, in 1992, when 200 people crowded into a small 
basement for the first event promoted by Feel Good Productions.  The name has now become Feel 
Good Entertainment, but the vision has not changed, and our mission is still to create positive 
events that make people FEEL GOOD.  Our parties are now safer, legal, more culturally 
diversified, always original, and virtually hassle free.
People often ask me, "What is FGE all about?"  Well, the answer is very simple.  We want to 
create a cohesive medium that culminates  Music, Dance, Spirituality, Expression, and Awareness, 
so that it promotes Peace, Love, Unity, and Respect for everything.  It means more than just 
throwing outrageous parties, it's producing incredible dance collectives for meaningful reasons.  
We are a dynamic organization with real concerns about our community, our culture, and the 
direction of the rave scene.  We work year-round on creating this cohesive medium that we called 
the Global Party Network.  By networking everyone's resources, we want to create a powerful 
organization that will maintain the integrity of the reason why we 'RAVE'.  This is what FGE is 
all about.   We are all the Rave Generation.  Lets keep it REAL.   

97 and Beyond 

The GPN (Global Party Network) has many aspects.  These include; The  Buzz-Line, Global Party 
Productions, The GPN News, GlobalParty.Com., the Membership Card Program, and YOU.  These are 
just some of the things that make up the GPN and much more is being worked on daily.  The 
following will hopefully bring everybody up to speed on the past, present, and future of  the 
GPN.   
Three years ago, we started the Buzz-Line.  This information resource is to help ALL promoters 
pass on their event info, and to help ALL ravers find out about all the parties and clubs.  We 
provide this service to spread the word about positive parties going on and to keep people 
informed and aware of our culture.  This service is free to you, but for us, it is expensive and 
time consuming to operate and maintain.  Sometimes 'Shit Happens' and it breaks down,  but we 
are still doing our best to make it even more reliable and dependable.   In the event that there 
are problems with the new number, 415-569-3300,  then please call the FGE info line @ 415-568-
1338 for updates or changes.   We plan on expanding the Buzz-Line with many surprises this 
year, so keep calling.
Global Party Productions is the engine that creates FGE events.  You are all members of the GPN, 
therefore Global Party Productions are parties for you.  Every one of our events is a growth 
experience.  With each party, we learn and improve the way we do things.  As always, we make 
sure that all of our events are positive for you, the community, and our culture.   We 
have always made some form of  donation to non-profit organizations, whether the event made a 
profit or not.  It is our ultimate goal to eventually expand Global Party Productions into a 
'Benefactory' collective, producing 100% beneficial events for our community.  This might still 
be a ways down the road but we plan on setting up our events so that each time we are able to 
contribute more, until we reach our goal.   This will give all of our events a method of 
channeling the positive vibe created at the parties into a meaningful direction.   Makes me FEEL 
GOOD just thinking about it.
What you are reading now is our second issue of the Global Party Network News.  We hope that 
this grows and becomes something informative and meaningful as a regular periodical of the 
network.  In future issues, we would like to see articles contributed by some members of the 
GPN.   Your comments, views, and questions are always welcome.  Please feel 
free to submit any articles, stories, poems, or artwork to us anytime.  If you have something 
you want to share with us, please fax it to 415-654-9354, or send it to Feel Good Entertainment,  
951 Old County Rd.  Suite # 217, Belmont, CA.  94404.
By summertime, the GPN will be online.  Our domain is registered @ WWW.GlobalParty.Com.   We 
will let you know as soon as it is ready.   If you want to contribute to our website, please 
leave a message on our voice mail. 
The GPN is like a support mechanism for our rave community.   Many of you already have the 
membership card, most of you don't.  If you did not pick yours up at Megga-Buzz, they will be 
available at the GPN booth at Love A-Fair on Feb 15th.   The card program will get you discounts 
at clubs, parties, food, merchandise, and other services that support the GPN.  It is just 
our way of saying thanks for your support.  Keep calling the Buzz-Line for updates.  
This is just the beginning of the GPN.  We have a lot of incredible ideas on how to create our 
network.  It will take a lot of hard work and a great deal of support.  By working together we 
can accomplish more than our wildest dreams.  Lets show the world the power of  RAVING. 

A Very Special Celebration of Unconditional Love.

How much do you love raving?  Does raving love you back?  What does it mean to you?   What do 
you get out of it?  Is it about the music, the dancing, the energy, the spirituality, the 
people, or the whole scene?  Why do you do it?  The answers to these questions are the reasons 
for this party.    In our own individual ways, we all have an intimate love affair 
with raving.  It means a lot more to us than just partying or dancing, it is the ritualistic 
devotion and dedication that makes us all feel good about ourselves when we know that our 
partying has a positive message, that it has a purpose,  a deeper meaning, and a direction.  
That is what creates our love affair with raving. 	
Valentine's is a reason to express love and affection.  This Valentine's, lets share our 
unconditional love.  Our five year birthday party is a festival dedicated to environmental 
awareness and consciousness.  A portion of our proceeds will be donated to several non-profit 
environmental activity programs.  Lets show our love for Mother Earth by helping to 
conserve our natural resources and  to protect our only planet. 
This party will be set up like a small festival, or like a FAIR (get it??)    We do not want to 
give away all the surprises, but I'll put it like this -  we are putting a lot of passion into 
this party.  It is our five year anniversary and we aren't going to do anything short of 
spectacular to celebrate this event.  We have a wonderful, fully permitted, centrally located, 
indoor and outdoor, Bay Area location.  Take a look at the flyer and read it carefully - this 
party is going to break new 
ground.  As always, we are going to do our best to create a large party with the small party 
feel.  We will do our part and set up the event, but you are the one that will set the vibe, so 
please come prepared to share your love with everybody, and it will turn out to be a very 
memorable night full of fun, excitement, and absolutely excellent music.
	We have enclosed a special gift for all GPN members.  It is a cutaway coupon on the bottom 
of the flyer.  This is just a small way to show you our love and appreciation for your support.  
We look forward to seeing you all on Feb 15th.  Get there early, or you might miss some of the 
incredible surprises that we have in store for you, and please recycle the flyer by sharing it 
with a friend. 

Tagging - Its Not Cool At All !!!! 

Graffiti is Art, but Tagging is Vandalism.  It's destroying our scene.  Here is a list of 
locations that will never again be used for raves because of tagging; Cow Palace, Richmond 
Civic, Henry J. Kaiser, Vallejo & Sonoma County Fairgrounds, Fashion Center, Concourse, 
Galleria, Santa Cruz Civic, and many more.  It costs the rave scene money by making raves 
more expensive, and gives us a bad image by giving society the wrong impression.  Please protect 
and respect our scene, as well as the art form of graffiti  by  putting an end to tagging before 
we run out of places to have raves.   Please spread the word.

Editorial  (Just My View on Things) 
 
Music is has a special way of distinguishing people and separating generations.  The 60's gave 
us Hippies.  In the 70's it was Disco.  The 80's brought us Rock and Roll, and now it's the 
90's, and everybody is raving to house music.   Raving is becoming  more and more accepted every 
day.  What started as underground music and parties has grown to become a major influence in our 
lifestyles and attitudes.  Some things, such as the spread of  Peace, Love, Unity, and Respect 
(PLUR) are good for society, and we feel proud about this positive contribution from our 
culture.  Other things, such as the exploitation of the culture by mainstream capitalization, 
are less appealing.  We can't sit around and wish for things to get better, because they won't.  
However, our attitudes, participation, and behavior can influence the expansion of raving 
in a more positive direction, bettering society.  We have a very unique heritage, and it would 
be a shame if it was forgotten or misunderstood.  It is up to each one of us to figure out what 
we can do to influence society's perception of our generation.  It's no longer 'Just Do It', 
it's about doing it the right way for all the right reasons.  Lets show our pride.  This is our 
time.  We are the Rave Generation.









From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Feb  6 13:07:37 1997

Dear friend,

	The climate of the sfraves list has become entirely to vicious.
I haven't read the whole text of your original post yet, but I
will do so.  For now, I will offer that many UG ravers
are coming to detest anything that's high-production/high-cost
(AKA "massives"), because they see it as voracious capitalism,
corrupting something that they'd rather maintain as pure as possible.
	I do not share this feeling.  The Gathering changed my mind
about massives in general.  There are some promoters who have found
other promoters to have impure motives, and justifiably so, but that's
no reason, IMHO, to blanket all promoters who wish to put together
extra-special events, even if those events *will* generate tall bank.
	I've never been to a party and come away from it feeling as
though I didn't get my pure chewing satisfaction (my money's worth).
I know how to be selective.  It's not my place to condemn others, no
matter their motives or actions, but I do feel, very strongly, that no
one is welcome in the scene who wants to exploit it solely for their
own gain or aggrandizement (sp?).  At this point, I don't see you as
that type.  Until and unless I have proof positive to the contrary, I
will support you.
	There, I've done it: stuck my neck out.  Is that a headsman's
axe I hear whistling my way?  OK, I'm posting too much again.  I'll
quiet down now...
Peace, PLEASE!
Eric

what I think I see in that phrasing.

Received: from 13474597.mcoe.k12.ca.us (ts1-slns-ppp18.salinas.net [205.179.129.48]) by lettuce.salinas.net (8.7.6/8.6.9) with SMTP id QAA12159 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 6 Feb 1997 16:55:44 -0800

X-Sender: silver@salinas.net

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "SpinSilver--'Robertj@Monterey'" <silver@salinas.net>
Subject: Spin Cycle & Term Limits
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



....hey,hey,....for the older ravers it sometimes feels like post or die.
If not, one simply fades into the hyperreal archives...My last party was the
Cloudfactory NYE so I got enough rave energy to power my life for a
while.....that and spinning at home...Rave parties of one.  The upside of
that is I get to pick the records and there are no cops or 15 years olds bad
tripping on drugs, etc.  However, I do miss "being there....and dancing with
the tribe...."

Anyway, when the cloudfactory boys posted that they a found another
spot..the CSUMB Black Box cabaret to play at on Tues...I said to
myself.."SpinSilver should be at the Spin Cycle!!""" Besides they are the
kinda people one likes to support, cause they're hearts in the right spot,
and they're do'in it right.....

It was on the old fort ord military base, so they was kinda fun.  It was an
old army barracks, coverted into a college coffee house.  Scott said they
had about forty people last week, but there were only about 15 hail and
hearty this week.  It always takes awhile to build a weekly.....WE danced
and had fun...It will be a cool place to play it LOUD!!!!!

Definately try to make it in two weeks for Astronaut Scott and Maya....they
will tear it up. Definately.

Bye the bye,..all this talk about age limits gets me to wondering.  I hope
no one starts thinks that there should be an old age limit for parties.
..."Sorry, you're over forty, you can't come in...you'll spoil the vibe...go
away old raver dude!!!!  Go play your Lawerence Welk records, and waltz
yourself to death...That's the knock I used to get sometimes,  "What are you
doing here?"

The younger ravers actually need the older ravers to shoe them the way to
responsible raving and responsible drug use, or the joys of sober
raving...(I do both). I actually miss the wizened, and sagacious voices of
Geoff White, and Lee Fogel, who were able to provide so much insight, with
so much love and experience.....

I hope to play at the Spin Cycle in a few months...just so I could say, come
and hear SpinSilver@Spin Cycle, it almost rhymes............

****************************************************************************
*******************************

..........."rEMEBER YOU'RE UNIQUE..........jUST LIKE EVERYBODY
ELSE....".............SpinSilver

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)

       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)

       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)

       Electronic dance, noise, spoken word, world music and more. Beats
       for your head. Sounds for your soul. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)

       (Berkeley)

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

>Subject:      beautiful experience to miss deadline

>xiwangmu,

>   Mara, my muse, please excuse me if I tell you that last night I dreamed
>that you raped the shit out of me in the guise of a 30-year-old Bangkok
>whore, a species rarely observed nature as nearly all are dead of AIDS
>by that age. You had Universal Knowledge. You brushed aside my excuses
>about taboos, keeping a clean grindstone on my nose, and the deplorably
>irreversible consequences of the Stony Brook Fumigation experience. Knew
>I'd awake with a wonderful HIV-Positive experience that I would refused
>to allow to vanish by getting tested.
>
>   The Jewish god got online saying: "My boy, AIDS is certainly a lethal
>enough disease, but I gave you a deadline of 30 June, which you are not
>going to make. You should have at least tried to sweeten the deal,
>denominated in Spirit Money, with real Monopoly money, and if that
>failed to suffice, Thai baht, even HK$. In my long experience dealing
>with the Chinese, they are hardworking, charge rock-bottom, and never
>full of germs. But they are perfectionists. They have incredibly high
>standards, and will take as long as it takes to meet them. If you need
>them to cut corners for JIT, Japanese Instant Truck, they charge you.
>One time I came down to Earth in lower Manhattan as a *gonser macher*
>in the recycling business. I ran into an old-timer Chinaman, fluent
>in Yiddish, and he sold me the Brooklyn Bridge at an irresistible price.
>Then started making delivery brick by brick. I went back to him and
>said, 'This is taking too long, those crooks who work for the City
>want their bridge back fast, and will make Trouble for me over the
>balance of the resale price, which will cut heavily into my admittely
>larger-than-anticipated profits. Gimme a break, speed it up, willya.'
>   "He said, 'Let's renegotiate.'"
>   "So I said, 'Fuck a goat.'"
>
>   So, Mara, I told the Jewish god that he spake enough, motherfucker, get
>lost, I told him, he screwed up from the start allowing me to be born, not
>the last of six miscarriages, for this gives Wrathful Judgment.
>
>   Your deities are no improvement, to say nothing. Chinese invented
>Professionals and -ism, they invented snobs. So the Xiwangmu idol, MADE
>IN CHINA of ALL MAN MADE MATERIALS first thing yesterday morning gives
>me "I absolutely *refuse* to be worshipped by scum like you in a dump
>like this. From your standard of living, you by definition have No
>Education. I demand you donate me to the Yale Art Museum *at once*!"
>
>   Realizing it was pointless to tell that bitch that no museum will
>touch a $5 plastic tourist idol, I put her in a brown paper bag, handed
>her to Congregation B'nei Emeth, and said, "This is a graven image. You
>know what to do with it."
>

Received: from ucdata.Berkeley.EDU.ucdt (ucdata.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.165.25]) by nak.berkeley.edu (8.7.3/8.6.10) with SMTP id SAA03255 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 6 Feb 1997 18:06:50 -0800 (PST)

	id SAA22766; Thu, 6 Feb 1997 18:03:34 -0800
Date: Thu, 6 Feb 1997 18:03:34 -0800 (PST)
From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Sacrificial Lamb
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9702061751.A22598-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



You know, the viciousness of SFRavers is wrecking my PLUR much more than 
any massives happening this weekend...

Values mean nothing if preached but not followed.  And to skewer some 
promoter or other for not showing "enough" respect/love/etc. is almost 
laughably hypocritical.

Massives are not by definition evil.  They are huge productions that
require a larger ticket price.  Why is a small $15 Harmony party just
dandy, and a huge massive, just five dollars more, with dj's from all over
the country/world, permitted space, lightshows, etc. suddenly the fount of
all evil?  On that note, why does a $20 Martin party get the blessing of
SFRavers, while a $20 Feel Good party get roasted (a nice word for it)? 

I am not a fan of commercialism, the general attitude at commercial 
parties, or the prospect of turing "rave" into a profitable commodity.
But if our intent is to create a positive and loving community, we need 
to start living by the values we are demanding others to follow (and, 
seemingly,  being arbitrary about who gets labeled pure and who is a rave 
outlaw!)

Massives _are_ commercial ventures, and this is enough to brand them bad 
- or at least suspect - in many people's eyes (including mine!).  But 
massives ARE how most people are exposed to our scene.  By highlighting 
PLUR and benefiting good causes, massives are in fact EXPOSING people to 
these ideals.  We can grumble about their "exploiting" these ideals to 
entrap idealistic - and, I guess, stupid - SFRavers into shelling out 
$20, but if a massive doesn't meet our elitist definition of what's 
_really_ peace and love, don't we have the mental capacity to evaluate 
that for OURSELVES?  Ever hear the term, vote with your pocketbook??  

Meanwhile, newbies go to a Feel Good and hear these virtues included on
the flier as an integral part of the party, something they are told to be
aware of before even coming to the event.  Do they have the cynical eyes
we do?  Or are they then opened in a way?  And for us old cynics who laugh
at the idea of PLUR at (certain) $20 parties, there still is a damn good
dance event for our money. 

I personally cringe when I see Vlad post, because I know he will be the 
recipient of an unbelievable torrent of verbal abuse from peaceful, 
respectful underground ravers.  What is his crime, exactly?  Daring to 
mention the virtues peace, love, unity, respect while charging money?  Then 
why aren't other promoters held to that same standard?

We have promoters who are charged with attempting to have someone stabbed 
to death.  We have promoters who had a person beat to a pulp in 
front of hundreds of people in line for a "party".  Where is the outrage 
over these _real_ outrages??!  Is Feel Good Entertainment some sort of 
sacrificial lamb, some syphon into which we can sublimate all the rave 
scene's problems?  A convenient scapegoat, because the promoter dares to 
post on SFRaves.

A $20 party isn't the problem.  Making our touted values real is what 
_really_ needs our attention.

Because I love the scene,
and all of you,
Nancy

  This scientific veiw, makes no scence to me..
  LSD can make you one wacked out individual. No matter what you read. This
is a fact.  LSD is not something you want to use as frequently as, POT for
say.
  Even last week (if my story is staight)  I heard that some girl raped her
self in a closet, on LSD.. Let this be a leson to you little kiddies on
Acid.

  I myself dropped out of school becouse, I spent all my lunch money on
Acid. But what a trip lunch was everyday though.
  I would buy two hits of acid everyday, save one, and take the other. At
the end of the week, I would take all the hits I saved and pop them all at
once. Up to as many as 20 assorted hits!  And Acid gets weeker every
century. So you could amagine how high I was ten years ago.
  My Dad, and step Mom were all drunk one night.  And..  Me and my older
brother ended up frying with them.. Anyone else ever fry with there
parents?  Ha.

  It's just a freaky drug.
 Being an Acid head sucks.

Jeff

Hey all, thought this was kinda funny.  

Love
Shawna



>Imagine if you will... the leader of the fifth invader force speaking 
>to the commander in chief...
>"They're made out of meat."
>"Meat?"
>"Meat.  They're made out of meat."
>"Meat?"
>"There's no doubt about it. We picked several from different parts of 
>the planet, took them aboard our recon vessels, probed them all the 
>way through.  They're completely meat."
>"That's impossible.  What about the radio signals?  The messages to 
>the stars."
>"They use the radio waves to talk, but the signals don't come from 
>them. The signals come from machines."
>"So who made the machines?  That's who we want to contact."
>"They made the machines.  That's what I'm trying to tell you.  Meat 
>made the machines."
>"That's ridiculous.  How can meat make a machine?  You're asking me to 
>believe in sentient meat."
>"I'm not asking you, I'm telling you.  These creatures are the only 
>sentient race in the sector and they're made out of meat."
>"Maybe they're like the Orfolei.  You know, a carbon-based 
>intelligence that goes through a meat stage."
>"Nope.  They're born meat and they die meat.  We studied them for 
>several of their life spans, which didn't take too long.  Do you have 
>any idea the life span of meat?"
>"Spare me.  Okay, maybe they're only part meat.  You know, like the 
>Weddilei.  A meat head with an electron plasma brain inside."
>"Nope.  We thought of that, since they do have meat heads like the 
>Weddilei.  But I told you, we probed them. They're meat all the way through."
>"No brain?"
>"Oh, there is a brain all right.  It's just that the brain is made out 
>of meat!"
>"So... what does the thinking?"
>"You're not understanding, are you?  The brain does the thinking.  The 
>meat."
>"Thinking meat!  You're asking me to believe in thinking meat!"
>"Yes, thinking meat!  Conscious meat!  Loving meat.  Dreaming meat. 
> The meat is the whole deal!  Are you getting the picture?"
>"Omigod.  You're serious then.  They're made out of meat."
>"Finally.  Yes.  They are indeed made out meat.  And they've been 
>trying to get in touch with us for almost a hundred of their years."
>"So what does the meat have in mind?"
>"First it wants to talk to us.  Then I imagine it wants to explore the 
>universe, contact other sentients, swap ideas and information.  The 
>usual."
>"We're supposed to talk to meat?"
>"That's the idea.  That's the message they're sending out by radio. 
> 'Hello.  Anyone out there?  Anyone home?'  That sort of thing."
>"They actually do talk, then.  They use words, ideas, concepts?"
>"Oh, yes.  Except they do it with meat."
>"I thought you just told me they used radio."
>"They do, but what do you think is on the radio?  Meat sounds.  You 
>know how when you slap or flap meat it makes a noise?  They talk by 
>flapping their meat at each other.  They can even sing by squirting 
>air through their meat."
>"Omigod.  Singing meat.  This is altogether too much. So what do you 
>advise?"
>"Officially or unofficially?"
>"Both."
>"Officially, we are required to contact, welcome, and log in any and 
>all sentient races or multibeings in the quadrant, without prejudice, 
>fear, or favor.  Unofficially, I advise that we erase the records and 
>forget the whole thing."
>"I was hoping you would say that."
>"It seems harsh, but there is a limit.  Do we really want to make 
>contact with meat?"
>"I agree one hundred percent.  What's there to say?"  'Hello, meat. 
>How's it going?'  But will this work?  How many planets are we dealing 
>with here?"
>"Just one.  They can travel to other planets in special meat 
>containers, but they can't live on them.  And being meat, they only 
>travel through C space.  Which limits them to the speed of light and 
>makes the possibility of their ever making contact pretty slim. 
>Infinitesimal, in fact."
>"So we just pretend there's no one home in the universe."
>"That's it."
>"Cruel.  But you said it yourself, who wants to meet meat?  And the 
>ones who have been aboard our vessels, the ones you have probed? 
> You're sure they won't remember?"
>"They'll be considered crackpots if they do.  We went into their heads 
>and smoothed out their meat so that we're just a dream to them."
>"A dream to meat!  How strangely appropriate, that we should be meat's 
>dream."
>"And we can mark this sector unoccupied."
>"Good.  Agreed, officially and unofficially.  Case closed.  Any 
>others?   Anyone interesting on that side of the galaxy?"
>"Yes, a rather shy but sweet hydrogen core cluster intelligence in a 
>class nine star in G445 zone.  Was in contact two galactic rotations 
>ago, wants to be friendly again."
>"They always come around."
>"And why not? Imagine how unbearably, how unutterably cold the 
>universe would be if one were all alone."

though.  security perhaps gets stressed out because it's friggin HARD to 
control a crowd that size.  quite often your life can be on the line 
(this has been proven a few times where people have been trampled to 
death).  of course, that doesnt' really give security any special 
privelege to be agressive, but i've noticed that agressive people have 
different motivators, and people do things for their reasons, not ours, 
wouldn't you agree?  =]

> 
this is verry true.  this is true in all industries.  that's why i 
believe that $$ is a crude way to value items and services and will 
eventually (probably not in our lifetime, but definitely in the next 
couple of hundred years) not exist.  

but be careful, try to keep your mind open at all times, otherwise you 
might miss a perfectly legitamite environmental movement that is actually 
enacting change!  

not everyone does things to save the planet.  duh!  of course.  but if we 
can start using that to our advantage.  some people just like to have 
fun.  

well, that's enough from me...fog

What's wrong with a 14 year old going to a rave with an adult.  I'm not
talking 30 and over.  Just someone at least eighteen who agreed to stay
sober for the evening.  They have designated drivers.  Why can't we have
designated ravers.   I know how parents worry about where their rebellious
young kids are, and I think I would feel safer if someone older was at a
party where there was probably going to be drugs, anyway.  I like the idea
of "escort" service.  It would make parents feel a little more at ease and
hopefully more accepting of rave culture.  Although my solutions for my son

>Massives are not by definition evil.  They are huge productions that
>require a larger ticket price.  Why is a small $15 Harmony party just
>dandy, and a huge massive, just five dollars more, with dj's from all over
>the country/world, permitted space, lightshows, etc. suddenly the fount of
>all evil?  On that note, why does a $20 Martin party get the blessing of
>SFRavers, while a $20 Feel Good party get roasted (a nice word for it)? 


Actually, if I remember rightly, a LOT of flame wars have happened as a
result of Martin's parties alone, I was starting to wonder if they'd ever
shut up about it! :)  Massives in general almost always seemed to get flamed
overall.  I think that in this case, it's happening more so because it's (at
least from what I've seen) pretty rare that massive promoters actually come
onto sfraves and advertise as much as Feel Good has.  And another thing, a
point correctly raised by Black Adder, is that the offense is not
necessarily in simply having a $20 party (which does cause enough of an
outrage in & of itself), but rather that Vlad appears to be advertising a
party that is "for charity" but is not upfront at all about the details of
that intent.  I don't personally feel that a promoter is required to open
his books to us any more than any other capitalistic venture we frequent
(such as the stores we shop in, etc), but in situations where large amounts
of money will be collected "for charity", it seems more reasonable to want
to know where our money is going and how much is going there.  I would.  If
something is really being for charity, there should be no reason to hide the
details, imo.  And Vlad, this is not intended to be a flame towards you, but
I do think perhaps you could have handled the questions differently (as
could have the flamers, imo), it doesn't help your credibility (which you
appear to be working very hard for) to immediately clam up about things that
people will be sensitive about such as where & how much of their hard-earned
money is going.  If you really are as PLURy as you say, you need to look to
your real goal here  (sound of shawna giving Vlad the benefit of the doubt
cuz she doesnt know him).

Blah blah blah.

Ok, I'm done!

Love,
Shawna

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Feb  6 20:13:53 1997

Received: from [165.227.109.23] by scruz.net (8.7.3/1.34)
	id UAA06418; Thu, 6 Feb 1997 20:13:40 -0800 (PST)
X-Sender: anarch@mail.scruznet.com
Message-Id: <v01530501af2051357764@[165.227.109.23]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Thu, 6 Feb 1997 20:16:55 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: anarch@scruznet.com (Anarch)
Subject: Re: why i get knocked on at raves
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

blkadder@value.net wrote:
>On Thu, 6 Feb 1997, Anarch wrote:
>> certain costs are too high, you may want a stronger guarantee.  If you can
>> come up with some sort of statistical connection between an easy-to-measure
>> quality--say, age--and your hard-to-measure target-- "maturity" --then you
>> can get that stronger guarantee by testing people on the easy one.  And
>> yes, it will be unfair; you're bound to get false positives and negatives
>> both.  But maybe the tradeoff's acceptable.
>
>Really?
 ...
>Now, do you think it would be an "acceptable tradeoff" to say, limit the
>number of people of color in a store at a given time because statistically
>the store could show that people of color commit more crime?

When I said "maybe," I meant maybe.  As in "may be the case, for some
people, in some circumstances."  I wasn't just rhetorically suggesting
something that I believe in myself.  And did you miss the "matters of
judgement" paragraph?  Some people probably would think it wise to limit
blacks or gangstas or whatever in their store.  Well, that's them
exercising their judgement, but it doesn't have anything to do with me.
Same for people who decide they want to restrict ages for their parties.
I'm just describing a method of addressing a problem, which anyone is free
to apply or not in any situation, whatever they think best.  I don't say
it's right or wrong, or that you should or shouldn't--it's a matter of
judgement.

I brought it up because I wanted to make clear the details of what I think
is really going on when people say, "There are real risks to having younger
people at a party, so maybe we should set an age limit."  It didn't look
like discussion was headed in a productive direction; I thought suggesting
some kind of rational framework and exposing some details might help people
argue more usefully.

>We are criminalizing a whole group in our
>society based on their age alone. It is no more right than the above
>senario. The only difference is that young people have no rights in this
>society. What kind of message do you send to young people when you treat
>them like criminals until the age of 18? How do you expect them to act?

This is the kind of thing I meant by unproductive discussion.  They're
huge, categorical statements, strident and vague at the same time; it's
just too easy, especially in brief, casual discussions, for this sort of
argument to turn into yes-it-is/no-it-isn't, or just to go nowhere.

>Finally, I think that many people are making a big, possibly false
>assumption here: Anyone under 18 who comes to a party is going to do
>drugs, and therefore should not be at the party.

Now this is a bit more like it.  This is the sort of detail I was hoping to
call attention to by looking at the way people rationalize restrictions by
age.  It's a smaller claim, so easier to assess in itself, and you can also
look at the role it would play in the kind of argument I outlined, how it
does or doesn't support the conclusion, fits with other elements, and so
on.

anarch@scruznet.com

it so (or the take-off of it on a Simpson's Halloween Special  [Bart turns 
homer into a jack-in-the-box  and makes Snowball breathe fire]).  Thus, THIS IS 
YOUR ONLY WARNING.  THINK ONLY HAPPY THOUGHTS ON SUNDAY  OR YOU WILL BE TURNED 
INTO A JACK IN THE BOX.


This is not a joke. 






just try to dance, Jerky,  when you can't even get out of your box 'cause no 
will wind you up all the way so you never reach the end of your doo-doo   
doo-doo   doo-doo-dee-doo-doo  song that indicates its now time to spring 
out.   Yah, think about it.

This has been an interesting thread...

I have to admit I feel most comfortable at parties where all age groups
are represented.  That includes teens, 20s, 30s, and beyond!

I won't tell you my age, but let's just say I ain't no teenager. *smile*

In fact, it's been so many years since I haven't been a teenager that I'm
starting to get damned maudlin about the youth.  I sure do miss the
energy, the freshness, the dreamy innocense, and even the angst I used to
feel when I was that certain age.  

As an ocassional thrower of parties, I do get a little nervous when I see
folks under the age of 18 doing dangerous stuff.  Because I can't help it-
I feel responsible for them because they're young and I want to protect
them from doing stupid things that they'll regret later.

Even so, I love it when young people come to parties because it makes me
feel young, too. Ever see an older cat play with a kitten?  It's the
cutest thing...the older cat acts all annoyed at first, and then starts
getting into it, and eventually acts like a kitten itself.

Respect,

Ann

Once, as Tiffy, Robby, Tyndall, Dano, Matt, Brian, Lotus, Kim and I sat in
GG park...visiting the spirit of the mushroom... 

I thought (out loud) "next time, i'll be born as a bird, so i can just...


fly away..."

And as I flew away in time from that magical day...

The birds were all i could see.  

One paper square, one large tylenol (code word then was 'cookies'), wet, 
squishy, long bladed grass, the impending blistering sacramento sun, 
booming black speakers oozing Markie Mark's fat vibes; they were all it 
took to make me see those birds.  

I could see their feathers.  

There were five.  

And then their energy amplified and I saw a bright light...

I was crouching down, talking to Martin and Julian.  but it wasn't me 
talking, it was the birds.  All of a sudden I felt like ALL of the 
answers were in my brain, I just didn't have a mouth big enough to tell 
everyone.  

It was a gift from the birds.  

And as the light diminished, one of the birds looked at me from afar and 
said, "go.  throw rocks in the American River."  

And as the first rock hit, and as I put sunscreen on my body to protect 
it from the now blistering 100 degree + Sacramento heat, I thought...

I touched God.  

but when Capt. Sisko visited the wormhole people, 

there were no birds.  

only images.  

images of people saying...

"they are linear.  it

				limits 	
			them."

==============
Golden Gate Park
on a random mushroom trip
May 1994

Wicked Full Moon Rave
June 1994
Sacramento, CA

Star Trek:  Deep Space Nine
?

People tweak out at raves all the time, and while it's not a _good_
thing, we tend to do what we can and take it in stride.  How come
everyone's getting all worked up about it because of where a person's
birthday happened to fall?

There are plenty of irresponsible old people, and plenty of together
young people.  To draw a line in the sand is ridiculous and exposes all
our talk about peace, love, and unity as a flat lie, to be discarded
when  in conflict with our prejudices.

The problem with this woman was most likely ignorance; ignorance of the
chemical she was putting into her body.  The solution to ignorance is
education, not prohibition.

Alcohol is as much of a drug as pot or acid, in that you can fuck
yourself up on it just as much.  You can even kill yourself if you
want.  Most European countries have NO DRINKING AGE, and much less of an
alcohol problem than the US.  Why?  It doesn't have the allure of
illegality, and as a legal substance its problems can be addressed
directly and straightforwardly.  

What do we get?  "Just Say No."  So kids find out that you won't
immediately die from one toke (contrary to the propaganda) and decide
that _all_ the warnings must be bullshit, since obviously you can't
trust adults to give you the truth.

> And I'm not talking about keeping kids out
> for our sake. It's for their sake.

Listen to yourself.  This sort of sanctimonious bullshit is exactly why
your kids will come to hate you.  The solution to ignorance is
education, not prohibition.

Gods protect me from all the people ready to prevent me from doing
something "for my sake".  This is another No-Cost Moral Judgment (tm),
which I just got finished ranting about.

> You're right massives are (arguably) bad, having to turn away people
> from parties is bad, lots of things in the scence are bad but NOTHING
> compares to having a kid get so fucked up she has to be put under
> restraint. Short of death maybe.

And turning away young people will cause less deaths how?  Of the (very
few) deaths in the scene, how many were underage?

I like the idea of ensuring a maximum number of responsible people at
any gathering, whether through free admission or otherwise.  As a 100%
drug-free raver, which includes the legal drugs of caffeine and alcohol,
I know I will be able to deal with whatever panic situation might
happen.  

The key is "How can we take responsibility for our actions?"  This
problem is not solved by excluding arbitrary age ranges.

PS: I am well over 21 and have no personal stake in this matter.

// grigsbeast

The Grigsbeast writes...
> 
> People tweak out at raves all the time, and while it's not a _good_
> thing, we tend to do what we can and take it in stride.  How come
> everyone's getting all worked up about it because of where a person's
> birthday happened to fall?

It's a little confusing because it's being left unsaid, but the reason
age limits are being discussed is because people fear that, due to the
increased media attention, the authorities are going to start *really*
cracking down on raves.  It's all being driven by parents' fears.

It only has to get a little bit worse before laws get passed and promoters
start going to jail.  At that point the "scene" is going to be only
1) 21+ clubs and 2) totally underground, word of mouth small gatherings.
People just won't risk throwing parties when they can get taken to jail,
sued, fined, sound systems confiscated, etc.

So I think what we're seeing is a little proactive thinking to get
things under control before "raves" are outlawed entirely.

	aren't it is nobody's fault but their own. When a minor does the
	same thing our legal system & *some* ethical systems hold the
	adults around them responsible.

What If you got someone who is young, but can still be a good vibe and is
going sober and loves to dance and then you wont let them in. 
I have only done E twice and a half in my life. I have been raving since
May 24th of 96.
I may be very young, and i still dont know even 1/5 of everything there
is to know about raves yet. I celebrated my 16th B day at Cloud Factory
that was the second time I ever did E. I liked it a lot of course, but
that's not why I rave.
I know that a lot of people, well maybe some on this list know me and
know that I am a cool person. I am not a bad vibe. I understand enough of
the scene to be a good vibe.
People at undergrounds can not believe hoe young I am. They always think
I am much older.
Its not the age. Its the person.

I understand where everyone is coming from, for checking IDs at raves.
It wont make a difference at all. Our maturity and understandign of the
scene isn't on our ID and if anything thats what to check.
Even still how would you check a newbie if they knew nothing.

I beleve from what i know is that raves should have no age limits.

Date: Fri, 7 Feb 1997 00:22:50 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: anarch@scruznet.com (Anarch)
Subject: Re: why i get knocked on at raves
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

blkadder@value.net wrote:
>On Thu, 6 Feb 1997, Anarch wrote:
>
>> Same for people who decide they want to restrict ages for their parties.
>> I'm just describing a method of addressing a problem, which anyone is free
>> to apply or not in any situation, whatever they think best.  I don't say
>> it's right or wrong, or that you should or shouldn't--it's a matter of
>> judgement.
>
>And all I am doing is pointing out the error and unacceptability to me of
>judging people in this fashion. It is outrageous to do so with a
>group of people based on their race, but it is acceptable to do so based
>on peoples age. A very serious contradiction.

OK, but don't lay it on me.  I'm not saying that people should think this
way, just that they *do*, and so if you want to debate these things, it's
better to address points in that line of reasoning rather than falling into
some kind of "Kids under X can't handle raves," "Yes they can," "No they
can't," "Kids over X don't need their parents' responsibility," "Yes they
do," "It's unfair," "No it isn't" so-called argument.  (By, for example,
drawing analogies...that's perfectly sensible).

>> >We are criminalizing a whole group in our
>> >society based on their age alone. It is no more right than the above
>> >senario. The only difference is that young people have no rights in this
>> >society. What kind of message do you send to young people when you treat
>> >them like criminals until the age of 18? How do you expect them to act?
>>
>> This is the kind of thing I meant by unproductive discussion.  They're
>> huge, categorical statements, strident and vague at the same time; it's
>> just too easy, especially in brief, casual discussions, for this sort of
>> argument to turn into yes-it-is/no-it-isn't, or just to go nowhere.
>
>How is it at all unproductive? I offered a specific example, limits on
>the number of people that can be in a store based on their age.

I thought the example was restricting people of color.  But that doesn't
matter--I wasn't trying to criticize your example.  I took that bit out of
context, deliberately, just to illustrate a contrast between those sorts of
statements and your final comment.  Something like "we are criminalizing a
whole group based on their age" is a fine claim, great as a conclusion or
summation, but an entire argument drawn with such broad strokes--again,
especially in a brief, informal setting like this one--is, I think,
unlikely to deepen understanding.

Again, I don't mean to criticize your analogies or to contest any claim
about criminalizing youth, or the effects of doing so.  I'm just talking
about types of argument, and what I think would be useful for people who
want to think about the question of age limits for parties.

anarch@scruznet.com

and its not new years eve 	(to name a few)

people should go atleast to support Jonathan (fellow sfraver) whos 
spinning, one of his first BIG partees!

peas, 
LiQuiD

'''===---____
	     i think nancy really has a great point, there is a lot of way

On Thu, 6 Feb 1997, Nancy Shaw wrote:

> 
> 
> You know, the viciousness of SFRavers is wrecking my PLUR much more than 
> any massives happening this weekend...
> 
> Values mean nothing if preached but not followed.  And to skewer some 
> promoter or other for not showing "enough" respect/love/etc. is almost 
> laughably hypocritical.
> 
> Massives are not by definition evil.  They are huge productions that
> require a larger ticket price.  Why is a small $15 Harmony party just
> dandy, and a huge massive, just five dollars more, with dj's from all over
> the country/world, permitted space, lightshows, etc. suddenly the fount of
> all evil?  On that note, why does a $20 Martin party get the blessing of
> SFRavers, while a $20 Feel Good party get roasted (a nice word for it)? 
> 
> I am not a fan of commercialism, the general attitude at commercial 
> parties, or the prospect of turing "rave" into a profitable commodity.
> But if our intent is to create a positive and loving community, we need 
> to start living by the values we are demanding others to follow (and, 
> seemingly,  being arbitrary about who gets labeled pure and who is a rave 
> outlaw!)
> 
> Massives _are_ commercial ventures, and this is enough to brand them bad 
> - or at least suspect - in many people's eyes (including mine!).  But 
> massives ARE how most people are exposed to our scene.  By highlighting 
> PLUR and benefiting good causes, massives are in fact EXPOSING people to 
> these ideals.  We can grumble about their "exploiting" these ideals to 
> entrap idealistic - and, I guess, stupid - SFRavers into shelling out 
> $20, but if a massive doesn't meet our elitist definition of what's 
> _really_ peace and love, don't we have the mental capacity to evaluate 
> that for OURSELVES?  Ever hear the term, vote with your pocketbook??  
> 
> Meanwhile, newbies go to a Feel Good and hear these virtues included on
> the flier as an integral part of the party, something they are told to be
> aware of before even coming to the event.  Do they have the cynical eyes
> we do?  Or are they then opened in a way?  And for us old cynics who laugh
> at the idea of PLUR at (certain) $20 parties, there still is a damn good
> dance event for our money. 
> 
> I personally cringe when I see Vlad post, because I know he will be the 
> recipient of an unbelievable torrent of verbal abuse from peaceful, 
> respectful underground ravers.  What is his crime, exactly?  Daring to 
> mention the virtues peace, love, unity, respect while charging money?  Then 
> why aren't other promoters held to that same standard?
> 
> We have promoters who are charged with attempting to have someone stabbed 
> to death.  We have promoters who had a person beat to a pulp in 
> front of hundreds of people in line for a "party".  Where is the outrage 
> over these _real_ outrages??!  Is Feel Good Entertainment some sort of 
> sacrificial lamb, some syphon into which we can sublimate all the rave 
> scene's problems?  A convenient scapegoat, because the promoter dares to 
> post on SFRaves.
> 
> A $20 party isn't the problem.  Making our touted values real is what 
> _really_ needs our attention.
> 
> Because I love the scene,
> and all of you,
> Nancy
> 
>

Santa Cruz, or I might do a lil smokin parapanellia shopping in Berkley.

w/a 40 and a blunt (Yea, right).

> blkadder@value.net wrote:
> >And all I am doing is pointing out the error and unacceptability to me of
> >judging people in this fashion. It is outrageous to do so with a
> >group of people based on their race, but it is acceptable to do so based
> >on peoples age. A very serious contradiction.

No, it's not.  To judge someone by their race is to assume that there
are differences in their character that can be based solely on the color
of their skin, certainly a fallacious assumption.  But to judge someone
based on their age is to assume, regardless of their skin color, social
class, belief system, etc., that greater age TENDS to bring greater
maturity.  Therefore one must assume that a 25 year old will QUITE
LIKELY have more maturity than a 15 year old.  This is a perfectly valid
GENERAL assumption.

Much luv, BA.  I agree with you 9 times out of 10, but not on this
particular issue.

S

On Fri, 7 Feb 1997, SDream wrote:

> > blkadder@value.net wrote:
> > >And all I am doing is pointing out the error and unacceptability to me of
> > >judging people in this fashion. It is outrageous to do so with a
> > >group of people based on their race, but it is acceptable to do so based
> > >on peoples age. A very serious contradiction.
> 
> No, it's not.  To judge someone by their race is to assume that there
> are differences in their character that can be based solely on the color
> of their skin, certainly a fallacious assumption.  

Yes it is, however it can be backed up by statistics. 

> But to judge someone based on their age is to assume, regardless of
> their skin color, social class, belief system, etc., that greater age
> TENDS to bring greater maturity.  Therefore one must assume that a 25
> year old will QUITE LIKELY have more maturity than a 15 year old.  This
> is a perfectly valid GENERAL assumption.

You are substituting one group for another. I could just as easily say 
"but to judge someone based on their race is to assume, regardless of
their age, social class, belief system, etc. that white people TEND to
commit less crime, given prison statistics. Therefore one must assume that
person of color will QUITE LIKELY commit more crime than a white person.
This is a perfectly valid GENERAL assumption."

Now, a few things:

1) Lest anyone get ready to flame the hell out of me for using issues of
   race in this manner, I in no way condone the above statement as being
   valid or true.

2) I am not disagreeing with the *general* assumption that a 15 year old
   is less mature than a 25 year old, however I am disagreeing with
   the manner in which you draw this conclusion.

3) You make no mention of how it is acceptable to use lack of maturity
   should be used as an excuse to limit the number of "students" in a
   store, which is the example I was offering.


> Much luv, BA.  I agree with you 9 times out of 10, but not on this
> particular issue.

Well, wouldn't the world be a boring place if we all agreed on everything? :)

                                             Black Adder

> > You fell for that one Randy.  With this hail of inflammatory posts
> > upon us, you must have forgotten that Mr. Adder is in the habit
> > of trolling on this list.
> 
>  Oh it's okay. i gots me asbestos undies from KMart today. BA can do his 
> worse and it'll just make me feel cozy.  +)
> 
> 
> > Try not to take these disagreements personally.  Someone will jump in
> > and make you feel bad if you do, even on SFRaves :(
> 
>  Actually I'm using BA for Temper Action Control Training (TACT). Since he 
> likes to be so nasty, it's real good practice to engage him. especially 
> since he backs down when he is losing ground.
> 

I am including the above to highlight my point, but please, Randy and BA,
I am not singling you guys out.  YOu two are *definitely* not the only
ones involved in this.

I'd just like to point out that the above is an example of a volley of
"I'm right and your wrong."  I just find it tedious and time-wasting.  No
one listens to this pettiness.  It is really ineffectual in getting your
point across.  When this happens it makes the attacker look bad, not the
attackee.  Unless both get going, which so frequently happens.

What is the reason for pointing out every *single* foible that someone
makes?  Let's grow up.  People can make themselves look pretty bad, no one
needs to point it out.  Trying to demean someone (in any way, shape, or
form), is very selfish because you are trying to make yourself bigger at
their expense.  This is just not such a great way to treat others, and in
the end you only hurt yourself.  It takes a bigger person to let things go
and not try and prove themselves rather than take the easy route and get
in an argument.

I'm not saying that *I'm* not guilty, either.  I am well intouch with my
own hypocrisy, as well as that of humankind.  I would just plead with
sfravers to think about what they are posting.  If you find that the
majority of your posts happen to be involved in arguments, maybe you
should think twice before doing this.  You are being selfish to the whole
list and monopolizing a COMMUNITY forum.  Don't get me wrong, I'm not
saying controversy should be avoided, or even negativity, because both
serve there purpose. But, pettiness in large quantities might
be something worthwhile to pass on.

Pick your battles.  There is a lot of energy that could be spent for much
better things.

And to paraphrase Samuel Clemmens, "No one knows of your ignorance until
you open up your mouth and tell them."

-KaySEE

p.s.  If someone feels personally attacked, DON'T.  There is such a thing
as constructive criticism.  I WILL NOT reply to anyone's defensiveness
because THAT is EXACTLY my point!

Precedence: bulk


"Drawing a line in the sand" as far as age limits go is not 
at all ridiculous.  Unless something is done, you're going to get your
inevitable share of young people at raves who are simply not mature enough
to handle the situation, just as you will also get young people who can
handle it.  But we live in a civilization, where all the rules always have
to be based on percentages--it's all math-based.  
I mean, what's the alternative, interviewing potential ravers to see if
they're mature enough to handle it?  Is that any less arbitrary,
ultimately?  
Limits aren't intended to exclude people, they simply want to make sure
the highest possible level of communal safety is maintained.

Okay, discuss--  :)

peace,
Timothy

Timothy McIntyre

On Thu, 6 Feb 1997, The Grigsbeast wrote:

> People tweak out at raves all the time, and while it's not a _good_
> thing, we tend to do what we can and take it in stride.  How come
> everyone's getting all worked up about it because of where a person's
> birthday happened to fall?
> 
> There are plenty of irresponsible old people, and plenty of together
> young people.  To draw a line in the sand is ridiculous and exposes all
> our talk about peace, love, and unity as a flat lie, to be discarded
> when  in conflict with our prejudices.
> 
> The problem with this woman was most likely ignorance; ignorance of the
> chemical she was putting into her body.  The solution to ignorance is
> education, not prohibition.
> 
> Alcohol is as much of a drug as pot or acid, in that you can fuck
> yourself up on it just as much.  You can even kill yourself if you
> want.  Most European countries have NO DRINKING AGE, and much less of an
> alcohol problem than the US.  Why?  It doesn't have the allure of
> illegality, and as a legal substance its problems can be addressed
> directly and straightforwardly.  
> 
> What do we get?  "Just Say No."  So kids find out that you won't
> immediately die from one toke (contrary to the propaganda) and decide
> that _all_ the warnings must be bullshit, since obviously you can't
> trust adults to give you the truth.
> 
> > And I'm not talking about keeping kids out
> > for our sake. It's for their sake.
> 
> Listen to yourself.  This sort of sanctimonious bullshit is exactly why
> your kids will come to hate you.  The solution to ignorance is
> education, not prohibition.
> 
> Gods protect me from all the people ready to prevent me from doing
> something "for my sake".  This is another No-Cost Moral Judgment (tm),
> which I just got finished ranting about.
> 
> > You're right massives are (arguably) bad, having to turn away people
> > from parties is bad, lots of things in the scence are bad but NOTHING
> > compares to having a kid get so fucked up she has to be put under
> > restraint. Short of death maybe.
> 
> And turning away young people will cause less deaths how?  Of the (very
> few) deaths in the scene, how many were underage?

> I like the idea of ensuring a maximum number of responsible people at

> I know I will be able to deal with whatever panic situation might
> happen.

> problem is not solved by excluding arbitrary age ranges.
> 
> PS: I am well over 21 and have no personal stake in this matter.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Feb  7 10:36:13 1997

The Grigsbeast wrote:

> People tweak out at raves all the time, and while it's not a _good_
> thing,

Thank you for agreeing on that at least.

> we tend to do what we can and take it in stride.

We don't do *all* that we can.  That's why there are problems.  
That's why parents are in an uproar.  That's what this is about.

> How come
> everyone's getting all worked up about it because of where a person's
> birthday happened to fall?

Because of the maturity that comes with a birthday that falls further
back.

> There are plenty of irresponsible old people, and plenty of together
> young people.

How young?  What percentage at what age?  Yes, it's a blanket 
rule, a generalization, but one which is valid, that older people
are GENERALLY more mature than younger people.

> To draw a line in the sand is ridiculous and exposes all
> our talk about peace, love, and unity as a flat lie, 

I see NO conflict between looking out for our young folks, as a
COMMUNITY, and the concepts of PLUR.  No conflict whatsoever.

> The problem with this woman was most likely ignorance; ignorance of the
> chemical she was putting into her body.  The solution to ignorance is
> education, not prohibition.

The solution is education AND limitations.

> Most European countries have NO DRINKING AGE, and much less of an
> alcohol problem than the US.  Why?  It doesn't have the allure of
> illegality, and as a legal substance its problems can be addressed
> directly and straightforwardly.

That is such a MYTH!  People, if you don't listen to anything else,
listen to this:  Kids don't get busted for it because it's legal,
and drinking is not frowned on like it is here, but that's about 
where it ends.  There is just as much alcoholism, just as many, if
not more, drunk-driving deaths, more problems with fetal-alcohol
syndrome, etc., etc., etc.  The attitudes in some other countries
towards alcohol are certainly different, but to say that 
legalizing a substance makes all the problems with that substance 
just vanish like a bad dream is LUDICROUS.

> What do we get?  "Just Say No."  So kids find out that you won't
> immediately die from one toke (contrary to the propaganda) 

Please show me propoganda that says you'll die from one toke.
And whatever substance they say that *can* kill you at one toke,
please show me the evidence that it's a lie.  

> since obviously you can't
> trust adults to give you the truth.

And you're well over 21, so why the hell did I bother to 
respond to all this since you OBVIOUSLY can't be trusted?
Kids!  Warning!  Don't trust this guy!  He's OVER 21!!!

> Listen to yourself.  This sort of sanctimonious bullshit is exactly why
> your kids will come to hate you.

If my kids come to hate me for taking care of them and looking
out for their best interests, so be it, but I highly doubt that's
what will happen.  On the other hand, if you're saying that you
hate your parents because of some perceived slight or your idea
of a bad childhood based on the limitations they put upon you,
then that is *your* problem to work through.

> Gods protect me from all the people ready to prevent me from doing
> something "for my sake".  This is another No-Cost Moral Judgment (tm),
> which I just got finished ranting about.

And it was a rant, alright.  God protect that child with a 
parent that doesn't do things for the child's sake.  You're
beloved and "trademarked" "No-Cost Moral Judgement" describes
EVERYTHING a parent does for a child.

> I like the idea of ensuring a maximum number of responsible people at
> any gathering, whether through free admission or otherwise.

Otherwise=ID checking?  That's all I'm proposing - maximizing
the number of responsible people at a rave.

> As a 100%
> drug-free raver, which includes the legal drugs of caffeine and alcohol,
> I know I will be able to deal with whatever panic situation might
> happen.

Imagine that -- I suppose you once partook of many things, but
intervening years have seen you come to the conclusion that
you don't need the substances to have a good time, right?
If you had to give a name to your experience, what would it be?
Not that horrible word, Maturity?

> The key is "How can we take responsibility for our actions?"  This
> problem is not solved by excluding arbitrary age ranges.

You're absolutely right.  Excluding arbitrary age ranges is not 
the key to "How can we take responsibility for our actions?"  It
IS the key, along with decent parenting, to "How can we take care 
of the younger folx in our community and insure that they reach 
an age, safely, where they can make their OWN decisions, regarding 
medicating themselves with potentially dangerous substances, in a 
mature fashion?"

S

>Or they'll provide a staff to look out for everyone, but do you 
>have any idea how tough it would be to have a raver staff that had to 
>stay *sober* the entire night and hold some little kid's hand as they 
>puked their way through an evening gone bad? 
 
I dunno, I've done it many a night.  And afterward, I have always hoped (and 
often found) that the person  
1) will take a more responsible attitude towards whatever substance was used, 
and 2) will understand that people at these events do truly care, and that 
they should feel safe returning to the scene once the ordeal is over. 
 
I can see your point quite clearly, but any form of discrimination strikes me 
as wrong. Imagine if I was a bank, and gave different interest rates based on 
age, sex, race, religion...  Things like this irk me.   
 
We're trying to restrict access to what is illegal in our scene.  Now, as far 
as society *as a whole* is concerned, we, as adults, are no more responsible 
than those kids in regard to the illegal drugs.  You're not mature enought to 
handle these things, and neither am I.  Nobody on this list is mature enough 
to deal with drugs.  If we're ID-ing because we are restricting access to a 
substance that legally has an age limit, then fine.  Can somebody answer these 
questions for me?  At what age is it legal to take E?  At what age is it legal 
to take LSD?  When we have an age limit for the drugs that are "causing the 
problems for these youngsters", then I will support ID-ing at a rave. 
 
Regards, 
 
Lucas Ritting

LRITTING.US.ORACLE.COM wrote:

> I was more trying to point out that no matter how these laws are
> set up, they are still entirely arbitrary.

I'll give you that.  There's no magic number to go by, no moment of
epiphany when someone is suddenly "all grown up", but you got to start
somewhere.

> For instance, most of the people
> from outside of the US feel that our age restriction on drinking causes more
> alcoholism and substance abuse.

There's greater number that feel it does reduce substance abuse (not
alcoholism - those would be dependent/addictive personalities that would
become hooked regardless), but that they grossful elevate
substance-related crime.  When I've been in Europe I've discussed this
stuff at length with a variety of people.

> No matter what laws or restrictions we set,
> there will be disparities on either side.

Agreed.

> So who among this community can
> rightfully attempt to put such an age restriction to the entire group?  

No one person.  But promoters that decide to be responsible will limit
the ages of the attendees, the point being to discourage kids from
going.  Or they'll provide a staff to look out for everyone, but do you
have any idea how tough it would be to have a raver staff that had to
stay *sober* the entire night and hold some little kid's hand as they
puked their way through an evening gone bad?

> Are we going to kick the kids off of the SFRaves list?

Of course not -- no way to do it anyway -- but we can use the list to
promote education and attitudes towards responsible raving.

Another $.02...

S

time i check my mail there are either flame wars or just a bunch of
bickering going on in this list.  So...i just have to start cutting
things out, which i don't wanna do because a lot of u have good points
and information.  But it just gets to be too much with all the
bickering...so i cut it all out.

Why can't we seem to talk about or go on about positive things on
here??  I know life isn't all positive and sometimes there are more than
1 side to an opinion, but GEEZ, i get enough of that in life.  I really
don't need it on here ALL the time.  TO debate is okay with me, but all
this bickering..finger pointing or whatever....just gets old.

I rarely post and i think part of that is due to the fact that the list
has gotten so hostile.  When i joined this list, 1.5 years ago, i posted
much more because i felt a certain sense of community amongst the list
and its subscribers-(either that or i was just really naive and
stoopid), either way, the list was much more fun back then.  I've seen
some really lovely people either un-sub or just vanish from the list
because of the negativity on here.  I want u guys BACK.

I have met a few of u on the list in person and seem to like most, if
not all, of u.  (well...with the exception of 1 or 2 ;) :) :P

My point is this: let's try to make this a more fun and enjoyable list
and leave all the BS to the outside world, where there's plenty of it.

To: LRITTING@us.oracle.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Fwd: Age Limit at Parties ( was: "Re: odyssey (rape)")
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> If we're ID-ing because we are restricting access to a 
> substance that legally has an age limit, then fine.  Can somebody answer these> questions for me?  At what age is it legal to take E? 

	It's not legal to "possess" E at any age - but if you're an adult
and you are caught in possesion of E, the other adults around you can't be
held responsible for *your* actionns. If you are a minor and you are caught
in possesion of E, the adults around you can be held responsible. It's
called contributing to the deliquency of a minor. If you're an adult in
the scene and you don't think you have a personal stake in this, you're wrong.
