Date: Fri, 7 Feb 1997 11:49:37 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <199702071949.LAA22916@atari.saturn5.com>
From: Steve Simitzis <steve@saturn5.com>
To: SFRaves@hyperreal.com
In-reply-to: <32FAD5A8.201C@earthlink.net> (seestone@earthlink.net)
Subject: Re: 420 (NRR)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> Date: Thu, 06 Feb 1997 23:11:39 -0800
> From: "C. Stone" <seestone@earthlink.net>

> The origin of 420 ~
> 
> I thought it was in reference to the number of active components in
> buds, no?

A favor:

Even though drugs have a big influence on the rave scene, can you
please please please mark posts that are strictly about drugs as NRR
in the subject? Note that NRR = Not Rave Related. Putting NRR is the
subject line allows people (like me) who use filters not to have to read
about things that aren't interesting (ie. not relevant to raving).

Reading post after post comparing LSD and Ketamine and Ecstasy, various
interpretations about the origin of 420, what Ecstasy is being laced with
nowadays, and so on....

It's just too much. This is not a drug list... although, I assure you,
you should be able to find one with little difficulty. But since I
understand that the nature of SFRaves involves a large amount of
off-topic posting, remember:

Please, just use the NRR tag in the subject line. It's there for a
reason. :)

Put yourself in my shoes. I receive over 300 pieces of email everyday;
that's after filtering the hell out of it. :( Please be nice to those
of us with overflowing mailboxes. (I would say something about PLUR,
but I won't... >:)

Finally, I find it interesting to note that during the whole 20/20
hysteria, the SFRaves community passionately proclaimed how "Raving is
not all about drugs! How *dare* they insinuate that. Let's FAX bomb
then with protests." However, at the same time, the other thread on
SFRaves that was running concurrently was all about drugs... That
makes a very interesting statement about our community.

Steve

At 9:52 AM -0800 2/7/97, blkadder@value.net wrote:
>On Fri, 7 Feb 1997, SDream wrote:
>
>> > blkadder@value.net wrote:
>> > >And all I am doing is pointing out the error and unacceptability to me of
>> > >judging people in this fashion. It is outrageous to do so with a
>> > >group of people based on their race, but it is acceptable to do so based
>> > >on peoples age. A very serious contradiction.
>>
>> No, it's not.  To judge someone by their race is to assume that there
>> are differences in their character that can be based solely on the color
>> of their skin, certainly a fallacious assumption.
>
>Yes it is, however it can be backed up by statistics.

ANYTHING can be backep up by statistics.  Stupidity and ignorance are no
exception.

>
>> But to judge someone based on their age is to assume, regardless of
>> their skin color, social class, belief system, etc., that greater age
>> TENDS to bring greater maturity.  Therefore one must assume that a 25
>> year old will QUITE LIKELY have more maturity than a 15 year old.  This
>> is a perfectly valid GENERAL assumption.
>
>You are substituting one group for another. I could just as easily say
>"but to judge someone based on their race is to assume, regardless of
>their age, social class, belief system, etc. that white people TEND to
>commit less crime, given prison statistics. Therefore one must assume that
>person of color will QUITE LIKELY commit more crime than a white person.
>This is a perfectly valid GENERAL assumption."
>

No it is not. What kinds of crime are you talking about?  Violent crime?
White-collar crime?  The punishments are different for each, thus looking
solely at the prison population is no clear indication of anything other
than who gets locked up the most, not necessarily who has/will committ more
crime.  Jump in logic there Adder.  And by far it is African-Americans &
people of color.

>Now, a few things:
>
>1) Lest anyone get ready to flame the hell out of me for using issues of
>   race in this manner, I in no way condone the above statement as being
>   valid or true.
>
>2) I am not disagreeing with the *general* assumption that a 15 year old
>   is less mature than a 25 year old, however I am disagreeing with
>   the manner in which you draw this conclusion.
>
>3) You make no mention of how it is acceptable to use lack of maturity
>   should be used as an excuse to limit the number of "students" in a
>   store, which is the example I was offering.
>
>
>> Much luv, BA.  I agree with you 9 times out of 10, but not on this
>> particular issue.
>
>Well, wouldn't the world be a boring place if we all agreed on everything? :)
>
>                                             Black Adder


Indeed.

John

> 
> A favor:
> 
> Even though drugs have a big influence on the rave scene, can you
> please please please mark posts that are strictly about drugs as NRR
> in the subject? Note that NRR = Not Rave Related. Putting NRR is the
> subject line allows people (like me) who use filters not to have to read
> about things that aren't interesting (ie. not relevant to raving).

Unfortunatly, we are faced with a volume problem on SFR... namely, it
it is too high.  We can try to create systems that allow people to
sort their mail better, but there is only so much we can do.

I think educating people about drugs is a very important fuction of
SFR, espcially when the gov's just say no mentality has effectively
muted any real drug education.

Personally, I think the NRR tag should be reserved for chain letters,
funny jokes, and "I'm just writing to say how much I love you all"
messages.

Anything even remotely rave related should not have the NRR tag on it.

I suggest if you want to filter out drug info, you should add the
names of various drugs and their slang to your procmail file.
 
If you look at the archives of SFR, you will see there has been active
discussion about recreational drugs from the very beginning.

But, I fully understand your frustration about the volume on sfr.

-troy

Kewl--everybody is Kung Fu fighting  :)

Just my 2 cents re age/maturity re 15 y/o vs 25 y/o etc.

The 25 y/o may legally get drunk out of their mind, add to 
that a smattering of drugs--and they aren't more responsible 
than a sober 15 y/o

The view of most teenagers learning world history and 
current events is that the adults running the world and 
their lives are the irresponsible ones, petty, unable to see 
past their differences, and on power trips re their age and 
control over minors and politics

The psychological dysfunctions and illnesses induced in 
childhood (mostly from defective parents) often come to 
fruition in "maturity" and there are as many or more fucked 
up adults in this world as there are teenagers.

Actually the opposite might be true--people lose their 
sensitivity and awareness with age, drink, drugs, 
relationships, etc.

Why do adults take drugs but to re-experience the energy and 
lack of inhibitions of childhood;  or conversely--what use 
would a kid have for "mature people's drugs"--they are 
already high!

Respect for our youth--they don't fuck with the world 
anywhere as badly as adults mess it up!

DJ ASB

(Just when you though it was safe to read your email)

"John S. Lee" <jslee@apple.com> wrote:
>At 9:52 AM -0800 2/7/97, blkadder@value.net wrote:
>>On Fri, 7 Feb 1997, SDream wrote:
>>> But to judge someone based on their age is to assume, regardless of
>>> their skin color, social class, belief system, etc., that greater age
>>> TENDS to bring greater maturity.  Therefore one must assume that a 25
>>> year old will QUITE LIKELY have more maturity than a 15 year old.  This
>>> is a perfectly valid GENERAL assumption.
>>
>>You are substituting one group for another. I could just as easily say
>>"but to judge someone based on their race is to assume, regardless of
>>their age, social class, belief system, etc. that white people TEND to
>>commit less crime, given prison statistics. Therefore one must assume that
>>person of color will QUITE LIKELY commit more crime than a white person.
>>This is a perfectly valid GENERAL assumption."
>>
>
>No it is not. What kinds of crime are you talking about?  Violent crime?
>White-collar crime?  The punishments are different for each, thus looking
>solely at the prison population is no clear indication of anything other
>than who gets locked up the most, not necessarily who has/will committ more
>crime.  Jump in logic there Adder.  And by far it is African-Americans &
>people of color.

And you can turn *this* back around and ask similar questions about the
original case of maturity and age, which I think was Adder's point:  What
kinds of maturity are you talking about?  Education?  Depth of personal
sensitivity?  Growth proceeds differently for each...

Details!  Like I've been saying.  What do we mean by maturity?  Why do we
find it correlated with age?  How strong is the correlation?  How is it
substantiated?  That's the way to get somewhere with this argument.

anarch@scruznet.com

 One thing I wanted to mention here in support of Steve's perspective 
while showing another;

 I just learned about a week ago that students who have email tend to 
have something (sysop? help me someone) that filters out a lot of junk 
mail and spammed mail. We students don't "see" what folks in the "real" 
world have to deal with daily (thank you).

 In my haste to post sometimes I forget to add NRR to such posts that 
deserve it. I would like to thank Steve for reminding us all. Courtesy is 
catching (except to those in isolation suits).

From:=09Linda S. Masterson [SMTP:102526.2422@CompuServe.COM]

Subject:=09Let's Get Humorous!!!

QUOTES ON THE NATURE OF THE UNIVERSE
Carl Zwanzig: "Duct tape is like the Force. It has a light side, a=20
dark side, and it holds the universe together...."
Douglas Adams: "There is a theory which states that if ever anybody=20
discovers exactly what the Universe is for and why it is here, it will=20
instantly disappear and be replaced by something even more bizarre and=20
inexplicable. There is another theory which states that this has=20
already happened."
Albert Einstein: "Only two things are infinite, the universe and human=20
stupidity, and I'm not sure about the former."
Unknown: "Astronomers say the universe is finite, which is a=20
comforting thought for those people who can't remember where they=20
leave things."
Edward P. Tryon: "In answer to the question of why it happened, I=20
offer the modest proposal that our Universe is simply one of those=20
things which happen from time to time."
John Andrew Holmes: "It is well to remember that the entire universe,=20
with one trifling exception, is composed of others."
Max Frisch: "Technology is a way of organizing the universe so that=20
man doesn't have to experience it."
Kilgore Trout: "The universe is a big place, perhaps the biggest."
Woody Allen: "I'm astounded by people who want to 'know' the universe=20
when it's hard enough to find your way around Chinatown."
Douglas Adams: "In the beginning the Universe was created. This has=20
made a lot of people very angry and been widely regarded as a bad=20
move."
William J. Broad: "The crux... is that the vast majority of the mass=20
of the universe seems to be missing."
Rich Cook: "Programming today is a race between software engineers=20
striving to build bigger and better idiot-proof programs, and the=20
Universe trying to produce bigger and better idiots. So far, the=20
Universe is winning."
Fred Hoyle: "There is a coherent plan in the universe, though I don't=20
know what it's a plan for."
Ray Bradbury: "We are an impossibility in an impossible universe."
Christopher Morley: "My theology, briefly, is that the universe was=20
dictated but not signed."
Edward Chilton: "I'm worried that the universe will soon need=20
replacing. It's not holding a charge."
Calvin and Hobbes (Bill Watterson): "The surest sign that intelligent=20
life exists elsewhere in the universe is that it has never tried to =3D=20
contact us."

On Fri, 7 Feb 1997 10:23:34 -0800 (PST) Timothy McIntyre
<sidewalk@uclink2.berkeley.edu> writes:
>
>"Drawing a line in the sand" as far as age limits go is not 
>at all ridiculous.  Unless something is done, you're going to get your
>inevitable share of young people at raves who are simply not mature 
>enough
>to handle the situation, just as you will also get young people who 
>can
>handle it.  But we live in a civilization, where all the rules always 
>have
>to be based on percentages--it's all math-based.  
>I mean, what's the alternative, interviewing potential ravers to see 
>if
>they're mature enough to handle it?  Is that any less arbitrary,
>ultimately?  
>Limits aren't intended to exclude people, they simply want to make 
>sure
>the highest possible level of communal safety is maintained.
>
>Okay, discuss--  :)
>
>peace,
>Timothy

>On Thu, 6 Feb 1997, The Grigsbeast wrote:
>
>> People tweak out at raves all the time, and while it's not a _good_
>> thing, we tend to do what we can and take it in stride.  How come
>> everyone's getting all worked up about it because of where a 
>person's
>> birthday happened to fall?
>> 
>> There are plenty of irresponsible old people, and plenty of together
>> young people.  To draw a line in the sand is ridiculous and exposes 
>all
>> our talk about peace, love, and unity as a flat lie, to be discarded
>> when  in conflict with our prejudices.
>> 
>> The problem with this woman was most likely ignorance; ignorance of 
>the
>> chemical she was putting into her body.  The solution to ignorance 
>is
>> education, not prohibition.
>> 
>> Alcohol is as much of a drug as pot or acid, in that you can fuck
>> yourself up on it just as much.  You can even kill yourself if you
>> want.  Most European countries have NO DRINKING AGE, and much less 
>of an
>> alcohol problem than the US.  Why?  It doesn't have the allure of
>> illegality, and as a legal substance its problems can be addressed
>> directly and straightforwardly.  
>> 
>> What do we get?  "Just Say No."  So kids find out that you won't
>> immediately die from one toke (contrary to the propaganda) and 
>decide
>> that _all_ the warnings must be bullshit, since obviously you can't
>> trust adults to give you the truth.
>> 
>> > And I'm not talking about keeping kids out
>> > for our sake. It's for their sake.
>> 
>> Listen to yourself.  This sort of sanctimonious bullshit is exactly 
>why
>> your kids will come to hate you.  The solution to ignorance is
>> education, not prohibition.
>> 
>> Gods protect me from all the people ready to prevent me from doing
>> something "for my sake".  This is another No-Cost Moral Judgment 
>(tm),
>> which I just got finished ranting about.
>> 
>> > You're right massives are (arguably) bad, having to turn away 
>people
>> > from parties is bad, lots of things in the scence are bad but 
>NOTHING
>> > compares to having a kid get so fucked up she has to be put under
>> > restraint. Short of death maybe.
>> 
>> And turning away young people will cause less deaths how?  Of the 
>(very
>> few) deaths in the scene, how many were underage?
>> 
>> I like the idea of ensuring a maximum number of responsible people 
>at
>> any gathering, whether through free admission or otherwise.  As a 
>100%
>> drug-free raver, which includes the legal drugs of caffeine and 
>alcohol,
>> I know I will be able to deal with whatever panic situation might
>> happen.  
>> 
>> The key is "How can we take responsibility for our actions?"  This
>> problem is not solved by excluding arbitrary age ranges.
>> 
>> PS: I am well over 21 and have no personal stake in this matter.

	I was out at the Evoulution party last night.  It had a pretty decent vibe for a party 
that was over crowded, hot, sticky, and extreamly hard to move around at because they stuffed 
about 2000+ people into a location that can only "cofortly" acomidate 1000 people.  I left at 
about 2:30 am, so I can not tell you much more than that, but it looked to me like everybody was 
having a pretty good time.  Lots of smiles, Good music, great banners.

	The question I have is this:  Would this party be considered an 'UG' or a 'Massive'?

	And as long as I am asking, could someone explain to me where the origin of the term 
'massive' came from in defining large parties.  Is it a derivation of 'The Tribal Massive 
Gathering' from Europe??  Because if it is then it is being applied incorectly.   And what is it 
that seperates a massive from an UG party??  Is it the price, the lineup, the comfort/discomfort 
level, the location, the level of organization, or what??	Were these term coined here on 
SFRaves, because that is realy the only place I see them being used??

	I know that these questions must sound silly, but I am just trying to get a little better 
understanding of what public perception on this issue is.  It seems so ambiguose.  

	I personaly liked it whan they were all called RAVES it was a lot less derogatory and much 
less desceptive.  Some were smaller raves, others were bigger raves.

	I am not a big fan of labeling things, I believe that it inedvertantly implies bias, 
descrimination and prejudice.  Maybee it is time for us to recapture our heritage and revert 
back to calling things what they realy are??

	Anyways, Just a thought.


Keep it Real

PLUR
Ray Vonie.
Bad spelling is my trademark.

> State of the Nation
>
>     Recently our Rave movement has been under a fiercely competitive attack
> from all sides. The once loving family of united party people have
> apparently begun to faction off in small groups of promoters/dj's/and
> social scenes. We can't have this! The never ending search for money,
> success, and prestige can drive nearly anyone down to an all time low.
> Promoters skip town without paying for services rendered. Cliquish groups
> of people snub those around them. Innocent party people drive long
> distances and pay large amounts of money only to find an empty warehouse,
> or dj's that were on the flyer were never confirmed to begin with.
> Promoters give interviews to the press about our scene in order to turn a
> higher profit. All of these things and more are going on around us all the
> time. Obviously this kind of information is a sure fire bummer, but it's
> these kinds of problems that will eventually destroy our house nation
> forever! Many of us believe that this movement is a meaningful one, full of
> love and good people, NOT a money making business venture. We have the
> potential to come together from all walks of life (regardless of race,
> creed, religion, or sexuality) and unite in mind, body and spirit. It's up
> to us to make this happen, without our collective participation, love,
> trust and support we are nothing. Here are some suggestions from your
> friends:
>                                                                               > - Do question the cover charge you pay and
>   where the money goes.
> - Do question the intentions of a party bigger
>   than 500 people.
> - Do question your support of negative people,
>   dj's, and promoters.
> - Do question your association with people who
>   only seem to talk about money and/or drugs.
> - Do support a variety of dj's and parties.
> - Do know your promoters and who they are
>   involved with.
> - Do know if your promoters pay their dj's and
>   staff.
> - Do educate yourself and your friends about
>   the drugs you take and all the precautions
>   necessary to protect yourself from harm.
> - Do know your sources well.
> - Do remember to eat, sleep, and drink lots of
>   water.
> - Do take good care of yourself and your loved
>   ones.
> - Do make at least one new friend at every
>   party you go to.
> - Do love and remember.
> - Do forgive and forget.
> - Do remember that if someone tells you
>   something about someone else that isn't very
>   nice, that same person is probably saying
>   something that isn't very nice about you when
>   your not around.
> - Do question people who take sides and gossip.
> - Do smile often and go out of your way to
>   accept everyone around you.
> - Do share (your love, your thoughts, and your
>   drugs)
> - Do remember that you are the power of
>   example to everyone around you.
>
> We realize that these suggestions may not apply to all situations, however,
> it is our belief that information can only make us stronger and is yours to
> take or leave as you like.
>
> Please feel free to print and distribute this flyer.
>
> PLUR
> Curtis

Hi Everyone.... I dunno :P I decided that maybe I should go to a party at
aroudn 7:30pm or so.. so I got ready, got my friend into it and got in the
car and drove to SF... I wasn't really in the mood to go because I had to
work (and I am) wat 6am Sat.


Anyhow, I did not like the location very much :( there is something about
the Mission that I don't like... I dunno, it was a weird vibe. It felt
more like a club ravther than a rave it was weird, I did see people I knew
so I said hi and stuff... The Music was good, but it was too housey. I
dunno, I like House but something more upbeat (after all, I was hella
tired so I needed something to keep me going not make me fall asleep). I
dunno... it was way crowded and smokey and hot (I hate it when they
overcrowd small places)so I was very uncomfortable and
cluastrophobic..short of breath too. I was having a panic attack :( I
couldn't stay there one more second, I needed to go outside and breathe... 

so I left around midnight :( or actually almost 1am or so...
and I guess I still haven't had a chance to hear DjDan. I hear so much
about him...even though I haven't heard ;)

Oh and I almost forgot.. the Secutiry people where hella rude :(

So there goes a half-review of Evolution :) 
I'll see you alls laterz
love
Pab

From: The Laffin Happy Trip Farmer <shawna-@ix.netcom.com>
Subject: Re: Terminology
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>	The question I have is this:  Would this party be considered an 'UG' or a
'Massive'?


I didn't go to this party, but I've only seen DJ Dan (whom I like) at
massives, as in parties that have more than 1000 people or so.  Not that
1000 is the definitive number (now if it were only 999, it would be an UG!
;), but overall it seems like size-wise, UG parties tend to have people in
the 100's, massives in the 1000's.  I think there's often issues of legality
too.  Massives, as they often charge a lot more, from what I've seen tend to
have purchased/acquired all the necessary things to make their parties
legal, insurance & all that crap.  UG's tend to be more renegade, just some
people trying to find some hidden place to play music for a few hundred
people, hence old warehouses & such.  The feel is very different, in my
experience.   I dont know where the term massive came from tho, but it seems
a fairly accurate term to me.  


>	I personally liked it whan they were all called RAVES, it was a lot less
derogatory and much 
>less deceptive.  Some were smaller raves, others were bigger raves.
>
>	I am not a big fan of labeling things, I believe that it inedvertantly
implies bias, 
>descrimination and prejudice.  Maybee it is time for us to recapture our
heritage and revert 
>back to calling things what they realy are??


While I don't like labeling things either, I still feel that 'massive' is a
reasonably accurate term, and I think that both UG and massive are terms
that have been earned over the years, from people's experiences with both.
I know there is definitely a difference to me, and I do not consider
massives to be inherently evil, there are some things you will find at a
massive that you won't find at an UG.  The enormous energy of 2000-3000
people enjoying & dancing their asses off to seriously kick-ass music with
the entire space booming, in spite of all the magical experiences I've had
with small intimate parties, that is a feeling I've only gotten at massives,
both here and outside the U.S.  So yes there are differences, and while I
generally avoid massives, not all the differences are bad.  While it's
stupid to get too picky with terminology, I think it's silly to try to mash
vastly different experiences into one easy word.  "Rave" is just too broad a
term nowadays.


Shawna
The Self-Fulfilling Prophet

            
                   
         Do not go gentle into that good night.
       Rave! Rave into the dawning of the light!

vlad:

good question.  in fact, great question.  i've been asked that kind of 
stuff about the kind of music i spin on a daily basis, and i'm always at 
a loss of words.  

you see, someone might go to a 2000+ RAVE and not have a good time, and 
then start calling those parties MASSIVES.  

In fact, the one Funky Tekno party I've been to, I talked to someone who 
was having a great time, and someone who was having an apparently shitty 
time.  (I apologize in advance if anyone is offended by the word "shit" 
no purchase necessary must be 18 to read this).  

but you see, it's all about perception.  we might get a lot of responses 
to this thread, and they are all perceived through the eyes of whoever is 
reading them or writing them.  

I'll tell you a little story:

Last night I was taking down some of those little string lights.  The 
person who was instructing me to take them down is verry good with 
lighting, in my book.  But I didn't know what the heck he was talking 
about about wrapping them up.  He's really good with that stuff.  But I'm 
not, and I don't really have a care in the world to set up lighting.  
I'll do it to help out and give my share, but it's not my forte.  
However, give me 2 turntables and a mixer... he he he.  you won't be able 
to PRY me away from those things.  

My old roommate when we would go to parties together would always go up 
to the dj table and immediately report back to me "tony's spinning" or 
"simon's up next".  I would be like, "who cares?"  This was before I got 
good at beatmatching.  Now I'm up there sometimes spinning my head with 
the platter trying to figure out what song is playing.  

Now, what does this all have to do with mASSIVES vs. rAVES?  Absolutely 
nothing!  But it's a good exercise on perception!  =]

talk soon--->fog

Precedence: bulk

Too crowded was my first though.  About 1,500 at Ceasar's Latin Palace.  All
highschool, gangastas.  A lot of bad vibes.  But a lot of friendly people as
well.

Icey wasn't as good as I had hoped.  He played a lot of his stuff, of course.

Paul Johnson played like it was a fucking club in Tijuana!!  A lot of housey
music, a lot of slow, melodic house.  He even played "These Sounds Fall Into
My Mind" or whatever that mainstream club song is.

Dan was good!!!  He plays a lot of hard shit now.  He had the levels cranked
way up though and sometimes it hurt to listen to the music.

Overall it was a good party since I didn't pay, he he.  But it was so packed
that it was hard to dance.  Even at 4 in the morning.

They even had to carry one guy out because he o.d.ed



__________________________Matthew Wietzke_______________________________

xpress@popstar.com      mswietzke@ucdavis.edu         xpress@bigfoot.com

I think anyone who intends to throw a party, or is interested in some
authorities point of view would do well to read Lotus (v.1 iss.7).  There;s
a really good interview with the LA Fire Dept in there, that really spells
out a lot of stuff.  Safety, Legal, Permitting, type issues, and what happened
on NYE in LA.  There's also coverage of the whole NYE scene, busts, etc.. with
a lot of details.

Good stuff.  Thanks to the people at Lotus!

hugs,
Bruce

Message-ID: <970209153208_-1609529645@emout05.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Evolution
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

      the first thing that comes to my mind in regards to evolution is that
it was way too packed. cesar's is too small a place to pack that many bodies.
it was stuffy and there was no air circulating. the security staff was also
hella rude. i saw one of the punk ass security guards out front giving johnny
fiasco and kimo a hard time about coming into the party. from now on,
promoters should get potential security guards tested for steroid abuse. 
     although the party was packed, the music was incredible. jeno delivered
a wicked house set. i don't think i've ever heard him spin a bad set. i'm
always amazed at how consistent he is. 
     icey is a different story. i was expecting him to be some sort of
breakbeat god. the kids in orlando are right, he is a better producer than he
is a dj. i sat down for his entire set, because it was totally undanceable.
     paul johnson was amazing. i've heard a lot of his records and i was
amazed at how good he was. he played a lot of my favorite old school house
tracks. some people might complain that his set was too housey. but, i
disagree. the vibe of the party needed to be brought back up after icey's
disappointing set and he did it. anyone that opens their set off with "jack's
house" has my stamp of approval!!!!
     dj dan's set was good, but it was a little too hard for my tastes (sorry
sarvi, don't hurt me for complaining about your man). after grooving to some
phat house beats from paul johnson i needed to hear something funky. i've
heard dan spin some funky ass disco house before and it was the bomb. i had
hoped that he would opt to spin that instead of his harder stuff.
     johnny fiasco was johnny fiasco. for those of you who have heard his
records, you know that this man is the BOMB!!! i saw him once out here in san
jose during the summer and was amazed by his style. i wasn't disappointed
this time around either. he spun some funky ass chicago style house. i only
wish that i had been able to stay at the party longer to hear the rest of his
set. 
     overall the party was good. i went for the music and i wasn't too
disappointed. i hope to see some of you at splish on friday and at organic on
saturday.

PLUR,

dorena

Tomorrow (probably today for most of you) there is a protest in support of
the Dineh (navaho) resistors. In a nutshell they are indigenous people
that are getting kicked off (relocated is the nice way to say it) their
land. It is important to make a showing today since the court decision
regarding this case is being made this week. If they lose they may be
forcefully relocated beginning april 1st.

show your support:
Monday February 10
11:30 - 1:00
Federal Building 
450 Golden Gate Avenue
San Francisco

vigil begins at 8:00 am

for more info contact www.bmc@mailmasher.com

thanks =)

I couldn't resist posting this full message for those who don't have access=
 to the www. For those who do, check out this site. It has an incredible=
 amount of current information on a lot of the substances we all use and=
 abuse (and it has an awesome look to it as well):


http://www.erowid.com/entheogens


and the info below is specifically from:


http://www.erowid.com/entheogens/x/x_health2.shtml


MDMA : Staying Healthy                             MDMA - How to X properly


Seems like allot of sick ravers lately so here's some advice on tripping,=
 Xing and staying healthy gleaned from my 15 odd years of experience. No=
 these aren't cast in concrete, yes you don't have to follow them exactly,=
 but at 35 I'm still in good shape, hardly ever get sick and can still party=
 all night. Something to think about. :)


   1.Frequency and dose - It really takes about a week for you to completely=
 return to baseline after X or L. This means if you are doing it more often=
 than that your body is being stressed, which lowers your immune system.=
 Also, the higher the dose, the harder it is on your body. While X is easier=
 mentally than L, it is much harder on the body. Doing just enough to get=
 off will not only keep you healthy, it saves money too. :)=20


   2.Food - Both X and L suppress your appetite while increasing your level=
 of activity. (X is worse because the suppression lasts longer than the=
 trip.) This means that you are burning up your body's reserve energy when=
 you are dancing and not eating. When the body's reserves are gone, you then=
 begin burning muscle tissue, this is bad. Of course, all of this adds to=
 your physical stress levels and lowers your immune system. The bottom line=
 is that you must force yourself to eat correctly before, during and after X=
 or L. This is complicated by the fact that both X and L slow down the=
 movement of your bowels, making it harder to digest food. Before a trip -=
 eat fruits, vegetables and starches, avoid oils and heavy proteins, don't=
 eat anything heavier than fruit an hour before dropping, especially if you=
 are prone to nausea. During the trip - drink juice, eat simple starches=
 (bread, crackers) and nibble fruit (eating food is much easier on X than=
 L), set a schedule for eating and stick to it (remember, you won't feel=
 hungry) avoid candy, pop and anything with alcohol or caffeine. (These may=
 seem nice, but they do bad things to your blood sugar and hydration.) After=
 the trip - eat fruits, vegetables and starches, avoid oils and heavy=
 proteins, eat several small meals rather than trying to eat a few large=
 ones, remember you won't *feel* hungry but your body needs the food. Take a=
 good look at yourself, are you just skin and bone? If you are, up your=
 calories from starches and good fats (esp. olive/canola and fish). Your=
 body needs a slight layer of fat to stay healthy, men and women.=20


   3.Vitamins and herbs - Vitamins are NOT a replacement for eating right!=
 However, when you stress your body vitamins can help keep any negative=
 impact to a minimum. X in particular (especially when raving and drinking=
 lots of water) removes water soluble vitamins from the body. Also, certain=
 vitamins are used up a higher rates when you're under stress or over=
 exerting.


 Here are some of my favorites:

A good multivitamin multimineral for the day after. (break it up to help=
 digestion)

2-3 grams of DLPA (DL-Phenylalanine) if I feel "bummed out" the day after.

Melatonin 9-21 mg when I'm ready (and able) to sleep.

60 mg CoEnzyme Q 10 (oxygenates the heart), .5 - 1 gm inositol and 3.5 gm l-=
 orthine alpha ketoglutarate (keeps the cells in aerobic respiration), 2 gm=
 time release pantothenic acid (maintains endurance and fights stress) I=
 take these 1 or 2 hours before dropping.=20

Vitamin C 1-4 grams as needed 3-4 times a day. Every time they study vitamin=
 C they find it does more good stuff for ya. Pluses are: time release,=
 neutralized with calcium, mixed with bioflaviniods.=20

Herbs - This is a complex area with many conflicting opinions. Some that I=
 find useful:=20

Reshie mushrooms - Proven to boost the immune system shitake and miatake=
 mushrooms - contain "adaptogens" which help cope with stress=20

Ginseng - more adaptogens.=20

Ginko - increases blood flow in the brain=20


   4.Respecting yourself between trips - learn to meditate and then practice=
 it regularly. Take care of yourself, get some exercise, get some sunshine,=
 get out in nature. Don't have your whole life revolve around just tripping=
 and raving. Pay close attention to yourself and the world around you.=
 Realize that what you see in life really depends on what you are looking=
 for. Without any reason, do something good for yourself, a friend, a=
 stranger and some one you don't like. (try to keep it simple and personal=
 :) )=20


Physically touch and be touched by people.


Smile a lot, laugh out loud.


I take no credit for writing this and I have never done any drugs (one or=
 more true statements).

Hey everybody!
  (Yes, I changed my name... ;)
Sorry to bug you all with so many posts about finding a ride to
Evolution--it sucked.  Well, maybe that's a little harsh.  In any case, I
didn't like it.  Not really a "rave" at all, as far as I'm concerned.  Maybe
that's why I didn't like it--too sellout clubby.  I tried to have a good
time, but you gotta look pretty hard for fun when you spend an hour in line,
$20 to get in, get searched, and then it was so crowded that there wasn't
even enough room on the dance floor to bend your knees--let alone sit down
in a corner and have a little smoke...assuming you were able to sneak it in
past the frisk at the door in the first place.
  Not really what I expected of the music either.  A lot of bass, beats, and
some scattered vocals.  The mixing of course was fabulous.  But there was no
music--no melody, no harmony, no instruments other than different sounding
drums and such.  Dunno... not for me anyway. ;)
Peace & Love
+E

> This is complicated by the fact that both X and 
> L slow down the movement of your bowels, making it harder to digest 
> food. 


 hmmm, don't think I agree with this statement. I usually find that 
stimulants of ANY variety (this includes caffeine) tend to induce at 
least one quick bowel movement (eewwl!). It seem to me that stimulants 
make the bowels work faster, rather slower, making absorbtion of 
nutrients incomplete (nutrients tend not to be completly absorbed anyway 
but this situation makes it worse).
 In addition, I tend to get a bit of dhiarea (sp?) (double eewl!) so I 
think some water may be lost this way also.
 Any coments anyone?

 I found the rest of the info pretty good or unfamiliar to me.

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Fri, 07 Feb 1997 18:23:05 -0700
From: Collectively Unconscious <swarm@doitnow.com>
To: az-raves <az-raves@gn5.getnet.com>, Goa List <goa@party.net>
Subject: [GOA] Re: Something for you to chew on. (fwd)

> State of the Nation
> 
>     Recently our Rave movement has been under a fiercely competitive attack
> from all sides. The once loving family of united party people have
> apparently begun to faction off in small groups of promoters/dj's/and
> social scenes. We can't have this! The never ending search for money,
> success, and prestige can drive nearly anyone down to an all time low.
> Promoters skip town without paying for services rendered. Cliquish groups
> of people snub those around them. Innocent party people drive long
> distances and pay large amounts of money only to find an empty warehouse,
> or dj's that were on the flyer were never confirmed to begin with.
> Promoters give interviews to the press about our scene in order to turn a
> higher profit. All of these things and more are going on around us all the
> time. Obviously this kind of information is a sure fire bummer, but it's
> these kinds of problems that will eventually destroy our house nation
> forever! Many of us believe that this movement is a meaningful one, full of
> love and good people, NOT a money making business venture. We have the
> potential to come together from all walks of life (regardless of race,
> creed, religion, or sexuality) and unite in mind, body and spirit. It's up
> to us to make this happen, without our collective participation, love,
> trust and support we are nothing. Here are some suggestions from your
> friends:
> 
> - Do question the cover charge you pay and
>   where the money goes.
> - Do question the intentions of a party bigger
>   than 500 people.
> - Do question your support of negative people,
>   dj's, and promoters.
> - Do question your association with people who
>   only seem to talk about money and/or drugs.
> - Do support a variety of dj's and parties.
> - Do know your promoters and who they are
>   involved with.
> - Do know if your promoters pay their dj's and
>   staff.
> - Do educate yourself and your friends about
>   the drugs you take and all the precautions
>   necessary to protect yourself from harm.
> - Do know your sources well.
> - Do remember to eat, sleep, and drink lots of
>   water.
> - Do take good care of yourself and your loved
>   ones.
> - Do make at least one new friend at every
>   party you go to.
> - Do love and remember.
> - Do forgive and forget.
> - Do remember that if someone tells you
>   something about someone else that isn't very
>   nice, that same person is probably saying
>   something that isn't very nice about you when
>   your not around.
> - Do question people who take sides and gossip.
> - Do smile often and go out of your way to
>   accept everyone around you.
> - Do share (your love, your thoughts, and your
>   drugs)
> - Do remember that you are the power of
>   example to everyone around you.
> 
> We realize that these suggestions may not apply to all situations, however,
> it is our belief that information can only make us stronger and is yours to
> take or leave as you like.
> 
> Please feel free to print and distribute this flyer.
> 
> PLUR
> Curtis

 Attention all Pepsi Max kids, snow boarding suffragettes and high fibre 
 low-cal health freaks. Think you know the score? Think you're in control 
 of your lives? Think you're cool?

VENT'S got something to say about that and it goes something like this

 If your greatest fear is not where you next meal is coming from but when 
 you should trade in your old pair of air-cushioned wind resistant all 
 singing, dancing, thinking American-dream trainers, then vent's here to 
 tell you - you've sold out. 

 You can lead that cosy little life if you believe. Believe in the gods 
 of merchandise, instant gratification, dentally enhanced politicians. 
 The dream. It'll only cost you 9.99 at your local store. Stay tuned for 
 more.

 Your mind is theirs. They'll look after your nuerons now. A little tweak 
 here, a little tweak there. You won't feel a thing, except what they 
 want you to feel.

 What's it like to be a body without a cause? Don't think, don't talk, 
 don't even move until they tell you to. It doesn't matter who the 
 president is, where the war is, what the day is, it's not important. If 
 they don't say it, show it, sell it, you don't need to know it. 

 The world's too big for you. Let them make it smaller, safer. Hold their 
 hand now, prozac pedestrians, you don't want to lose your way to the 
 other pedastal sitters, street corner prophets, holier-than-thou 
 hipsters, purer than snow surfers and tunnel visioniaries. Don't lose 
 your way. They're vying for your loyalties, your pin numbers, your life 
 decisions. Stay loyal, stay cool, stay dumb, deaf and blind. They'll 
 make the decisions for you.

 Buy into their marketing empires, social conditioning, political 
 opppression, economic succession. Forget reality, forget the individual, 
 forget the rain forests, refugees, prisoners of conscience, child 
 soldiers, ethnic cleansing, freedom of expression. Plug into the 
 genetically-improved soya bean dream, know what I mean? 

 It's your life. Right?

To: "'Sfraves@hyperreal.com'" <Sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: A perfect end...
Date: Mon, 10 Feb 1997 09:37:04 -0800
X-Mailer:  Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.994.63

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Precedence: bulk

		
	Good morning you bleary eyed boys and girls.....

Well, here we sit, thinking back on the 48 past.  Some have fond (or
not-so fond) memories of Friday (Evoultion), Saturday (House parties,
House Nation or Lightseed) or/and Sunday (Friends).   In all aspects, it
shoulda been a bitchin' weekend...

It was.  

Friday:  _Evoultion_
Standing in line @ 11:30, listenin' to the deep bass resonate thru the
walls.  I honestly don't remember standing in a line since FTT's
Haloween thang (And many events have gone off between the two).  The
line is a mixed crowd, hoodies, and scensters, Klub kidz and candy
ravers,  mac daddys 'n' mac mommies...  I get in (flying solo, as usual)
and I make my way to the front.  Stuffy. crowded.  Little space to
gruuve out.  Very housey vibe.  I get into the the music and start
mooving.  Nice lasers scanning an image of two skeltions dancing on the
wall.  I run into a few non SFR ravers who are suprised to see me.  We
chat in the middle of the dance floor (the floor is soo crowded that not
many people are dancing anyways...) about the busted party in SJ and
hope that someday, SJ's house scene will grow to this standard...  I
break from conversation and wander around...  Jump into a breakdancer
circle and gruuve out for a few hrs.  Nice.  
Still very very crowded @ 4 and Im tired.  Tired? At 4AM?  Somethings
wrong.. I head home and take a nap.

Saturday:  Running around The City , Mr Pager goes off @ 4pm.  It's
DeepFog reminding me of a lil intimate house thingy going on in Berk.
By 8 PM, A wee-bit 420'ed Anakin shows up, helps set up, and opens the
event(round' 9ish). Spinning hardtrance and melodic trance for A few
Hrs. I also gained the privlige of meeting a few other SFRavers ( Hiya
Spencer, Pengo, Macgaines).  Afta my set Macgaines jumpes, on and my
friends and I are gruuving to so nicley laid progressive house only hung
around for a bit longer cos Im supposed to 'hook' with some more friends
@ lightseed...

And _Lightseed_ was the bomb.  Not too crowded (due to lack of
promoting, my guess).  But nice vibe.  I stayed upstairs dancin' to the
serious Drum and Bass blaring from the speaker, allthough the tunes were
on, I could FEEL the energy down below...
So downstairs I venture, Entranced to the front speakers Ethan is
spinning some grande ol SF Trance.  I dance away into the void, but
something keeps pulling me back to this reality...  Hmm. Somethings
defenitaly awry.  Afta dancing with a bunch of peoples to whom I know
and know not, I break away and head back upstairs, running into another
SFR'er Mr Rob Rayle (hey Rob!).  Big howdys to Dhren, Wonka and s few
others on the promoter side...
I spin out in a chill room and catch a few zzz's, prepairing myself
for....

Sunday: @ FnF.  I get there at about 2 Pm. The only sleep I had was 2hrs
@ light seed.  And allthough my body is funked a bit im still ready to
dance...
I hop to one of the front speakers and proceed to become an enviormental
hazard to the grass below me.  In about 2 hrs im dancing on a mond of
dirt (Sorry grass!) and havin' an absoultly i'll time.. Thanks for that
Sesame Street Disco 70's tune (And I though only I had that record...).
I saw many of you ( too many to list) but then again I feel the base of
FNF is the SFR family...
I stopp dancing @ about 4:30ish and finally realize what is the matter.
	Im sick.
		Really really sick...
The mind and spirit were up, but now I noticed that I've been wheezing
and coughing quite badly.  I sit in my car and try to focus on how I'm
to get home.  20Mins and a disoreantated Adam later, Im @ a friends
house chilling (well, shivering, actually) for a few more hrs. Home.
Bed. Sleep.

Oh well...

A family doctor says I have a worsening broncial infection and gotsa go
to the RX peoples today.  (goodie goodie  =P)  So, sorry to all of
thoese I was supposed to "hook" with yesterday.  I promise we will meet
again in the future.
And now I'll be spending this week (and next weekend most likley too).
With my good friends Peter penicillin, Cody codene, and Chelsa Chicken
soup.  
(At least I have my 1200's,  Gemini and Acoustic Research's to keep me
company) 

So i guess, dear raver, you need to keep me informed on nec\xt weeks
parties...

Keep the vibe alive.

---Adam
"Stay Con-COUGH,HACK,HACK-nected"

f'n great party!

Thanks to all of you who threw it and spun and set up and made tea!

Looked like it was going to rain, and besides a couple of scary 
sprinkles, it did not.

Outdoor parties are the best.  Dogs, children, just makes you want to
do cartwheels.

My only complaint was that gross outhouse--but I started bush'n it.

Music was great!

Thanks Ethan for playing Smack 3000 (Herwig Maurer)!  I was the girl
flipping out when you played that record (you probably thought I was
nuts.)  Now in L.A., Herwig and I lived together in Boston and had
adjacent recording studios, I miss him terribly!  I can't get him outta
my head, and now outta my ears.  It's hard when you put out records, you
really don't know if they are getting played or not.  He'll be glad to
know!

Peace,

--Goldilox

On 02/10/97 10:26:29 you wrote:
>
>Being the week before Valentine's Day, I'd like to suggest we reflect on 
>matters of the heart.  I'll start things out with a question for the 
>poets within us all.  In as few words as possible, what does "being in 
>love" mean to you?

WOW, 	good question.

Here are some of the things that love means to me:

Love is the unconditional giving and sharing of something that is intamate and personal to you, 
without the consideration of wather or not it will come back to you.

Love is believing in yourself and in your indevors.  

Love is viruous in itself.  It is its own reward. 

Love is a healing emotion.

Love is a circle.  No mater what it is you do, If you put it outthere it will come back to you.

True love is unconditional.

Love is the feeling released through the enrgy on the dancefloor.

Love is the spirituality at a rave.

Love is a the desire to share it.

Love breaks down bariers, removes anamosity, and destroys prejudice.

Love is everything - all at ounce.

Love gives purpose.

Love is the meaning of life.


Thanks for asking such a beautiful and wonderful question.
I hope everybody has a chance to respond to this thread and share their LOVE.
Happy Valentines.

Keep it real.

PLUR
Ray Vonie
Bad Spelling is my trademark.

From: Rick Riffle <rdriffle@ucdavis.edu>
Subject: fnf
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Simply the Best.

Got there around 3:30, after meditating and having a nice lunch at the KDK
Dharma Center celebrating Tibetan New Year.  Cool breaks were happening
which I love so I was dancing.....which was really nice because it had been
quite a while.  Who ever was spinning played "Bomb Scare" by Two Bad Mice,
ancient but classic tune and people were into it.....at least I was.  Spent
much time socializing with bay area friends I rarely get to see these days
and it felt really good.  Socialized through much of Joe's set, sorry bro.
Spent alot of Ethan's set talking as well, but really good tracks kept
breaking my train of thought and calling me to the dance floor.  Had some
Nub Chai thanks to Tony R., then started dancing.  Ethan was totally on.
Supurb mixes, with several of them leaving me wondering when the song
changed...cuz I didn't hear it.  Ethan's last two song were incredibly
beautiful tracks...they just need to be heard.  Feelings similar to "Rez" or
"Belfast."  Then Rich (happy b-day) came on.  He let Ethan's last song play
out before starting his set.  I had never heard him spin before and didn't
know what he was going to do....but I was standing there saying under my
breath..."let it be jungle" "let it be jungle."   Then I turned to my friend
Dave and said..."please let it be jungle."   And he said "oh yea, it'll be
jungle." .....I replied "now Dave, don't fuck with me cuz I really wanna
hear some d&b, to which he replied he was serious.  Soon after, the crazy
beats dropped and over the next hour or so Rich proceeded to spill my brains
all over the freshly trampled Pt. Molate grass.  Thanks Rich, and thank you
Friends and Family for a quite memorable Sunday.

Oh, yea...Dave gave me a flyer for the next Gateway party on March 1 called
"Shine", looked at it and it said Consciousness Lab was playing.........I
looked up at Dave and said...."uh, am I supposed to be playing here?"  He
gave me an "I don't know, I just got the flyers myself."  But it was all
good, I'll be there.  I guess Rich, who is also on the flyer said the same
thing when he saw it....as well as Joe Rice.....but hey, we're all friends,
and all of us were into it.  So maybe we'll see ya there.

Rick  




"When the iron bird flies and the horses run on wheels, the Tibetan people
will be scattered like ants across the world and the Dharma will come to the
land of the red man."
					--Padmasambava (8th Century)

Hey, Veronica, where were you?  I think I might of seen you, but I have no
idea what you look like, color hair etc.  You had to have seen me, I was
the one with the black beanie hat chasin' the little one all around the
park.  He was wearing a green beanie hat and Toy Story apparel.  You had to
have seen us, Andrew just about stepped on everyone and was dancing around
too.  He got so hard to keep up with cuz he would weave in and out of
everyone.  He was so full of energy, we stayed till the end and then we
took down our tent.  Right when we got in the car, he crashed with Oreo
cookie all over his face, he was even snoring.  We went to eat at Nations
(bad experience for some there!) and I took Andrew inside and put two
chairs together for him to lay on, and he did not WAKE UP!! He was sooo
passed out.  Poor guy, he raved his little heart out!

Thanks to everyone at FnF for making this event an enjoyable/memorable one
for Andrew as well as myself. I'm glad I got to meet Ethan and Jennie, and
of course their children, Andrew and Shannon. They are wonderful, and so
are all of you. Both of us send hugs and kisses to all. elina & Andrew

had a great time!! My buddy Tony kept lagging so we didn't get out there till
about 7... Just in time to hear Ethan... Sounds like you had a great set
Ethan!! =)
Now an amazing thing happened to me at this party... Moshe and i talked about
the jungle Rich was spinning and I said to him," I can't really get into this
hardcore stuff" Moshe was grooving hardcore... Then about 5 minutes later, I
was talking to some friends and my body started to move.. Then i kinda made
my way to the speaker, and for some Unknown reason except to the Techno
Gods... I LOST IT!!! I can't even dance to house music! I had a blast! That
jungle just made me get down like I never had in my entire life!!! Thank you
Rich, Thank you Ethan, Thank's to all my friends and family!! I'm a little
sore right now, but it was well worth it!!! I was the guy with the backwards
baseball cap and black jacket with a grey and white stripe across the
breast....
Peace,

Would that it were a joke...  Im not sure that the actual law-suit has
been filed (petition?  whatever) but it is definatelyy something that the
Local phone companies have been griping about for years.  I would imagine
that Capitol Hill would be where this was fought out... But I dont know
for sure.  Expect it to happen and be either :

1) Too expensive to enforce (you cant know Im using a modem unles you
tap my call...)
2) Too difficult to charge (by the minute?  the packet?  Each has a
workaround)
3) Too aggregious to the consumers (especially with the LDs getting into
the local phone biz... now there is competition)
4) Irrelevant (ISDN lines, cable modems, wireless transmission... people
will use whatever is cheapest).
5) Irrelevant part 2 : I *still* believe that it will soon no longer be
'cool' to use the net for absolutely nothing and people will leave in
droves.  Modem calls will no longer last forever (little Billy will get
his E-Mail and sign off) and so no-one will care anymore.

In other words, complain but dont get too scared.  This is utterly
winable.

- David

who is happy today.  :-)

Precedence: bulk

> >Your local telephone company has filed a proposal with the FCC to impose
> >per minute charges for your internet service. They contend that your
> >usage has or will hinder the operation of the telephone network.
> >Internet usage will diminish if users were required to pay additional per
> >minute charges. The FCC has created an email box for your comments,
> >responses must be received by February 13, 1997. Send your comments to
> >isp@fcc.gov and tell them what you think.
> >
> >Every phone company is in on this one, and they are trying to sneak it in
> >just under the wire for litigation. Let everyone you know hear this one.
> >Get the e-mail address to everyone you can think of.

My personal belief is that e-mail is not the main load-causer on the
regional telephone offices, but rather web usage. And quite frankly,
it's not the people that are putting up personal-interest sites such as
the various rave pages we see here, or some page telling you more than
you ever wanted to know about some Roland beat box. It's the commercial
usage, and the advertising.

I believe there should be a tax for internet usage to reimburse the
extra costs incurred at the RBOC's and backbone sites. This tax should
come from the ADVERTISERS and not the USERS of the  internet. A hell of
a lot of bandwidth on the internet is used up for commercial purposes,
not for personal purposes. Yet the advertizers are not paying their
fair share for clogging up the internet with lots of graphics for
products they're selling. Now they want US to pay more $$$ to look at
their advertising!

I therefore think there should be a special internet-sales tax for all
companies who get revenue for doing commercial activity (e.g. 
selling/advertizing/customer-support, etc) over the internet. They
should pay their fair share for turning a once relatively fast two-lane
highway (the internet circa 1993) into an online version of El Camino
Real (the internet circa 1997, lots of storefronts, lots of
traffic-lights, and lots of traffic). The costs of this should be more
distributed so that those that use lots of bandwidth (for graphics
intensive advertising) should pay their fair share to maintain the
roadway.

I have a feeling that employees of Organic Corp. might disagree w/ me
on this :-).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
== When yer swimming in a creek and an eel bites yer cheek, that's a moray!==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

   Love is something you can feel for any person at any time.  Since there
are different types of love, you could love everyone from your parents to
your significant other, to some guy who picked your wallet up for you when
you dropped it.  I won't go into detail, but loving someone takes a lot less
energy than hating someone.  Hate just isn't worth your time.  Hugs and
kisses are.  Especially for me since my birthday is two days before
Vallentine's Day.  I'm a love child.

Subject: Re: What love means to Me
References: <199702110026.QAA24918@klaatu.autodesk.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

-  Love is when your S.O. gives you the high sign, subtley so no one
notices, that you've got something hanging from your nose and keeps a
poker face about it so you won't die of embarrassment.

-  Love is handling your S.O.'s underwear while doing the laundry.

-  Love is changing your baby's diapers, especially the ones filled with
a cross between toxic waste and velcro.

-  Love is kissing your S.O. full on the lips right after waking up and
not minding the morning breath.

-  Love is seeing your S.O.'s new haircut and saying it's nice even when
it looks like the stylist cut it with live, crazed ferrets.

-  Love letting your S.O. put their cold feet on you at night.

-  Love is giving your S.O. a few minutes to cool off after a bad day,
then giving them a big hug before asking them to take out the trash.

-  Love is rubbing your S.O.'s feet while watching TV without being
asked.

-  Love is cooking up brussel sprouts just because your S.O. likes it,
even if the smell makes your skin crawl.

-  Love is listening to your S.O. tell about his/her job as though it's
really interesting, even if you only understand every other word they're
talking about.

-  Love is realizing that that other person's mind is priceless.

-  Love is admiring and cherishing someone for how they make you feel.

-  Love is seeing that other person walk into the room and suddenly
feeling like everything is now ok.

Niels P. Mayer wrote:
> 
> > >Your local telephone company has filed a proposal with the FCC to impose
> > >per minute charges for your internet service. They contend that your
> > >usage has or will hinder the operation of the telephone network.
> > >Internet usage will diminish if users were required to pay additional per
> > >minute charges. The FCC has created an email box for your comments,
> > >responses must be received by February 13, 1997. Send your comments to
> > >isp@fcc.gov and tell them what you think.
> > >
> > >Every phone company is in on this one, and they are trying to sneak it in
> > >just under the wire for litigation. Let everyone you know hear this one.
> > >Get the e-mail address to everyone you can think of.
> 
> My personal belief is that e-mail is not the main load-causer on the
> regional telephone offices, but rather web usage. And quite frankly,
> it's not the people that are putting up personal-interest sites such as
> the various rave pages we see here, or some page telling you more than
> you ever wanted to know about some Roland beat box. It's the commercial
> usage, and the advertising.
> 
> I believe there should be a tax for internet usage to reimburse the
> extra costs incurred at the RBOC's and backbone sites. This tax should
> come from the ADVERTISERS and not the USERS of the  internet. A hell of
> a lot of bandwidth on the internet is used up for commercial purposes,
> not for personal purposes. Yet the advertizers are not paying their
> fair share for clogging up the internet with lots of graphics for
> products they're selling. Now they want US to pay more $$$ to look at
> their advertising!
> 
> I therefore think there should be a special internet-sales tax for all
> companies who get revenue for doing commercial activity (e.g.
> selling/advertizing/customer-support, etc) over the internet. They
> should pay their fair share for turning a once relatively fast two-lane
> highway (the internet circa 1993) into an online version of El Camino
> Real (the internet circa 1997, lots of storefronts, lots of
> traffic-lights, and lots of traffic). The costs of this should be more
> distributed so that those that use lots of bandwidth (for graphics
> intensive advertising) should pay their fair share to maintain the
> roadway.
> 
> I have a feeling that employees of Organic Corp. might disagree w/ me
> on this :-).
> 
> =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
> ==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
> == When yer swimming in a creek and an eel bites yer cheek, that's a moray!==
> =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

My ideal form of love from anyone is for them to look past physical
appearance.

To not jump to conclusions when they speak. Give them the benefit of the
doubt. just because someone has stabbed you in the back before doesn't
mean that everyone else you meet is capable of the same thing.

Instead of firing back with a negative statement you respond with
positive energy. (Difficult to do especially in today's culture) Example
today I was at the SC post office and this couple was waiting in line.
They were talking and did not notice that there was an opening. Before
the couple had time to scratch their asses a gentlemen(HAHAHA) behind me
said HELLO!!!! real mean. I turned around and gave (parden my language)
this fat ass in a business suit the evil eye. He was not looking at me
but I wish he would have. I am trying so hard to not think negative
thoughts but when I am surrounded by ignorant, negative, miserable
people I feel that I have to stand up to the bullshit. I feel that I am
a very positive person who has alot to offer. Why is it that I cannot
shut this negative kharma out? In today's culture people recognize your
positive energy and try to take it away. I know that people can only
take something away if you let them but it is sooooo hard to remain
positive. PLUR  

My ideal form of love does not involve another person. I have found that
true love can only be found within one's self. I hope someday I will
find someone to share this trip we are on but until then I must love
myself. 

"To be happy, we must not be to concerned with others"- Albert Camus

II, "OHZone Layer". As you can see i play a variety of

Date: Tue, 11 Feb 1997 09:10:27 -0500 (EST)
Message-ID: <970211091027_-1844058693@emout09.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
cc: DavidPond@aol.com
Subject: Spread the vibe, keep raves alive
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Lately I've been noticing that the SF rave scene is gaining a lot of non
ravers who don't understand what raving is all about. They don't understand
what PLUR means. We need to help these people understand what we're all
about. If u see someone who looks like theyre having a bad time, ask them to
dance, or do something to make them laugh, or give them a lollipop and talk
to them for a while. These new ravers need to know what we're all about. SHow
them a little love and help introduce them in a friendly way. Do the same
with the unsocials too. Just whatever you do, don't offend them. We have to
keep the PLUR vibe alive. Don't let the scene turn into an unsocial gangster
party. Remember... spread the vibe, keep raves alive.

testing on cablemodems in the Philadelphia area and he has done some
testing and he has written his report about it.  If you want a copy of the
report point your www browsers to:

problem once cablemodems become available in my area.

Dave, I think that lately you haven't even been in the scene.  You've been
to 2 maby 3 raves that I can remeber, and you talk about being in the
scene.  If you've been to a party lately you'd see that the VIBE is very
ALIVE and PLUR, there is so much that it is spreading through the walls. 
Now I don't mean to sound like an asshole because your my friend.  But I
don't think you need to be posting messages like this to people when you
don't even really know what it's about.  What is the deal with "non ravers"
 It's not about being a newbie, or a "non-raver"  We will spread the PLUR
with ANYONE raver or "non-raver"  So if you did know what PLUR means you
wouldn't say things like that... U = Unity and that is what we are all
about not seperating ravers and non-ravers or us from them...that's all I
have to say about that...

I've posted this before, but here it is again:  I work with the 
wholesale distributor of Technics products & the wholesale price of a 
Technics SL1200MK2 is $384.00.  So use that as a starting  price of a 
point...keep in mind that your retailer also has to pay shipping of a 
(they ship from the Chicago area) plus make some money--when I g of a 
ordered mine (in May) the manufacturers suggested retail price was  a 
$650.00.  But I know that Technics only makes a set amount of 12's  a 
per year, so as demand increases, the price will go up.  And since  a 
that old line about "everbody wants to be a DJ" seems to be getting a 
more and more realistic everyday, you can't be sure that the prices a 
aren't fluctuating daily.  I hope that this will educate some rices a 
perspective 1200 buyers..  I hope that this will educate some rices a 

Mericective 1200 buyers..  I hope that this will educate some rices a

From: Blasthaus1@aol.com
Subject: (event 2/15) electrosphere: this SAT (fwd)
Date: Tue, 11 Feb 1997 16:09:54 -0800 (PST)
BestServHost: lists.best.com

blasthaus and The Fillmore Sessions invite you to electrosphere, an evening
of electronica from 9pm until 3am on Saturday, February 15, 1997. The event
features electronic music, art, film and performance at the historic Fillmore
Auditorium, 1805 Geary Street at Fillmore in San Francisco. The event is
presented by Henry Weinhards as part of the Fillmore Sessions, a monthly
music showcase at the Fillmore.

The evening features the latest trends in electronic music including ambient,
techno, jungle and electro. DJ's Jonah Sharp of Space Time Continuum, Daum of
Freaky Shakra and Jenkins of XLR8R will spin electro, jungle and techno in
the main room along with two live performances by Velocette (Reflective
Records) and Astral Matrix (oobe music). An intensive visual show will
accompany the music with film collage using an array of projected  "found
films" by Craig Baldwin's "Other Cinema" along with another slide and film
collage by Mark Johns.

A special fashion and performance installation by futuristic clothing
designers Deep Spacetime will also accompany the music and visuals in the
main room. Deep Spacetime, best known for their patented process of
hologramic textiles, will be showcasing their most recent line of space suits
and body gear. 

Upstairs at the Fillmore is the "anti-gravity" room featuring ambient,
atmospheric jungle, and ambient dub with DJ's Professor Smith, Payload
Specialist, Polywog and Alika. The room also features an electronic art
exhibition with recent work by Milton Komisar (computer controlled light
sculptures) and Austin Richards (tesla coils) among other artists from
blasthaus gallery. Chill out vibe included ambient alters, candles, beanbags,
and trees.

electrosphere is the first electronic music event of this kind to be
presented at the Fillmore and promises to be a groundbreaking evening
celebrating the progressive underground electronic music scene in San
Francisco.

This is an all ages show. Tickets are $10 and available at Bass (510)
762-BASS and Housewares at 1322 Haight Street. Tickets will also be available
the night of the show on a first come, first serve basis.

For updated information, call the electrosphere info line at 415-789-8212
extension 1



__________________________________________________________________________
for info on craigs-list:  http://www.cnewmark.com

---------- Forwarded message ----------


I've posted this before, but here it is again:  I work with the 
wholesale distributor of Technics products & the wholesale price of a 
Technics SL1200MK2 is $384.00.  So use that as a starting 
point...keep in mind that your retailer also has to pay shipping 
(they ship from the Chicago area) plus make some money--when I 
ordered mine (in May) the manufacturers suggested retail price was 
$650.00.  But I know that Technics only makes a set amount of 12's 
per year, so as demand increases, the price will go up.  And since 
that old line about "everbody wants to be a DJ" seems to be getting 
more and more realistic everyday, you can't be sure that the prices 
aren't fluctuating daily.  I hope that this will educate some 
perspective 1200 buyers.

Meric

Precedence: bulk

                       Love


     Why do we love anyone?   This question raises an idea that I feel we 
donUt normally discuss or think about.  Sure, there are particular 
characteristics, certain traits that we look for in our significant 
others, traits that we deem attractive and interesting but do we find the 
very origin of love here.  Is why we love someone described by 
revelations like  Rwow, you like cheese in a bottle too,S or Rhey, I Tm  
also really into Yoko!S , or is love a product of something ingrained in 
humanity, an instinctual urge, or a spiritual goal?  
      AristophanesUs concept of a once whole human that was both female 
and male  but was then split in two by Zeus can shed some loving light on 
the matter.  Aristophanes describes present day humans as only half an 
entity, only half a being.  He argues that we were split in two, from an 
androgynous being into distinctly sexed humans.  As we  are now only half 
the creatures we used to be naturally we feel unforfiled, empty, as if 
something is missing.  This RsomethingS being our other half, the part of 
us that was split away, and so we search vehemently for our match.  
According to Aristophanes we must bring the two halves together in order 
to be one again, once we have done this the two people coexist in a 
stasis of love through togetherness.  RLove is born into every human 
being; it calls back the halves of our original nature together; it tries 
to make one out of two and heal the wound of human nature.S states 
Aristophanies.  
      I agree with Aristophanies, not  that we were all androgynous 
nightmares with enough arms to make Shiva jealous (I am far to much a 
product of the Rhere comes scienceS, kindergarten movement of the 
eighties to buy that one) but that there is a definite intrinsic human 
need for fulfillment.  I have more often heard the argument that this 
feeling of disconnection and unforfillment comes from lack of religious 
connection and can be for filled through religion and spirituality.  But 
what strikes me the most is the use of the term love in both cases.  We 
are bombarded by religions telling us that Love of a god or deity can 
give us what we are missing, can for fill us, can bring us to the 
wholeness Aristophanes speaks about.  My specific interest here is in the 
Idea of love as something that can be shared between humans and as 
something between a human and their religious convictions.  This causes 
me to believe that what leads us to love is our personal manipulation of  
a force.  We can tap into the force of love (and I am speaking of love as 
if it is a tangible, viable,  and malleable energy) through our need to 
love, the intrinsic feeling of unforfilment I spoke of earlier.  Our 
personal manipulation may result in connection with another human, with a 
religion, or in some odd causes with a particular consumer product (its 
the American way).  But weather or not you are in love with a him, a her, 
a god, or a food processor you are in love and are being ravished by a 
force.  This force of love is what gives us forfillment.   Agathon, the 
greek philosopher, knows where I am coming from as he states that RLove 
fills us with togetherness and drains all of our divisiveness away.  Love 
calls gatherings like these together.  In feasts, in dance, and in 
ceremonies, he gives the lead.  Love moves us to mildness, removes from 
us mildness.S  This force is ours to manipulate and to do with what we 
may, we choose to for fill an emptiness within ourselvs with it. This is 
why we love.
                        keep yourself warm
spencer K.

On Tue, 11 Feb 1997, Spencer Franklin Knowles wrote:

>                        Love
> 
> 
>      Why do we love anyone?   This question raises an idea that I feel we 
> donUt normally discuss or think about.  Sure, there are particular 
> characteristics, certain traits that we look for in our significant 
> others, traits that we deem attractive and interesting but do we find the 
> very origin of love here.  Is why we love someone described by 
> revelations like  Rwow, you like cheese in a bottle too,S or Rhey, I Tm  
> also really into Yoko!S , or is love a product of something ingrained in 
> humanity, an instinctual urge, or a spiritual goal?  
>       AristophanesUs concept of a once whole human that was both female 
> and male  but was then split in two by Zeus can shed some loving light on 
> the matter.  Aristophanes describes present day humans as only half an 
> entity, only half a being.  He argues that we were split in two, from an 
> androgynous being into distinctly sexed humans.  As we  are now only half 
> the creatures we used to be naturally we feel unforfiled, empty, as if 
> something is missing.  This RsomethingS being our other half, the part of 
> us that was split away, and so we search vehemently for our match.  
> According to Aristophanes we must bring the two halves together in order 
> to be one again, once we have done this the two people coexist in a 
> stasis of love through togetherness.  RLove is born into every human 
> being; it calls back the halves of our original nature together; it tries 
> to make one out of two and heal the wound of human nature.S states 
> Aristophanies.  
>       I agree with Aristophanies, not  that we were all androgynous 
> nightmares with enough arms to make Shiva jealous (I am far to much a 
> product of the Rhere comes scienceS, kindergarten movement of the 
> eighties to buy that one) but that there is a definite intrinsic human 
> need for fulfillment.  I have more often heard the argument that this 
> feeling of disconnection and unforfillment comes from lack of religious 
> connection and can be for filled through religion and spirituality.  But 
> what strikes me the most is the use of the term love in both cases.  We 
> are bombarded by religions telling us that Love of a god or deity can 
> give us what we are missing, can for fill us, can bring us to the 
> wholeness Aristophanes speaks about.  My specific interest here is in the 
> Idea of love as something that can be shared between humans and as 
> something between a human and their religious convictions.  This causes 
> me to believe that what leads us to love is our personal manipulation of  
> a force.  We can tap into the force of love (and I am speaking of love as 
> if it is a tangible, viable,  and malleable energy) through our need to 
> love, the intrinsic feeling of unforfilment I spoke of earlier.  Our 
> personal manipulation may result in connection with another human, with a 
> religion, or in some odd causes with a particular consumer product (its 
> the American way).  But weather or not you are in love with a him, a her, 
> a god, or a food processor you are in love and are being ravished by a 
> force.  This force of love is what gives us forfillment.   Agathon, the 
> greek philosopher, knows where I am coming from as he states that RLove 
> fills us with togetherness and drains all of our divisiveness away.  Love 
> calls gatherings like these together.  In feasts, in dance, and in 
> ceremonies, he gives the lead.  Love moves us to mildness, removes from 
> us mildness.S  This force is ours to manipulate and to do with what we 
> may, we choose to for fill an emptiness within ourselvs with it. This is 
> why we love.
>                         keep yourself warm
> spencer K.  
>
