hello,


>>>This e-mail will donate 3 cents to cancer research by the American Cancer
>>>Society. ACS will donate 3 cents for everyone who receives it, so pass it
>>>along.

i copied the following from a page on the ACS homepage(www.cancer.org) entitled
"Statement on Fraudulent Chain Letter":

_______________________________________________________________________________
Fraudulent Chain Letter

The American Cancer Society is greatly disturbed by reports of a fraudulent
chain letter circulating on the internet which lists the American Cancer
Society as a "corporate sponsor" but which has in no way been endorsed by
the American Cancer Society. This letter appears to have started on America
Online but has now spread well beyond the online service. The text of the
message reads as follows:

LITTLE JESSICA MYDEK IS SEVEN YEARS OLD AND IS SUFFERING FROM AN ACUTE AND
VERY RARE CASE OF CEREBRAL CARCINOMA. THIS CONDITION CAUSES SEVERE
MALIGNANT BRAIN TUMORS AND IS A TERMINAL ILLNESS. THE DOCTORS HAVE GIVEN
HER SIX MONTHS TO LIVE.

AS PART OF HER DYING WISH, SHE WANTED TO START A CHAIN LETTER TO INFORM
PEOPLE OF THIS CONDITION AND TO SEND PEOPLE THE MESSAGE TO LIVE LIFE TO THE
FULLEST AND ENJOY EVERY MOMENT, A CHANCE THAT SHE WILL NEVER HAVE.
FURTHERMORE, THE AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY AND SEVERAL CORPORATE SPONSORS
HAVE AGREED TO DONATE THREE CENTS TOWARD CONTINUING CANCER RESEARCH FOR
EVERY NEW PERSON THAT GETS FORWARDED THIS MESSAGE. PLEASE GIVE JESSICA AND
ALL CANCER VICTIMS A CHANCE.

IF THERE ARE ANY QUESTIONS, SEND THEM TO THE AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY AT
ACS@AOL.COM

As far as the American Cancer Society can determine, the story of Jessica
Mydek is completely unsubstantiated. No fundraising efforts are being made
by the American Cancer Society in her name or by the use of chain letters.
Furthermore, the email address ACS@AOL.COM is inactive. Any messages to the
American Cancer Society should be instead sent through the American Cancer
Society website at http://www.cancer.org.

This particular chain letter with its heartbreaking story appears to have
struck an emotional chord with online users. Although we are very concerned
that the  merican Cancer Society's name has been used to manipulate the
online public, we applaud the good intentions of all who participated in
this letter. We are pleased to note that there are so many caring
individuals out there and hope that they will find another way to support
cancer research. Jessica Mydek's story, whether true or false, is
representative of that of many cancer patients who benefit daily from the
efforts of legitimate cancer organizations nationwide.

_______________________________________________________________________________

                               \/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/

                                   Tim McKnew
                               mcknew@salinas.net

                               /\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\

At 06:13 PM 2/11/97 -0800, Pengo wrote:
>What I want to know is will thoes new 'copper modems' be hit by this.
>Probably.
>
>Anyone know how something like ISDN would fit in to all this?

Home ISDN is charged per-minute during prime time, but not at other times.
Pac Bell has been repeatedly submitting the same proposal to charge per-minute
all the time for ISDN.  They already do charge businesses per-minute all
the time
for ISDN.   Another part of their proposal is to double all the per-minute
rates.
These proposals have been getting shot down, so far.  

I have no doubt that they and the other RBOC's would love to meter not only
all
data service, but all service, period.  They may find it rather difficult
to do this
when they no longer have a monopoly though.  One long-distance carrier is
offering
unlimited calling within the entire calling area (Crescent City thru Santa
Cruz, not
just what Pac Bell considers a local call).  With that kind of competition,
I don't see
how they can do it.

If they do, they may be giving the market away to the cable tv industry
anyway.


>-=Pengo=-
>Niels P. Mayer wrote:
>> 
>> > >Your local telephone company has filed a proposal with the FCC to impose
>> > >per minute charges for your internet service. They contend that your
>> > >usage has or will hinder the operation of the telephone network.
>> > >Internet usage will diminish if users were required to pay additional
per
>> > >minute charges. The FCC has created an email box for your comments,
>> > >responses must be received by February 13, 1997. Send your comments to
>> > >isp@fcc.gov and tell them what you think.
>> > >
>> > >Every phone company is in on this one, and they are trying to sneak
it in
>> > >just under the wire for litigation. Let everyone you know hear this one.
>> > >Get the e-mail address to everyone you can think of.
>> 
>> My personal belief is that e-mail is not the main load-causer on the
>> regional telephone offices, but rather web usage. And quite frankly,
>> it's not the people that are putting up personal-interest sites such as
>> the various rave pages we see here, or some page telling you more than
>> you ever wanted to know about some Roland beat box. It's the commercial
>> usage, and the advertising.
>> 
>> I believe there should be a tax for internet usage to reimburse the
>> extra costs incurred at the RBOC's and backbone sites. This tax should
>> come from the ADVERTISERS and not the USERS of the  internet. A hell of
>> a lot of bandwidth on the internet is used up for commercial purposes,
>> not for personal purposes. Yet the advertizers are not paying their
>> fair share for clogging up the internet with lots of graphics for
>> products they're selling. Now they want US to pay more $$$ to look at
>> their advertising!
>> 
>> I therefore think there should be a special internet-sales tax for all
>> companies who get revenue for doing commercial activity (e.g.
>> selling/advertizing/customer-support, etc) over the internet. They
>> should pay their fair share for turning a once relatively fast two-lane
>> highway (the internet circa 1993) into an online version of El Camino
>> Real (the internet circa 1997, lots of storefronts, lots of
>> traffic-lights, and lots of traffic). The costs of this should be more
>> distributed so that those that use lots of bandwidth (for graphics
>> intensive advertising) should pay their fair share to maintain the
>> roadway.
>> 
>> I have a feeling that employees of Organic Corp. might disagree w/ me
>> on this :-).
>> 
>>
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
>> ==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com

>> == When yer swimming in a creek and an eel bites yer cheek, that's a
moray!==

Love cannot hurt me, I'm numb to it's sweet kiss. I will not let it
bleed my soul, Or Posion me with bliss.  Love cannot touch me, My
disquise is too complete. My walls are raised, all weapons bared, I
taunt it in defeat. Love cannot mock me, I'm wise now to its ploy. No
facade of joy can hide the truth 
I will not be it's toy. Love cannot reach me, So armored in my sin,
Alone I sit, forever damned ,and dream what might have
been.......Love..cannot save me.
I wrote this acouple years ago, lemme know what you think! Peace Erik

>Love cannot hurt me, I'm numb to it's sweet kiss. I will not let it
>bleed my soul, Or Posion me with bliss.  Love cannot touch me, My
>disquise is too complete. My walls are raised, all weapons bared, I
>taunt it in defeat. Love cannot mock me, I'm wise now to its ploy. No
>facade of joy can hide the truth
>I will not be it's toy. Love cannot reach me, So armored in my sin,
>Alone I sit, forever damned ,and dream what might have
>been.......Love..cannot save me.
>I wrote this acouple years ago, lemme know what you think! Peace Erik

It hurts!  I felt these same things at one point.  I've written similar things:
"Love is the wound that never heals...", also some songs, one called
"Farewell" (meant to read as a suicide note) and one of my masterpieces,
called "Love Denied."  I'll send anyone who's interested a copy of either
or both.
I have a much more positive outlook on love now, though romantic love
always manages to elude me.  My interest has always been returned with
fear or rejection or a series of vicious attacks and behavior which made
me feel that women like nothing better than to find a nice guy and
destroy his heart.  I know better than that now, and I know that my
sweetheart is out there, somewhere.  I dearly look forward to the time
we shall meet, and give each other our whole hearts.
Love to all,
Eric

Now Wait a Minute!!!

I LIKE The Sound of Music!!!!

(Isn't that the one with Gene Kelly? He's one of the dancers I get my
inspirations from... waitaminute, I'm thinking of Brigadoon, not to be
confused with Bonnydoon)

But a very valid point Deep,  Many of my younger friends parents look at
me with a bit of suspicion when I tell them I rave.  But my actions are
not those of a seedy drug dealer/user and  I actually get some postive
feed back when I play one of my mixtapes (of course, my melodic mixes,
not, the hardcore / hardtrance stuff.).  I try to convey the aspect of
ravers moreso through actions, than just words.  If we believed
EVERYTHING the media protrayed (aside from being mindless sheep) we'd be
jumping @ our shadows with parinioa.


"Im singing in the rain...." (Cough, cough, hack...sputter...No wonder
Im sick)

Pengo made a good point here...

I'd like to sort of elaborate on that.  This story has an SFRaver 
starring in this one, I hope it was ok.  I didn't ask prior permission.  
Adam, you've got permission to put me in a story, ok?  =]

Imagine that we are all watching TV.  We're going to go rent a movie.  
Something with lots of action, like "Die Hard".  

Now Adam G. comes over and says "hey i heard there's a party here!"  and 
we say "yeah, man we're going to watch 'die hard', please pop the tape 
in."  so he does that and we get all excited because we're expecting to 
see lots of action (you might not like diehard, but play along, it's 
fun!) and we're going to see bruce willis and other people creating lots 
of explosions and all that...

and then the tape starts rolling.  

it's a wide shot panning up this grassy green hill, and out comes julie 
andrews singing "...the hills are alive, with the sound of music!"

oops. did someone put the wrong tape in?  well, don't worry adam.  it 
wasn't your fault, it was mine.  i handed the wrong tape to you.  

But you see, that's what some of us are doing in the rave scene.  We're 
putting the wrong tape in the VCR.  We want the cops and our parents and 
other people to see the show "raves are great and spiritual and lots of 
friends", but what they're actually watching is "20/20".  

now obviously some people have decided to stay on one channel for good.  
and that's sad, because we have thousands to choose from.  each person 
has a different point of view, and therefore a different channel we can 
choose.  

Perhaps we can all lead by example.  Work with parties and promoters that 
care and start creating a new show.  it's called "PLUR TV".

ToJeremy@aol.com wrote:
> 
> hi,
> 
> i have two questions on this sleepy tuesday night: one, why do sooooo many
> people come up to me and ask, "are you on e?" when im just dancing or
> standing around or sitting and talking?

Dunno, funny you say that, but the same thing happens to me, all the
time, especially when I am smiling.  E is too expensive, smiles are more
affordable for me.  I think when people ask you that, they want to
relate to someone who's also feeling the effects of the drug.  It is
very common that when you are tripping, especially on L, to think that
others are also tripping.
> 
> and two, is the dj DRC the same person as the dj Darcy?

DRC's name is Darcy, and so is her girlfriend's name.  I don't know if
her girlfriend is a DJ or not.  I am quite sure these are two different
people.  DRC has short blond hair, Darcy (the girlfriend) has long blond
hair.  Does this help a little?

Peas,

-Goldilox

It should be noted that the entire teleservice pricing schedule and switch 
network was and is designed to handle voice calls which have traditionally 
averaged around 3 minutes in duration.  With an average call of 3 minutes, the 
phone network infrastructure was perfectly capable of handling the volume of 
users.  With the use of modems and the vastly longer usage times (esp. with the 
use of the Web),  the switching networks have become overloaded, even to the 
point of occasionally becoming "full" at peak times (i.e., you pick up the 
phone, and receive no dial tone.)  This, of course, raises the ire of uses, as 
the phone is viewed as a lifeline tool.  Thus, local loop providers and RBOCs 
have had to make significant investments in infrastructure, which is not cheap 
(price out a public network-quality switch sometime.  The whole point is that 
there is some justification for this price raise.  RBOCs are trying to create 
almost two networks, one for voice (analog transmission) and one for digital, 
which will benefit users of both once its completed. Adios, Nathan








>-=Pengo=-
>Niels P. Mayer wrote:
>> 
>> > >Your local telephone company has filed a proposal with the FCC to impose
>> > >per minute charges for your internet service. They contend that your
>> > >usage has or will hinder the operation of the telephone network.
>> > >Internet usage will diminish if users were required to pay additional
per
>> > >minute charges. The FCC has created an email box for your comments,
>> > >responses must be received by February 13, 1997. Send your comments to
>> > >isp@fcc.gov and tell them what you think.
>> > >
>> > >Every phone company is in on this one, and they are trying to sneak
it in
>> > >just under the wire for litigation. Let everyone you know hear this one.
>> > >Get the e-mail address to everyone you can think of.
>> 
>> My personal belief is that e-mail is not the main load-causer on the
>> regional telephone offices, but rather web usage. And quite frankly,
>> it's not the people that are putting up personal-interest sites such as
>> the various rave pages we see here, or some page telling you more than
>> you ever wanted to know about some Roland beat box. It's the commercial
>> usage, and the advertising.
>> 
>> I believe there should be a tax for internet usage to reimburse the
>> extra costs incurred at the RBOC's and backbone sites. This tax should
>> come from the ADVERTISERS and not the USERS of the  internet. A hell of
>> a lot of bandwidth on the internet is used up for commercial purposes,
>> not for personal purposes. Yet the advertizers are not paying their
>> fair share for clogging up the internet with lots of graphics for
>> products they're selling. Now they want US to pay more $$$ to look at
>> their advertising!
>> 
>> I therefore think there should be a special internet-sales tax for all
>> companies who get revenue for doing commercial activity (e.g.
>> selling/advertizing/customer-support, etc) over the internet. They
>> should pay their fair share for turning a once relatively fast two-lane
>> highway (the internet circa 1993) into an online version of El Camino
>> Real (the internet circa 1997, lots of storefronts, lots of
>> traffic-lights, and lots of traffic). The costs of this should be more
>> distributed so that those that use lots of bandwidth (for graphics
>> intensive advertising) should pay their fair share to maintain the
>> roadway.
>> 
>> I have a feeling that employees of Organic Corp. might disagree w/ me
>> on this :-).
>> 
>>

Date: Wed, 12 Feb 97 12:22:09 PST

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Intro and thoughts on first rave
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello, tout.  First post disclaimer, etc.  Here's a little intro on
how I am getting drawn into it all.

I went to Nikita at 1015 Folsom a couple of months ago.  It was the
first time I'd ever been to a dance club, and I loved it.  I
especially liked the different vibes in each room, and the way you
could be your own dj by slowly walking from room to room.  I'd be
tranced out in that big ass room, and then slowly get drawn by the
drums and bass in the basement, all the while letting myself make
that transition from vibe to vibe.  I found a new type of music that
my body enjoyed exploring.  And so it was the music/dancing and not
the people that got me curious enough to go to my first rave.  So I
headed straight to hyperreal.com, where usually I ignore the rave
archives and head straight for the "chemistry" archives, but not this
time.  So I scoured the files.  Yum yum.  Read alot about PLUR.  My
personal philosophy is similar.

So I decided to go to First Contact (end of Jan), and it was cool,
but not mindblowing like I hoped.  Took 15 mg's to see bees, and many
things I did see.  I enjoyed to large visual screen and the slide
projection sequences.  I was expecting an infusion of PLUR, but found
the general attitude to be self-engrossed.  My self-consciousness was
probably hampering me initially, but then the bees started buzzing
and I too was self-engrossed.  So, you got to give to get, and that's
why I didn't feel the PLUR vibe.  

I danced, but for some reason i didn't click in.  Maybe because I was
too absorbed by the new experience, trying to figure out the system,
the vibe, I didn't have as much fun as I could have.  And so I'm
excited go to another rave, and I'd like to experience it as an
insider this time instead of an outsider.  Any thoughts on how I
should approach it this time?  Maybe I can find someone's wing.

On a different note, I've noticed a lot of discussion on public
perception of rave culture.  If you don't like the way the culture is
being perceived by the public, the rave culture as a community needs
to do some outreach.  That seems to be the general consensus.  It's
not going to stay underground forever.

Thanks all for letting me share,
George

At 1:19 PM -0800 2/12/97, Randy C Cone wrote:
> True. What I was doing was sending out a reaction to the silly threat of
>"I'm going to put it/you in my kill file." Kinda like folks threatining
>to leave SFraves.

The truth was that this message wasn't even sent to you. It was sent to SF
Raves. And the message I wrote never said anything even close to "I'm going
to put it/you in my kill file." I don't even use a kill file. I use
filters. They are different.

But since you have probably guessed correctly that you are in quite a few
peoples' kill files (understandably, based on how you responded to me, both
publicly and privately), you seem to be hypersensative to the possibility
that one more person is no longer reading your posts. This hypersensativity
has created a self fufilling prophecy.

And, once again, with feeling, what I said was: I am now going to filter
all messages with LOVE in the title to my SFR/NRR folder -- to be read
later (i.e. when I have insomnia) -- not to be killed.

Before you go off and jump the gun in the future, read the words and don't
be so Ran-centric and think that all messages posted to SF Raves are
written to *you*.

				Hi SFRavers!

Finally am able to be at the computer for more than 30 minutes here at 
Univ. of DVC :-)  Well, I'll be brief and get to the point . . . 
	This last weekend I threw a little b-day party for my cousin 
(she's in her teens), and all of her friends, and I would just like to 
say that the D.I.Y. thing definitely turned out perfect, and I had a 
wonderful time.  There was two 15" speakers, the 1200's, blacklights, fog 
machine, the works! It turned out beautifully, even though this was a b-day 
party and we were not going to make *any* profits whatsoever.  
	From the bottom of my heart, I would like to sincerely thank 
*ALL* promoters in this scene of ours (past, present, and future) for 
making events happen.  You guys have to go through a lot of B.S. and hard 
work in order to finally have that needle drop onto the vinyl, to the 
glow of the morning sun.  Thanks again!

>To avoid the proliferation of urban legends and chain letters, please
>include verification info whenever sending out something that says "please
>forward this to everyone" since so many such emails turn out to be bogus
>or at least contain inaccurate info.
>
>In this case, I called the FCC and got more info:
>* The proposal is called "Access Charge Reform".
>* On the Web: http://www.fcc.gov/isp.html
>* My info is from Richard Lerner of the FCC (main phone = 202 418 0200).
>* From the information I got from the FCC, the proposal is to charge ISPs
>  (not individuals) for calls in the same way it charges interstate long
>  distance companies.
>* On the point mentioned above, the FCC has already "tentatively concluded"
>  that this would not be a good thing. See the web page for more info.
>* the "input" dates specified below are correct for some parts of it, but
>  there is a later date of April 23, 1997 for some parts of it. See the web
>  page for more info.

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Wed, 12 Feb 1997 13:41:54 -0500 (EST)
From: Darin Porto <portod@ccbc.ml.org>
To: pb-cle-raves@hyperreal.com
Cc: mtn-raves@hyperreal.com, mw-raves@taz.hyperreal.com,
    ne-raves@world.std.com, nw-raves@hyperreal.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com,
    txraves@io.com
Subject: Union Of Everyone

To Everyone Who Cares:

   With all the media attention, legal issues, and violations of citizens
rights, we, as a culture, have decided to do something about it. We our
forming a national organization to protect and defend the rights of people
who chose to live their life underground. I have contacted the ACLU and
the Citzen's Commision on Human Rights and they have advised us to form an
organization of our own. They strongly agree that a whole organization of
people with the same interests is the best route to take.

So join in and let your voice be heard.

The organization is going to be named PLUR (Protecting and Living The
Underground Culture), for now. If anyone has ideas on a different name
mail it. We need it soon, within the next few days because we our going to
print flyers, t-shirts, member cards, bumper stickers, letterhead and the
whole deal. 

What you Get: The fee for joining is going to be $10.00 (the cost of a
small rave) and will include a mass amount of stuff. We will scope out an
area for you if you are planning to have a rave (i.e. legal issues such as
permits, curfews, building capacities, and everything involved). We will
have a legal staff to advise you on your rights for any reason (being
arrested, fined, harrassed, and barred entry from events). We have found
to volunteer lawyers to defend the rights of legal cases in which we think
a persons rights have been violated (This includes promoters, Djs, ravers,
average people). We will get and give you all legal information for
protests etc., as we plan to have a physical involvement in those. You
will also get a monthly newsletter, i.d. card, bumper sticker
(re-useable), an invitation to a members only national rave (coming this
summer, which hopefully will be free), along with all of the services
listed above for free. This isnot everything, as we are just forming and more stuff will be included in
the offical application. You must e-mail portod@ccbc.ml.org to recieve an
application. Include your name, address, phone number, and e-mail.
Depending on the costs we wish to include a t-shirt with our logo, your
member name, and your city and state.
We will be a legal organization. I have the papers on their journey in the
mail. We are legal and the Offical club of the underground culture.


This is going to be the best thing that has happened for our culture since
it was born. Please join, we need a couple of thousand people to really
stand up and make a difference. We are the first and only organization
that is not afraid to defend who we are. We have put alot of effort this
past year into this and it is finally here. Make a difference, join our
organization.

E-Mail portod@ccbc.ml.org for an application or more info.

 proves how spirit and dust can merge-
			-Grundtvig

On Wed, 12 Feb 1997, Matthew Wietzke wrote:

> I read that he was playing at Nikita.  If this is true, how come the last
> rave he played at he was billed as "Last rave performace".  Was this false
> advertising, did he decide to hop back into the saddle, what gives?

Because Nikita is _definitely_, without a doubt, anything but a rave.

Also because Nikita, in the face of lagging attendance, is willing to 
shell out big bucks to bigname "superstar" dj's in order to bring in the 
masses.

And because "superstar" dj's like to be paid like the superstars they 
think they are.  For some, it's all 'bout money and fame (or what's possible 
in the dance culture) - so perhaps, this is the reason behind Keoki's 
abandonment of "raves." 

I saw Keoki there in the spring.  Despite numerous trainwrecks and a 
shocking display of bad attitude, his set was crowd-pleasing and the 
place was packed.  I'd see him there again. 

N

From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Re: Intro and thoughts on first rave
To: gchan@ccmail.calgene.com
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <9701128557.AA855782944@ccmail.calgene.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9702121731.A10567-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Probably reading the archives and this list can mis-prepare you for the 
experience.  The friendliness and openness has definitely deteriorated 
over the years, even from when I started (2 years ago) - and back then 
old school ravers were bemoaning the "end of the scene" that occurred in 
'93 with wide-scale attendance.

This is why you will see people talk about bringing it back DEEP 
underground.  Because anyone can come to a party and they don't 
necessarily bring love and light.  It used to be that people brought toys 
and gifts and fruit for everyone.  I rarely see that now.  It is still a 
special environment, but the really transcendent moments of group 
togetherness seem more sparse.  But when they do happen, WOW.

A lot of people _are_ into their own thing.  In fact, a lot of people are 
tripping or just dancing or whatever.  But after a while, you realize 
that all (or most)  of you are there for the same reason, and there is a 
comfort and an easiness, and even if you aren't "bonding" with people, 
you are still there _together_, rather than separate "costumers" like at 
a club, for example.

My advice?  Look at it as a great party, a place to have fun with cool 
people.  Many many people have experienced great insights and 
mind-blowing connections at parties... so when we old-timers talk of 
PLUR or lessons we've learned, we understand each other... but it can't 
be forced.  Just go to have fun, and if you do, keep going.  And maybe 
along the way you'll run across something really cool.

love,
Nancy

There is something i don't quite understand.

If everyone only has to pay $10, where do all the other money nevessary to
start and run this "union" come from? It sounds like a good idea, I hope
it gets off the ground.

How long do you guys think this whole scene will last? All I know is that
I've been playing with computers and listening to techno since I the late
80s and they are both now exploding in our society... I guess you could
call us cyber-hippies. 

I'm staring out my office window into Oakland and I can see the twin
buildings and 2 American flags from my view point. I work for Farallon in
Alameda.

Piece.

-bYroni

Very surprised to run across a flier for a $6 Cool World make-up party,
with a (promised) thick line-up.  (I keep hearing that monster-truck-rally
voice in my head!) People can do their best to trash _this_ move, but it
at least shows some concern for their market.  My cynical side realizes 
that this is to keep the customers satisfied, but _at least_ it proves 
that even the largest and most commercial "rave" events have to display 
some commitment to the scenesters.

Also, I didn't hear a peep on here a few weeks ago when the rave held next 
door to Pacific/Gateway (forgot the name!) threw their ($5) make-up 
party.  Thought I'd point out that that occured.

So, whatever happened to the promised Pac/Gateway make-up party?!  I'm 
still clutching my ticket.  If the $20 turns into a donation for a summer 
of Sunsets, I'm cool with that... just wondering.

At 5:24 PM -0800 2/12/97, _LiQuiD_ wrote:
>YEAH!
>we should all propose ideas for possible laminates...
>	i was looking at socal raves site and they have a few different
>	laminates uploaded there... it might be cool ?!
>
>STILL!...  PHAT props out to terry (ctdzyne) who created the first and
>**original** sfraves laminate (to my knowledge)! he was my inspiration
>for collection laminated stuff :)  thanx terry!
>
>	we should designate a web site to host the new ideas for
>laminates if people are down to create such... i guess our site is a
>possibility if no one else has another idea!  PLUR PEEPS
>LiQuiD ~ ry@n

Wrong! :-)

I proposed the original SF Raves in August 1995. The night of the Friends
and Family party in August 1995 Vince immediately found me and agreed it
was an excellent idea to get us all together and soon after that he debuted
the original laminate design. We are partners in crime, and he's definitely
the visual artist in our family... we made and distributed a BUNCH of them
in 1995 and 1996.

Later Terry did his laminate design, which we thought was cool and Vince
didn't really make any more after that, giving Terry the opportunity to
spread his art around.

Then Vince, not to sit on the sidelines, rolled out the *very limited
edition* SFR button, of which there are only a couple hundred. The design
is an excellent "repurposement" of the STP logo. I have some at home and
will bring them to parties again if any of you want them.

pax, man.

-w

Not that anybody cares, but I believe an SFR badge/laminate predated
the Aug 1995 F&F badge -- I think it was made sometime around  92 or
93. My memory is fuzzy, but it was sometime between The Whoopie Ball
and the SFR Connection III rave... I'm not sure, but I think Bob
Ramstad and/or Arthur Chandler had something to do w/ this
badge/button.

for allowing my continued participation on this list over the years!

Dear Ravefriends,

        I've asked the San Francisco Libertarian Party to postpone until
next month the discussion of rave busts and what can be done about it that
I'd asked to have on the agenda of tonight's SFLP meeting.
        Since I haven't been part of the SFRaves conversation recently to
remind people of the meeting, or even to know what has been talked about, I
thought it best to wait and hopefully gather more folks to come next month
with a bit more preparation.
        My absence has been due partly to a problem of my getting
unsubscribed every time I rejoin the high-volume main list (apparantly a
bug in my service provider's software that they're working on fixing) and
partly to other things going on like a new fulltime job and the planning of
this Friday, when my fiance Chikako and I will be getting married!  (More
on this in separate post to come...)
        I haven't even yet gotten around to reading the posts to the SFR
legal list, but I have them all saved and intend to do so ASAP, because
this is an issue that is important to me.
        If someone hasn't beaten me to the punch I hope to do some legal
research on the permit process, public gatherings, and so forth in order to
be armed with some concrete data to bring to the table.
        Look forward to seeing many of you (I hope) a month from now...

May the bass be with us,
                                        <<< Starchild >>>

For those interested, I still have both the old and new designs on a web
page given to the SFRavers who want to put up art work on the web.  I've
only had a few submissions, but I invite anyone that wants to show their
artistic side to send me any art they'd like to add.  NOTE:  It doesn't
have to have the SFR logo, even though all the current art does.  The
URL is http://www.tgrigsby.com/sfraves/index.html.

clueless on what different promoters/parties are up to these days. ..

I want her to really feel the vibe and the positive emotion all
around....

I think the whole laminate thing is a great idea. By distributing them I
was able to meet a ton of you in a short period of time. Since then I felt
that my laminates would serve a better purpose if I gave a couple to other
SFRavers so they could meet new people just like I did.

As far as new laminates...there's no SFR commission, (Well, except for
Randy, Krusty, Black Adder, Neils, and JSL--->> I'M KIDDING!! PLEASE DON'T
FLAME ME!!) So if you have any kind of talent, by all means make up your
own. Or, for the artisticly challenged, feel free to download my laminate
at:

http://www.tgrigsby.com/sfraves/index.html.

                 or

http://www.cyborganic.com/people/ctdzine

Print some out, laminate them and give them out to fellow SFRavers. Or, ask
around, I'm sure there's still a few of mine floating around, and if
there's a demand I'd be glad to make more.

Still, I think it would be cool if I had a personalized laminate from each
and everyone of you.

love, energy, and viberations,

Terry

Date: Wed, 12 Feb 1997 21:55:57 -0800 (PST)
From: Arthur Chandler <arthurc@sfsu.edu>
X-Sender: arthurc@pluto
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Latin techno
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.970212214019.16396A-100000@pluto>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


  First, thanks to all who emailed me their suggestions. I wasn't able to
listen to a DJCarlos tape; but I did spend a good deal of time at Tower
and Borders (where they will let you listen to ANY 3 CDs at a private
listening post -- terrific policy!). Here's my take:
  1) The best -- or, at least, my favorite -- Latin mixes are dance based,
and very specifically dance-oriented. Merengue, salsa, and macarena
dominate, though there are others. And not all Latin dance mixes
are done by Latinos. Two very interesting CDs I listened to were *Fatal
Mambo*, done by a group from southern France, and Afrirumba, an African
group doing a Latin American form and speaking French half the time. :<O
  2) The Latin mixers excel the Nortes in the use of smaller percussion
instruments, whether real or sampled -- timbales, bongos, bells, etc.
Sometimes you're not even aware of all that's going on until you tune into
the mid- and upper ranges.
  3) If you're used to brushing off Latin music because of the traditional
brass chorus shout lines or traditional harmonies (as I was), park your
prejudices and get up and DANCE. 

  That said, here's my Grand Champ Recommendation for SFRaves:

                    Fiesta Mix USA '97 (#PROD-7061)

  The least impressive tracks (like the Lambada mix in #2)  are merely
good. The best are volcanic. If you play this CD through a good stereo
system and remain sitting down, you need to see a doctor.  :<)

Today I started reading a book titled "Nothing in This Book Is True. But
It's Exactly How Things Are" by Bob Frissell. At first I thought this
was just another one of those crop cycle books the I found myself
becoming more and more interested as I read one. Is there anyone else on
SFraves who enjoys learning about extraterrestrial possibilities? And if
so could you explain some of the alien races further they mention in
this book? Such as the Anunnaki/Nefilim, Sirians, Martians, Greys,
Pleiadians, etc. If this subject matter is a little embarrassing please
respond privately. I find this book very interesting. I one specific
tale Bob talks about a tribe near Timbuktu in Africa called the Dogon.
The book claims that this tribe has had information for more than 700
years which is impossible for them to have known. They said that there
was another star orbiting the star Sirius. Scientists did not discover
the second star until 1970 when a large telescope was sent into space.
To quote from the book, "When a team of scientists visited the Dogon
tribe to find out how they knew about this, the elders said that a
flying saucer landed. Beings emerged and made a large hole in the ground
which they filled with water. The occupants, who looked like dolphins,
jumped into the lake they had made, then came up to shore, and talked to
the Dogon people." (Frissell, p. 26). I found this absolutely amazing. I
would have to see an alien before I believed in them but this made me a
little more partial to anyone who believes in UFO's. If anyone would
like to get the book it is only $12.95 available from Frog, Ltd in
Berkeley. :)

  I was listening to a BBC piece this evening about the rise of punk 
music incorporating fascist messages in Germany.  They had a DJ, Alex 
Empire (I believe) who commented on it.  They asked him if anti-fascists 
were also using music and he referred to how electronic music is used to 
unify everyone.
  The piece that followed was about Indonesia implementing the death 
penalty for ecstasy smugglers.  They said that E is more widespread (and 
expensive) than in Europe.  The reporter said it was available even in 
remote areas, and that clubs in that country attract crowds of ~15,000.

them were good...


<fontfamily><param>Monaco</param>1. If you throw a cat out a car window
does it become kitty litter? 

2. If corn oil comes from corn, where does baby oil come from?

3. When a cow laughs does milk come out its nose? 

4. How did a fool and his money GET together?

5. How do they get a deer to cross at that yellow road sign? 

6. If it's tourist season, why can't we shoot them?

7. What's another word for thesaurus?

8. Why do they sterilize the needles for lethal injection? 

9. Why is abbreviation such a long word? 

10. Why do kamikaze pilots wear helmets? 

11. How do you know when its time to tune your bagpipes? 

12. Is it true that cannibals don't eat clowns because they taste
funny? 

13. When you choke a smurf, what color does it turn? 

14. Do blind Eskimos have seeing eye sled dogs?

15. Why is there an expiration date on my sour cream container? 

16. What do they use to ship Styrofoam?

17. Why do they call it a TV set when you only get one? 

18. Do radioactive cats have 18 half-lives?

19. If you shoot a mime, should you use a silencer? 

20. What was the best thing before sliced bread?

21. Does a stich that's late save only 8?

22. Who are those "seeing eye dogs only" signs for, anyway?

</fontfamily>

when it finally reaches his nose hairs...it breaks up into a million

room in terror as you of course blow on that smoking barrel...

around last year, so it may have been repressed, as the original is from

one of his tracks sampling the original, which in itself was a sample...

>Hey everybody...
>  I was wondering if anyone knows of a bay area college that has a good
>program in...
>Sound Engineering, Sound Production or stuff like that.

Hey Man!!  Hows it going?

The school I went to, Cogswell College, has an absolutly amazing music 
program.  The program is a Bachlor of Science in Music Technology.  They 
also have a Certificate Program, which is what I took.  They basiclly 
teach you everything you need to know about sound, sampling, digital 
audio, recording techniques, sound design, sequencing, etc.....  The only 
bummer is, its kinda expensive.  Like 500 bucks a unit, and most classes 
are two or three units.  But that was a couple of years ago, not sure how 
much its costs now.

-M

earber@pacbell.net wrote:
>I find this book very interesting. I one specific
>tale Bob talks about a tribe near Timbuktu in Africa called the Dogon.
>The book claims that this tribe has had information for more than 700
>years which is impossible for them to have known. They said that there
>was another star orbiting the star Sirius. Scientists did not discover
>the second star until 1970 when a large telescope was sent into space.

The book to check out on the whole Sirius thing is "The Sirius Mystery" by
Robert Temple, a British astronomer.  He goes over the African stuff and
also draws similar information out of the Egyption and Babylonian
mythological traditions, tracing it all back to a common origin in
extraterrestrial contact six or seven thousand years ago.  It will point
you to the anthropological studies of the Dogon (and Bozo, another tribe)
that brought their Sirius-knowledge to light.  The Dogon/Bozo stuff is also
entertainingly expounded in Tom Robbins' latest novel, "Half Asleep in Frog
Pajamas."

anarch@scruznet.com

At 11:49 AM -0800 2/7/97, Steve Simitzis wrote:
>A favor:
>
>Even though drugs have a big influence on the rave scene, can you
>please please please mark posts that are strictly about drugs as NRR
>in the subject? Note that NRR = Not Rave Related. Putting NRR is the
>subject line allows people (like me) who use filters not to have to read
>about things that aren't interesting (ie. not relevant to raving).
>
>Reading post after post comparing LSD and Ketamine and Ecstasy, various
>interpretations about the origin of 420, what Ecstasy is being laced with
>nowadays, and so on....
>
>It's just too much. This is not a drug list... although, I assure you,
>you should be able to find one with little difficulty. But since I
>understand that the nature of SFRaves involves a large amount of
>off-topic posting, remember:
>
>Please, just use the NRR tag in the subject line. It's there for a
>reason. :)
>
>Put yourself in my shoes. I receive over 300 pieces of email everyday;
>that's after filtering the hell out of it. :( Please be nice to those
>of us with overflowing mailboxes. (I would say something about PLUR,
>but I won't... >:)
>
>Finally, I find it interesting to note that during the whole 20/20
>hysteria, the SFRaves community passionately proclaimed how "Raving is
>not all about drugs! How *dare* they insinuate that. Let's FAX bomb
>then with protests." However, at the same time, the other thread on
>SFRaves that was running concurrently was all about drugs... That
>makes a very interesting statement about our community.

I nominate this message for 'Krusty's Nice Netizen' "Let's not be in
denial, and, oh, by the way, mark your posts to SFR accordingly" post of
the month!



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Feb 13 11:52:57 1997

To: trose@uclink2.berkeley.edu (Tony Rose)
Date: Thu, 13 Feb 1997 11:40:47 -0800 (PST)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <Pine.ULT.3.93.970213015106.3362E-100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu> from "Tony Rose" at Feb 13, 97 01:52:04 am
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> 
> 
> >   I was listening to a BBC piece this evening about the rise of punk 
> > music incorporating fascist messages in Germany.  They had a DJ, Alex 
> > Empire (I believe) who commented on it.  They asked him if anti-fascists 
> > were also using music and he referred to how electronic music is used to 
> > unify everyone.
> note the love parade which happens every year since...? ... has anyone on
> this list ever been? how was it?
> tr.
> 
> 


A few years ago (maybe '93?) before I was ever into raving I just *happened*
to be in Berlin the very weekend of the love parade. I had no idea what
it was all about or even that it was happening until I found myself in
the middle of it! Man, if I had only known then what I know now!

We had walked down to the Kurfurstendamm (the main boulevard in Berlin)
to go out to dinner, and were wondering what all these crowds were doing, 
and along comes a whole procession of big flat-bed trucks loaded with huge 
speaker systems pounding out this GREAT techno - each truck sounding better 
than the last - and throngs of happy ravers dancing on the trucks and 
following them down the boulevard, dancing in the streets, handing out 
fliers, and just having a wonderful time. The vibe was amazing - of course
I'd never been to a rave then, so to my untrained heart it was something
to behold. People were smiling and dancing and it was just great. I think
it was then that I decided I'd better check this scene out - those people
were having WAY more fun than I was!

Now I kick myself that I didn't follow them down the street and join in
the rest of the evening's activities! But they planted the seed in me!
I'd be interested to hear if anyone else actually got more involved and
experienced the raves themselves - it seemed to me that it was pretty
much a weekend of raves rather than just the parade itself, and that
maybe there was even more than one parade (?) (but then again I guess 
that in Berlin, EVERY weekend is a weekend of raves!!!!).

Love to you all - have a GREAT weekend!!!!

- Martin  =]


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Feb 13 12:05:28 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id MAA27693; Thu, 13 Feb 1997 12:05:28 -0800 (PST)
Received: from host.domain.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with ESMTP id MAA27689; Thu, 13 Feb 1997 12:05:25 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [157.22.222.52] (x.domain.net [157.22.222.52]) by host.domain.net (8.7.5/8.6.12) with ESMTP id MAA22536; Thu, 13 Feb 1997 12:05:20 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <v03007801af2921b1d458@[157.22.222.52]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Thu, 13 Feb 1997 12:02:27 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "Krusty Mindless Loves All Of You :-)" <wayne2@club.net>
Subject: rant: PLUR
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I am now adding "PLUR" ot my NRR filter rules.

Why PLUR, that most sacred communication of raving? (I can hear the uproar
among those that are more feeling than analytical.)

PLUR is a very beautiful concept. PLUR should be practiced, PLUR should be
teached. But PLUR has gone from being an interesting utopian meme to a
"bible" that is hit over others heads from on high as some kind of moral
hammer. I'm tired of seeing "If you practiced PLUR you would not have done
that." or "Blah, blah, blah... you would go around hugging your enemies if
you <blank> PLUR." or whatever.

So, to keep my main SFR mailbox in line with raving and not all the
tangentical drug and 12-step talk, "PLUR" now joined the filtered ranks of
"Addidas", "Cool World", "E", "Heroin" and "420".

Flame on, I love all of you! :-)

Love & peace,
Eric

Lots of parties this weekend, with Valentine's Day and President's Day 
on each end of it.  Saturday especially, features a couple of big
parties, Organic and Love A-Fair, a mostly live show (electro sphere)
featuring a lot of locals, and Pro-Soy further underground.  Sunday
has a Stompy day party and a big Spundae, so this weekend, you could
really dance non-stop!

I'm a little behind on the updates for the radio and TV shows, but thanks
everyone for sending in new info...


                                THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://www.hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Upcoming Parties in the San Francisco Bay Area

   Friday, February 14th - _Electric Fondue_
   Hardkiss boys, Paul, the niv, Gaza.
   21+. the Top, 424 Haight St, SF.
   
   Friday, February 14th - _Infinitely One_
   Join us on our cosmic and spiritual evolution towards the unity on one.
   Caban, Ivo, Tom.
   415.525.5052
   
   Friday, February 14th - Nomad Interactive presents _Splish Valentine's
   midnight cruise_
   An intimate Valentine's midnight cruise on SF Bay with the masters of house
   Doc Martin, Jeno.
   Aqua ambience funk deck with His Boy Elroy and surprise guests.
   Will take place on a luxurious multi-level all-weather yacht.
   Presale tix only, available for $25 from Housewares.
   415.675.5605 415.273.5850 408.236.3398 916.484.4213
   
   Saturday, February 15th - Feel Good Entertainment presents _Love
   A-Fair_
   A festival of unconditional love toward mother earth and brother man.
   Tony, Spun, Thomas Michael, Charlotte the Baroness, Matthew, Andre
   Lucero, Moda, Carlos & Melanie, Harry Who? and Mattski, Essence &
   Kwashi, Tripnotix & Paucus, Seanie Boy & Lil Ricky, Disco Boy, Juice,
   Mofo, Dr.Disco (Detroit), Kereoki (Singapore), Jazz-E, Jonathan,
   BioJeff, Miah, Cory, Brainee, Spinner, Kevin Kind, Moshe, Pat Allen,
   B.V.Dub, Boomerang Fidget, Chilly Willy (Alaska).
   This event it dedicated to environmental consciousness and awareness.
   $20 presale tix go on sale Jan 15th.
   A portion of the proceeds will be donated to environmental activity
   programs.
   415.263.0483 510.888.2358 408.881.0785
   
   Saturday, February 15th - Pro-Soy presents _Techno Love Children_
   HCMF, Maya, Deaks + InTIMidator, Cloud + Drenalin, Sig, Fat Tony, mc2,
   Bryce, Special Guest.
   Free H2O, Free Chai (Nub Circus), Free Organic Food
   Presale Tix Only. Available at Drop Beat, Nub Chai 408.458.2071, Vinyl
   Rev. 408.646.9020.
   All ages. 415.635.6815

   $15 b4 midnight, $20 after.
   415.266.8215 415.266.9215 408.236.2205 916.484.3727

   Jonah Sharp, Daum (Freaky Chakra), Jenkins (XLR8R), Velocette, Astral
   Matrix, Andrew Smith (XLR8R), Payload Specialist (Voyager 1), Alaura
   (Silent).

   Electronic Art by Milton Komisar and Austin Richards

   10am-4pm.
   Tix with surcharge at BASS.
   9pm-3am, All ages, $10. the Fillmore Auditorium, 1805 Geary @
   Fillmore, SF.

Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C.
       Electronic dance, noise, spoken word, world music and more. Beats
       for your head. Sounds for your soul. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night midnight-3am - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats,
       Breakz and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
   For a _search_ interface to the calendar, see the Late Train club
   section (http://www.latetrain.com/clubs/).
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

The top ten sexually explicit lines from STAR WARS:

10.  "Get in there you big furry oaf!  I don't care what you smell!"
9.  "Luke, t that speed do you think you'll be able to pull out in time?"
8.  "Put that thing away before you get us all killed."
7.  "You've got something jammed in here real good."
6.  "Aren't you a little short for a stormtrooper?"
4.  "Sorry about the mess..."
3.  "Look at the size of that thing!"
2.  "Curse my metal body, I wasn't fast enough!"
1.  "She may not look like much, but she's got it where it counts, kid."


i couldn't resist!

Nuggles the Whump-Whump bird flew quietly above the wonderful greenness of
Happy-Tree Meadow, eagerly awaiting the cheerful humming that always
signalled the beginning of the Gubbywub Parade and Picnic, which annually
provided the Whump-Whumps with enough Gubbywub fur and flesh to last the
entire winter.

Wow, talk about weird.  I receive this email today from some person I've
never heard of.  The message reads "Now that's a spam"

The kicker?  It's addressed to 191 different people, all named *Shawna*, all
different people with different addresses, but all with that same first name
spelled the same way.  Very weird!  While somewhat amusing (and with much
rumination with regards to why on earth he did this), it's still weird to
know that some people really do have nothing fucking better to do with their
stupid lives!  :/


Scratching my head,
Shawna (of course)

proposed (in the original post) is contradictory to true "rave" ideals and
I think that we all oughtta have our acts together before we go to capitol
hill or the front lawn of the white house to rave and/or protest...

>Date: Thu, 13 Feb 1997 14:07:48 -0500 (EST)

Totally, right on... BUT now you go on to say what (we're drugophobic)?...

>    drugs will not be tolerated at thsi event, and we hope to set a system
>    where ravers woudl keep an eye out for ravers to tell them to cut out the
>    drug use  (plus, if you ahve ever been in dc in august, you will know
>that
>    durgs at that time of year, coudl well, kill you, it's so hot)  this way
>    we police ourselves and focus on the music.
...

  I will simply say that an event like this cannot go down, truly
representing raves, without allowing each and everyone one of us to do what
we want. That's what I think it's about... Loving each other for what we
are. [people could be urged to accept repsonsibility for their actions]
  It woudln't be right to tell people that since we're in Washington: you
can't be a "homosexual" or "red head" or "southerner" or "female" or
"black" or "fucking PeeWee Hermain". We are all our best when we are
ourselves. :)
  If we are going to go to Washington as ravers, then we go as ravers and
stand up for what we believe in. I won't be a wimp-ass and go up there,
perpin'... Cuz', if it's going to hit home... It should be done up right.
Besides, Slick Willy might actually take a puff [and inhale]... ya never
know... :)

plurage,

On Thu, 13 Feb 1997, Aryck wrote:

>         I've found that Odwalla "Superfood" (it comes as a funky green
> drink) gives me a ton of energy and makes me feel really clear and fresh. 
> 
>         It actually seems to live up to it's name. 

--
It is actually pretty interesting stuff; it's based around a type of
algae (genus _Spirulina_, looks like a cool little spaghetti/corkscrew
shape under the 'scope) that aparently grows rampant in Africa. They 
supposedly contain just about *everything* anyone would ever need to
survive on (in terms of nutrients and such), and was being seriously
considered as an alternative food source in many 3rd-world countries,
where it can be grown quick and cheap.  The only problem is...
it smells *AWFUL*.  ;)  I mean *real* nasty.  Odwalla covers it up real
nice with the fruit flavors, though.
Okay, enough useless factoid-ish stuff...  Have a fantastic Valentine's
day, folks!  Hope to see some of you at the Pro-Soy event this weekend; I
love you all (even if I don't have my own Valentine this year)-

-=Joe=-

From: Rhea Gossett <rhea@xinet.com>
Subject: "Splish" ??   I say: "WATCH OUT !!"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I chose to stop subscribing to the sfraves mailing list, about
three weeks ago, after being on it for 3 of the last 4 years.

But this morning, when I read my sf-raves-calendar that had come in
last night, it triggered a memory that was just too STRONG, & I felt
I just had to get back on here and post:

** From this week's SFRAVES calendar:

>Friday, February 14th - Nomad Interactive presents _Splish Valentine's
>   midnight cruise_
>   An intimate Valentine's midnight cruise on SF Bay with the masters
>   of house   Doc Martin, Jeno.
>   Aqua ambience funk deck with His Boy Elroy and surprise guests.
>   Will take place on a luxurious multi-level all-weather yacht.
>   Presale tix only, available for $25 from Housewares.
>   415.675.5605 415.273.5850 408.236.3398 916.484.4213>

Help me remember this, any of you who were there, and correct me if
I'm wrong, but wasn't Nomad Interactive the people, a couple
years back, who advertised a SF Bay cruise party, then had the
following problems:

* boat didn't leave until way after midnight - people gathering in a
huge line freezing, since before 11:00 PM on....being cajoled & cajoled
into waiting, without being given any reason why..."we're still getting
things ready, we PROMISE we're almost done getting things ready"....
finally, near 1 AM, a Rydr truck screeches up to the dock, its back doors
are flung open, and two guys tumble out with a big GENERATOR....

* they take the $20 at the ramp to get on the boat - then everyone hurrying
downstairs to a ????? buffet where a dinner of  ?????????? chicken wings
????????? and rice ??????????? was laid out, people devouring "free"
chicken wings manically....

* on the "main" dance floor, there's tables & chairs _everywhere_,
the dance floor measures about 20x15, and NO ONE will let you push back
any tables and chairs to dance....

* main sound system is terrible, muffled...but with Tracy, still
doing a great job putting her songs together, even with the system she
had...

* boat is now smelling like CHICKEN....

* an ambient area was advertised, I remember discussion on sfraves
about how Rick's girlfriend was really looking forward to that, as she
was writing a paper on ambient spaces at raves - they never set it up,
never brought the sound system...

* one and a half hour into it, the boat turns back, and  - DOCKS!
the lights come on a bit, & it's like we're in a floating
Denny's...we're done with the water portion of this ride...

* boat is now smelling like sweaty CHICKEN...

* the lights stay on low, sound system goes down a bit - but it's
not over, no, we're invited to stay - as boat crew members start to
walk around, cleaning up - they open up the doors, a gentle cold
breeze blows in....official crew members in snappy white military yacht
dress begin to stroll back & forth on the dock, some 10 feet outside
the main dance floor's windows.....

* Ti-Fred & I are just sitting, perplexed, then laughing, looking
at each other - THEN Garth throws on "Rockit"  - and we are
SO out of there....


Do I have this story right???  If so, looks to me like they're
doing it again, this time for 5 more bucks a head, and covering
themselves a bit more in the ad:  "will take place on"
a multi-level....yacht.

"Tempts me to join SFR again, just so i can go on & make this post!
There are some people out there who may be kind of new, and may not know
this little bit of history," I said to my friend Ti-Fred.

He said, "oooohh....you should post it...!"  So I did.

Hi to everybody who remembers me & Ti-Fred !

R

At 09:46 AM 2/14/97 -0700, you wrote:
>I chose to stop subscribing to the sfraves mailing list, about
>three weeks ago, after being on it for 3 of the last 4 years.
>
>But this morning, when I read my sf-raves-calendar that had come in
>last night, it triggered a memory that was just too STRONG, & I felt
>I just had to get back on here and post:
>
>** From this week's SFRAVES calendar:
>
>>Friday, February 14th - Nomad Interactive presents _Splish Valentine's
>>   midnight cruise_
>>   An intimate Valentine's midnight cruise on SF Bay with the masters
>>   of house   Doc Martin, Jeno.
>>   Aqua ambience funk deck with His Boy Elroy and surprise guests.
>>   Will take place on a luxurious multi-level all-weather yacht.
>>   Presale tix only, available for $25 from Housewares.
>>   415.675.5605 415.273.5850 408.236.3398 916.484.4213>
>
>Help me remember this, any of you who were there, and correct me if
>I'm wrong, but wasn't Nomad Interactive the people, a couple
>years back, who advertised a SF Bay cruise party, then had the
>following problems:

The party below did happen, but I can't be sure if it was Nomad Interactive.
I thought it was the people from Ameba on Haight, but to tell you the truth,
I don't remember.

>* boat didn't leave until way after midnight - people gathering in a
>huge line freezing, since before 11:00 PM on....being cajoled & cajoled
>into waiting, without being given any reason why..."we're still getting
>things ready, we PROMISE we're almost done getting things ready"....
>finally, near 1 AM, a Rydr truck screeches up to the dock, its back doors
>are flung open, and two guys tumble out with a big GENERATOR....

Yes, this happened.

>* they take the $20 at the ramp to get on the boat - then everyone hurrying
>downstairs to a ????? buffet where a dinner of  ?????????? chicken wings
>????????? and rice ??????????? was laid out, people devouring "free"
>chicken wings manically....

Yes, this happened.  The rice was pretty good though....or maybe I was just
really hungry after waiting two hours on a cold dock.

>* on the "main" dance floor, there's tables & chairs _everywhere_,
>the dance floor measures about 20x15, and NO ONE will let you push back
>any tables and chairs to dance....

Yes.

>* main sound system is terrible, muffled...but with Tracy, still
>doing a great job putting her songs together, even with the system she
>had...

I believe it was Wicked sound.  I didn't notice anything wrong with it myself.

>* boat is now smelling like CHICKEN....

Yes...Yuck!!

>* an ambient area was advertised, I remember discussion on sfraves
>about how Rick's girlfriend was really looking forward to that, as she
>was writing a paper on ambient spaces at raves - they never set it up,
>never brought the sound system...

This part is incorrect.  They had an "ambient" area with a sound system, but
they never really played ambient music.  I can remember hearing some disco
though.  About an hour into the trip, they turned the lights on and took
down all the psychedelic wallhangings and visuals....probably because they
were worried that people were going behind the tarps and gettin 420'd.  

>* one and a half hour into it, the boat turns back, and  - DOCKS!
>the lights come on a bit, & it's like we're in a floating
>Denny's...we're done with the water portion of this ride...

Yep.

>* boat is now smelling like sweaty CHICKEN...

Yep.

>* the lights stay on low, sound system goes down a bit - but it's
>not over, no, we're invited to stay - as boat crew members start to
>walk around, cleaning up - they open up the doors, a gentle cold
>breeze blows in....official crew members in snappy white military yacht
>dress begin to stroll back & forth on the dock, some 10 feet outside
>the main dance floor's windows.....

Yep, somthing like that.

>* Ti-Fred & I are just sitting, perplexed, then laughing, looking
>at each other - THEN Garth throws on "Rockit"  - and we are
>SO out of there....

We left around then too.

>Do I have this story right???  If so, looks to me like they're
>doing it again, this time for 5 more bucks a head, and covering
>themselves a bit more in the ad:  "will take place on"
>a multi-level....yacht.

Someone's doin it again, but I'm not sure if these are the same people.

Rick

From: Rob Rayle <robertr@autodesk.com>
Message-Id: <199702141835.KAA06982@klaatu.autodesk.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Fwd: RAVE ON WASHINGTON - SUMMER 1997 (fwd)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


: >    drugs will not be tolerated at thsi event, and we hope to set a system
: >    where ravers woudl keep an eye out for ravers to tell them to cut out the
: >    drug use  (plus, if you ahve ever been in dc in august, you will know
: >that
: >    durgs at that time of year, coudl well, kill you, it's so hot)  this way
: >    we police ourselves and focus on the music.                             

:   I will simply say that an event like this cannot go down, truly
: representing raves, without allowing each and everyone one of us to do what
: we want. 

	First of all, they're right about the heat & the weather. 
I've been there. It will be at least in the 90's & *very* humid.

	Second of all, this sounds like it's about a political 
action, not just about having a good time. It's about getting 
results. 

	Way back in 68, there were a bunch of hippies who 
wanted to see Eugene McCarthy get the Democratic Presidential
nomination, because they felt he sincerely wanted to end the 
Vietnam war. They cut their hair & cut out the drug use so they 
could function effectively as political activists. It was called
getting "clean for Gene". 

	Now, I suggest that if all you want to do is party, 
don't go to this thing. This is about political activism for
rave tolerance - we have to show raving's *best* side. Part of
this thing is public relations.

	If you want to fight for drug legalization, that's a
*different* political action. And I doubt that the best way to
fight for that would be a drug-in on the White House lawn anyway.

Some of you might remember that I posted a while back, asking for help in
preparing my mother for her first rave.  I'd like to thank everyone for
their responses.  It helped a lot.

I ended up reading a lot of the responses to my mom.  I also had many
long talks with her about drugs.  I made a tape of all my friends talking
about their first rave, their first time on e, what the rave scene means
to them, etcetera.  My mom and I have listened to most of it already.

As a result, I think my mom will have some fun (unfortunately, she hates
techno) and I don't think she'll die of shock at her first party.

So, tomorrow night, my mother will be attending Euphonic Genesis in San
Jose.  I'm helping throw this party, so I'm gonna try to convince her to
come early and watch us set up.  I want her to see how much energy and
love goes into throwing a party.

If you're not already going to one of those big parties in The City, try
to come to Euphonic Genesis and meet my mom.  Trust me, it's worth it. 
My mom's a stud!  She's pretty, too.  And single!!!!  Any 40-somethingers
out there looking for a hot 40-something babe?  Come meet Libby's mom!

And, if you don't know me yet, you can meet me too!

--Libby

Date: Fri, 14 Feb 1997 14:23:28 -0800 (PST)

Attention Dance Producers and DJs

I have several pieces of studio gear for sale. All the equipment was bought
new, and has only seen use in my home studio.

Yamaha TX16W Stereo Sampler: Rack mount 12 bit sampler with great chunky
sound (brilliant for drums). 8 individual outs + stereo out, memory
expanded to 6 MEGS, includes all updated system software, three sets of
sound libraries (2 limited European sets), and my own collection of samples
made over four years. $500 obo

Kawai 16 input line mixer: 8 stereo channels/16 input line/keyboard mixer.
Each channel has 2 auxillary sends, pan, fader volume. 2 mic inputs,
low/med/high output switches. Very high sound quality, very quiet. Great as
a submixer for keyboards or sampler outputs, also good for digital
mastering. $300 obo

Roland D110 Synthesizer: Rack mount, multi-timbral synth. Uses PCM samples
and digital synthesis. 6 individual outs + stereo outs. Great sounds. With
additional sound card (Analogue Synth Sounds -awesome!) LCD display has
characters out, so needs light service, hence cheap price. $200 obo

Anyone who's interested in any of the above, should e-mail me here, or call
me @ xlr8r 415/861.7583

ALSO,

I'm clearing out about 4 or 5 crates of my record collection, I need the room.
Mostly HOUSE, ranging from some classic Chicago and NY stuff, good unusual
garage, some older imports, lots of solid workable uncommon house records
(mostly priced @ $2), a small amount of techno/experimental, some soul and
disco and the odd rarity. I'm still pulling stuff, but anyone who might be
interested should e-mail me, and I'll let you know when things are ready.

Respect
Andrew

On Fri, 14 Feb 1997, Rob Rayle wrote:
> 	Now, I suggest that if all you want to do is party, 
> don't go to this thing. This is about political activism for
> rave tolerance - we have to show raving's *best* side. Part of
> this thing is public relations.
> 
> 	If you want to fight for drug legalization, that's a
> *different* political action. And I doubt that the best way to
> fight for that would be a drug-in on the White House lawn anyway.

I disagree.  The use of drugs is probably the number one problems folks
have with raves - at least it's the aspect the news shows focus on the
most.  Pretending that that aspect doesn't exist, or that it can be
separated from "raving", wouldn't be a credible statement for these folks.

	Brian

will propel you for a long time, with no wiry-ness like a lot of 'stimulants',

myself.  I find a tablespoon of Spirulina powder, mixed in some liquid, and one
powerbar, and i can crank stone like a fiend, or dance for hours.  Initially
after ingestion, however, you may feel a little sleepy for .5-1.0 hours, whill
you assimilate the substances.

Hi Everyone!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Love -A-Fair was DaBombbbbbbbbbbbb......

I had soooo muchhhhh funnnnn!!!!!! :) The vibe was pretty good, not like
the
usual HomeBase party vibe, the decorations were Amazzzingg! The people were
Extra Nice, the candy extra sweet and everything was just good :) 

Thank you so much to Lara, Stariana, Rhona, Ryan, Ace (you rule!),
Fernando, Eric,
extra Special thanKs to Jason :) who else? that cool girl with the leopard
pants who showed me the slinky [sp?] trick, Lara's friends from Sonoma, and
that other guy I met at the Karma party... (I can't remember! I can't
remember! was it Eric?)  and not to forget Alex :o) and everyone else that
was there who helped the vibe! :)

I had a greeaaattt Time! :o)

Best parts of the night:
* They turned the lights on and the music off around midnight, but our vibe
kept
  going and we made our own music! then the lights went out again and the
music
  started playing again... It was just something you'd have to have been
there to 
  really understand! ;o)

* Johnathan was spinning good stuff (even though I didn't stay there for
*that* long)
  I specially liked the GrassMonkey tune ;O) or is that BrassMonkey? either
way...it 
  was rad! :o)

* Hanging out with everyone! :o)


Worst parts of the night:

Overall, this party 'PHAT' :o)

PlUr PlUR PlUR Plur!

so...which one was better?  

yeah, i'll bet you would like to know that!  =]

Deepfog Itinerary---

800 pm...all is well at da home base.  

915 pm...the first deepfog set starts after many rude interruptions by 
the plug strip/circuit breakers.  Great work from the electrical folx and 
Sean Murray.  

1045pm...the first deepfog set comes to an end...and he is informed that 
he'll also be CLOSING the room too (500-630 am) since bv dub got caught 
in an electrical storm or somethin...oh well, i don't mind driving!

1145 pm...arriving at the tekno love children, which is stationed at the 
secret rebel base.  skaters doin their grindy thing across the street.  a 
mysteriously funny curly topped dude busts out these glo-sticks to hand 
them out with the "Warmth" flyers (no purchase necessary must be 
open-minded to 
play)...420...talk...dance...420...talk...dance...420...ohp!  time to 
go!  

300 am...the shuttle pod 'el-baz' departs for starbase 23 so the fog can 
get some more rekkids...

420 am...no sorry kids, nothing exciting at this time.  on the road to 
the home base again after a yummy 
vegan-organic-fat-free-zippo-zippo-breakfast-burrito!  

503 am...entering the home base...the b((m (he always comes back to ya!)  
finishes his set with some fat-ass rekkid that i must have completely 
missed out on a few years ago...

630 am...set ends...off to an uncharted planet...hung out with 3 really 
cool people.  

830 am...at Andronico's in Berkeley...trying to find some of that yummy 
meuslix again...

930 am...after trying to find some street in Berkeley which apparently 
doesn't exist in the Berkeley map...now arriving at the secret rebel base 
to rendevous with a friend to give them a ride...always glad to help!

NOW...14 swedish pancakes later, i get to tell you which party was 
better.  the answer?  well, maybe i'll tell you later.  

nah.  i'll tell you.  

the answer is...they were both excellent parties, well decorated and well 
thought out.  one of them had too mmany people or was too hot, though, 
and the other was a little less personal because it was big.  big doesn't 
necessarily mean bad, though, and we did find some fans to turn on at the 
other event.  but be careful about packin in so many.  

but in my opinion, they were both great parties.  deep

 The party went all night.. 
 I heard about the bomb..  It was probably just some people talking about
how bomb the party was. And some dood on Acid just took it all out of
context. Or something.
 I myself, was not tripping off no bombs.. I just didn't want the party to
get busted.  It's usually all over once them lights come on.
 Fat, Dope, tight ass party. Although, the music never seemed to peak. But
shi, I was probably just E'in to hard. And my legs, my legs were dead.  I
could only dance for like 5 minutes, then it was time to take another 30
minute nap. Hopefully my second wind will kick in tonight at Spundae's!
 My friend Tim lost his wallet at Love Affair...  So if anyone knows
anything about that..  He would like to hear from you..   You could page
him @ 510.607.0223. He is pretty depressed about not having no ID to get
into Spunfreaks tonight.
 Anyways..  I had fun.. I was not suprized at all.  I knew the night would
turn out as it did. I am used to it...

Just call me Mr Unapproachable.

At 03:32 PM 2/16/97 -0800, you wrote:
>My friends and I tried to go to Love-affair.  We got there at about 11:30
        (snippity-snip)
>work and took off.  I also hear from another guy that there was a bomb
>threat.  So what's the right story?
Matthew Wietzke

I showed up at 10:00 in a fidgety panic, in fear of missing my set; found
out I wasn't due on until 3:00; and decided to take a nap in the chill room
under the REMguidance of Deepfog's mellofunky. Woke up at 11:00 to the sound
of grinding guitars and crashing snares, the kind of music you might expect
of the Jesus & Mary Chain after a weekend K bender..

What's this?   A rock and roll band in the the chill room?  Catsup on my
eggs? CD's in my tapedeck?  Muslims in my Israel?  C'est bizarre.  It was a
bit disconcerting, just because I've never seen anything of the sort before.
It certainly wasn't /chill/, but then again, chill rooms ain't what they
used to be.  That kind of got me to thinking about organizers like Feelgood
& CoolWorld among others, who sort of have a different vision of parties...a
bit more eclectic, not strictly  limited to the conventional
techno-in-one-room and ambient-in-the-other.  Sort of more like just a big
"party" with a focus on the rave but not limited to just that.  It's weird
only because it's unexpected.

There was a bit of disco in the back-back-back room, which I thought was a
bit refreshing; kind of takes the edge off of things, you know?

I think the confusion abouth the bomb was that someone called up Ray Vonie
and said, "JondaBomb is going to be tearing shit up tonight."  Then,
naturally, Mr. Vonie wanted to know where Jonathan daBombathan was: did he
have his records, and enough water and cigarettes to get him through his
set?  No one could find Jonathan, so they had to turn on the lights and off
the music,  shouting, "Jonathan!  Where's JondaBomb?"  Finally they found
him huddled in the corner in an abandoned knapsack, and from what I heard,
Jondabomb delivered an explosive set.  But then again, this is just what I
heard.  Things ain't alway what you hear.

~b))merang

Cybertribe,

What's up?  I moved out to SF in October, and was fortunate enough to meet
John Kowamoto (another SFraves member) who was looking for a roommate here
in San Francisco.  I moved in in December along with one of John's
co-workers at Excite.  Our three month lease is up at the end of this
month, but my roommate Gunter and I want to stay on for another year.
John will be buying a place of his own.

We're looking for a roommate to share our awesome apartment near
Japantown.  It's at 66 Cleary Court, right off Laguna and Geary.  It's a
three bedroom condo on the 7th floor of a fifteen story high-rise.  There
are two bathrooms, open kitchen, dishwasher, washer, dryer, tons of closet
space, balconies off every room.  There's even a doorman and two
elevators.  There's always parking in front of the building.

Gunter and I both work down in Mountain View and commute back and forth
every day.  I work as a software developer and DJ and produce music as
well.  If you've got good credit, can commit to a year lease and can
afford $600 a month, give me a call or send me e-mail.  We'll set up a
time for you to come by.  The number here is: 415.928.7901.

peace and love,
Marshal "Mars" Villarosa
