(This was written by Mark, not Amy)

well well well . Another smashing party of social macrocosms and techno 
insanity at Club homebase.whats this about a damn bomb threat?
the only people who would do such a thing would be F.G.E's competitiors 
and we all died last night , who would go to their raves? A hollow ploy.
Ive never been to a party that large before that actually held a tangible 
vibe besides the gathering. it must have had a lot to do with the 
Valentine factor. It was nice to see Lil' Ricky spinning along with the 
rest of the Fremont heads gathered round.Nothing kicks my ass more than 
that main room:700+ Heads,Tony rockin' us to the next dimension of 
musical consciousness,the neon figures dancing in the distance and the 
commeraderie of everyone ex'ed out of their minds. it was beuitiful.
	still, one complaint. When are these greedy fools going to 
release us from the water monopoly they have us under? No water aloud in, 
no faucets,and 2 dollars to buy what would cost us about 2 cents by 
turning on the faucet in our kitchen sink.It is almost evil what they are 
doing. Everyone needs water. Especially in a place where they have to 
remain for 12 hours of dancing, sweating, Eing,Frying,and mass socializing?
A guy who has just enough money to pay the ridiculous price of 25 dollars 
to get in might not have any more for water. So is he just fucked? Pretty 
much.
			
	sincerly, Mark the raveslave.

I think anyone who intends to throw a party, or is interested in some
authorities point of view would do well to read Lotus (v.1 iss.7).  There;s
a really good interview with the LA Fire Dept in there, that really spells
out a lot of stuff.  Safety, Legal, Permitting, type issues, and what happened
on NYE in LA.  There's also coverage of the whole NYE scene, busts, etc.. with
a lot of details.

Good stuff.  Thanks to the people at Lotus!

>

>hill or the front lawn of the white house to rave and/or protest...

>>    is  (as it is out here, we are the most integrated and least racist,
>>    sexist and homophobic of other predominant subcultures).
>
>Totally, right on... BUT now you go on to say what (we're drugophobic)?...
>
>>    drugs will not be tolerated at thsi event, and we hope to set a system
>>    where ravers woudl keep an eye out for ravers to tell them to cut out
the
>>    drug use  (plus, if you ahve ever been in dc in august, you will know
>>that
>>    durgs at that time of year, coudl well, kill you, it's so hot)  this way
>>    we police ourselves and focus on the music.


Two things, It is foolish to believe that drug use can be seperated from
rave culture.  But most drug use is illegal.  That said, people have to
decide what they want to accomplish.  In the civil rights movements of the
60's people made
a conscious choice to break or disregard certain laws, because they felt
that they were wrong, they realized the consequences and were willing to go
to jail for them.  Many of the drugs that raver are associated with carry
_very sever_
mandatory penalties for their possession and use, this is not something to
be taken lightly.  Drugs like Pot and Nitrous may be considered more
recreational and while I personally believe that all drugs should be
legalized my question is how will open drug use at an event like this best
forward this cause?
Traditionally, groups that hae come to Washington (African American Civil
Rights Movement in the 60's, American Indian Civil Rights Movement in the
70's,
Vietnam Peace Movement in the 70's, Million Man March in the 90's) Have all
been peaceful, but forcefull demonstrations where the participants are on
display for the world.  What message will be show the world if as a speaker
is talking, the shhhhhIIIIISSSHHHHHH! of a nitrous tank can be heard in the
background, or if three young people have to go to the emergency because
they took too much GHB?  I think it's well within the boundaries of the
organizers of such an event to request that people abstain from the use of
illegal substances for the duration of the demonstration/celebration.
After all, it's
only a few hours and you have the rest of eternity to Rave and take drugs,
if that's your thing.  Besides, there will be hella kool after-parties :)

Subject: Here is another poem I found!
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

As dark and morbid as some of these poems may be, they were a release
for me during a difficult time in my life. Some of you wanted me to post
another so here it is. Have a delicious day! Peace n Love Erik!

Tic...Toc...

The strongest of men,
not one, and not ten,
can hinder the hands of a clock.
With each passing day,
the hours they weigh,
as a chain round the neck with a rock.
No manner of coin,
no ally you join,
will waylay the dawn from its breaking.
And when all's said and done,
there is nowhere to run,
the morning of that final awakening.
Yet immortal we feel,
and made up of steel
we pretend to not see the rust.
Which gnaws us away,
with each passing day.
It's there....on that you may trust.
So color your hair.
Lift your face if they stare	
at the signs of your oncoming night.
And deny your mortality,
the one TRUE reality.
It is there...if just out of sight.

Yes there was a bomb threat as far as I know.  Security was searching through 
garbage cans, behind all the buildings, all over.  Somebody doesn't like the 
promoters at Feel Good Entertainment I guess.  The question I have is:  what 
happened that caused the fire truck, the ambulance, and the 2 or 3 cop cars to 
all show up while I was driving away at 3:30?  Oh, and why was Charlotte (The 
Baroness) scheduled to spin from 5:30 - 7:00 AM?  I was really looking forward 
to her set, but I wasn't about to stay at that size of party for so long.  I 
was happy to hear Deepfog spin, and in the main room Andre Lucero(sp?) and 
Thomas Michael laid down some *intense* tracks.   
 
I introduced myself to a few of you, by the laser, but I didn't catch names 
very well being right next to those speakers and all.  I was the guy in the 
grey long-sleeved shirt, shaved head and glasses.  Say hello again if we met!  
Great evening!  Thanks.

Date: Mon, 17 Feb 1997 10:41:19 -0800 (PST)
From: Sami Khoury <khoury@hyperreal.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: NRR: ActiveX trojan horse (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.970217103738.12114A-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This might be of interest to some of you -- particularly if you use
Microsoft's Internet Explorer.

	Sami

---------- Forwarded message ----------
> From: Ellen Guon Beeman <ellen@illusionmachines.com>
> To: 'IMI List' <imi-list@illusionmachines.com>
> Subject: ActiveX trojan horse
> Date: Monday, February 17, 1997 11:06 AM
>
> 
> Well, the nightmare that Microsoft did its best to snow job us into
> thinking didn't really exist has begun...
> 
> Somebody in Germany has developed an ActiveX control which can be
invisibly 
> downloaded while viewing a webpage using Internet Explorer 3.1.  The
> ActiveX program runs automatically, and if you have Quicken on your hard
> drive (a popular financial package), and if you're using Quicken to pay
> your bills electronically, the ActiveX program will insert a transaction
> into your next electronic bill paying session that will transfer money to
> the hackers' account.
> 
> Microsoft's response?
> "Clearly, ActiveX will get a bad rap here, but that's a mistake, this
> involves all executables," Wills said. "We are concerned that users
> understand that all executable content on the Internet is potentially
> dangerous. No user should download applets from unknown sources. The
basic
> message here is: don't take candy from strangers. The problems are
becoming 
> a bit better understood, but we've really got to educate users."
> 
> 
> This is BS.  Java applets downloaded from the internet CANNOT touch your
> harddrive.  They can only touch information from their original internet
> site.  That was built in as part of Java security design.  ActiveX on the
> other hand BINDS directly with Windows '95 (and soon the Macintosh), so
> whatever you can do with Windows, can be done by the ActiveX program.
>  AFTER this was pointed out to Microsoft execs, Microsoft hacked in
> "Authenticode"(tm) which is a digital signature that THEY will give out
to
> people who register their ActiveX programs.  The idea being that after
the
> ActiveX controls destroys your data, you know who to sue...  This is BS
as
> well.  It's theoretically been shown that the ActiveX control can wipe
out
> all trace of itself on your hard drive, or it can plant a program bomb
set
> to go off 6 months after you ran it.
> 
> In a nutshell, if you're going to use Internet Explorer avoid ActiveX
like
> the plague.
> 
> This has been a public service announcement...
> 
> Full article follows:  (It's been VERY interesting that I only heard this
> ONCE on CNN at 3 in the morning, and could find very little information
> about it on the net otherwise...)
> 
> (One other note, when Java was first released hackers found several
> security holes in it as well.  The Java team promptly corrected the
> problems, and there hasn't been a breach since (and they're still
> trying)... No, "It's the users fault, we must educate them with our
> superior knowledge because they do not understand" psychobabble, they
FIXED 
> it.
> 'nuff said.)
> 
> 
> Microsoft's Security Advice To Users:Don't Take Candy From Strangers
>        Microsoft's Security Advice To Users:Don't Take Candy From
Strangers 
>  (2/6/97; 5:44 p.m. EST)
>  By Clare Haney, TechWire
> 
>  REDMOND, Washington -- The activities of a group of German hackers in
> Germany a week ago has forced Microsoft to further accelerate its
attempts
> to publicize the inherent dangers lurking on the Internet.
> 
>  Last Wednesday, the Chaos Computer Club, a well-established hacker
> organization headquartered in Hamburg, demonstrated on German television
> how its members could theoretically electronically transfer funds from an
> individual's bank account without using a personal identification number
or 
> a transaction number.
> 
> The demo centered around the hackers being able to gain access to the
> transaction list contained within Intuit's personal accounting software
> Quicken via an ActiveX control, while using Microsoft's Explorer Web
> browser.
> 
> Once a user has accessed the Web site containing the ActiveX control and
> the applet has recognized that Quicken is on the victim's machine, the
> control gives the accounting software a transfer order which is then
saved
> along with other Quicken pending transfer orders. The damage is done the
> next time the user sends off their pending transfer orders to the bank.
> 
> All the orders would then be executed, including the ActiveX one, meaning
> that money could potentially be spirited out of the user's account,
without 
> their knowledge, and into that of the hackers.
> 
> Cornelius Willis, group product manager for Internet platforms at
> Microsoft, stressed the theoretical nature of the TV demonstration,
saying
> "We have yet to determine if there has been a security breach. This is
the
> usual thing people do - carry out a demo and get a lot of publicity. But
we 
> do take this kind of thing very seriously."
> 
>  He revealed that Microsoft has already made contact with CCC and is
> "encouraging them to co-operate," although the hackers have yet to
release
> the ActiveX control to the company so that they can check it out. The
Club
> is promising to publicly release the ActiveX control on the Web on
February 
> 20.
> 
>  Willis went on to emphasize the general nature of the problem.
> 
> "Clearly, ActiveX will get a bad rap here, but that's a mistake, this
> involves all executables," Wills said. "We are concerned that users
> understand that all executable content on the Internet is potentially
> dangerous. No user should download applets from unknown sources. The
basic
> message here is: don't take candy from strangers. The problems are
becoming 
> a bit better understood, but we've really got to educate users."
> 
> He added that Microsoft expects to highlight this issue with a program to
> be launched within the next few weeks, that among other things will
involve 
> bringing a chat site on Internet security already hosted on the company's
> Web site more to the fore.
> 
> He pointed to the fact that the current version of Internet Explorer 3.0
is 
> the only Web browser to include code signing, a feature Microsoft calls
> Authenticode, allowing users to identify "with a high degree of
certainty"
> the author of a Java applet, an ActiveX control or a plug-in and to
> determine that the component in question hasn't been tampered with in
> transit to the user's desktop.
> 
> Willis also recommends that, in order to ramp up their Internet security
> protection, corporations should establish internal testing organizations
to 
> give such components a digital certificate certifying that they've been
> shown to be non-malicious to potential end users.
> 
>  For Intuit, Mark Goines, the company's international vice president,
> asserts that its Quicken software already contains a stringent review
> process for any transaction comprising authorization, review,
verification, 
> review and reverification stages.
> 
> Goines said that the TV program provoked very little reaction, but that a
> few worried Intuit customers did contact the company's German office.
Like
> Microsoft's Willis, he stresses the theoretical nature of the hackers'
> demonstration and adds that Intuit German staff want to investigate some
of 
> the claims made by CCC in the program.
> 
>   Related articles from:
> 
> 
>   Advanced Search
> 
> 
> 
> Copyright (c) CMP Media, 1996.
> 
> 
> 
>

	id AA12076; Mon, 17 Feb 97 10:45:48 PST

Message-Id: <v02140b1aaf2de769dbe1@[17.205.32.116]>

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: qhelp@newton.apple.com (Ivan Vasquez)
Subject: saturday review
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Saturday night was tha BOMB! It's the first time in a few years that I went
to 2 raves in one night and my first time partying with Deepfog. What's up
Deep? The first party, "Love A-fair," was huge. Massives are cool, but
there's usually that good old gangster element around that brings a bad
vibe with it. The place was awesome though. You should've seen the
decorations and special effects and all the other cool stuff. There were
about 5 or 6 DJs spinning different shit in different rooms at the same
time. In one room, there were 2 DJs spinning at the same time on 4
turntables. I love that shit! That was fucking awesome to watch. We stayed
at the first party from about 8 pm (before the party even started) unitl
around 11 pm, when we took off for party #2, Techno Love Children.

TLC was way smaller but WAY Phatter! The vibe was phenomenal (sp?)! We got
into the place and my body just started to move. I couldn't even help
myself. By this time, my E was making me feel really goooood, so I danced
my ass off to the hardcore shit that was being spun. My only complaint
about the location is that the dance room was Oh Sooo Fucking HoT! I swear,
it was about 120=B0 in the room, and if you started dancing, it only took
about a second to feel sweat dripping down your face. When it came to
dancing though, I couldn't help myself because it was sick-ass track after
sick-ass track, so I only left the dance floor when I was severely over
heated. When 3 am came I didn't want to leave, but it was time cuz one of
my friends had to go home to his woman, so I reluctantly stepped outside
the building where the party was and cooled off. Luckily, there were some
sick ass skaters skating the BART station across the street. It made me
wish I had my skate, but it was cool just to watch them.

What's up for next weekend?

Ivan

From: Adam Guevara <aguevara@rely.com>
To: "'Bay Area Funksters'" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Ok, so I lied.
Date: Mon, 17 Feb 1997 11:10:36 -0800
X-Mailer:  Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.994.63

Are you out there?  

I'd still be asleep if I didn't hafta work today either....

Anyways, the subject tells it all.  Yes I was out and about this
weekend, Yes there were some terrific parties.  Yes, I'm sooo sorry to
hear about the 'incident' regarding the boat thang. But lets get to
reviewing..

Friday:  Didn't make it to D-7 for that Trance thang (_Infinite One_)
just because if I did I'd possibly be another fatality on V-day as well.
 So I chilled it @ the mappoint buyin' wrekkads & talking to Dhrien a
bit about future parties in the Santa Cruz area. Im soo hyped about
seeing this scene flourish again in other areas of the bay (but more on
that later).  Got home early (1:45) and slept.

Saturday:  Had a nice day @ the beach, waiting, sitting, looking....
Something, anything... But nothing in regards to seeing anything on this
thing about something in regards to that trainwreck-thing.  Oh well.  We
(myself and a few other partygoers I found on the beach) spent the
remainder of the day playing, "spot the raver" on the beach...

Went to F-8 later and chatted with MARS, saw some REAL promoter drama
(All the while im thinking that I'll soon be getting involved with these
kind of politics, uhg...).  But also caught up with 411 with the
many'o'DJ's about the boat partie, D-7,cancelled Trainwrecks (too bad no
one updated the VM#). and what was happening where tonite.  Ended up
going to...

_Euphonic Genesis_ in SJ.  Putting my faith in the South bay scene
(again).
It was a phat partie.  Not too many people for the space (large
warehouse /w multiple rooms) but a really, really nice vibe.  The
"gansta" element was nil (I actually felt pretty Ganstaish w/my black
and grey clothes and biege trenchcoat).  I saw Pengo (hey dude) and said
hi to (Matt?).  All though the music was nice and diverse, I stayed
pretty true to my word and really chilled more than dance.  Well,
actually every time a PD Cruser rolled by, the sound would almost cut
off... Which made it hard to dance (drum roll building, building,
BUILDING and then... Cut - volume drop - uhh. hmm.) .  So I pretty much
had a nice time zoning 420'ing and chillin...

Sunday: A friend calls from Cupertino, it's the afterparty for E.G. at
sone of the promoters house.  I called a few people to whom I was
suppoed to hook up with, Hmm they're out doing things with thier SO's I
guess.. So off I head, record bag in hand.
	A very VERY crazy E-party is going on as I get there.  People chilln on
the lawn, some nice domestic trance and breakbeat pumpin thru the
speakers.  Others dancing on the tables thru the kitcken.  Mucho 420 and
other E-partie consumeables.  Nice lil DJ setup. I kickit, chatting with
some of the _EU_ promoters compleminting them on a fine job.  party gets
crazier and zanyer but a lot of fun.  Everyone pretty much packs ut up
and carries to a small office space in Sunnyvale.  Drop by for a few
hours and let one of the promoters spin on my decks (everyone wants to
be a DJ, and personally,I think that's a good thing.).  I jump on for a
bit to express my style and several hard tracks later I give the tables
back.  
Everything winds well into midnite when I remember that Im supposed to
be here (@ work ) by 8.  ugh.  I hate Mondays. 

I really have to say that I feel that the south bay has promise.  SJ in
97' seems like SF in 94': lil' intimate parties, E-parties.  The fuse is
lit.  A new crew relocating in Santa Cruz.  A bunch of Rebels in the
SoBay plotting and planning.  A new trance store on the horizon in SJ.
The time is coming, the seeds are spreading.

"Stay Connected"

---Adam

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Feb 17 12:55:10 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id MAA22149; Mon, 17 Feb 1997 12:55:10 -0800 (PST)

Received: from localhost (mayer@localhost) by netcom10.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)
	id MAA15207; Mon, 17 Feb 1997 12:55:02 -0800
Message-Id: <199702172055.MAA15207@netcom10.netcom.com>
To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: NRR: ActiveX trojan horse (fwd)
Date: Mon, 17 Feb 97 12:55:01 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Yeah, this ActiveX crap is just the tip of the iceberg. And people
shouldn't be getting all dreamy in the shorts about Java either. Cool
thing, crappiest UI toolkit I've ever seen, and nothing revolutionary about
it other than good marketing for a ho-hum language. Unfortunately, it's
really no more secure than anything else once embedded into Netscape,
especially if someone wasn't real careful w/ LiveConnect extensions in your
browser installation. Nonetheless, given its widespread usage/adoption, it
will eventually get there and give us some cool new toys. I'm certainly
planning on working on it... but quite frankly, I would trust Java applets
more if there were a half-decent public domain browser using it, so the
source could be "peer reviewed" by computer scientists and hobbyists
worldwide. "peer review" is one of the main reasons why I trust Linux as an
OS...

The post I'm forwarding below is right-on w/r/t the overall problem of this
lemming-like industry that seems to be accepting and perpetrating shitware
from Microsoft. Like the author below, I too have spent untold hours
getting W95 to "behave" on my laptop, and often the only reason why I don't
have to do the usual wipe-filesystem-and-reinstall is that I can manipulate
my entire MSDOS/Win95 filesystem from Linux and use backup and directory
comparison scripts (e.g.
http://www.eit.com/software/winterp/scrnsnaps/dircmp.gif,
http://www.eit.com/software/winterp/examples/dircmp.lsp) I've written to
check for damaged stuff and suck the appropriate undamaged files off of a
backup tape.

I find it hard to imagine that Win95/NT is the operating system "for the
rest of us", given the lengths I've had to go in order to make it behave
(having about 12 years of professional software engineering experience,
having the ability to run the Linux OS on my laptop which allows me to fix
a damaged Win95 filesystem, and having the luxury of a daily DAT backup of
my systems). Now I'm not dissing the usefulness of certain apps built on
MS-Win (e.g. CakeWalk 5.0, Turbotax, various games and media apps that I
use) but it is amazing how brittle some of these apps become when built on
such a shaky foundation. And you wouldn't believe some of the crap software
developers have to go through in order to deliver windows apps. No wonder
people get computerphobic. Hell, I'm a computer scientist and Windows makes
me computerphobic....

------- Forwarded Message

Microsoft at Apogee 

by John Walker
http://www.fourmilab.ch/autofile/www/autofile.html 

This document is in the public domain.

It's been a heady week for Bill Gates. As Microsoft stock hit a new
all-time high, he was hailed on the front page of the International Herald
Tribune as the superstar of the World Economic Forum at Davos, eclipsing
mere heads of state, enthralling the audience with geeky details of how
Office 97 would fuse desktop, Internet, and Intranet into a seamless
whole. Afterward Bill was invited to a lengthy tete a tete with French
President Jacques Chirac, whose finance minister had, the week before, said
that Europe's economic crisis could best be solved by the emergence of one
or more "European Bill Gates".

What's a crusty contrarian to make of all this?

I think Microsoft have peaked. Do I subscribe to the fantasy that the Java
gang or US$500 network computers are going to displace Windows? That OS/2
will Warp into Number One? That Apple will become the NeXT de-facto
standard? That in a year or two disgusted Windows users will be lining up
to buy Linux? Of course not--I am a contrarian, not crazy. Microsoft's
rapid growth has been fueled by taking over more and more sectors of the PC
business and gaining effective control of standards so that, once the
engine is up to speed, competitors cannot keep up with Microsoft's
development and marketing capabilities. Nobody can outspend Microsoft, even
in a narrow sector, once Bill decides he wants to own it. Microsoft have
been able to dominate the sectors of the industry they deem strategic by
deliberate rapid change, often coordinated among multiple products. Since
no other vendor has similar control over operating systems, development
tools, and applications, Microsoft are alone in being able to do this.

It is now possible to discern the technological vision Microsoft have for
their customers in the years to come. It will be a COM-mediated world of
ActiveX (which, of course, will continue to be re-named once or twice a
year to embody whatever buzz word is on the tip of the industry's
collective tongue) components, flitting here and there across networks,
interacting in sophisticated and subtle ways with one another's methods,
accessing databases hither and yon and components everywhere with DCOM, all
under the benevolent supervision of an evolved NT which embraces objects in
its very kernel.

But this is complete bullshit, and it will never work, at least not very
well or for very long. Why? Because the underlying architecture lacks even
the most rudimentary security and configuration control mechanisms required
for a distributed system of such complexity. Academic and industrial
computer scientists have invested a great deal of effort into this problem,
and have come to understand at least some of the requirements. Microsoft
have none of them, and these are not things you can retrofit--at least not
without discarding one's entire investment to date and doing everything
over. Now, this is something Microsoft have been very willing to ask of
their customers, but there comes a time when the lost investment becomes so
great customers refuse to accept it. Do they bolt to another vendor? No,
they simply stop updating their systems, continue to use the software they
have which gets the job done quite well, thank you, and begin to bank the
productivity gains which come from *not* throwing everything out and
retraining users on something new every two years.

In the 1960's and 70's, many IBM 360/370 sites ran DOS for years and years
because it got the job done, and because the pain of "upgrading" to the
hardware requirements and the reprogramming required for OS/360 was simply
not something they could afford, nor did the benefits justify it. I think
we're reaching that point with Microsoft's PC software.

Anecdotal ground truth: in the last month, I have attempted to install
32-bit updates to three separate commercial Windows applications I have
been using for three years or more, each a best-seller in its market, all
bearing the Windows 95 logo, and claiming full compatibility with Windows
NT 4.0, which I am running. Three times I have failed to get the update to
work. In the most recent case, an update to the bank order-entry software I
use, which does nothing other than display forms and write files, modified
*thirty-seven* files in my C:\WINNT directory tree (without asking for
confirmation first), then crashed when attempting to import the database
from the previous version with a numeric error code from ODBC. Customer
support for problems like this in these enlightened times seems to have
converged onto the All Purpose Answer: "Reformat your hard drive, then
re-install Windows and all your applications".

I have a life which does not leave me adequate free time to play system
administrator, continually repairing damage inflicted by Microsoft. So, I
think I'll just stay with what I have, thanks. And I think I am not
alone.

When I look at Microsoft's current product line (which I avoid doing as
much as possible, I must confess), the problem is not that it lacks
features--God, most of it has way too many features for its own good, and I
suspect 90% of the users never discover nor use a majority of them--but
that it is bug-infested junk. What users need is not ActiveXYZ, the
NanoGenetic TransSpecies API, etc., etc., endless etc. but software which
works properly and does not crash. Jamming 1.5 megabytes of roach-motel
USER and GDI code into the kernel of NT 4.0 to "improve performance" shows
Microsoft lack the basic competence and/or willingness to provide a
reliable operating system.  And that has been a solved problem since the
1960's. Now they're going to sell us a global distributed component model
secure multi-platform multi-media object oriented operating system. Right.

I think we're approaching a pause, where the pain of staying on the
treadmill outweighs any possible benefit. I wish it were possible to
measure the pain, anguish, and lost productivity resulting from Windows
applications installing a mismatched set of DLLs in users' WINDOWS
directory. The distributed component world will be just like that, only
thousands of times worse. I think users will simply stay with what they
have, and Microsoft will be unable to push more down their throats.

When you consider how much the PC hardware industry has been driven by
upgrades needed to run new Microsoft releases, the consequences of this go
well beyond the software industry. Also, Microsoft's stock multiple
envisions growth continuing at the present rate. A mature market, where
sales plateau and product lines become stable, does not sustain a P/E
greater than 50. By comparison, Washington State's other near-monopoly,
Boeing, trades at 34 times earnings, and IBM at 14.

Absent a colossal strategic blunder (which is possible, but unlikely in the
extreme), I don't see Microsoft falling. But I think we'll soon experience
a kind of plateau in the PC world that resembles the mainframe business in
the 70's or minicomputers after DEC and Data General had staked out their
territory.

The technological frontier will not close, but it will be somewhere other
than the PC software business. In terms of my 1989 nanotechnology screed, I
think PC software is moving from the "Oh Wow"

http://www.fourmilab.ch/autofile/www/section2_84_3.html 

to the "Oh Well" stage on the following page. Microsoft may succeed in
continuing to grow by diversification into media ventures and plush toys:

(http://www.microsoft.com/corpinfo/press/1997/feb97/actimate.htm), 

but will see revenues from PC software transition from exponential growth
to cyclical performance tracking the overall economy which is typical of
mature industries.

I'm certainly not about to run out and short a huge block of Microsoft
stock--momentum often carries a trend much further than rational
calculation justifies. But it will be interesting to observe how what
Microsoft have in the pipeline is accepted, and how the landscape of the PC
market will shift if and when users conclude, "Enough, already".

------- End of Forwarded Message

There is a simple solution to this problem.
Simply goto the Microsoft home page, download all the ActiveX controls. And
if you goto a WEB site that starts to install another ActiveX component,
Leave before it finishes.

Peas...

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Feb 17 13:32:42 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id NAA02926; Mon, 17 Feb 1997 13:32:42 -0800 (PST)

          by dfw-ix4.ix.netcom.com (8.8.4/8.8.4)

Date: Mon, 17 Feb 1997 15:31:58 -0600 (CST)
Received: from smx-ca1-07.ix.netcom.com(205.186.78.39) by dfw-ix4.ix.netcom.com via smap (V1.3)
	id sma022711; Mon Feb 17 15:31:57 1997
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Subject: From Fell Good Entertainment about  Love A-Fair.

Precedence: bulk


Dear Friends:

	I would like to start of by extending a deep thank you to all the people who believed and 
came out to experience this event.   It was a wonderfull night and I honestly beliueve that this 
was one of the more incredible parties I have ever seen.  There was some intense energy created 
here.  

	This event was also able to raise some cash for the environmnet, how much is still to be 
seen.  When all the acounting is reconciled, we will post it on the list.  Untill then please 
keep your asumptions and speculations to yourself.

	I would also like to address some topics that have been brought up on the list.  I would 
like to coment about them before they get blown out of perspective.

The Bomb thing:
     Yes, at 11:30 the Oakland police department recieved a call from an individual that said 
that he placed a bomb of 36 sticks of dynamite in the facility and it was suposed to detonate 
sometimes between 12 and 1:30.  While talking to the police, the agreed with me that this was 
obviously a sabatoge tactic that was being used to shut down the party and they left it up to my 
discretion to act on it.  The police protocall on this was vage and unclear because they new as 
well as i did that this was just a bunch of BullShit.   
	However, when it comes to the safety of our guests, we do not take any chances.  I had my 
security check the groungs, the trash canns, the back packs in the coat check and we turned on 
the lights, and stoped the music to make an anouncement for everyone to look around and if they 
see something strange, th contact any of the security.
	At about 2 am, after the building was still there, the police told me agin that they 
recieved another bomb threat called into 911 from the same person from the payphone at a nearby 
gas station.  Neither the police or myself took this threat very serously.

That person:
	There was a person that was outside on the streets, telling a lot of you that the party 
was going to get shut down by 1 a.m.  We, and the police believe that this was the same person 
that was responsible for the bomb threat.  Our staff could not find the perpetrator, but 
multiple witnesses have given descriptions and the police have information from the phone calls, 
we are sure that justice will be served.  If any of you talked to this person, please contact 
me, if there is any information that you may have, It would be more than apreciated.  A lot of 
people worked very hard to put together this event, and it is a shame whan anyone for whatever 
reason takes it upon themselves to not only destroy something that was worked hard on, but to 
deprive people the opertunity to enjoy a good time with lies, desception ,and terorizm.  once 
again, If anyone has any infgormation, please contact me directly at my office @ 415-593-3664, 
and I promise I will keep our conversations stricly cofidential.  I am not trying to turn this 
into a manhunt, Karma always catches up to you, But I would like to find out why someone would 
be this way.  

The ambulence:
	Unlike most homebase parties, when the anmbulences number between 3-7 ocurences, we were 
fortunente to only have one out of 5000 people require a trip to the hospital.  This was even 
more astonishing when you aply the fact that most abulence trips are because of drug overdoses.  
This guy, had an epaleptic seizure, and it was apearently not drug related.  beacuse we have 
to call 911 for the ambulence, It is routine protocall for the fire truck to show up with the 
ambulences.  
	The guy who was taken away is dooing fine and the hospital informed us that they were 
relesing him that morning. 	
	It is a brath of fresh air to look back at an event of this size, that almost doubles the 
atendence of the average evets at this facility, and to realize that you had absolutely no drug 
realted ambulence rides, while other parties that have 2-3 thousand people are sending 3-4 
people to the hospital for drug overdoses.  Makes us feel good about our crowd, and the fact tha 
the message about partying responsibly and in moderation is getting through.		

Donald Gluade was also not at this party, we could not get him, he had prior arangements.

Also, DJ Carlos missed his flight out of chicago, so DJ melanie, pulled the set byherself, and 
had the bes set of her life.  Way to go Girl.

I acn't remenber if ther was anything else?

	Anyways, I just want to thank everyone agoin from the bottom of my heart for coming out 
and sharing your live and believing in us as well as yourself.  We are all here together, lets 
work together to make it as pleasant as posible.  Life is just to short for negative 
distractions from a positive course. 

	Our next party is going to be a little bit diferent then what we have done in the past.  I 
think you guys will particularly like it.  I will keep everyone updated.

Yesterday is history,
Tomorow is a mystery,
today is a gift,
Thats why it is called the "present"

Keep it real.

Vlad, Feel Good Entertainmnet.
Bad Spelling is my trademark.

On Sun, 16 Feb 1997, Deepfog wrote:

> > after ingestion, however, you may feel a little sleepy for .5-1.0 hours, whill
> > you assimilate the substances.
> > Bruce
> > 
> those substances would probably be the carbohydrates.  if im not mistaken 
> it contains like 68g of carbos, which makes it a yummy but unbalanced 
> food.  all that needs to be done though is to add fat to slow down the 
> sugar (carbo) intake and protein (to build muscle and burn fat).  

You don't want protein and fat if you're going to be *dancing*, though!
You need easily-uptaken NRG; if you're moving around a lot, carbos seem
way better for you than proteins, (IMHO).  They digest quickly, last
longer than sugars, but kick in significantly faster than protein does.
Now the morning after, well that's a different story.  Then, I'd say pack
on lots of protein then so that your muscles can actually recover.  But
for the night, I think carbos will save you, balanced or not.  
Just my .02/\/\/
-=Joe=-

On Mon, 17 Feb 1997, Eric Johnson wrote:

> Sugar is a carbo.  

I know, technically.  But I was talking about the traditional longer-chain
polysaccharides (i.e. more than 3 rings involved) that I've always
assumed people mean when they're referring to "carbos", not just basic
sugars like sucrose or fructose.  Those 1-2 ringers get absorbed hella'
quick!  :)  (Hence the term sugar-high, as opposed to carbo-high...)
Okay, just wanted to add that in.  Peace and respect-
-=Joe=-

>        still, one complaint. When are these greedy fools going to
>release us from the water monopoly they have us under? No water aloud in,
>no faucets,and 2 dollars to buy what would cost us about 2 cents by
>turning on the faucet in our kitchen sink.It is almost evil what they are
>doing. Everyone needs water. Especially in a place where they have to
>remain for 12 hours of dancing, sweating, Eing,Frying,and mass socializing?
>A guy who has just enough money to pay the ridiculous price of 25 dollars
>to get in might not have any more for water. So is he just fucked? Pretty
>much.

I have to agree about the water situation.  While standing around a water
station that was being shut down around 4, myself and a few others were
ready to liberate crates of water to hand out to the masses.  None of us
seemed to have the courage of Robin Hood, though.  :)

All in all, there was an incredible spirit in the place and the music kept
me moving most of the nite until the body finally surrendered itself to the
floor.  The best moment had to be when the lights were turned off
accompanied by an explosion of music around midnight after that bit of
confusion.  It seemed to unite the rave and set the course of the night.
Don't know if it was intentional or not but it definately made me smile
anyway.

n8

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Feb 17 15:52:44 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id PAA05841; Mon, 17 Feb 1997 15:52:44 -0800 (PST)
Received: from netcom18.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with SMTP id PAA05836; Mon, 17 Feb 1997 15:52:39 -0800 (PST)
Received: from localhost (mayer@localhost) by netcom18.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)
	id PAA12699; Mon, 17 Feb 1997 15:52:37 -0800
Message-Id: <199702172352.PAA12699@netcom18.netcom.com>
To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Cc: jack@twaxx.com, "Jason Grotte" <jason@precipice.v-site.net>
Subject: stompy vs spundae
Date: Mon, 17 Feb 97 15:52:37 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


stompy -- double plus good thumbs up.
spundae -- double minus bad thumbs down.

Mark Farina, Derrick Carter and DJ Sneak ripped it up big time and I
was most pleased that the scene is still alive and that I didn't have
to drive all the way to Pittsburgh to hear some real dance music (i.e.
house music!)... Despite the potential sleaze-club vibe of the SF
Oasis, little was noticed, and it had the added benefits of the roof
that opens up to vent in a little fresh air. I was happy to hear
Derrick Carter spin a nice groovin' choon built off a simple loop from
the Fatback Band's '74 funk classic "Wicky Wacky" -- something that I
had tried and failed at a few years ago and is still waiting in the
bowels of my sampler, waiting to get out. (uh, i guess it helps if you
speed it up to 125 BPM)... The crowd was friendly, nice, good,
uplifted, and dancing hard w/ good vibe. I've come to expect this from
Stompy events, which is why I'm a return customer.... Hello to Sfravers
Sid, SunK, DougZ, and AndreL..

On the other hand, I attended Spundae for a few hours hoping to hear
Doc Martin and DJ Dan do some good stuff. Not! Perhaps it was just the
crowd of 20something-kawlich-whiteboys and same-looking-peninsula-chix
that made this thing a vibeless affair, maybe I was tired after
attending Stompy from 5:30-10:00PM. Or maybe it was the total lack of
oxygen and the  sweltering heat and pushy crowd of people desperate to
find the best place in the party, which couldn't be found 'cause the
party sucked. In either case, I found Doc Martin's set to be pretty
lackluster and boring, with a couple of interesting mixes here and
there, but a disappointing selection of what I thought of as "generic
LA club music." I've heard Doc do some great stuff in the past --
perhaps LA has gotten to him. I felt similarly about DJ Dan's set,
which was driving, but passionless/unfunky. I didn't have the patience
to wait for him to warm up cause I was sweating just standing still,
and dancing was making it rain, so I left and went to sleep.

Quite frankly, the only real vibe I saw at Spundae was happening
upstairs with DJ Julius Papp spinning the slower funky stuff.  People
were actually dancing with panache and having fun and letting loose,
and there was actually some semblance of a vibe. Downstairs in the
front room, The Hardkiss bros were spinning stuff I'd find interesting
on my stereo, but not that fun to dance to.

Perhaps spundae got better late in the evening as the "clubbers" and
the apparently fratboy/sorority-girl/peninsulanormals crowd went back
to watching MTV's the grind in preparation for their next outing. I for
one, was not impressed by this event. Perhaps I had had my fill or
raving for the day -- Spundae was like having a pop-tart for dessert
after gourmet dining at Stompy -- an unecessary waste of money and
time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
== When yer swimming in a creek and an eel bites yer cheek, that's a moray!==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Feb 17 16:43:19 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id QAA14173; Mon, 17 Feb 1997 16:43:19 -0800 (PST)

Subject: Nomad's splish cruise tragedy
Date: Mon, 17 Feb 97 16:42:57 -0800
x-mailer: Claris Emailer 1.1
From: Ishak <ishak@faludi.com>
To: "Bayravers" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0

Message-ID: <1355924709-93353466@faludi.com>

Precedence: bulk

whilst i was stuck in limbo waiting to board the splish cruiser, 
i was whetting my chops in anticipation to report how lame nomad's prep
job was (an hour and a half late).  But, after the tragedy that ensued,
 i plunged into much more important
areas of deep question and thought... 

i share these with the community...

would this event cause stereotypical hype about ravers and their events?
--i guess that the media coverage was light and thankfully 
non-exploitative.

is the crew responsive to the emergency situation?  is there any 
hesitation in helping the jumpers?  why are we not being informed?  how 
long to deploy the choppers and rescue boats?  Shouldn't we all be on 
deck in an organized fashion to help visually search?  Was this a suicide 
or an accident? Is it appropriate for the beats to still be pumpin 
considering the overwhelming priority of finding the people overboard?  
Are they forcing the deejays to play so that no one asks for their money 
back?  Is the music successfully lending a soothing soundscape or 
backdrop to this ominous cruise?

I want to maintain that these unedited thoughts darting around my brain 
on friday night  should not be swept under the rug.  We need to be more 
responsible, communicative and caring or our generation will not progress 
any more than the others.
~ik~

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Feb 17 18:52:34 1997

Subject: oh, LOVE! (a-FAIR.. even..)

well, after spending valentine's day alone after last minute changes 
in plans, i was expecting love a-fair to make up for lost time. :)
	IT DID! um, in a way. here are a few things I learned on 
February 15th.
	1) SFRavers are the SHIT! I ran into Leslie, Ryan, Liquid, 
Madame Merc, Lucas, Eric, Pablo, Clay an tons more.. :) It was 
wonderful!:))
	2) I get easily bored with progressive and deep house 
(boomtisboomtisboomtis just doesn't do it for me). 
	3) I get easily intimidated by the crowd that was hangin 
around in between the heartbeat chamber and the main room - can't 
they hang out and look mean somewhere else other than a hallway? :)
	4) If any guy veers me into a wall and gets all creepy, tell 
them Pablo or a guy friend is your boyfriend (THANKS TONS PABLO!), it 
works wonders! :)
	5) Fruit -- oranges, lemons and strawberries are FUN to hand 
out and share with people. Thanks TONS to  Vlad for letting me bring 
some int, they put smiles on every single person I shared with's 
face. :) 
	6) Good things come to those who wait -- Jonathan's set, 
followed by Miah's set were my favorite highlights of the evening. I 
ran outside to get a crowd in to hear Miah's set (yay!) and it was 
the first time our group of rriends were inside the werehouse the 
whole night long.
	7) For me, the vibe was ALIVE outside. When the music 
stopped, we all started screaming and dancing until the music went 
back on. Found myself a handful of new friends out there as well as 
friends I haven't seen since way back. :) Plus it wasn't all hot and 
crowded, and cuddling to keep warm with everyone was the best!
	So yeah, I had a great time at Love A-Fair in general. Wow, I 
really can't believe I went to massives all the time before, they're 
so expensive and crowded and so many tense-angry looking people in 
some places! But you can't really control the crowd you're gonna get 
at a massive, and all things considering, the vibe was pretty good 
that night. I heard alot of KMEL-type "hi NRG" rappy stuff and as i 
said boomtis house, so i didn't concentrate on the music, i 
concentrated on people :) Boring review I know. Missed deepfog's set 
cuz of a flat tire (damn you, car, damn you!) :((( and spent about 
70% of the party outside, dancing, eating fruit, talking to friends.. 
15% in the heartbeat chamber saying hullo to sfravers and dancing... 
and 15% in the pulse/walking around home base with a friend and a 
teddy bear w/ a mask on.. (the teddy, not me!):)
	anyway, great to go back to the massive scene before they 
close home base (i hear they're turning it into a shopping mall cuz 
the guy was breaking even leasing out the space and they're tearing 
it down? can anyone confirm?).. if they DO close homebase, what will 
this do to the massive scene? just curious.. :) hey, many thanks to 
pablo and ryan for helping me find my lost things and to ALL of you 
for sharing your love and smiling :) and vlad, many thanks to a 
wonderful event :)
love and hugs,
lara

...but not too late to tell you all about this bitch'n gathering...

It's really good to see that the SouthBay can get it going-on!  This
party had "rave" written all over it - in the inside, of course!  To
start things off, the map-point was easy to find, filled with good
vibes/friendly people and fairly close to the final destination. The
crew was FEVERISH about making sure that everything went right at the
door which is a good thing, as San Jose is known to be inhospitable to
the Rave scene.
COOL, FREAKY, LOVABLE people we're hangin' in every room.....and....I
know that you won't believe it cuz we're talking about the SouthBay
but.... there was a dedicated lack of "thugs" which meant that the vibe
was WAY INTENSE!!!  Despite all of this killer vibe there was a few
downturns to this otherwise 5-Star affair.  Everyone was sooo paranoid
about a bust that the music was soooooooooo low that I coulda gone out
to my car - backed it up to the door and rocked the house with it!  I
know, I know... it didn't get busted and the music eventually got a
little louder....  The thing is is that we would all start getting
funky and rolling on that roller-coaster ride which is the hallmark of
a good sound engineer and WHAM - you are back to ground zero.
The other "little" thing that I heard people complaining about was that
it was too cold.  My thoughts were that IT IS NEVER TO COLD AT A RAVE! 
I know that you've probably heard it before, "If you are cold then you
just aren't dancing enough/fast enough."  Feel the relative comfort af
a chill, compared to the agony of not being able to drink E'nough
fluids to keep you from overheating or sweating so much that.... you
all know what I mean!
Wow, free power-drinks and fruit!  That was way kewl.  The place was
decorated in a way that you knew that it was an UG as you could tell
that the decorations didn't cost a lot but, MAN WERE THEY POWERFULL! 
The Tree-room, mushroom-room, "jungle"room and main room were all
gorgeous.  My favoritE was the manequin(sp), hanging from the ceiling,
with the butterfly wings and the cool things being projected on her (I
must have spent most of my time staring at that enchanting creature).
All in all, a great party.  Everyone was having a blast ('cept for the
few novice cAndy-flippErs holding onto my wife!)  Props go all-out to
Adam and his crew for a fine job and we hope to attend another superb
night of sonic sensations, huggy-smiley people and unequalled visuals.


pLOVEur,
-SoNiC
(a new kind of TechKnowHippie)

p.s. Deepfog, I'm sorry that I didn't get to hear you spin at
LoveAffair...next time.

If I could mention a couple of things to the promoter:
1. CHAI would be a welcome addition
2. The power-drinks were nasty, think about making them more like
power-drinks and charge us a couple of buck for them.  If they are good
you'll make money and we'll be satisfied.
3. Don't lose those visuals, they were Xcellent - and you know what I
mean.
4. Please, please find a place where there isn't next door neighbors,
we like to hear it LOUD!
5. This event had "gathering" written all over it.  Whatever you do,
try to maintain it. 

Rock the house, Adam!

Mr nStuff wrote:
 
> : Perhaps it was just the crowd of 20something-kawlich-whiteboys and
> same-looking-peninsula-chix that made this thing a vibeless affair.
 
This shit is getting old. This type of attitude is too common among the
ravers out here. For some reason I thought that I would be escaping this
type of stereotypic labeling from where I was from. Many times during my
short stay out here I had to keep myself from being absorbed with all of
this negative energy. I told a few people I was from Indiana and any
person who is familiar with body language could tell that they already
had their minds made up about this Indiana boy. I wanted to say looky
here wormboy you obviously have no concept of the rave scene(s) or dance
music period but that would just be bringing me down to their level.
Instead I kept on smiling. For those of you who still don't know there
are raves everywhere. In every state in every major city throughout the
world. Soon the entire rave scene in the U.S. will be like that in the
U.K. (If it is not already here) 
 I cannot look people in the face in public you see. It is a no win
situation. I cannot look at men because they will think I am gay, If I
do not look then I am too good for them. For women the same, If I look I
want to get in their pants, If I don't then I am gay. Maybe this was a
vibeless party because people actually waste their time worrying about
what other people look like. 
Dave Clarke is considered "normal looking" but does that make him any
less of a person. Just because someone looks like a frat boy does not
mean anything about what this person feels inside. Should all these frat
boys and glamour girls get garbed out in vintage adidas jump suits and
pierce their nose septums to fit in? I don't think so, they would be
just as fake as the people who continuously talk about each other on
this list. If there are any REAL(underground)ravers out there who have
better things to do than talk about other people let me know. I feel as
if I am the only happy person left on the face of the earth. 
I would love to meet new people who would like a friend. I don't care
who you are as long as you understand that we are all the same deep
down. I have had many winding roads to travel over to get where I am at
today, so in no way am I perfect or anyone else for that fact.
Peace(Hopefully some day), Love(Must love yourself first), Unity(???),
and Respect(Must give to recieve). Love to all who have love to give.

At 07:20 PM 2/17/97 -0800, Chris Beaumont wrote:
>After reading the story about the cruise party jumper I really felt sad.. 
>not so much for the person who jumped, although that is of course sad..
>
>People have a right to kill themselves.. I think.. However,
>the death of the security guard seemed really tragic.. 
>
>Here is a guy who was probably being paid $10.00 an hour,giving his life 
>in an attempt to save one of the partygoers..
>Someone should throw a benefit - or some kind of memorial to thank him.. 
>posthumously...


I second that, I was talking to the guy about 20 minutes before it happened.
He was pretty kool, when the party started he told people that if they
wanted to "burn" they needed to do it uptairs, outside so the captain
wouldn't smell 
anything (people didn't pay him any attention).

There are many things that really disturb me about this tragedy.  Yes, it
was dark, yes maybe people reacted slow but the more overwhelming thing
that worries me are the following...

	1) Where was the "jumper's" Family? Didn't he come to the party with
people? If he was blazing (as some people report) why didn't someone from
his posse keep an eye on him?  Why didn't other ravers keep a eye on him?
Back during the times when raving was a potentially dangerous affair
(abandonded warehouses, toxic landfills, sketchy neighborhoods), everyone
looked out for eachother, if some one was too high, people would keep an
eye on them.  I'm a big tall guy, I would have to do a little work to even
fall over the railing
on that boat, didn't anyone see this guy climbing up on the railing, didn't
anyone care? Or was everyone too fucked up to worry about it.  After this
all happened I heard people yelling to turn the music back on, lighting up
bowels and making out, even though two people just lost their lives.  This
isn't
what raving is about for me and it definitely makes me not want to go out
much anymore.

As far as the security guard is concerned, he was very brave, and very
compasionate to give his life to try and save another.  If anyone wants to
throw a tribute party in his honor.  I would gladly participate.  I once
went in some water to get to a hyperthermic person stuck on a rock, (and I
can't swim :) this incident makes me realize just how lucky (or foolish) I
was. My heart goes out to him his family and I so very sad that this guys
gave his life to save someone he didn't know, and none of the supposed
PLURist seem to give a fuck. This guys exhibited more PLUR then all the
windbags who talk shit on a regular basis on this list.



Action! Not words!

I am sorry if this starts a flame war but I am very curious on this
subject. I have noticed that there are alot of people who have a stud
between their eyebrows. Is this a test to see if people look at the stud
instead of the person's eyes when they are talking or is this for
aesthetic purposes? I understand that people have different reasons for
doing everything but I have noticed in the Midwest that in the
underground music scene piercing changes in styles over time. It seems
as if the in-group is constantly changing to distant itself from the
rest of society. Is this actually taking place. From my limited
understanding the nose septum was cool then too many fakies(not real)
started doing that then it went to such things as the ear expander.
Sorry if this offends anyone this was not my intention.

From: 	sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com on behalf of Sub Commander Lycos

Subject: 	Re: memorial for security guard

At 07:20 PM 2/17/97 -0800, Chris Beaumont wrote:
>After reading the story about the cruise party jumper I really felt sad.. 
>not so much for the person who jumped, although that is of course sad..
>
>People have a right to kill themselves.. I think.. However,
>the death of the security guard seemed really tragic.. 
>
>Here is a guy who was probably being paid $10.00 an hour,giving his life 
>in an attempt to save one of the partygoers..
>Someone should throw a benefit - or some kind of memorial to thank him.. 
>posthumously...


I second that, I was talking to the guy about 20 minutes before it happened.
He was pretty kool, when the party started he told people that if they
wanted to "burn" they needed to do it uptairs, outside so the captain
wouldn't smell 
anything (people didn't pay him any attention).

There are many things that really disturb me about this tragedy.  Yes, it
was dark, yes maybe people reacted slow but the more overwhelming thing
that worries me are the following...

	1) Where was the "jumper's" Family? Didn't he come to the party with
people? If he was blazing (as some people report) why didn't someone from
his posse keep an eye on him?  Why didn't other ravers keep a eye on him?
Back during the times when raving was a potentially dangerous affair
(abandonded warehouses, toxic landfills, sketchy neighborhoods), everyone
looked out for eachother, if some one was too high, people would keep an
eye on them.  I'm a big tall guy, I would have to do a little work to even
fall over the railing
on that boat, didn't anyone see this guy climbing up on the railing, didn't
anyone care? Or was everyone too fucked up to worry about it.  After this
all happened I heard people yelling to turn the music back on, lighting up
bowels and making out, even though two people just lost their lives.  This
isn't
what raving is about for me and it definitely makes me not want to go out
much anymore.

As far as the security guard is concerned, he was very brave, and very
compasionate to give his life to try and save another.  If anyone wants to
throw a tribute party in his honor.  I would gladly participate.  I once
went in some water to get to a hyperthermic person stuck on a rock, (and I
can't swim :) this incident makes me realize just how lucky (or foolish) I
was. My heart goes out to him his family and I so very sad that this guys
gave his life to save someone he didn't know, and none of the supposed
PLURist seem to give a fuck. This guys exhibited more PLUR then all the
windbags who talk shit on a regular basis on this list.



Action! Not words!

I don't usually like to get involved in these little festivals here on 
the lovely list (prob. why I *never* post), but here goes anyway.

On Mon, 17 Feb 1997, Chris Richards wrote:
  
> This shit is getting old. This type of attitude is too common among the
> ravers out here. For some reason I thought that I would be escaping this
> type of stereotypic labeling from where I was from. Many times during my
> short stay out here I had to keep myself from being absorbed with all of
> this negative energy. I told a few people I was from Indiana and any
> person who is familiar with body language could tell that they already
> had their minds made up about this Indiana boy. I wanted to say looky
> here wormboy you obviously have no concept of the rave scene(s) or dance
> music period but that would just be bringing me down to their level.
> Instead I kept on smiling. For those of you who still don't know there
> are raves everywhere. In every state in every major city throughout the
> world. Soon the entire rave scene in the U.S. will be like that in the
> U.K. (If it is not already here) 
>  I cannot look people in the face in public you see. It is a no win
> situation. I cannot look at men because they will think I am gay, If I
> do not look then I am too good for them. For women the same, If I look I
> want to get in their pants, If I don't then I am gay. Maybe this was a
> vibeless party because people actually waste their time worrying about
> what other people look like. 

I think you are maybe getting just a bit over defensive here.  It sounds
like you have had some bad experiences with peeps, but Niels was not
attacking you or your race (I think he is a whiteboy, also).  Though Niels
can often get inflammatory, this post seemed fairly tame.  I chose not to
go to this one, but I have attended my fair share of spundae events and
they do tend to be a bit more clubby with a meat-market vibe, especially
on holiday weekends.  Lots of peeps standing around (not dancing, even on
the dancefloor) checking out the opposite sex, with beer in hand. 
Whatever floats yer boat, but not the sort of vibe I'm looking for.  I am
just guessing that is what Niels is talking about, I'm not speaking for
him though. 

Stompy-stomp-stomp:

I definitely enjoyed myself, big time, at Stompy.  It was am awesome
Wicked-like vibe, with some getting incredibly decked out and almost
everyone in the place dancing uncontrollably (with the rest taking much
needed breaks).  Those that were drinking beer seemed to be just wetting
their whistle to get back on the floor.  It got a bit warm at times, but
never unbearable.  It was so cool when they periodically opened the roof. 
letting lots of nice air and smoke out. 

Those boys from Chicago sure know how to get a groove on.  Made me 
believe in house music again.  I wish they lived here.  I am never going 
to miss a gig that they do here again.  That is a promise.  

> Dave Clarke is considered "normal looking" but does that make him any
> less of a person. Just because someone looks like a frat boy does not
> mean anything about what this person feels inside. Should all these frat
> boys and glamour girls get garbed out in vintage adidas jump suits and
> pierce their nose septums to fit in? I don't think so, they would be
> just as fake as the people who continuously talk about each other on
> this list. If there are any REAL(underground)ravers out there who have
> better things to do than talk about other people let me know. I feel as
> if I am the only happy person left on the face of the earth. 
> I would love to meet new people who would like a friend. I don't care
> who you are as long as you understand that we are all the same deep
> down. I have had many winding roads to travel over to get where I am at
> today, so in no way am I perfect or anyone else for that fact.
> Peace(Hopefully some day), Love(Must love yourself first), Unity(???),
> and Respect(Must give to recieve). Love to all who have love to give.

You took one sentence of Niels' post and turned it into a huge rant about
race.  Neils' description brought an instant picture to mind (which I
think constitutes a good, if biased, description :).  I do not judge a
book by it's cover.  But if a frat-boy type is looking too cool and
*standing* on the dance floor (esp, if right in front of me while I am
dancing and trying to connect with the vibe), I will prob. think of him as
a frat boy.  On the other hand if he is getting sweaty and working in it
with the rest, I wouldn't even notice him as such.  Do you get it? 

The crowd at Stompy was just so funky (even the whiteys).  
It made me happy. 

Cheers***
Cami

question? I think you are missing the point. I believe I have the right
to talk about this subject because I myself have contemplated whether or
not getting my ears pierced and my nose septum. I tried to get my ears
pierced but they got infected. The doctor said I had to have solid gold! 
So what you are telling me is that you and others get face peircing done
for no reason at all. I find this very vague. You must understand that
you are separating yourselves from society. This is not a bad thing of
course. 

> separate themselves, but you are the one drawing the line as to what's
> acceptable and what's not. How can you tell if someone is a fakie?  Is

How did I draw a line? Did I say this is bad to have your nose pierced?
I will tell you how I know someone is a fakie. HMMMMM. Lets see from my
experience with raves. I noticed a certain girl who I tried to talk to
her. Walked up to her with a smile and I made a comment about her purple
vintage jump suit. She was very mean and DISrespectful, oh well I have
had this happen before. I later saw her at a rave in Ohio and she had
her nose septum pierced walking around without a smile on her face. It
wasn't until about two weeks later that I saw her again and she was with
her friend hugging people. So, I said maybe she has had a change of
heart I will go talk to her again. Once again a meanie. I graduated with
a minor in Anthropology so I think some of my observations should be
considered valid. Some people will however not agree with this
assumption. This girl wanted to be cool she wanted to be part of the in
crowd and she was going to do whatever it takes to get there. In no way
was this post designed to make fun of body piercing. I think it takes a
very strong person to look different in this day in age.

something pierced,

something less common, (such as a cheek or chin) be sure you are
comfortable with it.  Tons of people will ask you about it, be sure to

the fact that it's there.  Remember there are piercings you can get that
you don't have to show the world everyday.  I am considering those.

At 11:43 AM -0800 2/18/97, Rob Rayle wrote:
>>People have a right to kill themselves.. I think.. However,
>>the death of the security guard seemed really tragic..
>
>	From what I've read, the jumper sounds like a drug casualty,
>	not a suicide. Sorry, but even "harmless" psychedelics can
>	kill under the right (wrong) circumstances.

I heard about this the night after I talked to a friend about the party.
One of the things that has really been bugging me about parties of late is
the ever present "Yeah that sucked, but it was still a great party!  The
DJ's ROCKED IT!!!" ;(

I said it during the Burning Man/Omar incident, during other episodes where
people had to be carried out of parties on stretchers, seeing people on
respirators, etc.  And usually some pollyanna will pipe up from the drug
induced euphoric moment with "Let's not concentrate on the negative..." or
the even more tepid and dumb "Let's not forget all the other GOOD things
that have happened...." ARRGH!!!

Maybe what needs to be done, instead of running away from this reality, is
to confront it.  Is to ask ourselves "What are WE doing?".  I remember
during many drug induced hours asking myself that same question.  What was
I doing crackerjacking when I coulda been home playin with my kid, what was
I doing in a dark ass club when I coulda been huggin' and snugglin' with
the wife, what am I doing while somewhere out there someone is hurting,
suffering, etc.  These were some of my "E" & LSD thoughts during my later
days of this scene.

Now I have no problem with people going out and doing the do.  I do not
foist the massive responsibilities I have, or my heavy thoughts on others,
but at some time we gotta ask why we do the things we do, and to what ends?
I mean, when someone dies, giving his life for a crackerjacker (who is
still a human), how important does the party become?  Someone has died,
someone was seriously injured, and someone might never have a daddy or
mommy ever again.  What up?

Does the party go on, or are we human enough to really take pause.  Take
time out to assess what is really going on....I'll tell you what's going on
these days, and I don't need to go out to know this either:

It is nothing but a drug party, and it has become the reason the majority
party.  That's it, plain and simple.  This scene has changed, for the worse
IMO.

Yes, there are pockets of "vibe" and "goodness" out there for sure, and I
know some of you are involved in various scenes or cliques that are more
positive.  But, alas, you are outnumbered and in the extreme minority.
Just a note.  Parties these days are all about:
#1 - Scoring the drugs.
#2 - Music
#3 - Friends (only those you'll see in the scene, cuz' you ain't hangin'
otherwise).

Once again, let me reiterate, this does not apply to everyone, but this
scene, as a whole, has become the biggest escape vehicle since television.
And we do know the value TV has in our society and the value-add it
provides overall to our society.  I think the same can be said of the
current state of our dance culture.  People die, and the party must go on.
People get hurt, hospitalized, and the party goes on.  Poeple will never
walk again, never dance again, but the party must go on.  Sick, sick, sick!

"Yeah man, I saw this guy get decapitated, but dood, fuckin' DJ SoAndSo
tore it up, and man, I had a great time, despite the fact, this guy is
fertilizer."  Of course, in order for us to feel better, a group of
genuinely good people will get together to throw a party to collect some
funds for whatever.  How ironic.  And this is often touted  as a way for
the scene to heal itself...yeah, let's throw another drug party, collect
some money then give it to the family.

You know, if I didn't know the people I do, if I were half as bitter as
some would make me out to be, I would have a mind to call up the TV
stations, the cops, and whoever else I could, and have them investigate
FULLY what happened.  But even *I*, with all my high falutin talk won't
step up to that plate. Ironically my honor to many of the people in all of
this means I keep lotsa shit to myself, and that is where it'll stay.

So I have my own little forms of protest.  I stay away from the majority of
all of this.  I do go to really small events, like @ the TOP, or even a D7
party every blue moon.  I would even probably go to Stompy if it weren't on
the weekends I have visitation w/ my son, His Excellency (I love my boy,
he's the BOMB!).  But crackerjackin' @ a party is OUT.  Being out of my
skull is OUT.  And socializing ONLY at parties is OUT, OUT, OUT!

Out of all of this what do we get:  DRAMA.  The drama of people losing
thier lives because of drugs & irresponsible use.   The drama of people
never being able to dance again.  The drama of people throwing benefits
(read drug parties) for the purpose of, er, healing. The drama of girls
snatchin' other girls men, actively.  The drama of guys and girls notchin'
up thier bedposts with the conquests of other people's mates.  The drama of
some mother, some brother, some father, some sister, some daughter, some
son, crying because the person they love will never come home again.

But the party must go on.  Damn, that DJ' really rocked the fucking house....

I need a Kleenex, an enema, and even more of a break from parties...months
and counting,
John

P.S.  These are my opinions and thoughts.  I will pray for both of those
people who lost thier lives.  For the person who got so high he would never
ever touch the ground again, and for the person who gave his life trying to
make sure that this person would see his tribe again:  My hopes and prayers
are with you both.  Peace.

"Those who profess to favor freedom and yet depreciate agitation, are people
who want crops without ploughing the ground; they want rain without thunder
and lightning; they want the ocean without the roar of its waters... Power
concedes nothing without a demand; it never has and it never will."

Frederick Douglas, 1857

Lecture to follow.  Flame me at will, I'm beyond that and need to say
something that has been on my mind.  

Do we have to hear so many posts about the plethora of drugs one did at a
party?  How many people really care about how you were E'in/fryin'/420'in 
your ass off?  I think people say this stuff because they think this is a
forum where others are sympathetic.  I'd just like to say that I
personally am not sympathetic to hearing how fucking high someone was.  If
you want to do 4 E's, 18 hits of acid, please keep it among your substance
abusing friends. (and if you don't think that's abuse, maybe that's the
answer, or was that the question?)  I think this just equates with where
the rave scene is going.  Mentioning how high you were used to be a
severely frowned upon topic here on this list 2 years ago.  If you wanted
to ask information, or even talk about how E or LSD helped you gain some
insight into the world around you, or maybe bond with your friends, the
list tolerated that.  Maybe because it meant that drugs were a tool and
not a vice.

But no one talks about it in this manner any more.  After every weekend, I
get on my computer only to find out how the party was so great and you
were E'in your ass off.  Props to you.  

People, look at the trends.  Do we wonder why the scene is changing?  Just
read the list and see what the recent posts are about for greater insight 
into the "raver world". All you see these days (with exceptions, of
course) are the posts about how PHun or how PHat a party is.  How PHony
is my reply.  I can honestly say that I think most people see this.  I
used to go to a party to come home a better person the next day, to a
certain degree.  Now, when I think about going to a party, I think, "let's
find somewhere were I can ignore the rest of the crowd, hang with my
friends, and chill to some music."  I used to feel like we were all in
this together, but now I feel like it is an individual pursuit to have the
best time you can at the biggest party you can go to.  

Believe me, I know my part in this.  I try and turn it into more self
exploration and think about my part in the puzzle.  I just know
something's up when Nancy gets called old-school for bringing oranges to a
party, though, and everyone I see talks about how high they are.  I'm
trying not to bemoan better days because it is all relative to our age,
maturity, and experiences.  However, incorporate everything into your
world view, know your history, and accept change in that manner.  It's
over when it's just a party.

And, as a qualifier, I'm not anti-drug, anti-pleasure, nor anti-hedonism,
but I am anti-abuse and anti-materialism.  It's a trap when your excuse is
"there is always someone who does more than I do." Be careful about the
cycle you put yourself in.

I know I'm putting myself out on a limb for saying all this, but I promise
not to drag it on. Flames come from defensive people usually, and I won't
play that game.  No one wins. 
 
I don't want to be entirely negative and it's nice to still read the
reviews about how people found a sense of community or discovered
something about themselves, or even put effort into something they
believed in.  That is what has always amazed me about the rave scene.

-KaySEE

"Maybe I woke up and the E-trip was over..."  

"Life was mundane again...."

... becuase you can move to it at different energy levels.

It is really too bad that so much of the jungle scene in this city takes
place in 21+ venues.  Its the younger people who really have the energy
to effectively get into jungle anyway...

But, you make the most of it.  King Kong was in a little bar on Folsom.
Generally a good vibe.  You could tell the promoters had their heart
in it, bananas and a stuffed gorilla was a nice touch.  The sound system
was nice.  The bar scene made it a little difficult for people to really
let go and bust into some jungle moves... but shortly after midnight it
finally happened, and the party went off for the rest of the night.

I was disappointed that 2 rooms were advertised and there was only 1.  No
big deal for 3 bucks, but little things like that make you wonder about
the intentions of the promoter.

Also, when you say a party goes until 2am, that means the lights stay off
and the music on until 2am... you don't stop the party at 1:40... its just
not right... espcially when everybody is going off.

-troy

Under the circumstances...

I was the person who the cops originally reported the bomb threat to.
Here's what was explained:

1) Evacuating the premises would have created a minor riot, possibly
leading to more harm.
2) This is an extremely common promoter trick that many party promoters
have used at one time or another. This also happens with concerts, etc.
Everyone should open their eyes to the fact that many of the promoters who
you view as being non-commercial or "old school" have done many of these
lame promoter tricks to bust other parties, in order to further their
material wealth.
3) Feel Good security went through all precautions to make sure something
like this didn't happen.

Granted, maybe the best thing to do would have been to evacuate for safety
precautions... But would you want to leave, provided that bomb threats have
happened at many parties that you have attended, even though you did not
know about them.

-dnns

around looking at girls.  Their appearance seemed to indicate they belonged
to some sort of Fraternity.  Whether it be Theta Epsilon Tau, or Bridge and
Tunnel Society.  I mean, from a simple glance, we here on the list have
become rather adept at figuring out whose who.  After all, it's not only a
matter of appearance, it coulda been the frat 'tude they were throwing off.

and who's a gangstah.  It's all in appearance & 'tude.  We already firgured
