Peeps, is what Cami said, it is short for people.  I am well versed in
Ebonics, got a doctorate in it (from the skreets).  And I can definitely
tell you, peeps ain't no ebonics word.  See, it's a Caucasonic word.  Kida
like supersonic, but whiter than supersonic.  See what I mean?

>> attacking you or your race (I think he is a whiteboy, also).
>
>How do you know I am white? Does this even matter?

You know how?  I'll tell you:  The only people who get in a real hackles
when you try to attach race to people, in general, are whites.  People of
color , in general, don't like the labels given them since they are usually
given from the majority (white) culture.  So you'll see me go off on people
about "gangsters" or "undesireables".  But the second you try to pigeonhole
someone into a category racilly, usually a white person will jump up to
demand, er, justice.  Becuase there is only one group that is allowed to
defy categorization.  And we know that many whites in this country have a
real problem with race.  So much so, they want to erase it from
consciousness so it never has to be dealt with.  So one can assume, by
previous actions of others in life, and on this list, that your reaction to
the labelling or characterizations of whites has some how hit a nerve.
Being the spokeperson for all blacks in this country (I was just elected
BTW), I did not have such a reaction.  Why?  Why should I?  Brothers don't
sit in no corner waiting for ladies, we is on da hunt fo dem 24/7.  Also,
we can't afford no $4 drinks.  Sheeit, a 40 is only 1.99 at the corner
store (run by my semetic brothers the Arabs usually).  So why I got's to go
to a club, when I can wait fo dem ladies on da corner, wit' my 40 and
gangstah ways ready to charm?  Uncut G?  Straight up!

And no, it doesn't matter unless it really matters to you, which it does
since you're in hackles about it.

>
>Could you PLEASE,PLEASE,PLEASE explain how I did this? Was it because I
>used Dave Clarke as an example? If so I think you need to look in the
>mirror. You are thinking in racial terms. Please, explain all of this
>talk about race. I am getting real scared of the list.

I have been so scared I unsubbed.  But then I got my nerve back and came
back on.  It's scarey here sometimes.  Sheeit, I'm scared now.

Oh yeah, don't fuck with this list.  These motherfuckers will bum rush you
in a second!  Uncut, straight up!

>I will use DAVE
>ANGEL as an example this time. My point was that if a person wearing a
>polo came into a rave (which Dave Clarke has been known to wear at
>times) he would no doubt be considered by many of the prejudgemental
>clueless ravers as a prep but after they hear he is Dave Clarke they
>would be riding his jock.

Riding his jock?  Is that like, er, on his dick?  Or is that "Get off my
dick, and tell yo' b*tch to come here!"

You're right though, people are rather sycophantic when it suits their
needs.  Hell, even I have kissed a few butts in my day.

>
>Neils' description brought an instant picture to mind (which I think
>constitutes a good, if biased, description :).  I do not judge a
>> book by it's cover.

Damn, so much for all those comic books.

>But if a frat-boy type is looking too cool and
>> *standing* on the dance floor (esp, if right in front of me while I am
>> dancing and trying to connect with the vibe), I will prob. think of him
>>as a frat boy.  On the other hand if he is getting sweaty and working in
>>it with the rest, I wouldn't even notice him as such.  Do you get it?
>
>No, sorry I don't get it. So you are saying a prep who is dancing is
>more accepted by yourself than a preppy who is standing. Maybe he wants
>to make friends and he is afraid he will make a fool of himself.
>Maybe
>he is just like you but you are placing your prejudices of preppys upon
>him. It sounds to me that the preppy is the book and you are judging it
>by his cover (appearance).

Is there anyway else to judge a book?  C'mon, you walk into a bookstore,
the first thing you see is the cover art.  I think we need to revise this
saying cuz' it's just not true in our media driven society.  Soemthing more
like, "Don't judge a book unless you've read it page to page, but if they
didn't put any effrot into the cover art, it probably sucks."  Yeah, I like
that better.

>> The crowd at Stompy was just so funky (even the whiteys).
>
>Even the whiteys. I cannot believe that this happening.

Ok now, let's get real for a moment...who brought you break dancing,
scratching, beats, re-manipulation of music, disco, jazz, hip-hop, rap,
gospel, graffitti, tagging, Adidas, the twist, Motown, shimmy (and every
other creative modern dance form) and the High Top Fade...well it sure as
fuck wasn't Pat Boone (non dancer).  Now, I gotta give my white brothers
and sisters thier due, part of the reason Hip-Hop exists is due directly to
Kraftwerk.  Brothers from Dusseldorf were on the one.  Who made blues style
accessible to a worldwide audience? Rolling Stones, Led Zepplin, Janice
Joplin (Henrix smoked all of them, but that's another issue, he didn't play
60,000 stadiums regularly), and Patsy Kline. And of course the main kool
kat, the brotha who made porkpie hats kool (fo da masses, we already were
sportin them 10-15 years before Frankie got ahold of one) and the ONLY
person who could call the President Of The United States "Chickee Baby"
fuckin' Frank "Chairman Of The Board" Sinatra (I have his Columbia Years 4
pak CD set, smokin' baby!).  Now that brother had a smooth voice, great
phrasing, and about 100 years ahead of this country when it came to race
relations.

Look at who the giggers, stompers, and circle dancers are at a party.  Now,
I gotta hand it to some of my white brothers and sisters.  I have seen many
a white sister SMOKE a dance floor.  Same with some of my white bretheren.
But on as a whole, the brown, when it comes to moves, got it down.  But yo,
white is alright!  Ya know why?  Cu'z it's all the same at night!  (damn, I
am one poetic motherfucker!)

Many ;)'s and :)'s!,
John

P.S.  It's all IMO, good to go!!!

who want crops without ploughing the ground; they want rain without thunder
and lightning; they want the ocean without the roar of its waters... Power
concedes nothing without a demand; it never has and it never will."

Frederick Douglas, 1857

Just wanted to offer a word of support for KC <scarab@value.net>.

I personally tend to think that drugs are pretty much just a
distraction from anything worthwhile.  The people that I
respect who are (or have been) into drugs, are the people
who talk about them as "training wheels" for getting into a
mental state that you can also reach without them.  People
bragging about how much they do, on the other hand, seem to
be stuck in some kind of high school status contest...

In reply to something Brian posted about how you can't get
someone from the major media to believe you if you downplay
the drugs-rave connection: there's some truth to this, but
if I were talking to the press, I would probably go on the
offensive and accuse them of helping to create the
situation.  Every time they run a story about teenagers
dancing all night on drugs (booga-booga), they're running a
highly visible ad telling all the teenagers that the cool
thing to do is get out there and do some drugs.  

Anyway, I can't claim that drug-obsessed ravers are the only
reason I don't hang at raves much these days.  The music
seems to be evolving a lot slower than it used to be, and my
interests have shifted more toward live improvised music. 

Speaking of which, I thought Electro-sphere was okay, though
I have to say I expected a little bit more in the way of
live jamming.  Mood Clinic was pretty good, but the rest of
it seemed to be the usual live DJ stuff, with maybe a little
better than average music.  The crackling Van de Graff
generator up on stage was okay, though.

That was a very REAL posting...thank you for being soooo honest.  It
made me take a step back and honestly assess where I'm at in the rave
scene.  I have to say that MOST of the stuff(situations) don't apply to
the way my wife and I and our extremely close circle of friends rave. 
But, I can definately see how things can change without you being aware
of the changes and how catastophic those said changes can be.  Here's
to making sure that your eyes are open and that you are ready to be a
responsible individual *even while partying!*

Stay REAL, party as you see fit - just don't lose touch of your
humanity.

At 11:43 AM -0800 2/18/97, Rob Rayle wrote:
>>>People have a right to kill themselves.. I think.. However,
>>>the death of the security guard seemed really tragic..
>>
>>	From what I've read, the jumper sounds like a drug casualty,
>>	not a suicide. Sorry, but even "harmless" psychedelics can
>>	kill under the right (wrong) circumstances.


>I heard about this the night after I talked to a friend about the party.
>One of the things that has really been bugging me about parties of late
>is
>the ever present "Yeah that sucked, but it was still a great party!  The
>DJ's ROCKED IT!!!" ;(

>I said it during the Burning Man/Omar incident, during other episodes
>where
>people had to be carried out of parties on stretchers, seeing people on
>respirators, etc.  And usually some pollyanna will pipe up from the drug
>induced euphoric moment with "Let's not concentrate on the negative..."
>or
>the even more tepid and dumb "Let's not forget all the other GOOD things
>that have happened...." ARRGH!!!

>Maybe what needs to be done, instead of running away from this reality,
>is
>to confront it.  Is to ask ourselves "What are WE doing?".  I remember
>during many drug induced hours asking myself that same question.  What
>was
>I doing crackerjacking when I coulda been home playin with my kid, what
>was
>I doing in a dark ass club when I coulda been huggin' and snugglin' with
>the wife, what am I doing while somewhere out there someone is hurting,
>suffering, etc.  These were some of my "E" & LSD thoughts during my
>later
>days of this scene.

>Now I have no problem with people going out and doing the do.  I do not
>foist the massive responsibilities I have, or my heavy thoughts on
>others,
>but at some time we gotta ask why we do the things we do, and to what
>ends?
>I mean, when someone dies, giving his life for a crackerjacker (who is
>still a human), how important does the party become?  Someone has died,
>someone was seriously injured, and someone might never have a daddy or
>mommy ever again.  What up?

>Does the party go on, or are we human enough to really take pause.  Take
>time out to assess what is really going on....I'll tell you what's
>going on
>these days, and I don't need to go out to know this either:

>It is nothing but a drug party, and it has become the reason the
>majority
>party.  That's it, plain and simple.  This scene has changed, for the
>worse
>IMO.

>Yes, there are pockets of "vibe" and "goodness" out there for sure, and
>I
>know some of you are involved in various scenes or cliques that are more
>positive.  But, alas, you are outnumbered and in the extreme minority.
>Just a note.  Parties these days are all about:
>#1 - Scoring the drugs.
>#2 - Music
>#3 - Friends (only those you'll see in the scene, cuz' you ain't hangin'
>otherwise).

>Once again, let me reiterate, this does not apply to everyone, but this
>scene, as a whole, has become the biggest escape vehicle since
>television.
>And we do know the value TV has in our society and the value-add it
>provides overall to our society.  I think the same can be said of the
>current state of our dance culture.  People die, and the party must go
>on.
>People get hurt, hospitalized, and the party goes on.  Poeple will never
>walk again, never dance again, but the party must go on.  Sick, sick,
>sick!

>"Yeah man, I saw this guy get decapitated, but dood, fuckin' DJ SoAndSo
>tore it up, and man, I had a great time, despite the fact, this guy is
>fertilizer."  Of course, in order for us to feel better, a group of
>genuinely good people will get together to throw a party to collect some
>funds for whatever.  How ironic.  And this is often touted  as a way for
>the scene to heal itself...yeah, let's throw another drug party, collect
>some money then give it to the family.

>You know, if I didn't know the people I do, if I were half as bitter as
>some would make me out to be, I would have a mind to call up the TV
>stations, the cops, and whoever else I could, and have them investigate
>FULLY what happened.  But even *I*, with all my high falutin talk won't
>step up to that plate. Ironically my honor to many of the people in all
>of
>this means I keep lotsa shit to myself, and that is where it'll stay.

>So I have my own little forms of protest.  I stay away from the
>majority of
>all of this.  I do go to really small events, like @ the TOP, or even a
>D7
>party every blue moon.  I would even probably go to Stompy if it
>weren't on
>the weekends I have visitation w/ my son, His Excellency (I love my boy,
>he's the BOMB!).  But crackerjackin' @ a party is OUT.  Being out of my
>skull is OUT.  And socializing ONLY at parties is OUT, OUT, OUT!

>Out of all of this what do we get:  DRAMA.  The drama of people losing
>thier lives because of drugs & irresponsible use.   The drama of people
>never being able to dance again.  The drama of people throwing benefits
>(read drug parties) for the purpose of, er, healing. The drama of girls
>snatchin' other girls men, actively.  The drama of guys and girls
>notchin'
>up thier bedposts with the conquests of other people's mates.  The
>drama of
>some mother, some brother, some father, some sister, some daughter, some
>son, crying because the person they love will never come home again.

>But the party must go on.  Damn, that DJ' really rocked the fucking
>house....

>I need a Kleenex, an enema, and even more of a break from
>parties...months
>and counting,
>John

>P.S.  These are my opinions and thoughts.  I will pray for both of those
>people who lost thier lives.  For the person who got so high he would
>never
>ever touch the ground again, and for the person who gave his life
>trying to
>make sure that this person would see his tribe again:  My hopes and
>prayers
>are with you both.  Peace.

At 12:47 PM -0800 2/18/97, John S. Lee wrote:
>You know, if I didn't know the people I do, if I were half as bitter as
>some would make me out to be, I would have a mind to call up the TV
>stations, the cops, and whoever else I could, and have them investigate
>FULLY what happened.  But even *I*, with all my high falutin talk won't
>step up to that plate. Ironically my honor to many of the people in all of
>this means I keep lotsa shit to myself, and that is where it'll stay.

I *totally* and *completely* agree with what John Lee said.

In fact, I would have personally called *all* the radio and TV networks
myself and clued them in so that they would be waiting to shove cameras and
microphones into the faces of these promoters as the boat returned to the
dock.

But alas I was out of town enjoying life outside the tiny manufactured
reality that is raving. :-)

If you call Nomad's voice mail lines (one per area code, of course) all you
get now is "Thank you for calling. Please leave a message and we we'll get
back to you as soon as possible."

That's quite a bit different from the usual "It was the most beautiful
party in the most beautiful space with the most beautiful crowd. Thank you
for all coming out 'blah blah blah'" type crap that's usually heard there.

I really hope they stop having parties before anyone else gets killed
("collateral damage.")

Not a flame at all from this guy!  I applaud you for saying what you
needed to say.  Do you really need to get *fucked-up* to rave?  I think
that the intensity of traffic on this list about sober-raving will
speak volumes about that idea.  Drugs are a tool.(period)  If you use
them otherwise you are opening yourself up to be a possible abuser.  Be
smart when you party, people.  I love my raver friends(and non-raver
friends) and I don't want someone to screw-up their lives - I've seen
it happen and it ain't pretty.

pLOVEur,
-SoNiC
(TechKnowHip)

On Tue, 18 Feb 1997, John S. Lee wrote:

> 
> I heard about this the night after I talked to a friend about the party.
> One of the things that has really been bugging me about parties of late is
> the ever present "Yeah that sucked, but it was still a great party!  The
> DJ's ROCKED IT!!!" ;(
> 
> I said it during the Burning Man/Omar incident, during other episodes where
> people had to be carried out of parties on stretchers, seeing people on
> respirators, etc.  And usually some pollyanna will pipe up from the drug
> induced euphoric moment with "Let's not concentrate on the negative..." or
> the even more tepid and dumb "Let's not forget all the other GOOD things
> that have happened...." ARRGH!!!
> 
> #1 - Scoring the drugs.
> #2 - Music
> #3 - Friends (only those you'll see in the scene, cuz' you ain't hangin'
> otherwise).
> 
> Once again, let me reiterate, this does not apply to everyone, but this
> scene, as a whole, has become the biggest escape vehicle since television.
> 
john and all,

i don't know if you guys have gotten my last post on this subject but i
wanted to clarify my point of view a bit.  the parties that the Ahau
Collective (PDX) and Starseed (SEA) are on a very different tip...i know
because i throw them and am family with Starseed.  We truly care about
each other and are in each other's live daily...we ARE family.  we take
care of each other when we're sick, we study and we share with our
community.  I know of many beautiful collectives in SF that feel the same
way.  We want children involved in this type of celebration that's why
Ahau throws dance events in the middle if Pioneer Square, downtown, and
invite the whole community during a beautiful summer day, or up in the
park.  We have our adult only nighttime things too where whoever wishes
will alter their consciousness in which ever fashion fancies them or they
run into, but, I just forget soemtimes how much more intense and
potentially diverse the SF scene is.  not to say that we have a perfect
scene, at all, we just work and keep each other in check, make sure we're
doing things for the right reasons.  you don't have to wait for a tragedy
to clean up your act.

love,

brenda
a performer, raver, mother, human being, lover

Yes, we froze to death on the dock waiting 2+ hours to get on the boat.  
Yes, the boat stayed out on the Bay for no more than 1.5 hours.  Yes, the 
lights came on and crew started cleaning up around 4AM.  Yes, there was a 
food buffet (though I don't think this was a bad thing!).  Yes, it cost $20.

there were a bunch of people in suits and dresses and shit drinking the 
alcohol and yes, I got hit on by drunk men.  

Yes, the party sucked!  :P

A letter to Troy and everyone who made it out to KING KONG the other night:
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Thanks for the honest review.  I was one of the organizers of the party,
and I was really happy the way it turned out.  The vibes were good, the
music was great, and I danced my ass off.  Thanks to everyone that made it
happen!

To address some of people's concerns...  the second room didn't happen
because the club owners decided to paint the floor in there on the day of
the party - we brought 4 turntables down and found out upon arriving.
There were 2 DJs who came down and didn't get to spin - thanks to Vanka and
Ian for not being sore.  I was pretty bummed about not having the chill
room, and I'd like to say that we'll have it up and running for the next
party, but I won't promise, so I don't have to go back on my word.  I
apologize on behalf of the club for false advertising.

As far as the lights going on at 1:40, again this was the club owners being
in a hurry to get home.  I will do my best to make sure in the future that
the sound system stays on and the lights stay off until 2.  This time, we
were under observation by the club, they were checking us out to see if
they wanted to have us there every week, so I was going out of my way to be
accomodating and nice to the owners.  On the bright side, I think we proved
ourselves capable of working with the club and throwing a fun party, so
they're going to give us a weekly starting in March.  I'll post to this
list with more details as soon as I have them - in the meantime you can
find out more by checking out our website -
http://www.betalounge.com/kingkong/ or calling our hotline, (415) 276-8549.

Thanks again for all of those who came out to dance, and big up all
junglists - support your local scene!

Jonathan aka Mudfoot

>... becuase you can move to it at different energy levels.
>
>It is really too bad that so much of the jungle scene in this city takes
>place in 21+ venues.  Its the younger people who really have the energy
>to effectively get into jungle anyway...
>
>But, you make the most of it.  King Kong was in a little bar on Folsom.
>Generally a good vibe.  You could tell the promoters had their heart
>in it, bananas and a stuffed gorilla was a nice touch.  The sound system
>was nice.  The bar scene made it a little difficult for people to really
>let go and bust into some jungle moves... but shortly after midnight it
>finally happened, and the party went off for the rest of the night.
>
>I was disappointed that 2 rooms were advertised and there was only 1.  No
>big deal for 3 bucks, but little things like that make you wonder about
>the intentions of the promoter.
>
>Also, when you say a party goes until 2am, that means the lights stay off
>and the music on until 2am... you don't stop the party at 1:40... its just
>not right... espcially when everybody is going off.
>
>-troy
>
>---------------------------------------------------------------------------=

On Tue, 18 Feb 1997, Joe Brenner wrote:
> Just wanted to offer a word of support for KC <scarab@value.net>.

Me too!  Great post.

And good to see you at Electrosphere Joe, glad to see some of us sfr
oldtimers still kicking around. :)

> I personally tend to think that drugs are pretty much just a
> distraction from anything worthwhile.  The people that I
> respect who are (or have been) into drugs, are the people
> who talk about them as "training wheels" for getting into a
> mental state that you can also reach without them.  

On the other hand, I think it's perfectly valid to consider that certain
drugs, used responsibly, can also be used recreationally.  When people
drink beer there's usually no higher purpose other than to get loosened up
and numbed from a lot of trouble around them temporarily - I think it's
alright to look at smoking a joint in the same way.  

> People
> bragging about how much they do, on the other hand, seem to
> be stuck in some kind of high school status contest...

Definitely.

> In reply to something Brian posted about how you can't get
> someone from the major media to believe you if you downplay
> the drugs-rave connection: there's some truth to this, but
> if I were talking to the press, I would probably go on the
> offensive and accuse them of helping to create the
> situation.  Every time they run a story about teenagers
> dancing all night on drugs (booga-booga), they're running a
> highly visible ad telling all the teenagers that the cool
> thing to do is get out there and do some drugs.  

Life imitating the media, or the media imitating life?  

I think the tide is turning somewhat.  The article in the Chron about the
tragic boat party on Friday night said it was a "private party", which is
cool.  

> Anyway, I can't claim that drug-obsessed ravers are the only
> reason I don't hang at raves much these days.  The music
> seems to be evolving a lot slower than it used to be, and my
> interests have shifted more toward live improvised music. 
> 
> Speaking of which, I thought Electro-sphere was okay, though
> I have to say I expected a little bit more in the way of
> live jamming.  Mood Clinic was pretty good, but the rest of
> it seemed to be the usual live DJ stuff, with maybe a little
> better than average music.  The crackling Van de Graff
> generator up on stage was okay, though.  

Yeah, I had a pretty good time too, particularly during Astral Matrix's
set, and Jason Velocette's set was really good too.  The crowd wasn't
really responding well to the jungle at the beginning of the night, and it
got really industrial at one point when Daum put on some stuff he had been
working on off of a DAT.  It was definitely cool to be at the Fillmore, a
place with a ton of history.

	Brian

Subject: NRR: PLUR vs. the booty machine (was Re: Body Piercing)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

What I don't understand about the "rave" scene, and about this thread, is
why people seem to think that PLUR and sexual attraction are mutually
exclusive. Granted, there is a sleazy way to approach that attractive
someone, and it's very often found in your "meat market" type places. I
admit, this can be very offensive. But it's really a matter of how you
approach the person, isn't it? Granted, many people, no matter how
respectfully they are approached, are not interested in meeting anyone -
but if that's the case, then they should say so politely, and the other
person should take the hint. There seems to be an attitude among many
people on this list, and people I've encountered in the scene, that you
can't mix PLUR and approaching that attractive someone out there on the
dance floor. And I have to say I don't agree. Discuss?

-Brian

In this country, we have everything we need.
Except what we don't have.

it was for real, what would you do...?

!!!! PARENTAL UNIT RAVE !!!!

Richmond Civic Center
Feb. 31st, 1999 - 10PM to 7AM

Admission: >>> FREE <<< If you bring one or more of your parents!!!
                        and the parents get in free too!
Otherwise: $35 per person

DJs: ( At least four of your most favorite DJs )
Live Performances By: ( Your favorite musicians/noise makers )
Visuals: ( Your most favorite visuals people )

Chill Room!

"Big Chill" Room! : For your parents ( and maybe you too) to dance 
   in, if they're not in the main room doin' it to techno . Music 
   ranges from Dave Clark Five to Iron Buttery to K.C. and the 
   Sunshine Band to War to Sly and the Family Stone to Donna Summer 
   to ...( insert your parent's favorite dance music here ) .

Medical Tent

Free chai! Free fruit! Free dop...er, well, maybe not that.

All ages!!!  
No alcohol allowed ( this restriction may affect some people's 
 parents more than their kids )

Hey Brian,

In reference to your version of PLUR...

PLUR is not a vice to get your mack on. Granted, they may interweave at
points.

PLUR is not a way to approach a person, it is, in essence, a way to exist.

Always show: PEACE, LOVE, UNITY, & RESPECT and good things will happen.
Now... if these good things end up being things like getting your mack on,
go with it. If PLUR leads to you making new friends, go with it. If PLUR
helps you to unravel the secrets of the universe, go with it. 

The secret of PLUR... FLOW WITH IT. GO WITH THE VIBE. GO WITH WHAT YOU FEEL
IS RIGHT, NOT ONLY FOR YOU BUT FOR THE FAMILY AROUND YOU.

Also, in reference to the fact that people don't agree with you approaching
someone on the dancefloor... take this into consideration...

When I dance, I lose myself. The music and I are essentially one entity.
When someone comes up to me and taps me on the shoulder, or bumps into me
or whatever, I fall out of that world. Something as small as someone
tapping me on the shoulder has brought me out of my own private nirvana.

The moral of the story is... just flow with it, don't try to make it happen
just let it happen. There is a lot of love flowing on the scene, mental,
physical, & spiritual. You gotta let these elements come together for
yourself as well as others, and then you will understand why people say
macking on the dancefloor and PLUR don't go together.

----------
> From: Brian Benitez <benitez@hotwired.com>

> What I don't understand about the "rave" scene, and about this thread, is
> why people seem to think that PLUR and sexual attraction are mutually
> exclusive. Granted, there is a sleazy way to approach that attractive
> someone, and it's very often found in your "meat market" type places. I
> admit, this can be very offensive. But it's really a matter of how you
> approach the person, isn't it? Granted, many people, no matter how
> respectfully they are approached, are not interested in meeting anyone -
> but if that's the case, then they should say so politely, and the other
> person should take the hint. There seems to be an attitude among many
> people on this list, and people I've encountered in the scene, that you
> can't mix PLUR and approaching that attractive someone out there on the
> dance floor. And I have to say I don't agree. Discuss?

I saw the news last night on Ch. 7 and they called it a Murder/Suicide.
William Cortez, I think was the sec. guard's name.  They have been
searching for his body since Valentine's Day weekend, and have not found
it.  They did not mention the other guy too much, just that he committed
suicide on a Tour Boat of the Bay that had 500 passengers, and that Mr.
Cortez went in after him.  They said nothing about what kind of party it
was or if it was drug related nor did they mention dancing or raves.  

Both the people who went overboard are considered missing by police.  It
is very likely that they are both dead.

some of you out...I made this to send to my mom...this is usually the most
annoying part of filling out those forms, so if you can get this done,
the rest is pretty easy...oh yeah...if you dont apply you dont get
anything...=)

forms are due real soon...march 3rd

please send us the FA information from the FAFSA ASAP! Ill even include
the exact info you need so that you dont even have to go to the FA office
and get the form...hows that...=)
ps it is due in 1.5 weeks so hu8rry!

What form did you fill out:
  (1040, 1040a, 1040ez)

1996 total # of exemptions:

1996 adjusted gross income:

1996 us income tax paid:

1996 income earned from work
joe

mom

earned income credit

peaceful than sharing a little love =)

unity: what better way to promote unity than to try to meet someone you
dont know?
respect: if your not interested, be nice, if your interested, be nice
	
my .02

At 12:47 PM -0800 2/18/97, John S. Lee wrote:
>You know, if I didn't know the people I do, if I were half as bitter as
>some would make me out to be, I would have a mind to call up the TV

I *totally* and *completely* agree with what John Lee said.

In fact, I would have personally called *all* the radio and TV networks
myself and clued them in so that they would be waiting to shove cameras and
microphones into the faces of these promoters when the boat returned to the
dock.

But I was out of town this weekend.

If you call Nomad's voice mail lines (one per area code, of course) all you
get now is "Thank you for calling. Please leave a message and we we'll get
back to you as soon as possible."

That's quite a bit different from the usual "It was the most beautiful
party in the most beautiful space with the most beautiful crowd. Thank you
for all coming out 'blah blah blah'" type crap that's usually heard there.

I really hope they stop having parties before anyone else gets killed
(read: "collateral damage")

So, who's going to tip off the media about what *really* happened?

I actually was surprised and quite glad that the media has not caught on 
that this boat party was a "rave" event.  Surprised in that if they did 
know about it, they haven't jumped all over the rave/drug-related aspect 
of it.  Glad because I don't think publicity of this sort would be 
helpful to anyone, really.  Is there some reason you would want the media 
to know that there may have been drugs involved?  

Also, I haven't heard anything to make me think it was the promoter's
fault.  How could they have prevented something like that from happening? 
Is there something I don't know about?  I mean, really, Nomad doesn't
always put on the most well-organized events, but are they really all that
bad?  Please eduacate me why it would be a good thing to have the media 
jump on Nomad, other than that you don't like them or their events.

Don't get me wrong, I think that what happened was truly tragic.  No one 
really knows why the kid jumped, but who's to say that same kid couldn't 
have done it on a Sunset?  Would your attitude be the same?

Cheers***
Cami

>Hey Brian,
>
>In reference to your version of PLUR...
>
>PLUR is not a vice to get your mack on. Granted, they may interweave at
>points.
>
>PLUR is not a way to approach a person, it is, in essence, a way to exist.
>

I wasn't suggesting that the concept of PLUR is about "the right way" to
approach someone to score... I was just commenting that some people seem to
think that living life with PLUR and approaching an attractive stranger at
a rave are completely incompatible. They are not, IMHO. I've noticed again
and again on this list, that there are those who wish that raves could be
some sanctuary in the world where sexual attraction does not exist. I would
have to say that: 1) anywhere that you put a bunch of people together, it's
almost guaranteed that there will be SOME form of sexual attraction; and 2)
It's possible to treat someone with love and respect and still "hit on"
them. I think that those who want to pretend that sexuality doesn't exist
at raves, have probably had some bad "meat-market" type experiences. For
that, I'm sorry, but I think it would be foolish to try and pretend that
because you don't want the sex vibe to be there, it shouldn't/won't be
there. It's a fact of life for healthy human beings. Rather than wishing it
away, I think it's best to try to educate people so that the vibe is
"healthy, fun sexuality" and not "scamming meat-market."


>Also, in reference to the fact that people don't agree with you approaching
>someone on the dancefloor... take this into consideration...

I totally understand where you're coming from here, I was just using the
word "dancefloor" very loosely. It IS pretty rude to break someone out of
their dancefloor trance/bliss.

--
Brian

on as though nothing happened - the boat just puttin' along, leaving two 
people to fend for themselves in the middle of the bay??!

They should have stopped the boat (and the party!!), put on any
searchlights, and immediately called authorities for help.  Anything less
than that is unconscienable. 

All we can do now is try to make this easier on the families.  I think a 
memorial fundraiser is a great idea.

N


>

To: "Brian Benitez" <benitez@hotwired.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: RE: PLUR vs. the booty machine (was Re: Body Piercing)

I'd have to go with Brian here.  I don't think it makes sense seperate PLUR 
from normal human attraction.  The vibe sucks when a party becomes nothing but 
a single's bar, and I'm not down with that kind of activity at a rave.  But I 
think it also destroys the vibe to say that you can't to get to know somebody 
a little better.  A simple rule of thumb is this:  1.  Don't go to raves 
expecting booty.  That is sleazy.  2.  If you just have to talk/dance with 
someone, be civilized about it.  The only problems I've ever had with guys 
approaching me is when he just won't leave me alone, otherwise it's cool.  
Unfortunately, the most annoying tend to be high or drunk.  Many people who 
are cool when sober can be most difficult when high.  In short, my only 
problem with people approaching others is when they go about it in crude and 
incessant manner.

Miccaela

----------
From: 	sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com on behalf of Brian Benitez
Sent: 	Tuesday, February 18, 1997 2:48 PM
To: 	sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: 	NRR: PLUR vs. the booty machine (was Re: Body Piercing)

What I don't understand about the "rave" scene, and about this thread, is
why people seem to think that PLUR and sexual attraction are mutually
exclusive. Granted, there is a sleazy way to approach that attractive
someone, and it's very often found in your "meat market" type places. I
admit, this can be very offensive. But it's really a matter of how you
approach the person, isn't it? Granted, many people, no matter how
respectfully they are approached, are not interested in meeting anyone -
but if that's the case, then they should say so politely, and the other
person should take the hint. There seems to be an attitude among many
people on this list, and people I've encountered in the scene, that you
can't mix PLUR and approaching that attractive someone out there on the
dance floor. And I have to say I don't agree. Discuss?

-Brian

Brazillian proverb:

In this country, we have everything we need.
Except what we don't have.

>From Sunday's Examiner.

http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/examiner/article.cgi?year=
1997&month=02&day=16&article=METRO708.dtl

Would-be hero "had a big heart' 

Search called off for two men who jumped into Bay

Anastasia Hendrix
OF THE EXAMINER STAFF
Michael Dougan of The Examiner staff contributed to this report.

           As nightfall halted the Saturday search for two men who leaped 
into the Bay during a St. Valentine's Day cruise - a
           Georgia tourist and the San Franciscan who tried to save him - 
the would-be rescuer's family and friends painted a portrait
           of a hero time and again. 

           "He never had the desire to be a hero. He just had a big heart 
and cared about people and didn't want to see people get
           hurt," said Sean Ravenscraft, who witnessed the valiant effort 
of fellow security guard Ricardo Ortega Jr. 

           Starting at 2:05 a.m. Saturday, a U.S. Coast Guard helicopter 
and five search and rescue boats combed a 20-square-mile
           area from Hunters Point to Bay Farm Island in Alameda looking 
for Tavaris Willis, 20, and Ortega, 28. 

           Life expectancy in the 55-degree water is from four to six 
hours for a healthy adult, according to Coast Guard officials,
           who called off the search at dusk Saturday. 

           A Coast Guard spokesman said the search would not be resumed 
Sunday because all areas of the water had already been
           thoroughly examined. 

           Willis, a resident of the Atlanta suburb of Marietta, jumped 
from the third deck of the Jack London Commodore dinner
           cruise ship around 2 a.m. Saturday during a private party. 
Ortega, who lives on Potrero Hill, immediately climbed over the
           waist-high railing of the deck and jumped 26 feet into the 
Bay. 

           "There was all this commotion as I made way up to the deck, 
and then I saw Rick standing on the other side of the railing,
           and I said, "Rick, don't jump in after him,' " said 
Ravenscraft, who was working with Ortega that night. 

           "But he just looked back at me and took off," said 
Ravenscraft, Ortega's best friend. 

           It was a split-second decision that reflected a lifetime of 
trying to help others, say those who knew Ortega best. 

           Ravenscraft said that when a brawl broke out in a nightclub 
and someone wielded a knife and tried to stab him, Ortega
           grabbed the knife and handcuffed the person before any harm 
was done. 

           After an armed robbery at another club, Ortega chased the 
getaway car even as the robbers fired at him. 

           "He just always wanted to help people," said Willa Ortega of 
her husband. 

           The San Francisco firefighter said her husband was a highly 
trained expert in law enforcement. 

           Raised in San Francisco, Ortega graduated in 1986 from El 
Camino High School. He served several years in the U.S.
           Army after high school and was trained as a sharpshooter, his 
wife said. She added that Ortega won numerous military
           awards. "He was proud of them, but he didn't display them," 
she said. 

           Ortega worked as a community service officer, assisting 
regular police in various chores, in San Bruno before moving
           back to San Francisco and attending the SFPD's Police Academy, 
said Willa Ortega. A certified lifeguard, Ortega was a
           strong swimmer who regularly worked out at the gym. 

           He started his own security business, Panther Private Security 
Services, with Ravenscraft while waiting to land a job as a
           firefighter so he could work with his wife. 

           Hired those closest to him 

           Willa Ortega said he wanted to take care of those closest to 
him, which is why he trained and hired his father to work for
           his company. The two also played racquetball and loved to 
tinker with cars, she said. 

           Willa Ortega learned of her husband's disappearance Saturday 
morning after returning from work. Despite the fact that the
           search had not found him after 15 hours, she said she was 
still optimistic he was alive. 

           "I've experienced a few losses in my life and usually I can 
feel it when someone close to me has departed," she said. "And
           I don't have that feeling." 

           Ravenscraft said partygoers had complained Willis was unruly - 
accosting people and telling them he was the devil.
           Alcohol was being served to passengers over age 21. 

           Responding to the complaints, Ravenscraft made his way to the 
top deck - and finally arrived just in time to get a glimpse
           of Ortega leaping into the Bay. 

           He looked over the rail and spotted the flashlight that Ortega 
was holding when he jumped - its light bobbing in the water. 

           "My impulse was to jump in after him to try and save him," 
Ravenscraft said. 

           Instead, he ran to the first deck to get a life preserver and 
inform the captain there were two men overboard. Every minute
           seemed like an hour, he said, recalling his desperate attempt 
to flash the SOS signal with his flashlight to signal for help. 

           4 captains aboard 

           "It was a tragedy that never should have happened," said Capt. 
Ward Hornblower Proescher. 

           Proescher - one of four captains aboard the yacht - said he 
was horrified when he heard there were two people in the
           water. 

           "I immediately spun the yacht around, and in the water about 
75 yards away I could see the flashlight - one he had asked to
           borrow from me earlier," said Proescher, fleet commander and 
president of Commodore Dining Cruises Inc. 

           "We were so excited when we saw that and we started moving in 
that direction," he said. "And I thought Rick is going to
           be a hero, he'll be in all the papers tomorrow. 

           "And then the light went off. And we never saw anything 
again." 

           The music stopped. And the party turned panicked and somber as 
the nearly 500 partygoers ran to the rails to see if there
           was any trace of the men. 

           "It was so sad and eerie," said Proescher Saturday, looking 
out at the empty Jack London cruise ship docked in the harbor
           near Jack London Square in Oakland. "Everyone was calling out 
after them." 

           Willis jumped just as the 80-foot-long replica of a Hudson 
River steamboat - which had departed from Alameda - crept into
           the Bay from the Oakland Estuary, he said. The boat was 
traveling at 6 knots, about 9 mph, and the water was calm. 

           It's the first time since Proescher began sailing in 1973 that 
anyone has gone overboard, he said, calling such an event an
           "extreme rarity." 

           But he was filled with praise for Ortega. Even though they had 
just met earlier that evening, Proescher said he was
           impressed with the security guard's professionalism and 
personality. 

           Ortega did not work for the Commodore cruise line but was 
hired by acquaintances - promoters who sponsored the party
           as a commercial enterprise. Ortega had previously provided 
security for a rave party the same people had thrown at Cesar's
           Latin Palace. The Valentine's party was scheduled to last from 
midnight to 5 a.m. 

           "Courage and bravery' 

           "When I see courage and bravery like that I draw back in 
reverence," Proescher said. "This man is a hero. Who the hell
           else would have gone in there like that? If I were a guest on 
a yacht and someone went overboard, I would not be the hero
           that Rick Ortega was. What he did was incredible." 

           Leona Ortega, the eldest of his four siblings, said she was 
anxious but held a glimmer of hope that her brother was still
           alive. 

           "He is so strong, and he is a fighter, so we are still hoping 
and clasping our fingers and hoping for the best," she said, as
           she sat with her father by the phone. 

           "Who knows, maybe he did save this guy and they are somewhere 
just waiting to be found," she said. "Maybe he's
           unconscious. Maybe he's already in a hospital somewhere." 

           The family's stress was heightened because Ortega's mother is 
away visiting relatives and doesn't know what happened. 

           "We don't want to call her," said Leona Ortega. 

           Another sister, vacationing in Monterey, also does not know. 

           Willa Ortega said not knowing was the worst - and spoke of the 
many unanswered questions darting through her mind. 

           The Coast Guard will investigate the incident to determine 
whether anything could have been done to prevent it, said
           spokesman Bruce Pimental.

poon@juno.com wrote:
>there's so many good reviews for love a fair ... and only one for techno
>love children... i guess there weren't too many sfravers @ TLC.

OK, OK, I'll kick down.  I got there late, around 2, and decided to make up
for lost time by planting myself by one of those big fans and freaking out
as hard as I could for the rest of the night.  Fun!  And hot, yes.
Strange...it was probably the least crowded event I've been to there, but
definitely the hottest and wettest.  Just more movin, I guess.  Music: good
thumping techno stuff, though occasionally monotonous and generally less
melodic emphasis than I like to hear--still plenty to get me jumping (of
course, I am one of those white people).  The 2x4 approach was interesting.
I was really glad to see them trying it out and broadening the DJing
horizon a bit, but I think it had some drawbacks.  The mixing, overall,
seemed more abrupt than it might have been.  Not less precise, but quicker
and with less consistency of feel or rhythm from track to track.  I didn't
pay close enough attention to the decks to say for sure that it was really
was due to the two-DJ arrangement, but it seemed like it.  I heard Deaks
solo the night before at SJDRS, and that was definitely smoother.

The "Dream Core" room was excellent, too, but what a difference!  Every
time I stepped in there I felt like I'd been teleported to a completely
different party.  The temperature dropped ten or fifteen degrees, the
humidity about 50%, the lights came on, the colors changed, the music got
all slow and funky, you could suddenly hear people talking...quite a shock.
I was actually more comfortable back in the Storm Core, but I wish I'd
spent more time chilling...everyone was cool, fruit was great, chai was
awesome--kept me alive all night--and grooves were fat.  Did I really hear
Fishbone?  Who put that on?

Great party.  I know because I found myself filthy and exhausted, wandering
the streets of San Francisco with the rising sun on my face.  That's a
sign.

There haven't been any reviews for Friday night parties, either...anyone go
to Infinitely One?  I was considering it, but by good fortune ended up at
St. John's.  Also a great party, that.  Congrats Starchild.  And what an
amazing laser.  It showed up at TLC, too, so I suspect it's a new Gateway
fixture.  Very simple, but what an immense effect.  It fit the long, high
body of St. John's beautifully--didn't come through quite so brilliant at
TLC, but still an excellent accoutrement.

anarch@scruznet.com

John S. Lee wrote:

>Of course, in order for us to feel better, a group of
>genuinely good people will get together to throw a party to collect some
>funds for whatever.  How ironic.  And this is often touted  as a way for
>the scene to heal itself...yeah, let's throw another drug party, collect
>some money then give it to the family.


I agree with John on this. Throwing another party for someone who may be an
inocent victim of our scene does not feel right to me. I would much rather
ask everyone who feels for this family and wants to help them out, to just
dig into your pockets, and take the $10, $20 or $50 you would spend on a
night of partying, and give it to them. Maybe even spend a night at home
with your family/friends that you would normally have been out partying.

Think about the impact of your actions.....just for a second, lets consider
the kid who jumped, and assume that it was a suicide, do you think that he
could in his wildest dreams thought that his killing himself could have
taken another mans life. Could he have even thought of the devestation to
the lives of a total stranger, that his actions could cause ?? I don't
think so. And to think that he might have been acting totally irrational
due to some drug induced state just makes matters worse.

I'll stop now before I get all worked up.

Vince

  Ok... maybe a bad subject line but I know there are an abundant number of
Jewish people on this list.  Time for a NRR event.  This one is on March 1st
at the Lawrence Hall of Science... check it out--

           *Havdalah Beneath the Stars*
            ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
 
            At the Lawrence Hall of Science Saturday, March 1st

               Begining @ 7:30 p.m.
          A Havdalah cellebration for the whole family.  Havdalah is the
closing ritual for Shabbat.  Join the East Bay Jewish community as we light
the braided candle, pass the sweet spices and celebrate the coming of a new
week.. together.

         Activities to follow ceremony:
    Sidewalk astronomy-discussion of Judaism and cosmology-arts and
crafts-music and dancing-and of course all of the Lawrence Hall of Science
exhibits.














------------------------------------------------------------------------------
------
       There are a limited amount of tickets so if you are interested call
Jamie @ the center for Jewish living and Learning or the Jewish Federation of
the Greater East Bay at (510) 839-2900.  Tix are $7 dollars for adults and $5
for teenagers and children.  All ages welcome.
        Tix also available through CJLL or Afikomen Jewish Books & Arts.  
        ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

           You don't have to be Jewish to attend.  For those of you who have
never been a part of a Havdalah ceremony, or one in this large of a group, I
strongly reccomend it.  This is one of those events where you'll feel a
strong vibe between everyone there and even learn a thing or two.  It is very
spiritual, I hope to see some of you there, Jewish or not.  Until then....

         Hugs,
           'trice                           <<<<RAVEON>>>>

for some reason i've never really heard of anyone having a good time with 
gems...the ones i've ever used at record stores (i think i might have 
used directs) were horrendous about noise nstuff (hi jeff!)...so i 
dunno.

were $100 brand new each and they are super small so they didn't seem to 
have that noise problem.

1200's.  and a good mixer.  then when you get that first credit card 
payment you'll be REAL motivated to find the $$  =]...

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Feb 19 08:43:04 1997

Received: from upmajb06 ([204.95.110.89]) by upsmot01.msn.com (8.6.8.1/Configuration 4) with SMTP id IAA07215 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 19 Feb 1997 08:37:29 -0800
Date: Wed, 19 Feb 97 16:34:01 UT
From: "Anonymous " <vbaird@msn.com>
Message-Id: <UPMAIL09.199702191641360707@msn.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Confessions of a techno newbie / it's gonna be all right
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I've been hearing a lot of concern about techno's growing popularity and what 
effect it will have on the whole scene.  I just thought I'd share my views on 
the subject, why I'm not to worried about it . . .

First of all, I'm one of the newbies myself.  I used to listen to (actually, I 
still do) alternative, hip hop, and r&b, and some other stuff as well.  
However, I've always been attracted to techno.  Sure, high energy and all that 
was okay, but the few techno songs I used to hear (the first being "Charly" 
and "Sesame's Treat," i believe) I loved.  I couldn't get enough of it, but I 
didn't have any friends who listened to it, so I didn't know where to go to 
get more.  Ravers were just people I saw on TV, I never saw one in real life 
before.

Then came along the infamous Prodigy and Chemical Brothers buzz clips, and 
Mtv's Amp.  It blew me away about how much stuff I had never been exposed to 
(not even the super popular songs).  I began taping Amp through my stereo, and 
I'd listen to the tapes 24/7 (this was the only techno I had).

I expected my friends to feel the same way.  So at a kick-back party I popped 
one of my tapes in.  First song was Orbital, i think, "halycon and on and on," 
whatever that songs called (I'm trying, y'all)  It did not go over well.  
"What is this???" they asked.  "It's techno," I say.  "Techno?  It sounds a 
little weird to be techno," they reply.  "It doesn't sound like the normal 
stuff."  "Normal stuff?"  I say, thinking they've known about this stuff all 
along, "What normal stuff?"  "You know, like Gina G and all that."

Needless to say, before the first song was over, the tape came off.  That 
leads to my first conclusion, that most people aren't ready for, or interested 
in, techno music.  My friends aren't that crazy about The Prodigy even.  They 
like the song, but they aren't going to be charging any record stores to get 
the new album.

When I came to school yesterday, I mentioned to these same friends that there 
was a rave last weekend (the loveaffair thing).  "RAVE???" they said.  "You 
should have told us!  We could have had hella fun!"  You see, most people have 
this idea of a rave being all about sex, drugs, and techno (and you don't have 
to be 21!!!)  Perhaps the media is responsible for this, I dunno, but it's 
supposed to be some grand, gigantic party.  And whether they like techno or 
not, they all like a good party.

However, I'm not too concerned with this either.  #1, you can't go to rave and 
not like techno.  I know my friends would become weary of dancing for over 2 
hours and never hearing Real McCoy.  #2, there are plenty of clubs playing 
HiNRG, alternative, industrial, house etc., that are much cheaper than a rave, 
within a reasonable distance, less likely to be broken up by cops, serve 
alcohol, and you can "meet people there--" the meat market atmosphere.  It'll 
take one or two raves before the average person moves on to something more 
appealing to them.

So if the music and the rave isn't turning them on, then what is?  What turned 
me on to techno was how simply sitting down and listening to the music could 
take me to a whole higher level--something that doesn't happen listening to 
most popular music genres.  Raves are only attractive to me because of the 
music, but especially that nonmeat market, superficial vibe so present in the 
r&b / hip hop house parties I've been too.  As for alternative, I could never 
dance to it . . . you can't express yourself like you can with techno.  You 
just bang your head or get in the mosh pit and throw chairs.  Not the same 
effect on the soul, imho.  But when I talk about how the music affects me to 
my friends, they think I'm going nuts.

>From someone who's on the "other side," return all your black gear you were 
going to wear to mourn the death of the scene.  Straight up, the american teen 
isn't going to trade in their Alanis Morrissette and/or Snoop Dogg cds for 
Orbital or even Prodigy for awhile.  I'm concerned about what might happen 
when they get bored with alt. and hip hop, but most likely they will create 
new forms of rock and rap to listen to, instead of turning to techno.

In other words, I think everything will be fine.

Miccaela
becalmacidrage   (<------it's an anagram)

P.S.  I'd like to 1.  apologize for waste of bandwidth, 2.  hear your views on 
the subject (even flaming, although I don't know what I've said to deserve 
it), and 3.  ask if there are any ravers in Sacramento who wouldn't mind 
hooking up with me and educating this poor ignorant girl about the scene 
(don't you feel sorry for me?  I have no friends w/ the same interests, I'm an 
outcast  *sniff sniff*)

email at vbaird@msn.com

Hello Everyone, 

		My name is Marco and I've been on this list for about a 
year now without posting once.  I think that my time has come although 
I've felt like posting before, but have not come across to it yet.  Well 
I won't talk too much about myself just because I know how boring it can 
be sometimes.  Anyways I'm from Toronto, and have been raving since early 
1995.  I've been to over 50 parties and consider myself quite addicted!  
I used to go almost every week, but now I just go to select parties that 
i'll know i will have a good time at.  ( I used to go to every party no 
matter how large or small just because it was a "rave" but now I usually 
choose the smaller parties, because that's where I usually have the most 
fun).  
I really like reading the posts to see what's going on in San Fran.  I 
usually can't say anything about the parties because I've never been to 
SF or any of these parties that everyone talkes about.  I just want to 
say that many of the people on this list are very bright and most of them 
have nice positive things to say, although this does not stop people from 
voicing their personal opinions, which is also fantastic!
Anyway's I look forward to posting more often, and getting to know more 
people on the list!  Much Love




Marco

Cybertribe,

I know some of you on the list already, but I felt I'd sort of reintroduce
myself as well since I just resubbed this past weekend (finally got a
computer at home!).  I had been out here visiting like 5 times last year
from the East Coast, and finally landed a job in Mountian View in October.
I spun at this amazing party in Newark, New Jersey, on the day before I
moved with Joey Beltram, Electric Indigo ( <----she is the fucking
*bomb*), Frankie Bones, and more.  I literally went straight from the
party to the airport got on a plane and moved out here with little more
than a suitcase and my records.

I've been devoting myself to my work and setting up my home studio, but
have managed to spin at two raves in the Bay Area, one in L.A., and one
back in NYC since I've been here.  I love the vibe and the openness of the
San Francisco scene, though.  The joy and positivity you feel at the
parties here is amazing.

I'm 25 and started DJing five years ago when DJ GeoffE and I started a
tekno club called the Freight Yard in Allentown, PA, that is still open
and running today.  Actually, it's the last of the original weekly tekno
parties on the East Coast with the unfortunate closing of Scott Henry's 
Fever and Buzz down in Washington, DC, a couple of weeks ago.  I've thrown
and helped produce hunderds of raves on the East Coast and it was very had
for me to leave my rave family and blood family.  I needed a chance to
experience something new and to change and grow.

Out East, people know me as DJ Mars, but out of respect for Mike (aka
MARS) from Frequency 8 and to avoid all the confusion the two of us have
encountered already using the same DJ name, I'm now just using my real
name when I spin (well, except for the Bagok Tribe's party on Mar. 29th).

I'd really like to get to meet more of you in the next few weeks, and if
I do, ask me for a DJ demo tape.  As I had said in a previous post, I'm
living in the City, and looking for a roommate, if you're looking, drop me
a message.  Also, if you're interested in hearing the rave history of the
East Coast or seeing every flyer for every event there, or just wanna come
over and listen to my record collection or the music I've been working on,
reply too!

peace and love and Spring and Summer,
Marshal

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Marshal H. Villarosa                               Applications Engineer
Talarian Corporation                               415.965.8050 x. 168
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Just one more stupid promoter trick...

If any of you have received a flyer for Field Trip...

Please be wary.

This party is falsely putting DJs names on their flyer.

3 DJs: Jazz-E, Corey, and Leo were never booked for this event, YET their
names appear on the flyer.

Please avoid this party at all costs, as it is probably a scam, in addition
to the fact that they are showing an enormous amount of disrespect.

thx,
dnns

Amy R Starkey wrote:
> 
> On Sat, 15 Feb 1997, ameba wrote:
> 
> > Splish started off just like the last one...but got worse. Some guy
> > jumped off into the Bay and a security person jumped in after him. I
> > think they found the security person but not the person who jumped.
> 
> I heard this too, this morning.  I have heard that the City is suing
> Stacy of Nomad Interactive because of the person who jumped overboard
> (due to OD'ing I also heard).  I am just repeating rumors heard from
> someone else.  I would really like to know what actually happened from
> someone who was there....

I got married over the weekend on a boat run by the same company, the
night after this incident.  The captain of our boat was the same captain
that piloted the ill-fated boat of the night before.  Apparently the
security guard that jumped over was a good friend of the captain.  The
captain saw the guard go over, saw that he had a light, brought the boat
around thinking he'd see the light, but never found either person.  Both
are still unaccounted for.  

The captain was hoarse.  He did our ceremony, but you could hardly hear
him.  Afterwards I asked if he had a cold.  Apparently he had spent the
entire night before trying to find his friend in the darkness...

S

From: solle@ix.netcom.com (Sunny)
Subject: Raving Lunacy
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Its been awhile since I have contributed to the list and I 
apologize that my response couldnt be to a more positive thread.  

First, as a promoter my worst nightmare is the thought that I 
should be forced to endure what the Nomad promoters did this past 
weekend.  To suggest that they are truly culpable for such a tragic 
sequence of events is both callous and absurd.  

That said, I remember the sense of disgust I felt when my friend 
(who was on board) told me that after approximately two hours the 
party proceeded.  Her excuse to me was, Shit everybody was outta 
their minds man and Doc and Jeno were there so the music had to go 
on.  In that instance, I do fault Nomad.

I think, or at least I hope, that people can accept the excuse of 
two possible deaths as reason enough to call a night quits. Once 
again, I was not on board that evening.  Had I been, I cant 
imagine that I would want anything to do with continuing the party 
under those circumstances.  Ive seen a lot over the years and I 
have to admit that sometimes the extremes that this scene offers 
can really scare me.  But partying after two people have died is 
not only sick but disrespectful. 

My sympathies are with the families of those that departed that 
evening.  Put yourself in their shoes.  I'm sure that they'd be 
very relieved to hear that the party was able to proceeded as 
planned.

-Sunny

KC wrote:
> I'd just like to say that I
> personally am not sympathetic to hearing how fucking high someone was.

Right on!

> All you see these days (with exceptions, of
> course) are the posts about how PHun or how PHat a party is.  How PHony
> is my reply.

Wouldn't that be "Fony"?  ;)

> Now, when I think about going to a party, I think, "let's
> find somewhere were I can ignore the rest of the crowd, hang with my
> friends, and chill to some music."

Before I stopped, that was EXACTLY what it was getting to be.  So I
turned to the smaller raves with a known factor, friends of mine that
shared a similar desire to be with good people at a good event with good
music.  The people make the rave, and some of the people I was running
into were just not on the same wavelength or were so entirely messed up
they couldn't function anymore.  Not a lot of fun, that.

> I just know
> something's up when Nancy gets called old-school for bringing oranges to a
> party, though, and everyone I see talks about how high they are.

Nancy's comment stuck with me, too.  Yeah, I always bring fruit and
candy, but the last party I went to I got some pretty strange looks when
I was handing stuff out.  I found one person that was enthusiastic about
sharing an orange.  I sat down with that lady and had a wonderful time
chatting, giving a backrub, talking some more, meeting her friends,
laughing, etc. -- you know, that "Old Skool" stuff...

> It's over when it's just a party.

Amen, but that's just what it's turning into; the "beer bust" of the
'90s.

S

I am going to jump into this snake pit because people don't really give a
damn about each other.  There is no respect for anything, and people take
the first opportunity to beat the fuck out of each other via , this, thing,
this ether crap.

others presence.  Practice in ether what you do in reality, and we'll all
get along better.

Dorena,

PLUR means nothign to me, it means little to the majority on this list.
Let's start to face some real facts here.

PLUR:  You start out calling Wayne D. and asshole.  Can you please tell me
where the value is in callign someone names?  Wayne was expressing his
opinion about my post and his feelings toward the event.  Can't he have
whatever opinon he wants?  He never names the two promoters, YOU DID.  To
me, Nomad is an entity that throws parties, a posse, I don;t know tom and
stacy from spit.  Of course you told the whole list about who was who and
now everyone knows.

If Wayne has a beef with these folx, so be it.  There was no need in you
making this a public matter.  As for his feelings, maybe you and Wayne can
hook up and talk FACE TO FACE, and get to know his feelings, instead of
reading a post and inferring alot of stuff out of it.

PLUR: You said "keep your personal conflicts with people off of the list
and GROW UP!!!!".  I see, and what were you doing in that singular
sentence?.  You were doing the same thing you chastised Wayne for doing.
Practice what you preach sistah.

Look, I really don't care who who threw what party, who promoter X is, and
why they do what they do.  I don't give a fuck about Burning Man's mythic
mystical moments, I don't give a fuck about the next big party, or even
these days the next small one.  Somebody died, get it, someone passed away
as a direct result of, oh yes, THIS SCENE.  That is what can happen when
people are amatuers or are disturbed, or are novice crackerjackers; they
can lose thier lives.  That is what can also happen when the focus is on
getting high and NOT on the music.  If homeboy was concentrating on the
music, and had a responsible posse around him, we might be talking about
reviews of the party instead of the obituaries.

Stop trivializing two peoples death with trivialities of whose friggin'
party it was.  It DOESN'T MATTER.

responsible action:  Nomad should take pause, they should put an
announcement up with thier regrets and good wishes.  Next, they should take
some time off from doing parties for a while, and should spearhead a
collection effort for teh families of these two young men.  I will go even
farther, although this will NEVER, EVER HAPPEN.  Maybe this scene needs an,
oh my, ENTIRE MONTH OFF.  No parties, no nothing.  No music, no dancing, no
beats.  There are many more weeks of fun to be had, and maybe it would
allow people to re-connect.  People should do little get togethers in thier
houses, have a fuckin' cookout, a barbeque, listen to something other than
house.  Groove with your friends to some different beats, some different
music, talk about the things that have made a difference, talk about the
scene w/o actually being in it.  Talk about it w/o the latest
goa/house/trance playing as a backdrop.  Go hear some REAL music, the music
of nature.  Go cmaping, snowboarding, skiing with pals.  Yeah, smoke your
herb, drink your beer, hey even engage in some mushies, but do it in a
remote, yet very, very, safe place w a responsilbe posse who has your back
24/7 like a ripe as melon.  But like MLK said I have a dream, and like his,
I know mine will never be realized on a large scale.  Well sometimes a
dream is all one has.

Now can we please stop this incessant bullshit fighting.  I tell ya what.
If you want to fight , fight me.  I'm 100% down to clown, and can take as
well as give.  If you ain't up to that, why not just let it all go and just
get along.

Can we do that, for a little while...please.

Back to sensible commentary...

Audi 5000 and counting,
John

PS!:  All you PLURHeads; I wish you would practice what you preach.  If you
are calling someone names, pissing on someone, picking a fight, telling
others how to live, chastising others w/o constructive critique, and of
course all the while beating people over the head with that mantra, you are
looking like a hypocrite.  Practice the acronym or drop it from your
signature.  Spare me the brain cycles trying to figure out if words mean
anything other than a way to indentify yourself with a pop-mantra.  Action
ALWAYS speaks louder than words.

Much peace to you all! Out.

> jphelgeson@ucdavis.edu,Internet writes:

> >"Underwater" then?  ;)

I'm sorry, I didn't mean any harm by that...  I guess that was sort of
inappropriate; it's just that I have been hearing so many tragic stories
as of late that I wanted to try to lighten up my public comments a bit.  I
started to feel incredibly depressed thinking about the fact that the
security guard lost his life helping another; that's about the noblest way
one can die (imho).  But I also find that rooting in sadness makes one
very bitter, and that looking for a shred of happiness in the face of such
sorrow tends to make serious issues easier to take, for myself at least.
My sincere apologies if my words offended anyone, I really had no
intention of doing so... 
-=Joe=-

people on it.  Just my guess, but I'd limit it to 300, tops.  I welcome
corrections to that number.

> Nomad is not responsible for the actions of it's partygoers.

        I have to agree. Any activity has risks. We all take our 
lives in our hands every time we get in some car to go for a drive.
Without risk, we have no life at all.

On the other hand, I now plan on avoiding Nomad events.

> Before this it was Burning Man, and people were defending that.

        There's a difference between 2 deaths during a 5-day party
of 10,000 people, and 2 deaths during a 5-hour cruise of 300 people.

        Also, if you read any of the literature the Burning man people
put out, it said many times "fuck up out in the desert and you may die. 
Take personal responsibility for your own survival." and so on. I doubt 
the Nomad folk were putting out those kinds of warnings.

jslee@apple.com,Internet writes:
>I hate it when whites
>utter this word, much less spell it out.

John, I have a lot of respect for you because of all you have done by
responsibly directing people down "the path."  You've really hit a
nerve with this one though.  The word is "nigger."  It is a word of
hate and oppression (which it sounds like you know) and thus, it is
veryVERY ugly.  The usage of this word in Tina's post was not what YOU
made it out to be.  I personally HATE the damb word and only used it
because I felt that I needed to in order to make this intelligible but,
for you to say that it is okay for African Americans to use that word
while other people shouldn't is wrong.  It is simply perpetrating the
sickness behind the word.  That itself defies PLUR which is a
philosophy of life quite a lot of us on this list live by each and
every day.

>P.S.  Funny I could give a damn about the curses, the drug talk, but I
>won't stand for racially devicive language.  Zero tolerance.  Be glad
>I'm
>in a good mood today.

I understand and reciprocate the feeling.  Do you really NEED to
threaten in order for you point to be taken?  That's the way the last
sentence comes thru.  Personally, I'm always glad when people are in a
good mood!

Here's hoping that we can all live with, love with and learn with each
other,

hugZ,

-SoNiC

p.s. Even though that word is sooo very offensive - it still is just a
word.  The hate and atrocities perp'd with that word are different
today than they were even 20 years ago.  The negativity resides within
each of us.....

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Interesting point.

I'm pretty much on the fence when it comes to these issues. You see I'm
1/2 black and 1/2 white. But I'm considered black because when you're even
a smidgen black you're treated differently by the general public. Although
I don't look black in most people's eyes I don't look caucasian either. I
look like a mix. This both to my benefit and against it.

It's to my benefit because I'm not assumed to be black and am not
discriminated against based on my appearance. It's against my benefit
because I hear all kinds of racist remarks from people who are oblivious
to my heritage. I've lost respect for A LOT of people this way.

But as far as the N word, it doesn't bother me if it's used in the correct
context. Meaning if you're quoting someone else and not using it to put me
down it doesn't bother me. His post didn't bother me. But I never use the
word unless I'm joking around with my friend who's also half black....

I think people are a little too uptight about how to call people of
certain races... like do I call an African american "Black" or do I call
them "African American".. I have friends who have a hard time with this.
But it's kind of upsetting to be called a color instead of a race. I never
call someone "white". I was raised by my mom's side of the family that is
caucasian and have most always had caucasian friends. But one of my best
friends is also half African American....  

I'm babbling....

All I know is that we're all the same color underneath... and we're all
related in one way or another.

We should all love eachother. There is no reason to not love one another.
Life is too short for hate. 

Hugz,

Byroni

(The tall slender dude that was dancing at the front of the stage in the
main room.... looking like he was on something... and HE WAS!)

MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: This is one of the most fucked up things I have ever heard

>      you are the BIGGEST ASSHOLE on this list. what happened was tragic
> enough without you trying to start shit with tom and stacy. don't you think
> that they feel guilty enough over what has happened? now, you are trying to
> place the blame on them for something they had no control over. no one could
> have predicted what was going to happen the night of the party. they took the
> proper precautions to make sure that everything would go alright.
> unfortunately, something went wrong.

I agree that yelling to the media won't necessarily solve anything.

HOWEVER.

I am completely stunned by the fact that _no one_ did anything once
people fell overboard.  I hold the promoters, the ship captain, and the
partygoers responsible -- EVERYONE ON THE SHIP.

Here is the situation:  

Two people have just fallen off a boat into the Bay at night.  They are
*guaranteed* to be dead within five hours (hypothermia) unless someone
finds them, and could easily die much sooner if they're not good at
treading water.

The fact that everyone did not IMMEDIATELY stop what they were doing,
SHUT OFF the sound system and tell everyone to SHUT UP so that they
might hear the people who fell off (who no doubt were yelling their
lungs out),  call the Coast Guard and anyone else who would listen, tell
everyone to take those flashlights and glowsticks and start LOOKING for
them, is completely incomprehensible to me.

I know what I would be thinking if I was the security guard.  "Aw, fuck,
I'm gonna have to go save this asshole", so you jump out.  Maybe you
don't find him, so you signal back to the boat that you need help.

The boat doesn't stop.

You get to watch it slowly motor away into the distance while you
realize that YOU ARE GOING TO DIE if they don't turn around.  You are
yelling your lungs out.

But everyone is too self-absorbed to care, and they can't hear you
anyway, and the sound of laughter and "thump-thump-thump" slowly fades
off into the distance.

Within full sight of the lights of San Francisco, you are dead.  But you
get several hours to think about this.

Piss on everyone on that goddamn boat.  And if you can't figure out why
I'm angry, piss on you too.

// grigsbeast

> There's a difference between 2 deaths during a 5-day party
Of 10,000 people, and 2 deaths during a 5-hour cruise of 300 people.

>Also, if you read any of the literature the Burning man people
Put out, it said many times "fuck up out in the desert and you may die.
Take personal responsibility for your own survival." and so on. I doubt
the Nomad folk were putting out those kinds of warnings.

I totally agree.  Frankly, it is a testament to the folks who participated
in Burning Man that more people didn't die.  The playa is a VERY dangerous
place, and not for the typical drug-partyer that we all know and dislike.

As a note:  It is absolutely disgusting to me that the party resumed after
the two people disappeared.  This "party must go on" attitude is a perfect
example of the facile, trashy behavior that many of us older (20-something)
folks don't like about the scene.  We want music, conversation, dancing,
and a good vibe.  We don't want gangsters, dealers, and tweakers who have
no conception of reality.

"Underground" doesn't mean "lacking any sense of morality", does it?
