From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Feb 19 17:17:24 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id RAA21810; Wed, 19 Feb 1997 17:17:24 -0800 (PST)
Received: from bass-station.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with ESMTP id RAA21764; Wed, 19 Feb 1997 17:17:19 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [207.76.139.151] by bass-station.com
 with ESMTP (Apple Internet Mail Server 1.1.1); Wed, 19 Feb 1997 18:09:49 -0700
Message-Id: <v03007801af30cbe4f0fd@[207.76.139.151]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Ethan Miller <ethan@bass-station.com>
Subject: responsibility
Date: Wed, 19 Feb 1997 18:09:49 -0700
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

It's long been my belief that promoters are responsible for what happens at
their parties. The promoter picks who they 'market' to, they pick who they
let in and they either do or do not facilitate some form of what I'll call
magick to  protect the party and those who attend it. Might sound wishy
washy and new age but I've been to plenty of parties where I felt safe and
protected and I've also been to plenty of parties where I could feel random
violence waiting to happen, and it all, quite literally, begins with the
promoter.

A whole complex of things including the promoter's intentions and
awareness; the people at the party, their intentions and awareness; things
done before, during, and after the party to direct all of the above toward
a positive result, ultimately shape the energy that guides and informs the
party.

I would call turning the music back on with two people overboard, the
actions of people not terribly tuned in -- to anything.  How I would feel
as the parent of one of those missing were I to know this, horrifies me.
What could there possibly be to celebrate at that point? If this did in
fact happen, ultimately, no one but the promoters can be held responsible
for that decision.

Anyone facilitating the gathering of hundreds of people most of whom will
probably be out of their heads must have no illusions about their
responsibility for creating as safe and as healthy an environment as
possible.

Whether or not, as the promoters, Tom and Stacy should be held legally
responsible, I hope that, to the appropriate degree, they do feel
personally responsible: they invoked this voyage, and none of it would have
happened had they not. Oonly they will know if they did *everything* they
could to make it a safe trip. If they did, the deserve our sympathy, if
they did not they deserve our wrath.

yours in deep regret
ethan






( ethan miller )-------------- ----------
( http://www.bass-station.com )---------- -----------------------------------

On Tue, 18 Feb 1997, Kathryn Ankrum wrote:

> 
> From Sunday's Examiner.
> 
> http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/examiner/article.cgi?year=
> 1997&month=02&day=16&article=METRO708.dtl
> 
> Would-be hero "had a big heart' 
> 
> Search called off for two men who jumped into Bay
> 
> Anastasia Hendrix
> OF THE EXAMINER STAFF
> Michael Dougan of The Examiner staff contributed to this report.
> 
>            As nightfall halted the Saturday search for two men who leaped 
> into the Bay during a St. Valentine's Day cruise - a
>            Georgia tourist and the San Franciscan who tried to save him - 
> the would-be rescuer's family and friends painted a portrait
>            of a hero time and again. 
> 
>            "He never had the desire to be a hero. He just had a big heart 
> and cared about people and didn't want to see people get
>            hurt," said Sean Ravenscraft, who witnessed the valiant effort 
> of fellow security guard Ricardo Ortega Jr. 
> 
>            Starting at 2:05 a.m. Saturday, a U.S. Coast Guard helicopter 
> and five search and rescue boats combed a 20-square-mile
>            area from Hunters Point to Bay Farm Island in Alameda looking 
> for Tavaris Willis, 20, and Ortega, 28. 
> 
>            Life expectancy in the 55-degree water is from four to six 
> hours for a healthy adult, according to Coast Guard officials,
>            who called off the search at dusk Saturday. 
> 
>            A Coast Guard spokesman said the search would not be resumed 
> Sunday because all areas of the water had already been
>            thoroughly examined. 
> 
>            Willis, a resident of the Atlanta suburb of Marietta, jumped 
> from the third deck of the Jack London Commodore dinner
>            cruise ship around 2 a.m. Saturday during a private party. 
> Ortega, who lives on Potrero Hill, immediately climbed over the
>            waist-high railing of the deck and jumped 26 feet into the 
> Bay. 
> 
>            "There was all this commotion as I made way up to the deck, 
> and then I saw Rick standing on the other side of the railing,
>            and I said, "Rick, don't jump in after him,' " said 
> Ravenscraft, who was working with Ortega that night. 
> 
>            "But he just looked back at me and took off," said 
> Ravenscraft, Ortega's best friend. 
> 
>            It was a split-second decision that reflected a lifetime of 
> trying to help others, say those who knew Ortega best. 
> 
>            Ravenscraft said that when a brawl broke out in a nightclub 
> and someone wielded a knife and tried to stab him, Ortega
>            grabbed the knife and handcuffed the person before any harm 
> was done. 
> 
>            After an armed robbery at another club, Ortega chased the 
> getaway car even as the robbers fired at him. 
> 
>            "He just always wanted to help people," said Willa Ortega of 
> her husband. 
> 
>            The San Francisco firefighter said her husband was a highly 
> trained expert in law enforcement. 
> 
>            Raised in San Francisco, Ortega graduated in 1986 from El 
> Camino High School. He served several years in the U.S.
>            Army after high school and was trained as a sharpshooter, his 
> wife said. She added that Ortega won numerous military
>            awards. "He was proud of them, but he didn't display them," 
> she said. 
> 
>            Ortega worked as a community service officer, assisting 
> regular police in various chores, in San Bruno before moving
>            back to San Francisco and attending the SFPD's Police Academy, 
> said Willa Ortega. A certified lifeguard, Ortega was a
>            strong swimmer who regularly worked out at the gym. 
> 
>            He started his own security business, Panther Private Security 
> Services, with Ravenscraft while waiting to land a job as a
>            firefighter so he could work with his wife. 
> 
>            Hired those closest to him 
> 
>            Willa Ortega said he wanted to take care of those closest to 
> him, which is why he trained and hired his father to work for
>            his company. The two also played racquetball and loved to 
> tinker with cars, she said. 
> 
>            Willa Ortega learned of her husband's disappearance Saturday 
> morning after returning from work. Despite the fact that the
>            search had not found him after 15 hours, she said she was 
> still optimistic he was alive. 
> 
>            "I've experienced a few losses in my life and usually I can 
> feel it when someone close to me has departed," she said. "And
>            I don't have that feeling." 
> 
>            Ravenscraft said partygoers had complained Willis was unruly - 
> accosting people and telling them he was the devil.
>            Alcohol was being served to passengers over age 21. 
> 
>            Responding to the complaints, Ravenscraft made his way to the 
> top deck - and finally arrived just in time to get a glimpse
>            of Ortega leaping into the Bay. 
> 
>            He looked over the rail and spotted the flashlight that Ortega 
> was holding when he jumped - its light bobbing in the water. 
> 
>            "My impulse was to jump in after him to try and save him," 
> Ravenscraft said. 
> 
>            Instead, he ran to the first deck to get a life preserver and 
> inform the captain there were two men overboard. Every minute
>            seemed like an hour, he said, recalling his desperate attempt 
> to flash the SOS signal with his flashlight to signal for help. 
> 
>            4 captains aboard 
> 
>            "It was a tragedy that never should have happened," said Capt. 
> Ward Hornblower Proescher. 
> 
>            Proescher - one of four captains aboard the yacht - said he 
> was horrified when he heard there were two people in the
>            water. 
> 
>            "I immediately spun the yacht around, and in the water about 
> 75 yards away I could see the flashlight - one he had asked to
>            borrow from me earlier," said Proescher, fleet commander and 
> president of Commodore Dining Cruises Inc. 
> 
>            "We were so excited when we saw that and we started moving in 
> that direction," he said. "And I thought Rick is going to
>            be a hero, he'll be in all the papers tomorrow. 
> 
>            "And then the light went off. And we never saw anything 
> again." 
> 
>            The music stopped. And the party turned panicked and somber as 
> the nearly 500 partygoers ran to the rails to see if there
>            was any trace of the men. 
> 
>            "It was so sad and eerie," said Proescher Saturday, looking 
> out at the empty Jack London cruise ship docked in the harbor
>            near Jack London Square in Oakland. "Everyone was calling out 
> after them." 
> 
>            Willis jumped just as the 80-foot-long replica of a Hudson 
> River steamboat - which had departed from Alameda - crept into
>            the Bay from the Oakland Estuary, he said. The boat was 
> traveling at 6 knots, about 9 mph, and the water was calm. 
> 
>            It's the first time since Proescher began sailing in 1973 that 
> anyone has gone overboard, he said, calling such an event an
>            "extreme rarity." 
> 
>            But he was filled with praise for Ortega. Even though they had 
> just met earlier that evening, Proescher said he was
>            impressed with the security guard's professionalism and 
> personality. 
> 
>            Ortega did not work for the Commodore cruise line but was 
> hired by acquaintances - promoters who sponsored the party
>            as a commercial enterprise. Ortega had previously provided 
> security for a rave party the same people had thrown at Cesar's
>            Latin Palace. The Valentine's party was scheduled to last from 
> midnight to 5 a.m. 
> 
>            "Courage and bravery' 
> 
>            "When I see courage and bravery like that I draw back in 
> reverence," Proescher said. "This man is a hero. Who the hell
>            else would have gone in there like that? If I were a guest on 
> a yacht and someone went overboard, I would not be the hero
>            that Rick Ortega was. What he did was incredible." 
> 
>            Leona Ortega, the eldest of his four siblings, said she was 
> anxious but held a glimmer of hope that her brother was still
>            alive. 
> 
>            "He is so strong, and he is a fighter, so we are still hoping 
> and clasping our fingers and hoping for the best," she said, as
>            she sat with her father by the phone. 
> 
>            "Who knows, maybe he did save this guy and they are somewhere 
> just waiting to be found," she said. "Maybe he's
>            unconscious. Maybe he's already in a hospital somewhere." 
> 
>            The family's stress was heightened because Ortega's mother is 
> away visiting relatives and doesn't know what happened. 
> 
>            "We don't want to call her," said Leona Ortega. 
> 
>            Another sister, vacationing in Monterey, also does not know. 
> 
>            Willa Ortega said not knowing was the worst - and spoke of the 
> many unanswered questions darting through her mind. 
> 
>            The Coast Guard will investigate the incident to determine 
> whether anything could have been done to prevent it, said
>            spokesman Bruce Pimental. 
> 
> On Tue, 18 Feb 1997, Rob Rayle wrote:
> 
> > > What the hell was done about this?!  Is it true that the party just went
> > > on as though nothing happened - the boat just puttin' along, leaving two
> > > people to fend for themselves in the middle of the bay??!
> > 
> > 	Unfortunately, my copy of this article has been recycled. My
> > understanding is that the boat did turn around to search for the two
> > who went over, and that they did call for help, but they didn't stop
> > the party. Anybody got better info? Anyone who was there?
> > 
> > 
>

On Wed, 19 Feb 1997 elizabeth_o'connor@ccmail.rsco.com wrote:

>      There's no price listed for this... How much will it be?


YEP!!  I notice that the biggest parties refrain from putting price on 
SFR, their fliers, or their voicemail.  I just assume $25!

I remember one party at Pittsburg Skate that was a major-surprise $25 -
but at that point, everyone had driven an hour so they just shelled out
the cash rather than turning around and driving back...  I wonder how many
would not show up if they knew how much it would have been!  (The major
reason behind price secrecy, I imagine).

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Feb 19 18:18:57 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id SAA12687; Wed, 19 Feb 1997 18:18:57 -0800 (PST)

From: SFO2!SFO2PO!sgalloway@msatt.attmail.com (Galloway, Scott)
Received: from msatt by attmail; Thu Feb 20 02:17 GMT 1997
Subject: RE: memorial for security guard
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (SFraves), jslee@apple.com (John S. Lee)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: Text/Plain; charset=us-ascii

John,

Your words ring very true.  I agree wholeheartedly that people really need 
to take a break for a moment to reflect on what has just happened.  You're 
right about raving becoming a crutch to many, a shield people can hide 
behind to excuse their actions, or hide from the truth.  As a group, ravers 
in San Francisco have taken their place for granted, we all keep saying 
things like peace, love, unity and respect, but how many really know what 
these things mean?  I would like to believe that we all know the answers, 
but unfortunately, this is not the case.  I have only been on sfraves for 2 
days now, mostly to hear chat about the local scene, and to see what people 
had to say about the weekend, including the Splish cruise.

I'll say that I'm a bit suprised at the attitude of the posts found on 
sfraves.  At one time, sfraves was filled with people that were really in 
tune with what PLUR meant, before it became a buzz word.  Now I hear people 
saying PLUR like its going out of style, like it is just another passing 
fad, or secret handshake into the underground community of ravers.  Well, I 
honestly do not believe that the majority of these people truly understand 
its meaning, or even what it represents to them.

Yep, it's definately time to take a moment to reflect.  What just happened? 
 Do people realize what kind of reprecussions might happen from this type of 
accident?

As far as throwing another party for someone who was just killed at a 
party...well I would like for us as a group to think of something a little 
more appropriate to do than raving our butts off for "charity."  This simply 
isn't enough.  If people really would like to honor the heroics of the 
security guard, or mourn the death of a fellow raver, we all need to look 
deep into ourselves, and find the true meaning of these past occurances, and 
what they mean to us.  We need to really talk to each other about it, and 
support each other, and take that moment of reflection throughout our 
community in the hopes that we can reach that person who might have a 
similar accident in the future.  It's all about education, not partying or 
charity events.  Those merely soften the blow enough to allow our conscience 
to move on with as little guilt as possible.  We simply cannot hide from our 
fears, we must each individually confront them, and only upon fully 
understanding our fears can we really move on.

Thanks again for you post,

Scott =)
 ----------
From: John S. Lee
To: Rob Rayle; sgalloway
Cc: internet!cybertribe.com!Sub-Cmdr.Lycos; internet!netcom.com!ccat; 
internet!hyperreal.com!sfraves; internet!msn.com!vbaird
Subject: RE: memorial for security guard
Date: Tue Feb 18 1997 12:47PM

At 11:43 AM -0800 2/18/97, Rob Rayle wrote:
>>People have a right to kill themselves.. I think.. However,
>>the death of the security guard seemed really tragic..
>
>    From what I've read, the jumper sounds like a drug casualty,
>    not a suicide. Sorry, but even "harmless" psychedelics can
>    kill under the right (wrong) circumstances.

I heard about this the night after I talked to a friend about the party.
One of the things that has really been bugging me about parties of late is
the ever present "Yeah that sucked, but it was still a great party!  The
DJ's ROCKED IT!!!" ;(

I said it during the Burning Man/Omar incident, during other episodes where
people had to be carried out of parties on stretchers, seeing people on
respirators, etc.  And usually some pollyanna will pipe up from the drug
induced euphoric moment with "Let's not concentrate on the negative..." or
the even more tepid and dumb "Let's not forget all the other GOOD things
that have happened...." ARRGH!!!

Maybe what needs to be done, instead of running away from this reality, is
to confront it.  Is to ask ourselves "What are WE doing?".  I remember
during many drug induced hours asking myself that same question.  What was
I doing crackerjacking when I coulda been home playin with my kid, what was
I doing in a dark ass club when I coulda been huggin' and snugglin' with
the wife, what am I doing while somewhere out there someone is hurting,
suffering, etc.  These were some of my "E" & LSD thoughts during my later
days of this scene.

Now I have no problem with people going out and doing the do.  I do not
foist the massive responsibilities I have, or my heavy thoughts on others,
but at some time we gotta ask why we do the things we do, and to what ends?
I mean, when someone dies, giving his life for a crackerjacker (who is
still a human), how important does the party become?  Someone has died,
someone was seriously injured, and someone might never have a daddy or
mommy ever again.  What up?

Does the party go on, or are we human enough to really take pause.  Take
time out to assess what is really going on....I'll tell you what's going on
these days, and I don't need to go out to know this either:

It is nothing but a drug party, and it has become the reason the majority
party.  That's it, plain and simple.  This scene has changed, for the worse
IMO.

Yes, there are pockets of "vibe" and "goodness" out there for sure, and I
know some of you are involved in various scenes or cliques that are more
positive.  But, alas, you are outnumbered and in the extreme minority.
Just a note.  Parties these days are all about:
#1 - Scoring the drugs.
#2 - Music
#3 - Friends (only those you'll see in the scene, cuz' you ain't hangin'
otherwise).

Once again, let me reiterate, this does not apply to everyone, but this
scene, as a whole, has become the biggest escape vehicle since television.
And we do know the value TV has in our society and the value-add it
provides overall to our society.  I think the same can be said of the
current state of our dance culture.  People die, and the party must go on.
People get hurt, hospitalized, and the party goes on.  Poeple will never
walk again, never dance again, but the party must go on.  Sick, sick, sick!

"Yeah man, I saw this guy get decapitated, but dood, fuckin' DJ SoAndSo
tore it up, and man, I had a great time, despite the fact, this guy is
fertilizer."  Of course, in order for us to feel better, a group of
genuinely good people will get together to throw a party to collect some
funds for whatever.  How ironic.  And this is often touted  as a way for
the scene to heal itself...yeah, let's throw another drug party, collect
some money then give it to the family.

You know, if I didn't know the people I do, if I were half as bitter as
some would make me out to be, I would have a mind to call up the TV
stations, the cops, and whoever else I could, and have them investigate
FULLY what happened.  But even *I*, with all my high falutin talk won't
step up to that plate. Ironically my honor to many of the people in all of
this means I keep lotsa shit to myself, and that is where it'll stay.

So I have my own little forms of protest.  I stay away from the majority of
all of this.  I do go to really small events, like @ the TOP, or even a D7
party every blue moon.  I would even probably go to Stompy if it weren't on
the weekends I have visitation w/ my son, His Excellency (I love my boy,
he's the BOMB!).  But crackerjackin' @ a party is OUT.  Being out of my
skull is OUT.  And socializing ONLY at parties is OUT, OUT, OUT!

Out of all of this what do we get:  DRAMA.  The drama of people losing
thier lives because of drugs & irresponsible use.   The drama of people
never being able to dance again.  The drama of people throwing benefits
(read drug parties) for the purpose of, er, healing. The drama of girls
snatchin' other girls men, actively.  The drama of guys and girls notchin'
up thier bedposts with the conquests of other people's mates.  The drama of
some mother, some brother, some father, some sister, some daughter, some
son, crying because the person they love will never come home again.

But the party must go on.  Damn, that DJ' really rocked the fucking 
house....

I need a Kleenex, an enema, and even more of a break from parties...months
and counting,
John

P.S.  These are my opinions and thoughts.  I will pray for both of those
people who lost thier lives.  For the person who got so high he would never
ever touch the ground again, and for the person who gave his life trying to
make sure that this person would see his tribe again:  My hopes and prayers
are with you both.  Peace.

"Those who profess to favor freedom and yet depreciate agitation, are people
who want crops without ploughing the ground; they want rain without thunder
and lightning; they want the ocean without the roar of its waters... Power
concedes nothing without a demand; it never has and it never will."

Frederick Douglas, 1857

I apologize in advance for assuming some things about the circumstances
of the party in my last post.  Probably some of them are wrong and I'll
get plenty of well-deserved flamage for it.  And it's very easy to point
fingers at others when it wasn't your decision to make, so I am guilty
of that too.

However, I look back at how I've reacted to previous situations in my
life (friend borrows my motorcycle and bails off it, etc.) and I have a
hard time believing I would have reacted as those responsible did.  It
would have taken so little effort to search more, and the cost of not
doing so was so high...

Note to self: the ocean is not a swimming pool.  It can easily kill you
through your negligence, stupidity, poor communication, or just blind
circumstance.  A boat is much more than just a relatively bust-free
location.

In fact, many things we take for granted are very dangerous (cars), and
many things that look dangerous aren't.

For instance, despite all the fires, explosions, machines,
flamethrowers, and mayhem at Burning Man, what did people get injured or
killed by almost without exception?

Motor vehicles.  People ran into trucks, got ran into by trucks, got
their tents ran over by cars (with them inside), and I think there was
one drug overdose (from rave camp).

// grigsbeast

> Just one more stupid promoter trick...
> 
> If any of you have received a flyer for Field Trip...
> 
> Please be wary.
> 
> This party is falsely putting DJs names on their flyer.

reference to PCP was hurtful, and boy did I have to answer for it with my 
dad. I am 23 for Gog's sake! 

It's just when I was in HK last summer the scene pretty much changed. 
THey played all the cheesy stuff at raves, and it became a meat mkt. I 
couldn't turn on the TV without trance, techno, goa selling something I 
don't want to me. 

I would like to scene to get bigger and more popular, (more choices). But 
then you start getting the ;lager louts with their beer out on the pull. 
You know? Have you ever had to fiend of some drunk asshole in a rave?

comercialization it always becomes sexualised, blah blah blah. You've 
heard it all before.

hello all
my name is April.  Some of you know me. I finally got on line yay!!!!!  

I guess what i wanted to write about was what happens to people who do drugs
at parties.  it's not going to stop.  we all know that.  But maybe we can
educate those who do drugs.  I want to throw my first party sometime in the
near future.  What I want to do with the proceeds of the party is to make
pamphlets about the drugs people are doing. 
I guess the reason I think this would be a good idea is because I'll talk to
people who love 'e' and advocate it's use, yet they don't know what it is.
 about 75-80% of the people i know who do 'e' on a regular basis do not know
that it is a meth-amphetamine and that it has heroin in it.  
I used to tell people drugs were cool, but as soon as i found out what they
do to you, my views changed.  I've dropped 'e' three times, it was fun, but
it wasn't worth it, especially because i feel how it has effected me even
know, when i haven't done it in a really really long time.  
There are other drugs out there that are also harmful that people that people
don't know anything about, yet they still do them (GHB, Special K, Crystal
Meth etc...) Why would someone put somehting in their body that they don't
even remotely understand?
I'm sure i'm not the first person who has wanted to throw a benefit about
drug education.  i guess the kid in me is just asking for support and knowing
that there are you people out their that are willing to support me and my
friends makes me feel a lot more secure and my aspiration.
Hope to hear from all of you soon in the future!!!
Much Love
April :):):):):)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Feb 19 21:46:48 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id VAA03608; Wed, 19 Feb 1997 21:46:48 -0800 (PST)
Received: from upsmot02.msn.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with SMTP id VAA03602; Wed, 19 Feb 1997 21:46:44 -0800 (PST)
Received: from upmajb06 ([204.95.110.89]) by upsmot02.msn.com (8.6.8.1/Configuration 4) with SMTP id VAA10372 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 19 Feb 1997 21:42:53 -0800
Date: Thu, 20 Feb 97 05:44:36 UT
From: "Anonymous " <vbaird@msn.com>
Message-Id: <UPMAIL09.199702200544590082@msn.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: of course commercialization isn't all right--clarification
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

If it came across like I was advocating commercialization, sorry about that.  
I didn't mean it was all right, or it's good.  My point was that real techno, 
or the non-"cheesy" stuff is not very commercial at all, and it's not going to 
catch on like a lot of people think it will.

It sucks to get all hyped up about a rave, and go there and they're playing 
crap to cater to the people who just want to hear the commercial stuff.  
However, this means the DJs are selling out, and you know not to bother with 
them anymore.  And you also know to avoid those promoters.

If commercialization has any benefits, it is that the allmighty dollar will 
lure away all the fakers, and only the real ravers will be left.  And wouldn't 
that be much better for the vibe?

The same goes if the scene is bogged down by bad publicity.  If the media 
keeps talking about drugs & death that are sometimes associated with raves, 
this will scare off the people who don't know what the scene is really about.

But can we really dis the media for talking about the negatives of the scene?  
Haven't many of the threads on sfraves been discussing drugs, death, and other 
bad things that have been going on?  (not that it's okay for the media to rag 
on the rave scene like they've done in the past, and will continue to do)

I'm no philosopher, but I believe in the yin & yang concept . . . that in 
everything good there is bad, and in everything bad there is good.  
Commercialization and bad publicity are pretty horrible things that we'll have 
to face, but there may be a light (however dim) at the end of the tunnel.

I hate to say it, but no matter how much we discuss it, only the head honchos 
at Mtv and in the media are going to have any input how much commercialization 
and bad publicity is going to occur.  We can only try to address the results.

I'm human, I can and just might be wrong.  Feel free to give your opinion on 
the subject.

Miccaela
(p.s. thanks for all the support from those who responded to my letter.  much 
love to you all  {{{{{{{huggs}}}}}}})

I don't know I use to be one of those who was like, "no comercialzation 
is GOOD! The more the merrier."  But now i can't bear the thought. I was so 
upset at the News Week article on the scene I wrote a letter to them. The 
reference to PCP was hurtful, and boy did I have to answer for it with my 
dad. I am 23 for Gog's sake! 

It's just when I was in HK last summer the scene pretty much changed. 
THey played all the cheesy stuff at raves, and it became a meat mkt. I 
couldn't turn on the TV without trance, techno, goa selling something I 
don't want to me. 

I would like to scene to get bigger and more popular, (more choices). But 
then you start getting the ;lager louts with their beer out on the pull. 
You know? Have you ever had to fiend of some drunk asshole in a rave? 
 The 
scene 
have mostly  been filled with people that respect the values of PLUR. 

If people can respect the ideals I would be happy. But with 
comercialization it always becomes sexualised, blah blah blah. You've 
heard it all before.

Nailvarnish

Q:How many ravers does it take to change a light bulb?

A: 15, 1 to actually do the work and the other 14 to complain how it use 
to be better.    


ANd boy was it... Just kidding....//;>

sometimes it's not so much what's being said, but who's saying it and 
what their intentions are.

it's pretty easy to tell where a Chris Rock live at the Apallo HBO special
is coming from, posts are another matter. sarcasm doesn't allways
translate well on the net.

or another example : some people jump off of a party boat. the promoters
head back to rescue them but decside to keep the party swinging. were they
coming from a place of callous, self-centernedness, or was it ther intent
not to create a panic in a tricky crowd control situation ? i don't know -

i think that one of the problems with race relationships in america is
that everybody's so quick to play racism police, for all the good that
does. 

if somebody says something that bothers me, or rubs me the wrong way,
instead of pulling a citizen's arrest, i try and ask the guy to elaborate. 
"i don't understand. what do you mean ?" maybe he's hip to some knowledge
that i'm not privy to. maybe he's just an asshole. and calling an asshole
for what he is doesn't really accomplish much ((espically in the mind of
an asshole)). but all it takes is a "how do you mean ?" for an asshole to
dig themselves into a hole and do your job for you.

"that word" :

i choose to use it to make a point. it's not a word that i've incorporated
into my vocabulary and something that has allways left a bad taste in my
mouth. i remember cringing when i read Mike D throwing that word around in
Grand Royal #1. it's like, "yeah, he's from Brooklyand, he went on tour
with Public Enemy and did Paul's Boutique, but he's still a white boy.
he's not allowed to use that word."

nazi, baby-killer, racist. these are buzz-words. they ignite powerful
emotions and kill most rational thought. use them at your descretion and
be very carefull when accusing someone of being one of them. 

some more thoughts on that word :

i remember thinking all throughout that LA soap opera thing that the media
representitives were fucking cowards for refusing to even identify that
word. if drug use is the 20th century equivilant of whichcraft, that word
has become taboo in a culture that holds little sacred. i think a lot of
polite racists use the word african-american and no one ever calls them on
it. though now after having now used the word in public i can see some of
the logic in that decesion.  

sometimes it's not so much what's being said but who's saying it and
sometimes it's not so much what you say but how you say it.

everything you do and say can be taken out of contex and used aganinst you
in this world. EBL ((i think i got that right)) is a perfect example of
that. they're that techno group that edits together video clips satarizing
conservative figures. check it out if you haven't already. 

i think Dennis Miller hit the nail on the head when he did his bit on
Perot's old running mate ((the first time around)). here was an educated
man, a guy who fought for his country and was tortured for it in a POW
camp, a guy who later came back home and was public crucified by his
country because he comitted one of the cardnil sins of our culture :
he was bad on TV. my old man was in Vietnam. i have a certain amount of
respect for any soul that finds themselves in that kind of fucked-up
situation, if for no other reason than i'm from a generation that'll never
have to worry about a draft. even so, i was busting up when Phil Hartman
was slagging on that guy's ass on SNL...

everything you say can be used against you. your entire essence as a
person and as a human being can be reduced to a 2 second sound byte in
this world. guy shoots 1 hour of material of good people getting down at a
party and 45 seconds of assholes drag racing on nitrus. what material do
you think Hard Copy's gonna use ? words have power, careful in how you use
them, espically when adressing the public. 

sometimes it's not so much what you say, but how you say it. that being
said, i'm out of here. despite the psychaphrenic whether of late, i've
been having a really good week.   

and yeah, i'm glad you're in a good mood too.

At 6:09 PM -0700 2/19/97, Ethan Miller wrote:
>It's long been my belief that promoters are responsible for what happens at
>their parties. The promoter picks who they 'market' to, they pick who they
>let in and they either do or do not facilitate some form of what I'll call
>magick to  protect the party and those who attend it. Might sound wishy
>washy and new age but I've been to plenty of parties where I felt safe and
>protected and I've also been to plenty of parties where I could feel random
>violence waiting to happen, and it all, quite literally, begins with the
>promoter.
>
>A whole complex of things including the promoter's intentions and
>awareness; the people at the party, their intentions and awareness; things
>done before, during, and after the party to direct all of the above toward
>a positive result, ultimately shape the energy that guides and informs the
>party.
>
>I would call turning the music back on with two people overboard, the
>actions of people not terribly tuned in -- to anything.  How I would feel
>as the parent of one of those missing were I to know this, horrifies me.
>What could there possibly be to celebrate at that point? If this did in
>fact happen, ultimately, no one but the promoters can be held responsible
>for that decision.
>
>Anyone facilitating the gathering of hundreds of people most of whom will
>probably be out of their heads must have no illusions about their
>responsibility for creating as safe and as healthy an environment as
>possible.
>
>Whether or not, as the promoters, Tom and Stacy should be held legally
>responsible, I hope that, to the appropriate degree, they do feel
>personally responsible: they invoked this voyage, and none of it would have
>happened had they not. Oonly they will know if they did *everything* they
>could to make it a safe trip. If they did, the deserve our sympathy, if
>they did not they deserve our wrath.
>
>yours in deep regret
>ethan

This is exactly what I wanted to communicate -- but I was just a little too
agitated to slow down, collect my thoughts and deliver them in a non-biased
way as possible. If I would have done that, this is basically what I would
have wanted to say.

first off,
WELCOME APRIL! I love you tons!
Second off, 
Major props to our newest lister, she has a good idea. In fact she 
and I have talked about education regarding drugs many a time. The 
biggest thing for me is making sure we get unbiased, true, 
fact-for-fact information. Sad thing is, wherever I look, I hear 
"some experts say that MDMA causes spinal fluid to drain whereas 
other experts say it's the actual procedure of testing your spinal 
fluid that drains it." Yup, contradicting, confusing "facts." Nothing 
solid. So what to do?
	Also another thing to ponder is how to go about PACKAGING the 
information. The fact is, there are kids out there who just don't 
give a fuck what they're doing to their bodies, either that or they 
just don't want to know because they know it's bad. They will see a 
flyer saying "the facts about <insert drug here>" and find a reason 
to justify every negative effect the drug has on your body. ALSO, the 
flyers will be less accepted by people if it seems as if it's 
preaching "DONT DO DRUGS". I'm not saying it should CONDONE drug 
usage, because that's the LAST thing wanted to be done in this 
situation. By saying "BE SMART IF YOU ARE GOING TO DO DRUGS and here 
are some FACTS", some may say this is condoning of drugs, but it 
really isn't. The truth is, we have no choice over what a fellow 
raver is going to take at a party, we have no right to walk up to a 
person you don't know and throw their hit of E on the floor just 
because you don't believe in drug usage. All you can do is say "hey. 
before you do that, you might want to know a little bit about what 
you're doing to yourself and how it will effect your body and mind in 
the long run." if they don't want to listen, give them a flyer 
anyhow. can't say you didn't try. 
	I think you get what I'm saying... :)
Take care all and if you're going to Planet New Year's remake party, 
look for me, I'm gonna try to bring some strawberries :)~
Love and hugs and warmth,
Lara

Hi!  ]=)

On Wed, 19 Feb 1997 Simply756@aol.com wrote:

> I guess the reason I think this would be a good idea is because I'll talk to
> people who love 'e' and advocate it's use, yet they don't know what it is.
>  about 75-80% of the people i know who do 'e' on a regular basis do not know
> that it is a meth-amphetamine and that it has heroin in it.  

 ummm, to be taken seriously and respected you need to educate yourself 
first. 

 E is not a "meth"-ampetamine. Someone correct me if I'm wrong on any of 
these staments. Methamphetamine is a specific chemical. E is a substance 
related to _amphetamines_. It is somewhat different as certain atoms 
have been rotated on the molocue chain to new positions.

 The chances of there being heroin in any E is incredibly small. Usually 
the caps or pills are far to small for an oral dose of heroin to do 
anything. There have been a lot of tests around the world (that I've 
heard of) that report _very_ few E's containing heroin. 

 While I appreciate your desire to help April, it is with educted 
decisions and actions that will bring about useful change. "The road to 
hell is paved with good intentions."

 Try accessing the Hypearreal archives for information on drugs and E in 
particular. There are several refrences to very good books written about 
drugs. I personally recomend the Psychedelic Encyclopedia by Peter 
Stafford to start. It has a good overview and again can refer you to 
other great books.

On Wed, 19 Feb 1997, Randy C Cone wrote:

>  E is not a "meth"-ampetamine. Someone correct me if I'm wrong on any of 
> these staments. Methamphetamine is a specific chemical. E is a substance 

MDMA = Methy-Dioxy-MethAmphetamine.
		   ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

While E is quite different from others in it's family, it is still a 
methamphetamine and does have some similar nerotoxic effects. Also, if 
you've ever heard nightmare stories about meth-labs, E is just as bad as 
far as EXTREMELY toxic and environmental nightmare by-products.

Hey marshmallow peeps


Had a weird little dream last night.  No point to it, just kinda weird.
Dreamed that there was another Love A-Fair (I didn't make it to the first
one) to which I was in attendance.  All my friends were there (Amy, you and
Mel were there!), but there were only 200 people.  However, the party was
held at a Home-Base sized warehouse, and it was decorated amazingly!  It
looked like a huge funhouse or something, and it reminded me of what I
always kind of imagined the old Toon Towns would have looked like, it was
all just such fun!  We all ran around like little kids, laughing & playing
among the funhouse decorations, climbing all over stuff & such.  But it
seems like we were there before the party actually started, very strange,
cuz I don't remember any music.  Weird, eh?  A fun dream, I enjoyed the
party (thanks vlad! ;)

And that was all!  A silly fun dream.

Love
Shawna

MDMA = 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (Supercala what?)

For thoughs of you in LA.
Read this, and call the number.
Maybe you can get some free E or something.
Although it probably won't live up to BayArea grade E.



We are currently recruiting subjects to take part in both of the studies
described above. We are looking for both male and female volunteers who
would be willing to invest the necessary time, energy and inconvenience
that participation would require. We are particularly interested in
identifying prospective subjects who have used significant amounts of MDMA
but have relatively little experience with other drugs. Our subjects will
need to be between the ages of 21 and 65, be in good medical and
psychiatric health and have had prior first hand experience with the self
administration of MDMA. The criteria that subjects must be health
professions was recently waived by the FDA with the stipulation that
participants be sufficiently knowledgeable of the controversy over MDMA's
effects that true informed consent be possible. Anyone interested in
participating in these studies can call our research coordinator, Carla
Edwards, at (310) 222-1663.

Friends,
	This party last saterday was an incredible experience I've 
had not before.
	1)	Got there during Andrew Lucero's set. While waiting
in the parking lot , my friends (family) and I got the butterflies.Weird.
	2) 	The visuals were UNREAL. From outside I thought they
were projected screens, but later realized them to be projected
on everything. Huge PROPS.
	3)	Then Thomas Micheal went on after Andrew Lucero. The
first thing I thought was this guy looks a lot like John Lennon.(no
offence intended).But this guy fuckin tore the shit up! This is the 
kind of techno that starts wigglin my head, then creeps down to my hands,
then my waist starts  doing the Heebee Jeebee. Completly out of
Control. My feet would not stop. The hairs on my body were dancing on
their own. Again UNREAL.
	4)	After about an hour, My body said "Time to chill". I am
waay out of shape. So I go to look for B))marang . Never met him before.
I'm looking for a guy with a tie and I find one, but his name is
Miguel. I am way off, so I go to chill on some bean bags with my brother
Gaby and his girl friend. Then all of a sudden these people come and
ask me if they can lie down with me. They treat me as if I known them
for years. What a great feeling. 
	5) 	I go to find B))marang again and he is all ready 
spinning. I say,"Boomarang". He looks up and I say,"DJ vertiblaaahhh".
I made no fucking sense, I know. I get real excited when I meet Sfravers.
When I realized what I did, I just chilled and did not want to interupt
his set.
	6) 	Then I see Leslie, Whom I met before. I LOVE talking to
this lady. She is just stimulating conversation. And when we were
talking I look down, to find a bag of candy. A bunch of jolly ranchers 
and such. She must be good luck.
	7) 	During this time, someone fell to the ground sick and a
bunch of us tried to move him to the back successfully. It looked as if
he had to much to drink.I believe he is fine. 
	8)	Around 4:30 Leslie and I go to listen to Johndabombs set.
This guy is in such control. Props to him. I believe there were other
Sfravers there but I did not Meet you. I was the big Mexican with
white pants, White hat, goatee with no mustache, and wearing a multi-
colour vest. If you saw me I'm Vertigo (aka Memo Lemus). This is the
closest I've come to meeting Sfravers and as minimum as it was, it 
was the best feeling. I hope to meet more of you, soon.

					Pure Love
					VERTIGO

firstly:
HI APRIL!!!!!!  Nice to have ya aboard!!!

secondly:
I'm all for drug education.  While working in the dorms I tried to
distribute drug info (not pro or con, just info) so my residents could
make their own educated decisions.  So I'm for it.

thirdly:
what is the deal with everyone talking about heroin in their e?  I would
think that since heroin is most effective when snorted or injected (from
what I understand) and heroin is not very cheap, why would someone
'cutting' MDMA want to put in heroin?  It just doesn't seem like a smart
business decision to me.  :/  If it is actually happening then I have on
ething to say to the folks doing it:  stop!  I don't want to hear about
anyone else getting heroin in their e!

PLUR

On Wed, 19 Feb 1997 Simply756@aol.com wrote:
> hello all
> my name is April.  Some of you know me. I finally got on line yay!!!!!  
> 
> I guess what i wanted to write about was what happens to people who do drugs
> at parties.  it's not going to stop.  we all know that.  

Yeah!

> But maybe we can
> educate those who do drugs.  I want to throw my first party sometime in the
> near future.  What I want to do with the proceeds of the party is to make
> pamphlets about the drugs people are doing. 

Education is a good thing.  Just be sure you know what you're talking
about.  Giving out medical advice if you do not have a medical background
is not a good idea.  

> I guess the reason I think this would be a good idea is because I'll talk to
> people who love 'e' and advocate it's use, yet they don't know what it is.
>  about 75-80% of the people i know who do 'e' on a regular basis do not know
> that it is a meth-amphetamine and that it has heroin in it.  

As noted previously, this is a myth.

> I used to tell people drugs were cool, but as soon as i found out what they
> do to you, my views changed.  I've dropped 'e' three times, it was fun, but
> it wasn't worth it, especially because i feel how it has effected me even
> know, when i haven't done it in a really really long time.  

In your opinion, sure.  That's a wonderfully valid opinion to have - in
fact many people feel all you need is a couple of times with the right
set/setting and you've basically obtained all the benefits which there may
be - sorta like reading a really good book.  Ah, but I see you didn't like
it - the book metaphor still applies, not everyone is a Shakespeare fan.
Just so long as those non-fans start telling us how Shakespeare shouldn't
be read, or is "bad for you", I'm fine.

About 5 years ago a really excellent flyer was produced by some
then-SFRavers called "Info-E".  I can't find the original online but it
has been recently redesigned with the same information, and is available
at < http://www.hyperreal.com/drugs/infoe/ >.  Some of the information is
outdated but none is completely invalid.  

> I'm sure i'm not the first person who has wanted to throw a benefit about
> drug education.  i guess the kid in me is just asking for support and knowing
> that there are you people out their that are willing to support me and my
> friends makes me feel a lot more secure and my aspiration.

In my opinion a "rave about drug education" is not the most effective way
to educate folks, since parties are about dancing, music, and non-symbolic
communication, whereas "education" is about broadcasting a message.
"Thump thump thump hey, crystal will mess you up! thump thump thump"
Write up some flyers like the Info-E folks did, and you can get across
some simple concepts; but if you really want to /educate/ folks, create a
resource that is deeper than that, and make sure you have all the facts.
That's why there's an archive of drug information on hyperreal, so that
people can read and learn about them, both the good and the bad.  

I completely apologize if the tone of this response is somewhat smarmy or,
er, "harsh".  I didn't intend it to be - this is just a subject which I
take particularly seriously, and hope others will too.  

	Brian

umm...im in a hurry, but i saw something about not giving medical advice 
unless yer a doctor.  

that's probably good.  however...i've met some people out there that know 
more about keeping the body healthy than a lot of doctors out there.  so 
i would choose your doctors wisely.  

***for instance...

i have a friend who was rushed to a hospital because his body was 
swelling.  they told him he had a toxic liver and they needed to remove 
his gall baldder.  he kindly refused that offer...he asked them if there 
was anything he should do different for his diet and they said, "no it 
doesn't matter what you eat."

he went to a cancer clinic in mexico and cleaned himself out naturally 
with herbs.  

i've heard that in these cancer clinics they have an 80% cure rate.  the 
only reason the other 20% die is because they've already convinced 
themselves they're going to die before they even get there.  

***disclaimer...im not a doctor.  but my good friend who is a doctor has 
told me it's ok to be a healer.  so i can offer a little info here and 
there.  but if it's too complex, im gonna pass you oon to someone that 
really knows what they're talking about.  


gotta go--->deep

With all this stuff of whats in E thread, educating the masses on drugs
and whatnot one must really remember...

What you buy off the street, is off the street:

This stuff is being made/cut in anything from really elaborate labs
(that look REALLY clean and pretty), to kitchen sinks (next to dirty
dishes and old food).

		Belive me...
  
I think that the best way to caution people would be to inform them that
what they're taking may/maynot be pure (again it is doubtful that X is
cut with heroin due to the expenses, on the other hand, it's doubtful
that a dealer would use crushed glass (remember THAT one old skoolers)
to cut his E as well. The usual inert ingredent is MOM (milk of
magnesea[I know, sp]).  But then again a whole 'batch' of anything could
turn up bad if not cut enough (anyone else remember the 'China White"
deaths in LA in 91???).  I've even went 'puffies' when tokin' on the
ole' Jnt and told later it was laced with opium (and that one was
w/friends who "forgot" to tell me).

Caution peoples, if you wish to alter your perception with syntehics...

"Music is MY drug of choice"

---Adam

>1/2 black and 1/2 white. But I'm considered black because when you're even
>a smidgen black you're treated differently by the general public. Although
>I don't look black in most people's eyes I don't look caucasian either. I
>look like a mix. This both to my benefit and against it.

Good insight as to what my son will have to deal with when he gets older.
I guess I look at being bi-racial as THE best place to be in this couldron
called America.  I eman, you defy classsification, so I guess "human" would
be the best bet since you are an amalgam of all things.  This is the right
direction, IMO, this country and the world needs to go to get away from the
severe tribalism we are constantly embroiled in.


>
>It's to my benefit because I'm not assumed to be black and am not
>discriminated against based on my appearance. It's against my benefit
>because I hear all kinds of racist remarks from people who are oblivious
>to my heritage. I've lost respect for A LOT of people this way.

Indeed and understood.  Funny how people will really show their true colors
if there is no threat of retribution.  Much like cyberspace, where nobody
knows who or what you are or may be.

Funny, that dumb MCI commercial that touts all this "On the internet, ther
eis no race, no color, no this no that..." and my SO and I laugh since it's
obvious that what they're trying to say is "hey you don;t havre to deal
with these very REAL issues with our country if you're on the net.  You
become and amorphous blob of bits.  Finally a real escape from our everyday
contrcut of isms we've built around ourselves.  Now there are no problems,
as long as you stay in cyberspace.  Now as for gettting a loan for a new
house?  That's another problem. ;)

>
>But as far as the N word, it doesn't bother me if it's used in the correct
>context. Meaning if you're quoting someone else and not using it to put me
>down it doesn't bother me. His post didn't bother me. But I never use the
>word unless I'm joking around with my friend who's also half black....

And thus the dilemma many whites and some blacks have with the word.
Whites,especially the younger ones who did not have the benefit of going
through the civil rights struggle or integration, don't understand the
paradox.  Simply put whites used the 'n' word to objectify and opress
blacks.  So the word has a certain power when a white person utters it.
That is why there is such a halting gasp when a white person, especially
those in power like cops, or business mean (read TExaco) use the word.
People understand that there are other implications due to the blanace of
power.  Now two African-Americans who may use the same word doesn;t have
the impact.  First we took the word, and created our OWN definition of it,
thus taking the sting out of it.  Giving the word another purpose than what
it was orignially intenede for.  Whites, because of history, do not have
this benefit. Why?  History, and please read what I said about the word
before.  No it may not be correct, to some a word is just a word.  But
often it is who uses the word that counts.

So homosexual men can call eachother f*g, I cannot since I am heterosexual.
Women can call each other a b*tch, I cannot, I am not a woman.
Whites can call each other wh*tey, I cannot I am not a part of that group.

Se how it works, there arte dozens of examples, and if people took the time
to realte to something other than bits, they would know this is common
practice in the real everyday world.  Now I am not saying it isn't fucked
up that such a paradx exists for mere words, but words are very, very
powerful, and have great weight.  Our Constitution is just words, but they
have a power when weilded.

Sorry people, words are NOT just words.  If they were, we wouldn't be
having this discussion.

>
>I think people are a little too uptight about how to call people of
>certain races... like do I call an African american "Black" or do I call
>them "African American".. I have friends who have a hard time with this.
>But it's kind of upsetting to be called a color instead of a race. I never
>call someone "white". I was raised by my mom's side of the family that is
>caucasian and have most always had caucasian friends. But one of my best
>friends is also half African American....
>
>I'm babbling....

No you're not.  I dig where you're coming from brotha.  AThis Amerikkka has
really fucked things up for the lot of us.  We are actually dealing with
the consequences set into motion hundreds of years ago.  And unlike South
Africa, we have YET to deal with our issues in a forthright manner.
Whether this be racial ineqaulity or gender inequality, we are light years
behind the ideal of the constitution that all people are created equal.  In
this country the only eqaulizer is money, and the more of that you have,
the more rights you have.  The converse is also true.  So is the Nike and
Rebbok and thge Adidas. :).

>
>All I know is that we're all the same color underneath... and we're all
>related in one way or another.

In reality, race is a social construct created by Europeans during the
18-19th centuries.

There is only one race IMO, the Human Race.  Until we all get to that
point, we'll continue discussions like these.

>
>We should all love eachother. There is no reason to not love one another.
>Life is too short for hate.

100%!!!!

ticket so I could go elsewhere and avoid the "nightmare" that I was sure it
was going to be.  If my cousin and his friends hadn't wanted to go, I would
not have gone.  But ya know what?  I went and I had a WONDERFUL time!!!  I
loved every moment of being there, and best of all, I talked to lots of
great people that night (HI, Lara, Eric, Yam, Baljeet, and everyone else I
met!!)  So, as they say about the net, "It's the PEOPLE, Stupid!!" :)  In

you didn;t give a fuck.  You went ahead and used it, in an attempt to
de-sensitize me or teach me a lesson, or to make a point.  I hate that kind
of condescention.  And I hate it when you go about spouting that PLUR junk,
yet in an instant DISRespect me by using the word n****r.  See it's a two
way street.  You can't expect me to have much respect for you if you dis me
by using that word.  You have got to respect one person if you wish to have
that respect returned.  That is how I live my life.

blacks, you inferred it.  But one must admit it is not so much the word as
much as who weilds it.  There is plenty to back me up and I've addressed it

becomes and insult.  Why?  I am not part of the group. As a matter of fact
I am part of the group that uses that word usually to insult or hurt those
brothers who are gay (i.e. heterosexual).

word.  There is no such thing.  Words carry great weight and great
consequence.  Ask anyone who has dared, in these days to utter that word ,
the 'n' word to someone who has not accepted you as part of the group.  A
fight would definitely ensue in some areas, or you might be chased.

years, as cocain has been much more difficult to get ahold of.

ravers don't tend to attract to heroin, it doesn't mean that the rest of
the world doesn't.

likely that you have heard this floating along the grapevine, just like
everyone else.

At 09:22 AM 2/20/97 -0800, you wrote:
>Let's put this question into play:
>
>Why would a MDMA cook put heroin in extacy when the cost of heroin is much
>more expensive than the MDMA?
>
>The only reason a drug would be cut with another drug is to lower the cost.
>

That is not true... heroin is much easier to obtain, but probably pretty
hard to get rid of, heroin could be put in pills and cut into low amounts
of ecstasy and sold 'as' ecstasy to be gotten rid of faster. 

I know for a fact that some ecstasy contains heroin. not so much that i've
seen here as when i was living in phoenix, but it does. there are labs that
test what is in ecstasy, and their results often times show some amount of
heroin in the samples, as well as ephedrine, speed, caffiene, cocaine,
ketamine, and many other drugs, often times the "e's" do not contain any
chemical related to mdma at all.

Read up on the subject... there are a LOT of really good books out there
about mdmda, as well as books about what the illegalization of mdma has
done to the quality of the drug to the end-user.

the best resource for information related to ecstasy on the internet is at
http://www.ecstasy.org

If you want to see what is in the ecstasy YOU are using... 
see this page: http://www.ecstasy.org/testing.html

-much love
-justin

> So homosexual men can call eachother f*g, I cannot since I am heterosexual.
> Women can call each other a b*tch, I cannot, I am not a woman.

I don't use any of those on any occasion.  I find them all offensive. 
My take on it is this: if you have class, you don't use "unclassy"
language.  Folks that use those words, along with the "N" word, have
zero class.  Period.  That's another tool I'll use when trying to teach
my kids to treat all people like potential friends, not probable enemies
based on their physical differences.

I found a page with this text:

"You've probably heard stories of E being spiked with addictive and
poisonous substances. True, when you buy "Ecstasy" there's no quality
control and you may well get cocktails of other drugs, particularly when
the dealer has run out of MDMA. You may also get a dud. But not heroin or
poison."

This will back those of you who believe there is no heroin in e. I have
also seen test results which did show an amount of heroin in the pills,
which i have no found on the internet, so cannot post.

I know some of you will look down on me for what I am going to say, but if
you do then it's your problem, not mine.

I have tried heroin by itself orally before. I liked the effect to an
extent, but later became nausious as i had done too much. I have not done
heroin since then, but I remember what the effects are like, much as you
remember the effects of your first trip on LSD. 
I have also taken pure MDA, the drug that MDMA is synthesised from.

I have taken way more than my share of ecstasy, and I will say this...
I can almost always tell what is in the e i am taking, or at least what
drug the effects are most similar to. I have taken pure MDMA very few
times. The majority of e's I have taken have contained MDA or a very
similar drug, and a lot of those pills have also contained heroin, or a
very similar drug. I do not go out and take every drug in the book, but I,
from the combination of experience and the very extensive reading i do on a
drug before i take it, am usually able to identify what qualities the drug
has. Im rambling here, (probably a side effect of too much e) =o)

But what my point is, is that if what was in a lot of pills I have taken
was NOT heroin, it was a very damn close substance...

You tell me what it is?

-much love

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Feb 20 10:49:01 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id KAA20148; Thu, 20 Feb 1997 10:49:01 -0800 (PST)
Received: from arau.ar.br.np.els-gms.att.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with SMTP id KAA20123; Thu, 20 Feb 1997 10:48:56 -0800 (PST)
Date: Thu, 20 Feb 1997 10:26:00 +0000
From: SFO2!SFO2PO!sgalloway@msatt.attmail.com (Galloway, Scott)
Received: from msatt by attmail; Thu Feb 20 18:45 GMT 1997
Subject: Re: my first time on sfraves!!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (SFraves),
        ZINTSMAS@SONOMA.EDU (internet!SONOMA.EDU!ZINTSMAS)
Mime-Version: 1.0

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Message-ID: <MS-MAILG-3.0-Note-msatt-sgalloway-0856462836>

There is absolutely no way for any of us to educate someone who does not 
wish to be educated.  I commend April's desires to help her community, and 
educate about drugs, but unfortuantely most people won't listen.  I agree 
that education is a top priority, and much more needs to be done, but it's a 
matter of approaching the issue carefully enough that some people do listen. 
 Also, we must all take this responsiblity on ourselves, and really learn 
about the things that we do to our bodies.  Few people on their first night 
of drinking, pick up a fifth of Jack Daniels, and pour it down their 
throats.  Why?  Because we see all the time what alcohol in excess can do, 
not only to our bodies, but also how drunks directly affect those around 
them, intentional or not.

Many drugs out there today are killers, particularly because we never ever 
know 100% what it is we are buying and consuming.  I have never met anyone 
that has tested their drugs before they took them, in fact most often people 
don't even bother to ask where they're pills come from, much less what 
impurities might be found in them.  As a community, we are in dire need of 
some serious social assistance in the realm of education.  Our government 
certainly doesn't see fit to provide the much needed money to improve our 
nations decaying public schools, and they turn the other cheek when it comes 
to our countries' drug issues, but it is our duty to first educate our 
government as to what our needs are as citizens and then apply pressure 
where needed to assure that those needs are taken care of.

Amsterdam has a great idea when it comes to drugs.  Everyone always talks 
about smoking weed in Amsterdam, buying huge sticky buds right in the cafe 
and lighting up right there, and nobody minds, but the real truth is that 
smoking marijuana is illegal in Amsterdam, but their government is 
progressive enough to tolerate marijuana use when used safely and in 
moderation.  Also, I have seen government sactioned medical reports on 
Ecstacy in the Netherlands, including booths set up at various club/rave 
events where doctors and medical researchers provide serious education on 
the Ecstacy that is being sold in the area, including pictures and visual 
samples of varying pills, their actual pharmecutical properties, (what's in 
them), and both their immediate and long term effects.  Although drugs are 
illegal in both countries, I believe that the United States needs to look 
toward other, more progressive countries, their policies on drugs, and 
follow suit, truly educating the masses, and saving lives.

So good luck April, I hope that whatever you do, you get the support that 
you need, it's a great idea, and with your best intentions, you'll help a 
lot of people.

Thanks for listening...

Smiles,

Scott =)

 ----------
From: internet!SONOMA.EDU!ZINTSMAS
To: internet!hyperreal.com!sfraves; sgalloway
Subject: Re: my first time on sfraves!!
Date: Wed Feb 19 1997 10:39PM

first off,
WELCOME APRIL! I love you tons!
Second off,
Major props to our newest lister, she has a good idea. In fact she
and I have talked about education regarding drugs many a time. The
biggest thing for me is making sure we get unbiased, true,
fact-for-fact information. Sad thing is, wherever I look, I hear
"some experts say that MDMA causes spinal fluid to drain whereas
other experts say it's the actual procedure of testing your spinal
fluid that drains it." Yup, contradicting, confusing "facts." Nothing
solid. So what to do?
     Also another thing to ponder is how to go about PACKAGING the
information. The fact is, there are kids out there who just don't
give a fuck what they're doing to their bodies, either that or they
just don't want to know because they know it's bad. They will see a
flyer saying "the facts about <insert drug here>" and find a reason
to justify every negative effect the drug has on your body. ALSO, the
flyers will be less accepted by people if it seems as if it's
preaching "DONT DO DRUGS". I'm not saying it should CONDONE drug
usage, because that's the LAST thing wanted to be done in this
situation. By saying "BE SMART IF YOU ARE GOING TO DO DRUGS and here
are some FACTS", some may say this is condoning of drugs, but it
really isn't. The truth is, we have no choice over what a fellow
raver is going to take at a party, we have no right to walk up to a
person you don't know and throw their hit of E on the floor just
because you don't believe in drug usage. All you can do is say "hey.
before you do that, you might want to know a little bit about what
you're doing to yourself and how it will effect your body and mind in
the long run." if they don't want to listen, give them a flyer
anyhow. can't say you didn't try.
     I think you get what I'm saying... :)
Take care all and if you're going to Planet New Year's remake party,
look for me, I'm gonna try to bring some strawberries :)~
Love and hugs and warmth,
Lara

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: John Darrow <jdarrow@waonline.com>
Subject: Re: MDMA DOES NOT CONTAIN HEROIN!
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>I know for a fact that some ecstasy contains heroin. not so much that i've
>seen here as when i was living in phoenix, but it does. there are labs that
>test what is in ecstasy, and their results often times show some amount of
>heroin in the samples, as well as ephedrine, speed, caffiene, cocaine,
>ketamine, and many other drugs, often times the "e's" do not contain any
>chemical related to mdma at all.
>
>Read up on the subject... there are a LOT of really good books out there
>about mdmda, as well as books about what the illegalization of mdma has
>done to the quality of the drug to the end-user.
>
>the best resource for information related to ecstasy on the internet is at
>http://www.ecstasy.org

I'd appreciate it if you would tell us more about how you know this for a
fact. You mention that lab tests have shown heroin in the samples... unless
you can produce these lab tests please do not say this. There was a series
of lab tests that has been posted to this list a couple times in years
past, and although many ecstacy samples have a lot of funny things in them,
not one of them anywhere was ever found to contain heroin. Maybe the
workings of the entire drug market has changed dramatically in the last
year or two from how it has been for many years before then, but I
seriously doubt it. One of the advantages of the internet is that a great
many people and resources are able to share their knowledge with each
other... this heroin and mdma thread has come up many times before on
sfraves, and not one person has ever successfully come forward with any
solid evidence of heroin in the capsules. If someone did, I'm sure everyone
would very quickly take notice, not just here but on all the rave mailing
lists. So then if you do have facts, please share them. If your facts are
second hand, please just quiet down and pay attention.

Your own quoted source above for valid information on ecstacy has an
article saying that there is no heroin mixed with MDMA. Did you not look at
your own source?

It seems like this myth should die as it's been hashed to the ground
numerous times. That will only happen when each of stop spreading second
hand information.

-Your message just came in about why you think there's heroin in your e. My
answer would be that MDMA has an incredible range of effects. Some people
get happy, some people get sad, some people get floaty, some people get
heavy... chances are if you expect or look for any kind of sensation while
on the drug, you will find it. If you know what heroin feels like it is
probably very easy to make your MDMA experience feel like heroin. That's
part of the whole empathic experience. But it is not a good reason for
justifying that your drug is anything other that what it is suppossed to
be. I bet you got MDMA much more often than you think. The different forms
that this single drug takes confuses a lot of people into thinking it's
completely different drugs each time. Again, unless you have any facts...
you mention studies done. Unless you can lead us to these studies, please
stop mentioning them. The only studies that have ever shown up here show
exactly the opposite of what you've said.

I mean no disrespect, but this is such an insidious and malignant topic,
and it seems it needs to be treated intensly.

-john.

John Darrow - http://www.he.net/~swoosh/ - jdarrow@waonline.com

Dear List:

	Here are some thaughts for people to ponder throughout this blame-flame war.

1.  Has it crossed anybodies mind that the reason  the organization that promoted the boat party 
CAN NOT respond to anything going on at this point due to legal-liability reasons because they 
are trying to keep a barioer of seperation between the fact that their event was a private diner 
dance cruiz, and not a rave.

2.  Have any of you for a second stoped to wonder how bad the situation for the scene would get 
if the media assumed that this was a rave party and not some private event?

3.  Have we not seen the ignorance and trechory of the media to manipulate the truth and bring 
negative publicity to our scene by presenting one sided reports on rave events.

4.  If you think it is hard for promoters to get permits now, wait untill the headlines read 
"two die at drug rave", the media is ruthless when it comes to things like this.

5.  Mabee there is a reason why they are keeping silent, and mabee everyone else should as well!

6.  Before we all go of half-cocked and create more trouble then good, lets consider ALL the 
senarios.

7.  This is an atomic bomb that is just balancing on the brink of exploding, lets not rock the 
boat(pardon the termonoligy)  or we might contribute to the scenes ditruction.  

8.  If this thing goes off because some insurance investigator with a real bug up his ass was 
monitering the list and made 'his own' conection between the posibility that this event might 
have been a rave(which it wasn't), and not a private party(which it was) then we could ALL be 
contributing to the aftermath that will follow.

9.  Lets not lose sight of the big picture:  If we love our scene, and we want it to not be 
damaged by this tragedy, then we will let this thread go without any further posts.  

10.  I am sure that once the group that organized the event knows more information, then they 
will release it.  But now is not a time for speculation.   Asumptions and rumors can only create 
more damage.  lets not add fuel to the fire.

Lets all bond together in thought during this time of tragidy, not insight a blame-flame post 
wars thatimplies that his boat party was a rave and people were taking drugs.  

If anyone has anything more to say or add to this thread, it should be done in private.

PLUR
Keep it real.
Ray Vonie
Badd spelling is my trademark

> think that since heroin is most effective when snorted or injected (from
> what I understand) and heroin is not very cheap, why would someone
> 'cutting' MDMA want to put in heroin?  It just doesn't seem like a smart
> business decision to me.  :/ 

Yes, this appears to be an urban myth.  Dealers CUT pure drugs with more 
inexpensive additives to increase their PROFITS.  Heroin costs more than 
ecstasy - do da math.  

I've noticed that the effects I have had mirror what, as my research tells 
me, should be expected at a "low" dosage of approx. 75mg - not the 
120-150mg stronger dosage that brings on a crazier trip.  Obviously 
what's marketed is not a pure product.  There is no consumer protection 
on the black market (another unfortunate consequence of prohibition).

Personally, I always suspected that "tylenols" didn't refer to a 
particular kind of e, but rather what it was probably cut with!! :P

That's the real beauty of electronic music.  As technology advances, and 
electronic music intstruments become cheaper, more and more people open 
themselves to the possibility of creating music on their own.  Anyone can do 
it now, and it's really not that expensive.  The world is filled with such 
vast differences in culture, and musical taste, and as we begin tapping into 
this vein of creativity, and fully realizing our individual musical 
potentials, I think we will all find new music daily that more closely 
reflects each of our dreams, emotions, and experiences.

I'm excited.

Scott =)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Feb 20 12:00:58 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id MAA09406; Thu, 20 Feb 1997 12:00:58 -0800 (PST)
Received: from arau.ar.br.np.els-gms.att.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with SMTP id MAA09388; Thu, 20 Feb 1997 12:00:52 -0800 (PST)
Date: Thu, 20 Feb 1997 11:44:00 +0000
From: SFO2!SFO2PO!sgalloway@msatt.attmail.com (Galloway, Scott)
Received: from msatt by attmail; Thu Feb 20 19:53 GMT 1997
Subject: RE: Confessions of a techno newbie / it'
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (SFraves), vbaird@msn.com (Anonymous)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: Text/Plain; charset=us-ascii
