Precedence: bulk


HI there,

So, welcome to the wonderous world of Techno.  I think you'll find as much 
depth and meaning in techno music as with nature itself.  The real beauty of 
the music, is that it subscribes itself to no set boundaries...anything 
goes...granted hi NRG stuff has its purpose, but it falls trap to the same 
retrictions that are placed on other popular musical genres like 
"alternative", and r&b.  At one time, alternative really meant that - it was 
an alternative form of rock to the existing scene, however over time, both 
alternative and r & b have lost their originality and instead of being 
pioneers of music, forging new and innovative ground, they have driven 
themselves into the ground by preying on the wealth found in americas 
stereotyping, and pigeonholing of what music should sound like and how it 
should be wrapped up and presented to us in quick, colorful music videos.

People are definately ready for a change, and electronic dance music is the 
just the thing.  Europe has embraced serious dance music on a major scale, 
its impact being felt in every aspect of European life.  In fact, Germany 
has acknowledged techno as one of their official musical exports!  We cannot 
possibly fathom all that this type of music has to offer to the world, but 
we aren't far from finding out.  I talked to an executive of mtv just before 
the end of last year, and there are serious steps being taken to adjust the 
face of mtv to prepare for the onslaught of this relatively new form of 
music on america.  So prepare yourselves, we are only just now watching this 
wave of music begin to peak.

Enjoy the music, and the ride,

Scott =)

 ----------
From: Anonymous
To: internet!hyperreal.com!sfraves; sgalloway
Subject: Confessions of a techno newbie / it's go
Date: Wed Feb 19 1997 4:34PM

I've been hearing a lot of concern about techno's growing popularity and 
what
effect it will have on the whole scene.  I just thought I'd share my views 
on
the subject, why I'm not to worried about it . . .

First of all, I'm one of the newbies myself.  I used to listen to (actually,
I
still do) alternative, hip hop, and r&b, and some other stuff as well.
However, I've always been attracted to techno.  Sure, high energy and all
that
was okay, but the few techno songs I used to hear (the first being "Charly"
and "Sesame's Treat," i believe) I loved.  I couldn't get enough of it, but 
I
didn't have any friends who listened to it, so I didn't know where to go to
get more.  Ravers were just people I saw on TV, I never saw one in real life 

before.

Then came along the infamous Prodigy and Chemical Brothers buzz clips, and
Mtv's Amp.  It blew me away about how much stuff I had never been exposed to 

(not even the super popular songs).  I began taping Amp through my stereo,
and
I'd listen to the tapes 24/7 (this was the only techno I had).

I expected my friends to feel the same way.  So at a kick-back party I 
popped
one of my tapes in.  First song was Orbital, i think, "halycon and on and
on,"
whatever that songs called (I'm trying, y'all)  It did not go over well.
"What is this???" they asked.  "It's techno," I say.  "Techno?  It sounds a
little weird to be techno," they reply.  "It doesn't sound like the normal
stuff."  "Normal stuff?"  I say, thinking they've known about this stuff all 

along, "What normal stuff?"  "You know, like Gina G and all that."

Needless to say, before the first song was over, the tape came off.  That
leads to my first conclusion, that most people aren't ready for, or
interested
in, techno music.  My friends aren't that crazy about The Prodigy even. 
 They
like the song, but they aren't going to be charging any record stores to get 

the new album.

When I came to school yesterday, I mentioned to these same friends that 
there
was a rave last weekend (the loveaffair thing).  "RAVE???" they said.  "You
should have told us!  We could have had hella fun!"  You see, most people
have
this idea of a rave being all about sex, drugs, and techno (and you don't
have
to be 21!!!)  Perhaps the media is responsible for this, I dunno, but it's
supposed to be some grand, gigantic party.  And whether they like techno or
not, they all like a good party.

However, I'm not too concerned with this either.  #1, you can't go to rave
and
not like techno.  I know my friends would become weary of dancing for over 2 

hours and never hearing Real McCoy.  #2, there are plenty of clubs playing
HiNRG, alternative, industrial, house etc., that are much cheaper than a
rave,
within a reasonable distance, less likely to be broken up by cops, serve
alcohol, and you can "meet people there--" the meat market atmosphere. 
 It'll
take one or two raves before the average person moves on to something more
appealing to them.

So if the music and the rave isn't turning them on, then what is?  What
turned
me on to techno was how simply sitting down and listening to the music could 

take me to a whole higher level--something that doesn't happen listening to
most popular music genres.  Raves are only attractive to me because of the
music, but especially that nonmeat market, superficial vibe so present in 
the
r&b / hip hop house parties I've been too.  As for alternative, I could 
never
dance to it . . . you can't express yourself like you can with techno.  You
just bang your head or get in the mosh pit and throw chairs.  Not the same
effect on the soul, imho.  But when I talk about how the music affects me to 

my friends, they think I'm going nuts.

>From someone who's on the "other side," return all your black gear you were
going to wear to mourn the death of the scene.  Straight up, the american
teen
isn't going to trade in their Alanis Morrissette and/or Snoop Dogg cds for
Orbital or even Prodigy for awhile.  I'm concerned about what might happen
when they get bored with alt. and hip hop, but most likely they will create
new forms of rock and rap to listen to, instead of turning to techno.

In other words, I think everything will be fine.

Miccaela
becalmacidrage   (<------it's an anagram)

P.S.  I'd like to 1.  apologize for waste of bandwidth, 2.  hear your views
on
the subject (even flaming, although I don't know what I've said to deserve
it), and 3.  ask if there are any ravers in Sacramento who wouldn't mind
hooking up with me and educating this poor ignorant girl about the scene
(don't you feel sorry for me?  I have no friends w/ the same interests, I'm
an
outcast  *sniff sniff*)

email at vbaird@msn.com

Date: Thu, 20 Feb 1997 12:27:35 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: ndurham@earthlink.net (n8)
Subject: Re: my first time on sfraves!!
Cc: Simply756@aol.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>I guess the reason I think this would be a good idea is because I'll talk to
>people who love 'e' and advocate it's use, yet they don't know what it is.
> about 75-80% of the people i know who do 'e' on a regular basis do not know
>that it is a meth-amphetamine and that it has heroin in it.

The pharmacology is incredibly different than "ordinary"
methyl-amphetamine.  Although, MDMA (Ecstasy) contains the term "MA" in
it's name...it's actions are completely different.  The negative actions
that are seen from use of e are in its binding and subsequent damage to 5HT
(serotonin) nerve terminals.  The level of damage and the ability of the
brain to repair itself is completely unknown and incredibly complex.
However, drugs (such as Xanax, Prozac, etc.) that are mass marketed by
companies located in this very area act upon the same region of the neuron
and are readily accepted by the American public.  Not that this changes the
effect of e...it just puts in in perspective.  The daily intake of these
accepted prescribed drugs is really no different than the raver who
ocassionally drops e to have a good time or to learn something about
themseleves or their world (IMHO).   To be perfectly honest, I can
sympathize with the ocassional recreational or spiritual drug use much more
than the addiction to psychoactive antidepressants that saturates this
country.  Not an attack...simply a comparision.

Heroin?  That's an old myth.  Not only are the costs too high to cut e with
heroin...ingesting it doesn't have much of an effect.


>There are other drugs out there that are also harmful that people that people
>don't know anything about, yet they still do them (GHB, Special K, Crystal
>Meth etc...) Why would someone put somehting in their body that they don't
>even remotely understand?
>Hope to hear from all of you soon in the future!!!
>Much Love
>April :):):):):)

I'd be happy to give you information that you could use to put together
some factual literature.  There is a lot of conflicting information out
there.  There is also a lot of room for personal beliefs here but _factual_
information is always good to help influence decisions.   Your heart seems
to be in the right place in concern for those around you.  Caution should
be taken to prevent forming a biased opinion; be careful not to judge.

Next topic...how neurotoxic is television?  :)

peace,
n8

p.s.  speaking of drug trips...check out david lynch's new movie, "lost
highway".  it opens the 28th nationwide.  it'll blow your  m i n d.

Forwarded from the On-U mailing list.  Lee Perry is in many ways the
originator and inspiration for many of the techniques used to make 
electronic dance music.  He started as a record producer in Jamaica in the
early 1960s and is responsible for a phenomenal amount of the classic 
tracks of that era, and then went on to invent or pioneer many of the
studio techniques that underlie dub.  I can't overstate his influence
(often unnoticed) on all kinds of music -- house, techno and jungle included.

He's also completely crazy, though he's crazy like a fox.  A true trickster,
a shaman, a force from beyond.  He's been holed up in Switzerland for years
and now, suddenly, will descend on SF to do a show.  I have no idea if it
will be any good, but I can easily predict it will be memorable.

phred

--------

> it doesn't make sense to "cut" E with heroin.

: No, it does make sense.  To my knowledge, ecstacy is not physically
: addicting (the drug, anyway ;).  Heroin is, however.  "First time's
: free..."

        It makes even less sense if you're aware that heroin doesn't
work when ingested orally. The digestive process breaks it down. That's
why it is generally injected, and sometimes snorted, and sometimes even
dissolved in water & taken as an enema.

        Of course, some drug dealers are pretty stupid. Just because
it doesn't make sense doesn't mean it won't happen sometimes. Some
drug dealers would be ignorant enough of the facts to try to make
"E" by mixing meth & heroin...

        Anyway, "E" ... IS related to Methamphetamine. If you're
doing high doses regularly, all you're getting is the meth effect.
You might as well just switch to meth. It's cheaper & it'll take
you where you're going more quickly ... there's a number of people
on the list you could talk to about that ...

Snip from Ran's post:
>
> I would like to ask, however, that you all be safe and take care of
>yourselves. It is a good idea to have at least one buddy with you when
>trying to help those in need. _Especially_ if you youself are not sober.
>
> With that said, I hope you all will take the time to communicate with
>each other about parties you plan on going to in the future so we can
>work together. If you can't, for some reason respond to the CC list, mail
>me and I'll foward it to everyone else.
>
It might be a good idea, for those who rave in groups, to select a designated
watchdog/guardian in your group, who will be sober and able to respond to
a crisis.  That person can have as much fun as anyone else at a party while
still keeping tabs on the rest of the group.
Another thought, this one kinda obvious: if you have a friend in distress,
and you feel help is needed beyond your ability to handle it, ASK
SOMEONE IF THEY CAN HELP YOU!  Chances are you'll find one
of us compassionate individuals who will either help or get help.  Let's
work together, my sisters and brothers.  How's about we care for one
another?  :)  Mom says: If you can't be good, be careful!
Love, peace, and safety,
Eric

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Feb 20 13:46:34 1997

Date: Thu, 20 Feb 1997 12:34:00 +0000
From: SFO2!SFO2PO!sgalloway@msatt.attmail.com (Galloway, Scott)
Received: from msatt by attmail; Thu Feb 20 21:39 GMT 1997
Subject: RE: responsibility
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (SFraves), ethan@bass-station.com (Ethan Miller)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: Text/Plain; charset=us-ascii

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hi there,

I agree with some of what you said, however although it is the promoters 
responsibility to provide a safe environment in which people can have fun, 
the promoter cannot possibly be held responsible for each individual persons 
actions.  I've seen kids at your parties that have passed out from too much 
GHB and the like, and I'm certain that you do everything you can to promote 
to the kind of people that you believe will best suit your party's 
aspirations, but noone can hold you responsible for that person's lack of 
knowledge about GHB.  The best that you can do, is to try and educate more, 
or perhaps search people more at the door, but people will always find a way 
to get around these things...this is uncontrollable.  The thing is, that no 
one person has any more or less right to the possible enlightment that can 
be found at raves.  Granted, Nomad caters to a much different crowd than 
yours, but they (for whatever their intentions) are allowing for new people 
to experience a different perspective from what they have ever known.  We 
all on sfraves know very well how raving has affected us, and what it has 
meant to our lives, and who are we to say who can or cannot be a part of 
that?

As far as the promoters of Splish go (Nomad), well we can do nothing but 
make assumptions as to why things happened the way they did.  When was the 
last time something like this happened at a party?  I'm willing to bet that 
they did the very best that they could with what resources that they had. 
 Perhaps they were simply not prepared for that type of occurance...but are 
you?....am I?...maybe we really need to focus on educating the promoters on 
what to do in case of such an unfortunate time, so that if something like 
this does happen again, we will all be better prepared to handle it.

Either way, some type of action does need to happen.  Not directed at Nomad 
in particular, but to all of us, as it is OUR responsibility to watch out 
for each other as well as ourselves.

Smiles,

Scott =)

 ----------
From: Ethan Miller
To: internet!hyperreal.com!sfraves; sgalloway
Subject: responsibility
Date: Wed Feb 19 1997 6:09PM

It's long been my belief that promoters are responsible for what happens at
their parties. The promoter picks who they 'market' to, they pick who they
let in and they either do or do not facilitate some form of what I'll call
magick to  protect the party and those who attend it. Might sound wishy
washy and new age but I've been to plenty of parties where I felt safe and
protected and I've also been to plenty of parties where I could feel random
violence waiting to happen, and it all, quite literally, begins with the
promoter.

A whole complex of things including the promoter's intentions and
awareness; the people at the party, their intentions and awareness; things
done before, during, and after the party to direct all of the above toward
a positive result, ultimately shape the energy that guides and informs the
party.

I would call turning the music back on with two people overboard, the
actions of people not terribly tuned in -- to anything.  How I would feel
as the parent of one of those missing were I to know this, horrifies me.
What could there possibly be to celebrate at that point? If this did in
fact happen, ultimately, no one but the promoters can be held responsible
for that decision.

Anyone facilitating the gathering of hundreds of people most of whom will
probably be out of their heads must have no illusions about their
responsibility for creating as safe and as healthy an environment as
possible.

Whether or not, as the promoters, Tom and Stacy should be held legally
responsible, I hope that, to the appropriate degree, they do feel
personally responsible: they invoked this voyage, and none of it would have
happened had they not. Oonly they will know if they did *everything* they
could to make it a safe trip. If they did, the deserve our sympathy, if
they did not they deserve our wrath.

yours in deep regret
ethan






( ethan miller )-------------- ----------
( http://www.bass-station.com )----------

wuzzup Rob,

You mention that drug dealers are pretty stupid...

I agree.

But, MDMA cooks are usually far from stupid. A few I have known are
UCBerkely PH.Ds, etc just to give you an idea. 

Again, it might happen sometimes (rarely), but for the most part, I believe
that 99.9% of the E on the market does not have H in it. Also, as far as
imported pills (from Amsterdam) breakdowns have been done that show no
signs of any H. 

A more frequent cut for E is speed. Speed give you the euphoric feeling,
keeps you up, and makes you happy. It's cheap, its a somewhat similar high.

But, for the most part, I agree with you.

-d

While I totally consider ecstacy.org and the hyperreal archives to be the
best source available to someone like me about recreational substances,
there have been two long standing concerns I've had about the on-line
information provided about MDMA and such.

1) This one may just be in my head, but I've always felt that writings by
Nicholas Saunders and others were somehow slightly "biased" in favor of the
recreational use of MDMA, and not completely neutral. Something like the
flip side of the D.A.R.E. program, although that is not a preferred
example. I dunno, maybe it's just my perception.

2) It wasn't more than two decades ago, I believe, that MDMA was legal to
buy in the U.S. First discovered in 1913... ....much of what we know comes
from recent discovery. What kind of effect does MDMA have after 40-50
years? No one really seems to know because it just hasn't been around long
enough. This is still a relatively new drug and there is still a lot that
is unknown.

Anyone else hear where I'm coming from on this? Or I'm I just loosing it?

Blake "Pengo" Merriam

Cops lie? ;]
My girlfriend is a  high school teacher and last year a uniformed officer
from the Santa Clara Co Sheriffs dept. dropped by her classroom for some
"straight" talk about THE DANGERS OF DRUGS.  During the course of his
speech, the nice mr officer mentioned MDMA and claimed that it was invented
in the late 1960's by "homosexuals" as a gay love drug! Argh! My girlfriend
had to just sit there and keep quiet, she couldn't tell her class the truth
as district policy expressly prohibits drugs as a subject for classroom
discussion.  Except for lying police.  


As far as heroin in E is concerned; in college I remember reading about how
the heroin being sold on the street was so diluted, and the efficiency of
oral ingestion so low, that eating enough heroin to get any effect at all
would be difficult.  

But I also just read (no, I don't remember where) that a much more potent
form of heroin is beginning to appear on the street, leading to a rash of
overdoses and dead rock stars.  Maybe this more potent form is active
orally? I bet that you would still have to eat an awful lot, I can just
imagine these great big horse (pun intended) E/H pills, yuck!  But still,
the only reason to cut E with anything is to make more money, cutting it
with smack would not accomplish this.  

        'k bye!
                        <chris>

> On Thu, 20 Feb 1997 SFO2!SFO2PO!sgalloway@msatt.attmail.com wrote:
> 
> > 
> > 
> > >Guess I am the only one.  We always have had ours tested.  I have never
> > >bought something at a rave or club and just popped it into my mouth.  My
> > >health is just too important to me.  But, I do understand your concern.
> > >I know many people who need to do drugs to have a good time so badly,
> > >that they will take whatever is offered them.  That's a definite
> > >problem.
> > 
> > Right on Cami.  I can only hope that more people will follow your lead and 
> > find out what they're taking before they're taking it.  You are a great 
> > example of someone taking responsiblity in their drug use, thank you.
> > 
> > Smiles,
> > 
> > Scott =)
> > 
> > 
> 

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Feb 20 15:52:59 1997

 with ESMTP (Apple Internet Mail Server 1.1.1); Thu, 20 Feb 1997 16:44:26 -0700

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (SFraves)
From: Ethan Miller <ethan@bass-station.com>
Subject: RE: responsibility
Cc: SFO2!SFO2PO!sgalloway@msatt.attmail.com
Date: Thu, 20 Feb 1997 16:44:26 -0700
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 12:33 PM -0000 2/20/97, Galloway, Scott wrote:

>I've seen kids at your parties that have passed out from too much
>GHB and the like, and I'm certain that you do everything you can to promote
>to the kind of people that you believe will best suit your party's
>aspirations, but noone can hold you responsible for that person's lack of
>knowledge about GHB.

This has happened only *once* at a Friends and Family and we took it very
seriously and brought the individual to the hospital immediately. And, we
have not thrown a party that size since then because we haven't felt safe
in our, and the community's ability to take care of itself at those sizes
and beyond.

True, though, as you note, tragedy can and does befall everyone, intentions
notwithstanding. Thus I would not assess blame based simply on the
occurrence of tragedy but, rather, on the response to it, which is the only
point I took issue with, and then, only theoretically so.

On a totally separate note, given that Alta Vista is happilly archiving all
this for all eternity, I'd be really happy if you didn't publicly associate
events I've helped produce with alleged drug overdoses. I'm sure you
understand.

take it easy
ethan


( ethan miller )-------------- ----------
( http://www.bass-station.com )---------- -----------------------------------

is really on Sunday.

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C.
       Electronic dance, noise, spoken word, world music and more. Beats
       for your head. Sounds for your soul. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night midnight-3am - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats,
       Breakz and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

Just two comments/suggestions:

1.  the hyperreal site is good for drug info, esp. about E.  I've checked it 
out, and I learned a lot.

2.  possible theme for the pamphlets (or whatever):  when i visited another 
website (can't remember which), they had a theme called "Just Say Know."  I 
thought this was great, it wasn't as anti-drug as "Just Say No" (not that 
being against drugs is a bad thing, but not everyone is willing to accept that 
view), and it encourages education.  There's no point is saying no if you 
don't know what you're saying no to, the same goes for saying yes . . . but we 
all know the saying "knowledge is power," and I think we'd all agree it's 
pretty accurate.  If the medium of education stressed education rather than 
trying to force a set of morals onto people, the raver could use it to make a 
smart decision about drug use.

Miccaela

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Fri, 18 Aug 1995 20:32:57 -0700 (PDT)
From: Jason Sydes <jsydes@osiris.ac.hmc.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Please Read This Ravers!

Hey guys,
       (Just one last post before I log off of sfraves for another two
semesters.)

           This is a great post about how to stop E Neurotoxicity!

        After reading that thread about the reorginazation of neurons,
I thought I'd put in a little bit of my knowledge and opinion. I've 
basically spent most of my free time this summer reading the current 
journal articles on MDMA, and I'm a junior chemist at Harvey Mudd College 
(which btw, has a pretty cool scene here...), so I THINK I am somewhat 
reliable of a source (though I am always learning, just like everyone else)

        If you don't like boring scientific brain stuff, just skip to the
        end for answers on how to stop E neurotoxicity. There are actually a
        lot of really effective things you can do, and I've tried to list
        all that I know of (I'm sure there are more things...).

Q: What does E do?
A: It causes the massive release of serotonin from serotonergic presynaptic
neurons. Basically the neurons terminals that contain serotonin as their
neurotransmitter are caused to fire (ie. release serotonin into the synapse)
by MDMA. 
A very simplistic view of serotonin might describe it as the "happy
neurotransmitter," since low levels of it are associated with
depression. After this massive release your body probably cannot recollect
all of your serotonin (some gets degraded, some just floats away). Hence
your serotonin levels drop.

Q: What else does E do?
A: It inhibits TPH, tryptophan hydroxylase. This enzyme is the first of two
steps which transforms tryptophan (an amino acid) to serotonin. Hence new
production of serotonin is halted (or at least slowed down signifigantly).

Q: Is this what causes depression the next day?
A: Most likely, yes. After a night in which a chemical has caused the
massive release of serotonin into the synapse, and then significantly slowed
the new production of serotonin, your serotonin levels are likely to be
markedly lowered.

Q: Is MDMA neurotoxic?
A: Yes. It selectively degeneretes (note - it does NOT kill, as far as we
know) serotonin neuron terminals. In experiments on monkeys, after stopping
MDMA use for approx a year, the neuron terminals were found to
regenerate. 

MY THEORY - It's at this point that the serotonergic neuron terminals grow 
back to the wrong place, hence causing the abnormal connections we were just
reading about in the "Rave Drug May Damage Brain...." or whatever. But this
is just my theory on things...

Q: What causes the neurotoxicity?
A: This one's a doozy.....  After the serotonin has binded to the receptor
on the other side of the synpapse (the post-synaptic neuron), there is a 
reuptake pump (on the pre-synaptic neuron) that sucks back up the serotonin 
from the synapse. Every now and then the pump will suck up a dopamine
molecule (another neurotransmitter that isn't really related to the
"feel-good" effects of E). That dopamine doesn't have any business being
inside of a serotonin neuron, so MAO-B degrades the dopamine, IN THE 
PROCESS OF WHICH HYDROGEN PEROXIDE IS FORMED!!!!! 
        
Q: So what's the big deal about Hydrogen Peroxide?
A: Nothing normally. H2O2 (hydrogen peroxide) is toxic to animals because it
splits in two to form two hydroxyl free radicals, which are very reactive
and very damaging. Normally your body can handle these varmits just fine,
just by reducing them with anti-oxidants (like Vitamin C, E, or
glutathione).

Q: H2O2 and MDMA: so what's the connection?
A: MAO-B also degrades serotonin, but not as well as it degrades dopamine,
but there is usually so much serotonin as compared to dopamine inside of a
serotonergic neuron, that it has a hard time getting around to the dopamine,
so very little H2O2 is formed. HOWEVER, during an E trip, a whole heck of a
lot of your serotonin is outside in the synapse, not in the neuron, so the
MAO-B has a much easier time getting to the dopamine, and hence forming more
H2O2. (Also I think E causes a larger production of dopamine elsewhere in
your brain, and eventually some of that dopamine will get inside of the 
serotonergic neurons). Now there is a much higher level of H2O2 INSIDE of
your serotonergic neurons than your body can effectively get rid of, and
NOW we start seeing brain damage: specifically, selective serotonergic
neuron degeneration.

MY THEORY - The neurons form abnormal connections after being damaged, maybe
because they just hook up with the closet thing nearby. If you could stop
this degeneration damage somehow, there would be no way for the neurons to
grow back abnormally since they are already fine.

                        END OF BORING SCIENTIFIC STUFF

Q: So how do I stop this shitty neurotoxicity?
A: Many Many different ways. Below is a list of the ways I am currently
familiar with, though I'm sure there are probably more...


1) Stop the reuptake of serotonin (and hence the accidental reuptake of
   dopamine also which is the real cause of the neurotoxicity) by taking an
   SSRI (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor). So take:

                                Prozac 

   Take it 3-6 hours afters taking your E dose, and this will significantly
   reduce neurotoxicity. THIS IS A WELL DOCUMETNED EFFECT! This is not one
   of my other theories. If you do this your brain will love you for it. Any
   other SSRI will also have the same effect (Xanax? Zoloft? Are those SSRIs?) 
   This might even make your trip a bit better, because it will keep the
   serotonin in the synapse longer....

2) Stop the breakdown of dopamine by MAO-B. This is the ultimate step which
   produces the toxic hydrogen peroxide. The documented case I read about
   used:

                               L-deprenyl

   which I believe is a commonly prescribed anti-depressant, though when I
   think about it, maybe it's not since.... Well does anyone have any info
   on this or where to get it? It would be greatly appreciated.... Anyways,
   take it the same time that you take your E, cause that's what worked for
   the rats.... Other MAO-B inhibitors will also work (ask your doctor about
   this....)

3) Increase relative serotonin levels. If you eats lots of tryptophan at the
   same time you eat your E, this will overcome the inhibitory effects that
   E has on TPH (tryptophan hydroxylase), which will increase relative
   serotonin levels, which will decrease the degradative actions of MAO-B on
   dopamine (since all of the extra serotonin will be getting in the way),
   which will produce less H2O2, and hence less damage. So....

        Take something like 2-3 capsules of tryptophan with 1 capsule E.

   Unfortunatley, the FDA has taken tryptophan (an amino acid!!!) off of the
   market for what I believe is essentially political reasons (they found it
   later to be a contaminent in a Japanese pharmaceuticals tryptophan
   product that was causing the sickness, not the tryptophan itself.....)
   You can still probably get it in Mexico though and you probably can even
   mail order it for European Pharmaceutical companies. It's not like it's a
   Schedule I drug like E is....
   This might also make your trip a bit better because you will now be
   continually producing serotonin. IT WILL ALMOST DEFINITELY HELP WITH
   POST-E DEPRESSION....

4) Stop the free-radical damage. This is the easiest to do, since
   anti-oxidants are extremely easy to come by. Some suggestions:

        Glutathione - This a naturally occuring tripeptide in your body. I
                      THINK it is one of the chemicals your brain uses in
                      the process that gets rid of free radicals. And it
                      itself is an anti-oxidant....

        Vitamin C
        Vitamin E
        Melatonin (fairly good report in recent Newsweek on this)
        Many others....

   It would probably be a good idea to take some with your E, and then maybe
   about 3-6 hours later....



                 Summary

Prozac & other SSRIs                    3-6 hours after taking E
L-deprenyl and other MAO-B inhibitors   When you take your E
Tryptophan ***                          When you take your E
Anti-oxidants
    Vitamin C
    Vitamin E
    glutathione ***
    melatonin

*** - highly recommend

        Well, that's it.... Hope I haven't gone too overboard. I would like 
to give one last thanks to the SF scene for giving me what I believe was the
greatest summer I've ever had. Thanks much to all you out there who have
make it so special....

                                          lots and lots and lots o luv,

                                                Jason Sydes
                                                







----- End Included Message -----

Good insight as to what my son will have to deal with when he gets older.
I guess I look at being bi-racial as THE best place to be in this couldron
called America.  I eman, you defy classsification, so I guess "human" would be 
the best bet since you are an amalgam of all things.  This is the 
rightdirection, IMO, this country and the world needs to go to get away from 
thesevere tribalism we are constantly embroiled in.
Being biracial myself, I don't agree that it's the best thing to be.  I'm too 
"white" for some black folks--since I'm so light people assume that I'm a 
"wannabe," or that I'm stuck up, etc.  And as for white people, they still see 
me as black.  And white racists still think of me as the infamous n-word (I'll 
leave it out so I don't offend anyone, but I won't act like I don't use it, 
because I do).  Being biracial is not a problem when you're around openminded 
people (whether they be black, white, or anything else).  It doesn't mean 
you'll immediatly identify with them either.  Being biracial around racists 
(be they black, white, or anything else) is just as bad, perhaps worse than 
being just one race, because you signify the union of two races that those 
people believe should never mix.  And we cannot forget that you're always 
expected to choose which "side" you're on.

To avoid flaming, let me say that I am not saying that all whites or all 
blacks are racists, or that being biracial sucks.  I love everybody and I love 
who I am.  But I've learned that not everyone loves me and who I am.

Racism is going to exist in America as long as there is black, white, latino, 
asian, pacific islander, etc.  It's human nature to categorize people and also 
judge groups of people without a rational basis for that judgement.  I'm the 
first to admit that I'm prejudiced and can be pretty damn ignorant.  That's 
why I rarely call anyone racist or trip off racist comments because I make 
them myself.  My white friends sometimes talk about black people, and my black 
friends talk about white people.  It's a fact of life.

I figure most white people have said "nigger," for whatever reason.  Most 
black people have used the words "cracker," "poor white trash," "honkey," etc. 
 I know I've used both.  But everyone has an ignorant moment, and I'm not 
going to base my opinion on someone because they used a racial slur.  If 
someone treats me and and all sorts people with respect, no matter what their 
race, I don't care what words they use.  Actions speak louder than words.  
I've met many racists who've never used a racial slur around me, and many 
great people who have used every word in the book.  I refuse to let words like 
nigger or cracker or whatever else get me riled up, because I'm not going to 
let a certain combination of letters have that much control over my emotions.  
But that's just me.

If someone doesn't like you to use racial slurs, respect them enough not to 
use them, at least not in their presence.  How you show respect is much more 
important than your vocabulary.

Miccaela






From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Feb 20 18:45:29 1997

	id VkJ08105; Thu, 20 Feb 1997 21:40:54 EST
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Thanks to all
Message-ID: <19970220.183939.10670.13.Libbyrose@juno.com>
X-Mailer: Juno 1.15
X-Juno-Line-Breaks: 4-5,8-9,11-12,14-15,23-24,26-29,31-32,35-39
From: libbyrose@juno.com (Libby Bundsen)
Date: Thu, 20 Feb 1997 21:40:54 EST

Precedence: bulk

Thanks to everyone who came to Euphonic Genesis!  It was lots of fun!  I
also want to thank everyone who was extra-nice to my mom and my
boyfriend's mom.  They had so much fun that they plan on coming to more
parties!!  Special thanks to the kids who gave them hugs, glitter,
stickers, glowstix, and lillipops.

Also, an apology to the poor guy they dragged out on the dancefloor. 
They had just arrived, and didn't understand yet that people dance BY
THEMSELVES at parties ;-)

For a while, they thought that the partyers were afraid of them being
there, but I convinced them otherwise.

We ended up having a lot of people bring their parents to our party.  We
even had special laminates that said "Parent Pass" on them.

Bringing my mom to Euphonic Genesis was a big step in my becoming closer
with my mother.  She thanked me repeatedly for caring enough to include
her in my life.  I saw not only an emotional change in my mother, that
night, but a physical one.  When I drove her home (at about 11:45--she's
not used to staying up late) she was hyper, giggly, and more positive
than I'd seen her in years.  When she looked at me, she had a twinkle in
her eye.  She looked as if a weight had been lifted off her.  She looked
younger, happier.

I remember my mom warning me that she wouldn't like the music at the
party...

           ...I got her ON TAPE saying, "I really liked the music"!!!

Stay tuned for more information; my mother will be posting from this
e-mail address, someday soon, to give her account of Saturday night.

Once again, thank you all very very very much for your help!  You have
helped me live out one of my dreams--to share the magic of raving with my
mom!

Love and kisses to everyone,

      Libby Rose (aka Spunky or HuggyBear)  :-)  :-)  :-)

>ignorance comes in.. most people think of "raves" as a place to get high
>and wasted...but this indeed is a big misnomer!..people who put drugs
>into their #1 list should just stay home and get fucked up
>there......peace..christian

If you don't think that drugs are a leading factor in the international
success of raves and rave culture, I suggest you:

(1) Watch *any* show spotlighting raves (Hard Copy, 20/20, Leeza, etc.,
etc.) They may be sensationalizing the drug use to a degree, but they have
gathered factual material with which to sensationalize. That is the
difference between manufactured news and slanted news. No matter how you
try to argue "how little" or "how much" with regard to the media's portayal
of drugs, you can't deny the drugs. Remember, they didn't make it up!

(2) Take a look at many of the rave flyers that sport thinly veiled drug
references. The Bagok Tribe 'Lucky Charms' flyer has to be the worst flyer
I have ever seen with regard to blatant "drug + rave" marketing to the kids
tactics, but there are others...

(3) Take a look at the home page of Hyperreal, where "Drugs" has about the
same amount of home-page real estate as "Raves" -- Hyperreal is known to be
the #1 world wide resource for raving and rave culture and drugs are linked
to it from the get go. There are five major things on the home page:
"Raves" "Music" "Publications" "Chemistry" [read: recreational drugs info]
and "Tools and Information."

For a culture that has nothing to do with raves, 20%'s a lot of real estate
for a completely unrelated subject.

(4) Take a closer look at a significant portion of the discussion on this
list (or most any other "geographical" rave-list) that is specifically
related to open conversation relating to: drugs consumed, drug
contamination, drug references ("420, dude!!1!" -- "That was a PHAT party!
I was on 2.5 hits of E!!1!" -- "What vitamins can I take to feel better
after E'ing my ass off all night?", etc.) Add to that constant" E vs. LSD,
vs pot vs sober vs natural stimulants" discussions...

I am *not making a statement here either endorsing or condemning drugs*. I
am not saying this applies to each and every raver on the planet, I am
simply bringing home the fact the issue of denial about just how important
and just how integral drugs and drug useage are with the world wide "rave"
movement.

Now, I say again, in reply to "most parents [and the media, and government,
and law enforcement, etc. etc.] see these kind of parties as drug-fests
where everybody gets high and wasted.."

And what part of that is not accurate?"

man, i've been away for too damn long...

:)


my take on the role drugs play in the rave scene:

you CAN rave without drugs and have an excellent time and feel the vibe and
give love and dance and that's beautiful...

but i don't think the scene would exist today if it hadn't been for the
drugs. the concepts of peace and love and all that have existed for a long
time, but i think it was Ecstasy that really drove those ideas home in the
minds of most ravers.  the idea of "we're all one" that really drives a
spiritual vibe at some parties has been around for a while, but that idea
was never quite real for me until i took acid.

_maybe_ you could take away all the drugs and the scene would keep on
going. i don't know.   but i think drugs were one of the integral building
blocks that allowed the scene to flourish in the first place, and they are
still very much a part of that scene. i doubt i would have fallen in love
with raving if i'd been sober at my first party.

and besides, who'd want to take away the drugs?  (okay, okay, i know...)

the problem with the media's portrayal of raves as drug-fests is the
negativity implicit in that... the idea that we're all putting ourselves at
great risk for nothing but a bit of hedonistic pleasure.  while there is
_some_ risk, and the pleasure is nothing to sneeze at, there's a lot more
to it than that -- which is exactly why drugs are an important part of the
scene.


covered in gasoline and ready to be lit,

;)

brian

Not a flame, but I just wanted to say that I fell in love with raving
after my first party, and I even managed to dance longer and harder
than my friends who were all up on speed that night...and the only
thing I was on was the excitement I felt because I was raving for the
first time.  I think it's kinda sad that you didn't get a chance to
rave sober the first time since one's first rave is probably, imho, one
of the most memorable.

> wheredo we want to go?
> all elitist "undergrounds" ? ... it doesnt take a genius to see the life
> cycle of that one.
> 
> tony rose

i think notifying the media would definitely be stooopid and
irresponsible as well as just plain old mean.  If people are happy with
their group then good for them, but i don't think it is their right or
perrogative-sp? to ruin the scene for everyone else.  Massives-as much
as i *personally* dislike them- do serve a purpose.

back east a LOT of the parties are *underground* and invite only....and
i'm not sure that serves any positive purpose.

One thing i DO like about the SF scene is its openess.  I remember when
i started partying 5 years ago i really appreciated having the option to
choose from several parties.  Having these options gave me the ability
to actually CHOOSE my place in the scene and CHOOSE which type of
parties i want to go to and be involved with.  By going to bad parties i
was able to appreciate the good parties and really see and appreciate
the effort that goes into the *good* ones. okay i'm rambling...sorry.

To sum it up:
Choice is good and i feel that i nor anyone else has the right to
dictate what is right for other people.  Let people figure it out for
themselves and lets leave the media OUT of this, because that will only
do BAD for everyone.

:)
Micron

	I think that one of the most insidious things about drug use
is that it tends to make you attribute any positive experience you 
might have to the drug. If you participate in some wonderful meditation
ritual that gets you totally stoned while you're on E, you're likley to 
think "wow, the E is really kicking in hard" rather than "wow, that was
a really powerful ritual."

	The flip side of this is that it tends to make you believe
you *can't* really enjoy yourself without the drug ...

> after my first party, and I even managed to dance longer and harder
> than my friends who were all up on speed that night...and the only
> thing I was on was the excitement I felt because I was raving for the
> first time.  I think it's kinda sad that you didn't get a chance to

> 
I just wanted to say that I went to my first rave sober (@16) and
continued to go for the music (still sober) till I was 18....I think a
major problem that hinders the progression of the rave culture (I said
hinder not stop) is the excessive use of drugs. I've seen too many people
go downhill due to excessive drug use and overdose. I'm not saying stop
using drugs, start using drugs or change your habits, I don't think it's
my right to tell any of you what to do or not do. I am asking that
you as human just think about what you do before you do it, think about 
who it will affect and be smart about what you do. Hey, if you don't look
out for you body and brain and community who is????

Ivan

> 
> 	I think that one of the most insidious things about drug use
> is that it tends to make you attribute any positive experience you 
> might have to the drug. 
> ....
> 	The flip side of this is that it tends to make you believe
> you *can't* really enjoy yourself without the drug ...

 That's a widespread opinion in "our" American culture. That's why 
you can be drugless ( but not sober ) dancing "in the light" and folks 
will be coming up to you and assume you're on some great drug(s) , and 
they want some of what got you to your ecstatic state. 

 I've been dancing in my trippy sorta way for 20 years, and the same
question used to come my way more than once.

 It's all part of our "ingestion to happiness" culture. Buy something,
ingest/use it, and get deleriously happy and fullfilled. Hey, it
happens to everybody else in TV commercials, why can't I ? But, you can't
get there unless you buybuybuy something outside yourself - you're
weird or even dangerous if you can get out of this world without the
help of "stuff".


Larry "Sometimes slightly weird, but not dangerous" Ching / larryc@netcom.com

Christian Sotto wrote:
> 
> with all the confusion that has been brewing up...what is exactly a rave
> and what is exactly a party?...cant we all live harmoniously and keep
> both definitions together...sentiments needed.....peace..christian

I realize this you are being rhetorical, but here is my rhetoric.


my 2
is that Rave is the concept of an all night gathering of dancing and
partying.  A party is a grassroots Rave.  Generally, people refer to
massives as Raves, and underground parties as Parties.  In the past,
when House music was breaking, there were house parties.  I did not hear
the word "Rave" until that ear-hurting "James Brown is Dead" song came
out and and someone told me about the concept of the all-night
gatherings that happened outside of the club venue.  That is probably
why I personally can't call a club night with techno a "Rave."  DJ's
have been spinning all kind of dance music in clubs since the disco era,
and it is constantly changing genre, so what's the dif now?  Since the
music that was originally introduced to the public in the Rave venue is
now and has been in liquor-licensed clubs, people sometimes call them
"Raves"  It's more important to seperate the music from the venue when
talking about it, but it is less important to validate one venue from
the other.  People have preferences over both the music and the venue. 
It's just nice to have a choice in this city.  It's not like that in
Boston, that's for sure.  Be glad we have a really loving, caring,
wonderful scene here, overall, I mean!!!

Peace,

Goldilox

>Lee Perry is in many ways the originator and inspiration for many of ...

I have been waiting for a show like this for years. You will not be
dissapointed. This guy(Lee Perry) is absolutely crazy... with some very
funny lyrics, from childish jibberish to downright nasty. And lately it
seems that anything the Mad Professor touches turns to gold.

Anyway some releases I have currently been into are:

-Lee Perry - Who put the voodoo pon reggae (with the Mad Professor) Kind
of overproduced with some really booming bass that your body will not be
able to sit still for. A good version of "Come back"

-Lee Perry - Experiments at the grass roots of dub - This is alot more
experimental. I'm really glad someone is willing to put out something
alittle less mainstream, as far a bub or dub/reggae goes. This one has
some interesting underwater-sounding  vocals. 

Hope to see some of you at the show,

I agree completely with you; drugs ARE a part of the scene AND
they play an important part of the scene.  BUT this doesn't also
mean that they are THE most important aspect of the scene.  I've
been hoping that the recent pleas by various people, including
yourself, to focus back on the important things rather than the
drug aspect would be headed.  Unfortunately this doesn't seem to
be happening too much (the recent dinner/drop getogether for the
NYE makeup party being an example; not to pick on anyone in particular,
it's just one that sticks out in recent memory.)  

To me, the things that are important are those you mentioned, all which 
come from the gathering together of our community to share ourselves with
each other.  It's through our ability to share our love and compassion
for each other that we gain.  The insight brought about through E is
secondary, IMO.

I've grown and discovered new things about myself through my interaction
with you all, and I would hope that everyone else who may come into
our scene would have the same opportunity.  They need to be properly
prepared for what they will encounter and how they can benefit from
it, not misinformed by some tabloid t.v. show and shut out of this
growth.

> The same thing happened for me. I had the greatest time at my first rave 
> and have never had the urge to change that feeling by using drugs. I love 
> the music and raving without the drugs. 

as do i.  but i doubt that i would have initially. you are fortunate,
perhaps, that you were able to see the value in raving without chemical
enhancement. i don't think i could have.

It is kinda sad at any point to 
> need the drugs to enjoy what you are doing. 

WHY? what makes it sad?  true, it's sad that this society directs us to
such an ingrained place of negativity that some people can't see past the
negativity to the light and love in the world.  but there is nothing sad
about the fact that Ecstasy enabled me to see that positivity.

and i did enjoy the 2 hours i spent sober at my first rave.  in fact, i
enjoyed them a lot, i gained an immediate appreciation for techno, and i
discovered for the first time the joy of dancing.  i'm not knocking the
non-drug-induced benefits of raves.  however, without E, raving
would have been little different from clubbing for me-- not
something i'm usually into.  taking Ecstasy that night, on the other hand, 
_changed my life_.

i don't think we should be so quick to say "this ISN'T about drugs!"
anymore than the media should be so quick to say that's ALL it's about...
the truth lies somewhere in between.  drugs are ONLY a PART of this scene,
but they can be a VALUABLE part of the scene if we are conscious of their
benefits and risks and use them accordingly.

Love and Light,

bri

From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Drug Hypocrisy?
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9702211124.A18845-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



I'm glad that people recognize that there are greater components to 
raving than just a "drug party," but I have to respond to what I feel is 
a hypocritical anti-drug tinge to these discussions.

I'm pretty tired of seeing anti-drug tirades against all those people who 
use them "for the wrong reasons" or "too much" with the disclaimer at the 
end, "note: I am NOT AGAINST DRUGS.  I take them often myself!"  Why is 
it that people feel THEIR drug use is reasonable but others' indulgence, and 
drug use in the scene, is somehow worse (or different from their own?!).
The "scene's" use is composed of a bunch of individuals' using, that 
includes a lot of the critics.

I'm also concerned that we are adopting the mainstream culture's
anti-recreational drug use mentality (except alcohol and tobacco, which
are just fine, of course).  For example, we must defend drug use as
transcendental, OR we must distance ourselves from the stereotype of a drug
party.  Why is this same standard not applied to alcohol?!  In other 
words, why can't it just be accepted that the dominant mood-altering 
substances at parties are drugs rather than alcohol.  Would you go to a club 
and then feel you had to defend the fact that you had a few drinks?!

In other words, apologies for choosing to indulge are expected only for
DRUGS, not for alochol.  Can you imagine - "I went to a club, and it was
just a huge booze fest!  Now, I drink too, but not to the extent as those
who use ethanol for the wrong reasons.  And it's really a shame that so 
many people feel they have to drink just because it's a club."

What bothers me, basically, is the assumption I see that drug use is 
categorically bad, and therefore one must jump to criticize the use, or 
must justify your own use in a higher context than just having fun.  

Yes, drugs can be just recreational, or they can have a higher intent.  But
why are we then judging one to be more valid than the other?  Doesn't that
seemingly liberal, "enlightened" approach actually smack of anti-drug
propaganda - i.e. forcing drugs to be evaluted on some arbitrary standard
that alcohol does not have to live up to? 

Try your morning without coffee, a deep depression without that slice of 
chocolate cake, and the party at your friend's house without a glass of 
wine before slamming ravers for doing drugs at a PARTY.

A moderate druggie
and proud of it,
N

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Feb 21 12:29:33 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id MAA14865; Fri, 21 Feb 1997 12:29:33 -0800 (PST)
Received: from host.domain.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with ESMTP id MAA14782; Fri, 21 Feb 1997 12:29:21 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [204.253.162.243] (wdc-mac.eff.org [204.253.162.243]) by host.domain.net (8.7.5/8.6.12) with ESMTP id MAA04631 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Fri, 21 Feb 1997 12:29:16 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <v03007801af33b59d07cc@[204.253.162.243]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Fri, 21 Feb 1997 12:27:13 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "Wayne D. Correia" <wayne2@club.net>
Subject: Re: another d r u g s and r a v i n g denial thread (was:Re:
 Thanks  to all)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 10:48 AM -0800 2/21/97, Steve Simitzis wrote:
>Thank you for an intellegent and accurate post on this subject.
>Why do people keep lying to themselves?

Re: "hey, let's focus on the community and the hugging...."

Yeah, but all the hugging and the community and the music and the dancing
in the world is not going to overcome the public's opinions on the stigma
of raves being a happy haven for kids to experiment with drugs. Many of
these kids are tweaked out on Ecstacy, LSD, Ketamine, GHB, pot, or a
mixture of those etc. at an age when it would be considered quite a scandal
if they were caught with beer in their posession.

You *have* to change that reality before the majority of the population
will be able to hear about the good aspects of raving: love, hugs, music,
community or anything else, and to an extent, these are still all memes of
a subculture in denial. Unless you do that, ravers/raving/raves *will* be
perceived (correctly) as a subculture in denial about their collective drug
useage.

To add another comparison, There are other groups and other eras that had
the same problems and the same realities with regard to being a community
of predominately drug users that socialized in groups, locations, music,
bands, etc. that ultimately found cohesion from their collective drug usege:

"The 60's."

As a group, they had all the negative and positive aspects that the world
wide rave scene has, and to this day, you can't be a proponent of that
subculture without a "regular" person retorting "But wasn't that just a
bunch of hippy kids high on acid and pot?" and if you are a truthful
person, you must answer "Yes."

Ravers are, stereotypically, "just a bunch of slacker kids high on acid and
pot, (and now even more)" and must be equally honest with themselves as a
demographic that the community that they choose to associate themselves and
their image with, for the most part, is comprised of a bunch young people
that really like to get high.

I am not calling you that. I am not calling me that. I am not calling my
friends that I celebrate with on an almost weekly basis that, but there are
a *lot* more of "them" than there are of "us", and until "they" can be
educated, can be excited about going out to a rave without the primary
directive to be "to score some E" and to really appreciate everything that
raving is "while sober", we're doomed to be lumped into the stereotypical
collective of "rave" that is fundamentally based on getting high.

But We (and the SF Raves community in general) are not a representative
sample of the world wide rave community. If you want to see a more
representative sample, go to a Ghost Tribe or Bagok Tribe or almost any
other "least common denominator" ma$$ive "come one, come all, just bring
your $20" type party -- take a look around. The meadian age hovers around
15 or 16 and the *majority* of the people there will be high as a kite.

That is not the reason that or the people I go out with to celebrate, but I
am never looking to associate with the "median" of any subculture, so you
won't find me there.

But your parents, your civic leaders, and your churches will not know the
difference, and it's not really their responsibility to understand the
nuances between what "We" do and what "the median" does while at or why
they go to a rave. They don't have to. "The median's" actions are in the
fat middle of the bell curve that is rightfully used to determine the
essence of any statistically arranged collection of data -- and that
basically tells all you need to know.

but I know plenty of people who go to raves just to enjoy the music.  drugs
play a part, but not in everyones experince.  it is up to the person at the
rave how they want to experince the rave.  what things they want to do while
at the rave.  but first and foremost it's about the music.  it was about the
music forst, but then drugs made their way onto the scene.  yes, to most it
may seem like drugs are the key element at raves.  a little e, some nitrous.
 it's all part of the experince.  but it goes deeper than that, one must look
at the rave as a place to get a close to techno as you can.  drugs, for some
people, enhance this experince.  For some people there is nothing that makes
the music come alive like drugs.  But I know plenty of people that use drugs,
but go to raves, and stay sober (sometimes) their take on the rave is that it
kicked ass.  if the dj is good enough, and he/she is spinnin' a set that is
just GOOD.  then you don't particularly need to enhance the experince with
drugs.  though for some people it might help.
     you can't say somebody is wrong for going to a rave/party and takeing
drugs.  because even if drugs wheren't a major factor to the scene in the
begining, they have become a major factor.  What people must do is reliaze
that not everyone at a rave is doing drugs.  that many come to the rave
solely to listen to good techno.  to see their favorite dj spin.  raves
produce a bond wiht people.  friendship cards, adresses, email adresses, all
of those things bring people closer together, that is what a rave can do.  it
is about the vibe that is at the rave.  if the mindstate that you come i with
is that I just wan to get fucked up, then the vibe shrinks a little.  If
everyone does that then you've got a lot of people that are gone.  But if you
come in with the minstate of haveing a good time, groving to some really good
techno, maybe doing some drugs, then the vibe is intact.  and everyone,
wether thier doing drugs or not can enjoy the rave.
after all it's about music....about good fucking techno blasting  you away.  
peace
nathan

On Fri, 21 Feb 1997, Eric P. Peterson wrote:
> >wayne2@club.net wrote:
> >> At 9:02 PM -0800 2/20/97, Christian Sotto wrote:
> >> >so happy for you:)....most parents see these kind of parties as
> >> >drug-fests were everybody gets high and wasted..
> >> And what part of that is not accurate?
> >well...I mainly go to parties because of the wonderful people that take
> >part in it....drugs sure is one part on the  whole "scene"...but it
> >should not be that important....the music..the community..and the vibe
> >is what makes everything work..its not the drugs....this is were all the
> >ignorance comes in.. most people think of "raves" as a place to get high
> >and wasted...but this indeed is a big misnomer!..people who put drugs
> >into their #1 list should just stay home and get fucked up
> >there......peace..christian
> 
> "You'll come for the drugs...you'll stay for the fellowship"
> (That was humor, BTW)
> I agree with what Christian says here.  If a person's primary interest is
> in getting high, there are many, often less expensive or free, alternate
> environments that are perfectly suitable.

I disagree.  It's usually the easiest means for teenagers to buy drugs.
Especially E, speed, and K.  The sensory overload is what many people I've
met want from the experience of being on drugs at raves.  On top of that,
there is very little, if any, authority checking on what they're doing
there.  Tell me many other places you can find like this at 15 - 18 years
old.

This mailing list probably draws the people who are most supportive of the
rave culture of the population at any given party by virtue of the fact
that we're reading and writing about it every single day.  A lot of you
seem to be getting much more from these parties than a drug experience.
Not so for a majority of the people out there at a party.  A lot of them
may be at the beginning of their search for "something more", but for
younger party goers, it's about experimentation and new experience.

If you do get something more from the scene than a place to get high,
hell yeah you'd love to shake the negative connotations that the scene
has with it's tight knit to the drug culture in the public's eye.  I doubt
this will ever happen, and that's sad in a way to those of us.

To those that feel drugs are great and intergral to the scene and the
"peace love and unity", why wouldn't they put drugs on their flyers and
sell drugs and push for their legalization?  The people that I've met
that have this view aren't saying it's only about the drugs (and would
anyone ever anyway?), they're saying it's about the drugs & the music &
the family.

Isn't the view that there is nothing wrong with doing drugs (excuse me,
"responsibly") the attitude of ravers at large?  I personally can't
subscribe to this belief, and it makes me hot and cold about the rave
scene all the time.  I've realized over my time and involvement in this
culture that I've been on a quest for meaning in life, spirituality, and
fulfillment.

Youth subcultures have seemingly replaced organized religion for many
people I've met in the last eight years, and your first statement really
pointed evidence to me once again of this, even if in jest--as with
organized churches, people go to find fellowship with others who share
beliefs and ideas and moral opinions.  I wonder how many people on here
who are really involved still find their spirituality from somewhere
other than the rave scene.

If you've got some thoughts and opinions on this, I'd love to hear them.

peace,
Marshal

Irving Walsh (author of "Trainspotting") has a new novel out about the
club and drug culture called (ahem) "Ecstasy."  Kinda pertinent to our
discussion about the perception of the scene's inseparability with drugs,
especially _that_ one!  His other books have been well-reviewed, so I'm
gonna pick this one up... 

BTW, I learned of this in a review in UC Berkeley's student paper, which 
writes that this novel is supposed to appeal to the "rave generation - a 
blanket term for those staving off the impending boredom of adulthood in 
a drug-fueled blitz."  Jeez.  (And I thought at 27 I already qualified as 
an adult!  guess not!)

Received: from default (cnc50214.concentric.net [206.173.223.14]) by mx0.ten.net (8.7.6/8.7.2) with ESMTP id SAA02068; Fri, 21 Feb 1997 18:46:30 -0800 (PST)

Subject: Re: Thanks to all
Date: Fri, 21 Feb 1997 17:47:11 -0800
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Priority: 3
X-Mailer: Microsoft Internet Mail 4.70.1155
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

    
> Youth subcultures have seemingly replaced organized religion for many
> people I've met in the last eight years, and your first statement really
> pointed evidence to me once again of this, even if in jest--as with
> organized churches, people go to find fellowship with others who share
> beliefs and ideas and moral opinions.  I wonder how many people on here
> who are really involved still find their spirituality from somewhere
> other than the rave scene.

 I've been a Methodist my entire life. And while I know that many people in
the scene feel at least somewhat religious towards raving and it's
lifestyle, it is far from being an organized one. I mean, if anything
SFRaves shows us that even among us the subscribers, there is no clear
sharing of similar beliefs, ideas, or moral opinions. Oh shure, there are a
couple of things that are shared, like a belief in living with Peace Love
Unity & Respect, or that blacklites are pretty cool, and Underground Dance
Music rules, but that's far from being a complete religion. What do I mean
by "complete religion"? Every major religion that I can think of has a
belief about how/why the world came into being, how/why human beings showed
up, specific do's and don'ts, ect.  There are exceptions, ofcource. I can't
really say I know much about Scientology (except that they hate
newsgroups), for example. Or remote religions like Balinese or Confushism.

 I'm not saying Raving (or an offshoot of) will never have religious
beliefs. But religions take time to develop. Raving's only been around a
little while, people! Give it time.

I do wish that Christianity would in some ways be more accepted into Raving
culture. Often I see Buddhist or Hindu or some other "eastern" religion's
art at a party. I guess this is because  because Christianity has in the
past been the most visible religion for people in this country and eastern
religions in general have a more open attitude about altered states, sex,
ect.

 And while I'm at it I'm going to get one last Religiously Rave Related
Rant (say that 5x fast) out: Whenever the topic of contemporary religion is
mentioned in this group, Christians are usually getting knocked one way or
the other. I pretty much keep my trap shut when this happens because that
thread would go nowhere fast. But I do want to mention that not all
Christians share the same beliefs. Examples: While Catholics do not openly
accept homosexuals as part of their congregation, Methodists do and without
a "Don't ask don't tell" policy. We OPENLY welcome all people. (Sound
familiar?)  And in California, many Methodist Churches have offered their
churches as sanctuary for people to buy and sell medical marijuana. The
reason? "Jesus broke the law of the land to help people." And in some ways
Christianity has been wrongly portraed by the media. (As if EVERY Church
Father was a child molester) Sound familiar too?

Give Christianity a break, it's not all bad. You may even *gasp* like some
of it.

-=Pengo=-

Hi folks!  ]=)


 A few days ago someone stated that E had meth-amphetamine in it. I 
answered that I thought it was only related to amphetamines by the virtue 
of the last A in MDMA.

 Someone obviously thought I was way off base and sent back (in all upper 
case) that the MA in MDMA stood for meth-amphetamine.

 Well, I drug out (  ;)  ) my trusty Psychedelics Encyclopedia to see 
wha' s'up.

 from page III - 65 

MDMA -- full name is N-methyl-3,4-mehylenedioxyphenylisopropylamine


 MDA is 3-4 methylendioxy-amphetamine or 3-4 methylendioxyphenylisopropylamine

from pages III-67 & 282 (I'm paraphrasing)

 Aminization (chemical conversion to amine form) makes MDA, MDMA and 
amphetamines, meth-amphetamines.


peas,


Ran D.Dreams

On Fri, 21 Feb 1997, Pengo wrote:

oh, cool.  i actually like it when calm discussions start about 
religion.  sounds actually like methodist is a pretty cool religion.  one 
question seemed to come up about people finding spirituality from places 
other than raving.  

i wasn't brought up christian, catholic...whatever.  in fact, in school, 
i wasn't exposed to any of that.  i remember my gramma was, she used to 
go to church and eat those funny looking bread things that i wanted to 
eat too, but my gramma didn't want to let me.  i just thought they looked 
yummy!  well if you saw how overweight i was when i was 5, you would 
understand that everything looked yummy.  

but anyway, back to spirituality.  those of you who may have read the 
'birds' post a while back...that is when i found spirituality.  but it 
wasn't just instant.  i actually read books by anton wilson and listend 
to some terence mckenna tapes which suggested an idea of god being the 
entire universe, and therefore since i am part of it, me being a part of 
god.  hence the phrase "god within".  maybe some of you know that old 
hardkiss song.  

obviously it should be true that we can find spirituality without 
raving.  but it's a definite way for a lot of people.  who is to say 
'god', whoever he may be (NO, IT'S A HE, NO IT'S A SHE!...oh, go 
away...yanno?)  one time as i was smokin a fatty with my now passed on 
David Sarlin...I said "do you think our race will evolve to where we 
don't need drugs to reach these dimensions?"  He said, "Yeah, yeah..."  
Man i loved that guy.  he was so generous.  

maybe we can just look at raves and drugs as a launch pad to take us to 
the next level.  level of what?  well, of spirituality of course.  a 
dimension where only the people that can conquer their own fears make it 
out whole.  and there is a tremedous reward for conquering one's own 
fears.  total peace of mind.  that's more than any amount of $$ could 
buy, any morsel of food could satisfy, and any drug or other stimulant could 
please you.  

love you guyz...mean it.  
>     
> > Youth subcultures have seemingly replaced organized religion for many
> > people I've met in the last eight years, and your first statement really
> > pointed evidence to me once again of this, even if in jest--as with
> > organized churches, people go to find fellowship with others who share
> > beliefs and ideas and moral opinions.  I wonder how many people on here
> > who are really involved still find their spirituality from somewhere
> > other than the rave scene.
> 
>  I've been a Methodist my entire life. And while I know that many people in
> the scene feel at least somewhat religious towards raving and it's
> lifestyle, it is far from being an organized one. I mean, if anything
> SFRaves shows us that even among us the subscribers, there is no clear
> sharing of similar beliefs, ideas, or moral opinions. Oh shure, there are a
> couple of things that are shared, like a belief in living with Peace Love
> Unity & Respect, or that blacklites are pretty cool, and Underground Dance
> Music rules, but that's far from being a complete religion. What do I mean
> by "complete religion"? Every major religion that I can think of has a
> belief about how/why the world came into being, how/why human beings showed
> up, specific do's and don'ts, ect.  There are exceptions, ofcource. I can't
> really say I know much about Scientology (except that they hate
> newsgroups), for example. Or remote religions like Balinese or Confushism.
> 
>  I'm not saying Raving (or an offshoot of) will never have religious
> beliefs. But religions take time to develop. Raving's only been around a
> little while, people! Give it time.
> 
> I do wish that Christianity would in some ways be more accepted into Raving
> culture. Often I see Buddhist or Hindu or some other "eastern" religion's
> art at a party. I guess this is because  because Christianity has in the
> past been the most visible religion for people in this country and eastern
> religions in general have a more open attitude about altered states, sex,
> ect.
> 
>  And while I'm at it I'm going to get one last Religiously Rave Related
> Rant (say that 5x fast) out: Whenever the topic of contemporary religion is
> mentioned in this group, Christians are usually getting knocked one way or
> the other. I pretty much keep my trap shut when this happens because that
> thread would go nowhere fast. But I do want to mention that not all
> Christians share the same beliefs. Examples: While Catholics do not openly
> accept homosexuals as part of their congregation, Methodists do and without
> a "Don't ask don't tell" policy. We OPENLY welcome all people. (Sound
> familiar?)  And in California, many Methodist Churches have offered their
> churches as sanctuary for people to buy and sell medical marijuana. The
> reason? "Jesus broke the law of the land to help people." And in some ways
> Christianity has been wrongly portraed by the media. (As if EVERY Church
> Father was a child molester) Sound familiar too?
> 
> Give Christianity a break, it's not all bad. You may even *gasp* like some
> of it.
> 
> -=Pengo=-

Hi all!  ]=)


 I recently recieved notice from UCSC to remove my sig file with it's 
refrence to Dionysus Dreams. This came about due to a complaint that 
someone called in.

 I'm sorry to say I strongly suspect that this complaint came from one of 
the three lists I'm sending this post to. Most likely a SFraves 
subscriber (but I have NO way of knowing anything for certain here).

 I am somewhat saddened by this realisation but not surprised. I do hope 
the individual who did this is reading this. I don't hate you, I'm just 
very saddened. I am exceptionally poor and working very hard to put myself 
through school. I was hoping to get my own buisness off the ground and 
my sig file was an attempt to do this.

 In any case I am now well known enough so that removing my sig file 
doesn't really matter. I doubt it did me much good anyway. People hire me 
because I am dedicated and produce kick ass results when I bring my 
little circus to town.

yours in peace,


Ran D.Dreams

for managing to throw a damn good party despite all the BS.  These
people had it together: nice space, free fruit, good music, one person
with their ear to a police scanner AT ALL TIMES, sane dealings with the
police when one did show up, and all in all this is the first big party
I know of that went off all night in SJ without a bust (I'm sure there
have been more but I never heard of them).

Sure, the whole volume thing was a bummer, but I actually enjoyed being
able to talk to other people without yelling for a change, so it wasn't
all bad.

So to all those who were stressing hard, losing backpacks, dealing with
The Man, and everything else in order to make it happen: thank you, and
congratulations.

// grigs
