but I know plenty of people who go to raves just to enjoy the music.  drugs
play a part, but not in everyones experince.  it is up to the person at the
rave how they want to experince the rave.  what things they want to do while
at the rave.  but first and foremost it's about the music.  it was about the
music forst, but then drugs made their way onto the scene.  yes, to most it
may seem like drugs are the key element at raves.  a little e, some nitrous.
 it's all part of the experince.  but it goes deeper than that, one must look
at the rave as a place to get a close to techno as you can.  drugs, for some
people, enhance this experince.  For some people there is nothing that makes
the music come alive like drugs.  But I know plenty of people that use drugs,
but go to raves, and stay sober (sometimes) their take on the rave is that it
kicked ass.  if the dj is good enough, and he/she is spinnin' a set that is
just GOOD.  then you don't particularly need to enhance the experince with
drugs.  though for some people it might help.
     you can't say somebody is wrong for going to a rave/party and takeing
drugs.  because even if drugs wheren't a major factor to the scene in the
begining, they have become a major factor.  What people must do is reliaze
that not everyone at a rave is doing drugs.  that many come to the rave
solely to listen to good techno.  to see their favorite dj spin.  raves
produce a bond wiht people.  friendship cards, adresses, email adresses, all
of those things bring people closer together, that is what a rave can do.  it
is about the vibe that is at the rave.  if the mindstate that you come i with
is that I just wan to get fucked up, then the vibe shrinks a little.  If
everyone does that then you've got a lot of people that are gone.  But if you
come in with the minstate of haveing a good time, groving to some really good
techno, maybe doing some drugs, then the vibe is intact.  and everyone,
wether thier doing drugs or not can enjoy the rave.
after all it's about music....about good fucking techno blasting  you away.  
peace
nathan

but younger party goers also--(if they know what their doing,) know what the

these raves you've gpot to expect to draw a somwhat 'street smart' youth, who
knows what the fuck e is, what speed is.  and probably have done it befor.
 everyone that i've talked to has told me to not try things for the first
time at raves.  and most youths today have been brought up in the know.  or
at least that is the way i feel about it.  maybe their not walking
encyclopedias on drugs, but they know what they are, and what they do.  this
of course cannot speak for everyone at a rave, the unusaula naive, or stupiod
that goto a rave, then try e, for the first time, might find it to be fun,
enjoyable, stimulating.  but they probably could have/would have done it on
the streeet had they not been at that rave.....

Subject: A dead horse
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Drugs, drugs drugs.

It seems that this list has gone to only discussing drugs this last week. 

We all know that some ravers take drugs. We also all know that some
senators, mayors, police officers, parents, and teachers do the same. There
is no 'scene' in which some of the participants do not use drugs. The
people in the rave scene approach this fact differently, making the
decision to inform those who do take drugs what possible side effects,
benifits, and experiences that the use of each drug may have or cause. The
openness in talking about such a taboo topic draws attention such as
Gay/Lesbian materials did not that long ago. 

The fact remains that there are those who are in the rave scene for the
drugs alone. Yet there are people in every scene that are not in it for the
all, such as those who go to church only because they know there are
virgins there.

I'm keeping this short because I've made my point, I'm just going to ask
one thing, could we please start a discussion on something other than a
dead horse?

-much love
-justin

"The Techno Cosmic Mass blends Western liturgical tradition with ecstatic
music and dance, urban shamanism, multimedia imagery, and Eastern and
indigenous spiritual elements to create a multi-cultural, intergenerational
and ecumenical form of worship.  Celebration of this Mass has uplifted and
inspired young and old of diverse faiths and traditions from coast to
coast."

anarch@scruznet.com

> >I do wish that Christianity would in some ways be more accepted into Raving
> >culture.
> 
> Well, it's not totally barren out there, as anyone who's been to St. John's
> Divine Rhythm Society can attest. 

I'd like to point out that St. John's Divine Rhythm Society
celebrations are transdenominational, open to people
of all faiths, or of no faith at all.  Although SJDRS events take
place in an Episcopalian church,  we are not in any way
affiliated with the church.  It is very important to SJDRS planners
that our event *not* promote Christianity or any other specific
spiritual path other than the ones that individual attendees choose
for themselves.

If there is any particular spiritual view fostered by SJDRS, it is
only the idea that "We are one in the Dance."

Lee

My mom will be 47 on Tuesday.

I was sure to educate my mom, prior to the party, about what she was
going to see.  Still, she left at about 11:45, so not many people were
high yet.  That's probably a good thing.

My mom's pretty open-minded.  She understands drugs a lot better than
some people.  She also knows that not everybody does drugs.  I explained
to her that the rave scene helped in my getting into drugs, but it also
taught me how to do without them.

I'm planning on taking my mother to more parties, so she'll have plenty
of opportunities to learn more about the scene.

----Libby

On Fri, 21 Feb 1997, Nancy Shaw wrote:

(snipped a bit off the top...)

> 
> Yes, drugs can be just recreational, or they can have a higher intent.  But
> why are we then judging one to be more valid than the other?  Doesn't that
> seemingly liberal, "enlightened" approach actually smack of anti-drug
> propaganda - i.e. forcing drugs to be evaluted on some arbitrary standard
> that alcohol does not have to live up to? 
> 
> Try your morning without coffee, a deep depression without that slice of 
> chocolate cake, and the party at your friend's house without a glass of 
> wine before slamming ravers for doing drugs at a PARTY.
> 
> A moderate druggie
> and proud of it,
> N
> 

--
You go!! :)  I **totally** agree, I am so sick and tired of some of the
caffeine freaks of the world trying to tell me *I* might be wrong for
using drugs!
I tend to believe that caffeine and alcohol are the opiates of the masses.
I've heard of VERY few trancendental experiences associated with the
average cup of coffee; people just drink it 'cause they're hooked on the
stuff.  And (imho) people are little more than blind sheep for not
admitting it to themselves, let alone each other.  Recreational
psychoactives, on the other hand, are often the doorways for the
shepherds.  It's true that not everyone who uses psychoactives uses them
for personal development, but the simple fact is that the *opportunity is
there* for personal realization and enhancement, whereas this potential is
almost completely lacking in caffeine and chocolate, and even alcohol
(although not quite to such a great extent, as alcohol *can* open people
up, IF used in the proper context).  
Anyways, just my $.02 again...  Thanx Nancy for the killer post!  :)
-=Joe=-

I have been meaning to respond to this thread for a while now, but just 
haven't gotten around to it.  Don't worry it will be short and sweet (and 
hopefully not flame bait!:)

The aspect of raves that struck me first was the freedom of it.  Freedom 
to do drugs, to not do drugs, to dance with utter abandon, to roll around 
on the floor, to make new friends, to sit by yourself, to enjoy 
the music, whatever.  The thing is - just about anything is accepted (at 
least to a degree).  IMHO, that is still the coolest thing about raving.  We 
are all free to experience it in our own way (as long as we don't hurt 
anyone).  I will be sorry when that changes.  I, personally, enjoy raves 
sober, my reasons for going tend to have to do more with the music than 
anything.  But, I don't want to tell others how to enjoy their rave 
experience.  I was free to experiment when I wanted to and I am glad; I 
wouldn't change any of it.  Granted, some people are not incredibly 
educated about the concept of moderation, some are a little young to 
be making educated decisions, some will never educate themselves; but 
aren't there always people like that - in every group or scene?  I agree 
we can do our best to educate each other, about the dangers of doing to 
much, not knowing what you are doing or who you are getting it from, 
knowing when to stop, etc...But, there will always be those that f*ck up 
and there is not much we can do about that.  That's just part of life. 
  
I really don't care a whole lot what society in general
thinks raves are (just like I don't care what it "thinks" about a lot of 
things :).   I know what raves are - to me - and that's whatever I make 
them.  

I love that many ravers are into higher pursuits, like healing the earth, 
nurturing community, peace, fighting hunger and homelessness, and the 
list goes on.  I wonder how much of that comes from opening their minds 
with psychoactives?  Hmmm.
I don't know if raving will change the world for the better, but if it does
it would be the icing on the cake.  Because in the meantime, we all just 
have a really good time (while we're not fighting about it:), don't we?  
(sorry about the babbling - I thought it was going to be short!)

Cheers***
Cami

> but I know plenty of people who go to raves just to enjoy the music.  drugs
> play a part, but not in everyones experince.  it is up to the person at the
> rave how they want to experince the rave.  what things they want to do while
> at the rave.  but first and foremost it's about the music.  it was about the
> music forst, but then drugs made their way onto the scene.  yes, to most it
> may seem like drugs are the key element at raves.  a little e, some nitrous.
>  it's all part of the experince.  but it goes deeper than that, one must look
> at the rave as a place to get a close to techno as you can.  drugs, for some
> people, enhance this experince.  For some people there is nothing that makes
> the music come alive like drugs.  But I know plenty of people that use drugs,
> but go to raves, and stay sober (sometimes) their take on the rave is that it
> kicked ass.  if the dj is good enough, and he/she is spinnin' a set that is
> just GOOD.  then you don't particularly need to enhance the experince with
> drugs.  though for some people it might help.
>      you can't say somebody is wrong for going to a rave/party and takeing
> drugs.  because even if drugs wheren't a major factor to the scene in the
> begining, they have become a major factor.  What people must do is reliaze
> that not everyone at a rave is doing drugs.  that many come to the rave
> solely to listen to good techno.  to see their favorite dj spin.  raves
> produce a bond wiht people.  friendship cards, adresses, email adresses, all
> of those things bring people closer together, that is what a rave can do.  it
> is about the vibe that is at the rave.  if the mindstate that you come i with
> is that I just wan to get fucked up, then the vibe shrinks a little.  If
> everyone does that then you've got a lot of people that are gone.  But if you
> come in with the minstate of haveing a good time, groving to some really good
> techno, maybe doing some drugs, then the vibe is intact.  and everyone,
> wether thier doing drugs or not can enjoy the rave.
> after all it's about music....about good fucking techno blasting  you away.  
> peace
> nathan

hi all:



__ new design ___

it's time to announce some more great news!  those of you who have visited
x-radio recently have noticed a dramatic change in the site layout and
design.  i think it's much stronger, much nicer, and considerably cleaner
than the old design, so please check it out again sometime soon if you
haven't seen it yet.

every sunday from now on we will feature a new music title, which we'll
place on the front of the site (goa gil, an awesome trancer, is this week's
feature... our first).  this will be a title that the entire x-radio crew
agrees is one of the best available.  we'll encode all the tracks, tell you
a little about it, and even put the cover art on the site so you can check
it out.  we'll try to pick carefully from all our favourite genres to keep
things balanced.  if you have any favorites, let us know!



__ new server ___

on wednesday we retired the old hardware and installed a new pentium pro 200
motherboard and processor.  it's fast!



__ new music ___

in addition, we have added a second distributor to the x-radio supplier
list, so our title list has more than doubled to about 560 different cd's
now.  i may be wrong, but i believe this is one of the largest selections of
techno titles on the web.  i've also got another two distributors in the
works, and once we bring their catalog's on-line, we'll have a complete
selection of the more mainstream titles, including Future Sound of London,
Chemical Brothers, Prodigy, and Astral Matrix. Of course, we will continue
to search for the best independent labels on the planet so you can get the
best selection around.



__ new year ___

and, as somebody pointed out to me the other day, february marks our
one-year anniversary!  we wanted to have a party, but nobody's had time to
plan one.  i guess i'll just have to spend more time at other parties to
make up...



__ new plans ___

and our plans for the near future...

 a secure server, 
 another thousand cd titles, 
 a few live events,
 some killer dj mixes,
 and a music-oriented music mailing list!




take care!

pauly and
the x-radio crew



____________________________________________________ x-radio ___
___ http://www.x-radio.com/ ____________________________________




_____________________________________________________ x-radio _____
_______ http://www.x-radio.com/ ___________________________________
______________________________________ the evolution of music _____

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Feb 23 06:11:10 1997

	id sma001580; Sun Feb 23 08:10:20 1997
Message-Id: <1.5.4.16.19970223061341.48ef4818@popd.ix.netcom.com>
X-Sender: shawna-@popd.ix.netcom.com

Subject: Madness!!
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello all!

Figured I'd write a bit of a review whilst I wait for my broccoli to cook
(yes, it is currently 5:30 am and I just got back!).

WOOHOO!  I had *such* a KICKASS time at this party!  It has been quite a
while since I've really gone out, as many of you know, and this was the
first party I've been to in several months.  Started out beautifully, when I
read the price tag, $5!  Now *that's* a great price!  Like gee, I coulda
bought a big mac & large fries instead. ;)  Anyway, nifty space, at the
Cyborganic office, I like the two story setup, groovin funky ambient stuff
upstairs, and pounding techno (a lot of detroit from what I heard)
downstairs.  I found the vibe to be very groovy both upstairs and down.  And
it was so wonderful after all this time not raving to see so many friendly
faces of so many friends I haven't seen in so long!  I was quite surprised
at the number of friends I saw there, kept hearing from other people "wow,
this is the old school crowd!  They've all come out of the woodworks!"  I'm
so completely happy to have been able to make it to a party where I could
see all the beautiful people I "grew up with" over the past year and a half.
It felt pretty old school to me (as I hear described on the list nowadays it
seems), every where I looked people were smiling, if you made eye contact
the smiles grew wider, Nancy had oranges of course! :) people were blowing
bubbles, people had glitter & pacifiers, and it was just so nice to see so
many familiar faces.  Had several amazing experiences here.  One was the
music.  It rocked!  I have not danced so hard (boy will I be sore tomorrow!
:) since last september at the Harmony 3 Year party (geez, five months!).  I
just looove that hard pounding techno.  And more specifically:  this is the
first party where *several times* a dj would play a song that I have at
home, completely *love*, but never expected to actually get to hear it at a
party!  And fuckin Minor Minor did it wild, he has now twice done that for
me on two separate occasions, played a song I love but *never* thought I'd
hear it at a party, in fact this time played my ultimate favorite song, the
one I least expected to hear at a party, Birds On E!  Ack! Me and Brad
thought we were gonna die when we heard that,  "oh my god!! it's birds on e!
Aaahh!"  Stub out the barely smoked cigarettes, mad dash out onto the dance
floor to grind our feet into the ground, hee hee! :):)  Frank boy, you made
my night.  And then I also got to hear a couple of faves I know from Joe
Rice's tape (altho he was not dj'ing at the time), also some big time
favorites.  Boy when that happened, I really thought I was gonna explode
along with everybody else, everybody's screamin & yellin at the top of their
lungs, such amazing dance floor energy.  You know the kind, where you make
occasional eye-contact with other dancers, and you both smile at each other
cuz you just *know*!  I danced so hard, I just couldn't keep it up any more
(gotta switch twixt downstairs & upstairs every now & then) so I headed
upstairs again to see what went on up there.  Get up there & everybody's
groovin big time to the ambient stuff that's going on, and then they throw
on "Sexual Healing" by Margin Gay!  That was so cool!  I've never heard that
song in that context before, very groovy, nice touch.  The positive energy
was just so high this evening, my cheek muscles were beginning to hurt from
smiling so much, honest!  

And another groovy experience was that I did this whole party sober, and had
a *fucking great* time, which really means a lot to me.  Of course I know
academically that I can have a good time with our without drugs, but those
amazing times when I have such a kickass incredibly intense time at a party
with no drugs just really drives that point home to me yet again.  And I
still did all the great e-things people do at parties, hang out with friends
in little love-puddles etc, and it felt just as great and natural doing it
all completely sober, which was wonderful!  It really means a lot to me,
because it really proves to me that I am into raving for (what I consider to
be) the right reasons: the music, the vibe, the wonderful random people you
run into again & again, beautiful friends, sharing experiences with people,
and generally being at peace with myself when I'm there.  This experience of
course is very important to me when I have them on something (insert
appropriate drug here), these drugs often facilitate these situations,
allowing people to have them when they would otherwise be too uptight or
caught up in their own little worlds, which I find beautiful that such a
thing can help people do that.  But to be able to do that without any of
that really makes me feel like I've grown, evolved, become more who I want
to be for real.  That was all me out there tonight, and it's all me now, and
it will be all me when I wake up in the morning (afternoon? ;) feeling
refreshed and ready for another day instead of spun out and grouchy. :)
Yippeee! 

What a beautiful weekend this has been.  Spent the first part of it with he
whom I love eating sushi, listening to live jazz, laughing & playing, eating
corn-pops on his balcony, and coloring mandalas in the sun, and the next
part of it with the above described experience.  Only to come home to find
the wind blowing beautifuly through the trees, the wind-chimes softly
tinkling, an expansive view of the City and Bridges glowing in the distance,
a full moon blazing above, and my comfy bed waiting for me.  I am at peace.

I love my life right now.

:)
Love
Shawna


We are all gods in the chrysalis.
            
                   
         Do not go gentle into that good night.
       Rave! Rave into the dawning of the light!

The music was weak and my patience was growing very thin with the freaking
tramps dancing up on the stage...   I think they have some issues to deal
with. Like their need for attention....  and the fact that 1/2 of the guy
there were gawking didn't help. I dunno, it just seemed really chessy,
over-populated and lame. 

I was dancing up on the stage. I was wearing a white t-shirt and a fishing
hat.... I think I'm going to stick with FeelGood Entertainment. Thing is,
I saw the same people working this gig as the FeelGood raves... Hmmmm???
Makes me wonder.

Carlos was a nice guy though.... a lot of smiles and positive energy. But
we need to lose the tramps who were dying for attention. Isn't it about
the music and the unity??? Lets put an end to the showboating by our
fellow rave attendees.

I'm off to bed.... see you guys at the next event... Stairway to
Headphones. I can't wait, this is going to be the shit.

Subject: As Pretty As They Wanna Be
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]

[ to sfraves list ]

 Recently, in someone's comments about the Planet New Year make-up party,
this was said:
"...and my patience was growing very thin with the freaking
tramps dancing up on the stage...   I think they have some issues to deal
with. Like their need for attention...."

 I didn't go to the make-up party, but I don't think that's important
for what I'm trying to say. I've read the same basic statement, in 
different terminology, in previous posts to SFRaves over the years.
I'll let others deal with the psycho-sociological aspects of the 
word "tramp" and get to the point. '

 Why not let someone at a rave be as pretty/sexy/slutty as they want to
be, AS LONG AS they're not physically forcing themselves upon others?
They want attention - so what? After a few hours of posing, they'll
probably get tired, and maybe another mode of thinking will kick in.

 ( Let's agree right now that physical and other intrusive/aggresive
   actions like rude words or hand gestures signing sexual intercourse
   are not what I'm talking about! Only visual displays that preserve
   the space between the displayer and the "audience" )

 If raves should be a space to feel free, why not as a space to be free
to be pretty, if only in your own mind? I'm applying my experience
from the science fiction fandom sub-culture ; people come to conventions
in all sorts of costumes, and gals who would never show more than
2" of flesh between collarbone and neckline in the "mundane" world
would be in costumes with severe decollete ( not to mention the 
brass-brassiere Amazons ). 

 To these fan gals, the convention was a "safe" place of fellow
fans and people they knew like a second family, maybe better than
their own family. I get the same feeling from raves. 

 If it's felt that "displayers" are distracting, well, that something
each person has to handle. If it's felt that the exhibitionists are
giving raves a "bad image" to first-timers , that will be corrected
by experience. And if they're the type to say "Oh, those raves are
horrible because they have those freaking tramps dancing up on
the stage!", well, maybe they're a bit too uptight for raving!

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

Hi everyone, here's my review for CoolWorld's PNY. Overall, I give this
party
1/2 star point. It was definitely a party I would have rather missed...

I got to the HomeBase location at around 11:00pm after being in line for 2
hours,
I finally get to go in at 1am. Payed my $6, gave my can O' food, and went
in to 
partee :) I have seriously NEVER seen that many HomeyG's in one place
before.
It was scary :( Anyhow,

My friends and I decide to go in and check out the place (you know, check
out the rooms and stuff) so we go into the jungle room and see everyone
standing there.
It was odd. No one dancing.. I left, and went outside to meet all my other
frends...

Lara, Rhona, Ace, Fernando, Ryan, Eric, Startiana, Natasha, etc etc etc etc
etc...
(I didn't forget you April! ;o)) They all seemed to be having fun (I wonder
why? ;O))
but not as much as they could have :( the vibe was amazingly evil, and it
was
extremely cold and dark outside. But we kept our vibe pretty friendly, so
people
came up to us and stuff.

At around 3am or so, we decide that is time to bring GoodVibes to the
party,
so we begin to be happy and share with everyone :) for example,

Eric and Rhona gave their Teddy Bear to this girl that was having a good
time
after Ryan gave her a bracelet after all her stuff had been stolen and
stuff.
She was EXTRA happy, I gave her a hug and we all just started to make her
trip the most wonderful! :) 

There was this couple sitting down in the ground freezing their ass off, so
I 
let them use my coat and my elephant so they could warm up (while I was
cold myself, but they seemed to be needeing it more :o)) that made me
happy,
and it made them happy :o)

Giving out blow-pops to people and candy, and hugs and kisses. Dancing, and
being happy despite of the evil vibes surrounding our group :(.

Then around 5, I start getting REAALLLLLYYYYY tired. So I get my friends
and
decide that is time to go home....

It was definitely a party worth missing though...I was afraid of dancing,
or going inside. There was someone who went into cardiac arrest [?] and
someone got stabbed in the back, and there were a couple of fights...

Overall this party gets 1/2 star point. :o)
Plur to alls
Pab

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Feb 23 14:49:07 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id OAA13177; Sun, 23 Feb 1997 14:49:07 -0800 (PST)
Received: from atari.saturn5.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with ESMTP id OAA13022; Sun, 23 Feb 1997 14:48:55 -0800 (PST)

          by atari.saturn5.com (8.8.4/8.8.4) with SMTP

Date: Sun, 23 Feb 1997 14:52:08 -0800 (PST)
From: David Lowe <dlowe@saturn5.com>
X-Sender: dlowe@atari
To: SF-Raver Family <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Madness review
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.970223142435.18351A-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey people :)

It's been a really long time since I've reviewed anything, but last
night's Madness really gave me the urge to dust off the old keyboard and
type a few words.

I had a similar experience to Shawna's, when it comes to the crowd, & the
vibe.  A lot of the people I met raving when I first moved to San
Francisco were there - including some real surprises like John Draper,
Leslie (still on the list?), and a bunch of the Harmony crewmembers.  Many
of the people who were active on the list when I got here, and have now
faded into lurking (much like myself) were there, and it was very good to
see them.

But, as usual, I did a lot more dancing than socializing...  The music was
really fantastic.  The basement was where the action was, for me, despite
the heat and a couple of problems with the sound system (as usual, the
Gateway crew was very quick to respond, good stuff :)  Minor Minor spun a
fantastic set, hard and minimal, had everyone moving & smiling.  I think
that the real star of the night, though, was T-1000 from Detroit.  I'm
really glad that he'll be at Mad on monday, because the heat down there
prevented me from really thoroughly enjoying dancing to his set, despite
*incredible* music.

What also really blew me away was the lighting.  I have been disappointed
by the last few parties I've gone to, in this respect.  But the lighting
at Madness was exactly what I like - visual chaos, lots of lights, and no
central focus thereof - there were a few strobes, some flashing spinning
things, some pin spots, a disco ball, some christmas lights.  There was
enough light everywhere that I didn't smash into people, but not so much
that I was blinded - and everywhere I looked, my eyes were stimulated and
entertained.  I don't think I've seen visual mayhem pulled off so well
since the Beautiful People parties prior to the Harmony 3yr.

It's good to know that I am still capable of enjoying raving.  I have had
not-so-great-sometimes-bordering-on-bad times at the last bunch of parties
I've been to, and I must admit to having feared that I had outgrown
raving.  Not so, and am I ever glad to know it :)

Feeling more like a raver than I have in a long time, I say bye bye and
see you next time (Mad w/T-1000!)

I'm sitting here kicking the shit out of myself (I'm double jointed in the 
knees) because I went to PNY last night instead of Madness. You see, for the 
past several months, I've been trying to "convert" several of my friends into 
ravers, which has been VERY difficult, to say the lease.  Anyway, last night I 
got 8 count 'em 8 of them to go with me to PNY.  I normally avoid massive, but 
I figured it was possibly a good idea, based on everyone's great experience 
with the Love Affair party. 

So we get there, around 11, wait for an hour in the line, then get in and split 
up into groups.  Went into the Jungle room, where (as posted) very few ppl were 
dancing. I did like the laser, but the music was to put it nicely, 
"uninspiring".  So we went into the other (techno) room, which was packed, and 
it seemed EVERYONE needed to be somewhere else-- they were just walking around. 
It was impossible to dance, as no matter where we were, there were constant 
people walking through and bumping into us. 

My group was standing there, very bored, and giving me annoyed looks that I 
dragged them to this. Six of them left at two, and I stayed with one until 
four, and just tried to dance away the evil energy, but it was impossible due 
to the aforementioned walkers. I think there must have been shuttle buses 
running from Bay Area correctional high schools to and from the party. 

All the while, it sounds like this kick-ass Madness party was going on...  
aren't there ANY SFravers who work for the Psychic Friends Network, who can 
predict this shit for me? Damn damn damn, it will be months before I'll be able 
to get them to come again. It's time to recruit from the inside, rather than 
proseletyzing to existing cliques. Who wants to be my raver buddy?  :)  You 
people have fun today, ya hear? 

Damned, 
Nathan

I must of stood out like a sore thumb, dancing near the right speaker then?

Fefferisullum.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Feb 23 18:20:15 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id SAA01434; Sun, 23 Feb 1997 18:20:15 -0800 (PST)
Received: from user.host.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with ESMTP id SAA01430; Sun, 23 Feb 1997 18:20:11 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [206.173.211.45] (cnc122045.concentric.net [206.173.211.45]) by user.host.net (8.7.5/8.7.3) with SMTP id VAA18910 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sun, 23 Feb 1997 21:20:01 -0500
Date: Sun, 23 Feb 1997 21:20:01 -0500
Message-Id: <199702240220.VAA18910@user.host.net>
X-Sender: crunch@207.182.222.10
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: crunch@host.net (John Draper)
Subject: Yet another Madness review...
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Thanx so very much goes out to one of F-8's customers who ran over to
Ameba to pick up a tix to Madness for me.    As usuall,   my bus connections
were totally phucked.    Just as I get to the bus stop,   I see the bus pull
away (Arghhh!  - yet another hour wait,  clearly I'll miss getting a ticket
now),  but I call ahead and some kind generous person was willing to go
to Ameba to pick up a tix,  and I make it to F-8 just at 8 pm when Mystr-E
was about to close.

I hung out on the haight,  waiting for the info to update,  hoping
upon hope that the location would be reachable via public transpo,   so
I sip some "programming fluid" waiting for the update.

I call shortly after 10 pm,  and learn "Oh Joy!!"  a SOMA location,  so
I head to SOMA,   with full intention of dancing my Waa Waa off BIG TIME,
and that,  my friends was just exactly what I did.

Not many people recognized me or came up to say Hi,   but that's OK,   as
my first rave in SF as "JohnnyD" and not "crunchman",   it was just purrrfict

I arrive to be greeted with a really mellow chill zone,  and proceeded to
look around this new venue (for me),  but I later learned it was used a number
of times before.

I eventually wind up in the basement as Alex was on the turntables developing
his set,   and looked around and saw Brian....    Hi Brian...

There were a few people (non-netters) who didn't know that Crunchman was
dead and I set them straight...

I headed back up to the chill zone for my pre-dance stretching exercises
I hold as being so important,   and make it down to start a long night of
dancing.

I met some dudz on the bus that were surprised that I was going to madness.
Obviously someone who doesn't know me,    but he seemed surprised I was going
to the rave.....

Anyway,   Alex didn't let me down,  as usual was a good bit of great techno
choons,   churning out those speakers.....    I wasted no time getting into
the groove....

Already,  it was getting hot in there,   but I didn't care,  and started
shedding my outer clothes,   and after that,  didn't care how hot it was,
but eventually had to talk to Monte and ask that he set up another fan,
which he did....  Thanx Monty....

Minor-Minor ripped it up BIG time,   going extra hard and building up the
energy level in preparation for T-1000 from Detroit...

Holy shit...  That dude was SICK....   he had me bouncing all over the place,
between the walls and ceiling,   but by that time,   the water was dripping
all over the turn tables,   and T-1000 eventually had to move them slightly
to keep them dry....    Afterwards,   there were a few glitches,   but
he recovered brilliantly,  and kept up the energy.

I don't recall who went on after that,    but while waiting for him to develop
his set,   I chilled and met and talked to Marco and a few old friends from
the list.

All in all,  the party was PHAT and a total bargain for just $5 and restored
my faith in the amazing SF Rave scene....   Totally nothing like it anywhere
else....

I'm honored to have been able to spend yet another time with you fine folks
before I fly down to PB on Tuesday...    I'll be BACK!!!

Oh yea,   while waiting for my favorite breakfast place to open up,   I decided
to check out the Endup....   We all end up at the Endup....    :-)    I didn't
stay long,  but got in another hour's dancing...   :-)

Thanx folks....

JohnnyD

Well, Shawna and David said *everything* I wanted to say (damn you
guys! ;), but I wanted to give a big, resounding "me too!" since I
haven't posted a review in so long. That was honestly the best party
I've been to in so long. 

It seemed like I knew everyone there... The whole old school crowd was
there: many people from the old Beautiful People parties, lots of
SFRavers (including long lost Shawna!), and just people that I haven't
raved with in so long. I was also so happy to see a good amount of my
favorite Cyborganic friends there... I was especially pleased to see
Forrest dancing his ass off with a sick grin during T-1000's set. >:)

Unfortunately (maybe it's been the winter), I've been getting old and
tired... So I only lasted until about 4am before I had to call it a
night. But I'll be back once the weather gets warmer and my life gets
less stressful...

Anyway, I felt like I was not so much at a "rave"(tm), but at a really
cool, under control party with a whole bunch of friends listening to
great music, at a place I'm at more often than my own apartment (I'm
at 654 way too much these days).

Mad crew, as always you guys kick ass, and I will see you tommorrow to
get my ass kicked (again) by T-1000!

I was the one with big pants and glow sticks. Did you see me??
huh, huh?

:)

Steve

SO now I'm *really* kicking myself for not coming down for Madness. 
Beautiful weather in Portland this weekend but it's been crummy otherwise.
Friday night I took my amp and monitors out to a bar in Vancouver, Wash.
where my friend Jeremy was playing.  Even though he was playing a good
set, the promoter kicked him off the decks after 45 minutes "because the
kids aren't dancing" (well, the kids weren't dancing much previously when
the DJ was playing shite "progressive" house and trance).  Then, last
night, back at my office where I was doing a practice set, the guy who
is illegally living down the hall from my office (because he is a waiter
in the restaurant downstairs which owns the building) shut me down by
plugging in his heater at 1:30 am which tripped the circuit breaker --
not that this hasnt happened before, the last time Thursday afternoon.

So yes, I'm whining -- I heard that AO wouldn't be playing at Madness and
I can't make it down for Mad Monday night, so, phooey!

Glad everyone had a great time, though.  


sigh

phred

Received: from [128.32.94.132] (w-301-1.IIR.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.94.132]) by econ.Berkeley.EDU (8.6.10/8.6.10) with SMTP id TAA02932; Sun, 23 Feb 1997 19:16:01 -0800

Precedence: bulk


>
> I've been a Methodist my entire life. And while I know that many people in
>the scene feel at least somewhat religious towards raving and it's
>lifestyle, it is far from being an organized one. I mean, if anything
>SFRaves shows us that even among us the subscribers, there is no clear
>sharing of similar beliefs, ideas, or moral opinions. Oh shure, there are a
>couple of things that are shared, like a belief in living with Peace Love
>Unity & Respect, or that blacklites are pretty cool, and Underground Dance
>Music rules, but that's far from being a complete religion. What do I mean
>by "complete religion"? Every major religion that I can think of has a
>belief about how/why the world came into being, how/why human beings showed
>up, specific do's and don'ts, ect.  There are exceptions, ofcource. I can't
>really say I know much about Scientology (except that they hate
>newsgroups), for example. Or remote religions like Balinese or Confushism.

>I do wish that Christianity would in some ways be more accepted into Raving
>culture. Often I see Buddhist or Hindu or some other "eastern" religion's
>art at a party. I guess this is because  because Christianity has in the
>past been the most visible religion for people in this country and eastern
>religions in general have a more open attitude about altered states, sex,
>ect.
>
>-=Pengo=-

        I think that part of the reason Christianity is not incorporated
into raves is that as an organized religion it has a history of repression
and exclusion.  Repression of many of the more villiage centered tribal
religions (by wiping them out or replacing pagan ceremonies with Christian
ones), witch burning (which is about repression of womens knowledge).
Exclusion: there is a tendency for christianity to mark a line believe in
christ and those who don't.  a line whihc historically has been used to say
basically who is thought of as human and who are not. IN addition, much of
christianity is based on having the priest as the intermediary between the
lay person and God. I know that for many of the protestant religions this
does not stricly hold, but there still seems to be something of that
attitude among many of the people.
        The eastern religions (mysticism, really- and this may really be
the key point) are a bit more about self-discovery.  In addition, they tend
to be a bit more about the "here and now" rather than focusing on the
afterlife.  Thus eastern mysticism is genrrally a process of enlightenment
and it deals with many thinhgs which are not generally discussed in our
culture.  Mainly, I am thinking of the conception of our bodies and souls
as energy. They also highlight the "oneness" and connectedness of us all,
which makes sense when thinking about dancing and the group collective
energy that flows at the rave and beyound.
        Raves are these little mini-tribal experiences and they have that
mixture of life and mysticism rolled up in the event.  So the eastern
religions (and tribal religions) with the emphasis on sprituality as an
aspect of living day to day life speak a bit more directly to what a rave
is all about.  Whereas with Christianity, where much of the spiritual
experience  is reserved for the afterlife, it misses speaking to some of
the magic of the rave.  (O.K. this previous pasage is quite vague and
sloppy- so sorry if you don't know what I am talking about).  Finally one
last point reguarding *magic*: Christianity has tended to view much of this
as being somewhat siinster and from the devil, thus a bit suspect.  While,
the eastern (and tribal) religions/mysticisms tend to connect it to our
very life force.  Talking about Chakras, transcendentalism, Chi and the
like.  More of a natural mystery to be explored - the way we are- instead
of good or bad.  You know?
        I really believe that Christ was a pretty amazing
person/diety/budda.  What he supposedly had to say is very powerful and
really fits right in with the eastern religions/mysticism.  Especially his
message of love-- intense stuff when you really think about it.  Fits in
with PLUR as well.  But people read Christs words with many different
interpretations-- look to the  relatively new school of revisionist
theology, who ask WHAT did Christ REALLY say to the stereotyped Southern
Baptist who tend to follow a more literal take on the Bible.  But the
organized religion of Christianity has a pretty poor track record over
history of truly promoting this message of universal love.  So many of the
symbols of the church are apt to be very loaded symbols.

Peace, Understanding, and
Love,
Dennis

Dennis Toseland
Nothing........Like a glowing...........ember.....in a.........
.........Plastic can........full of papers........

overt acknowledgement of the spiritual elements of the experience.

	  by emout02.mail.aol.com (8.7.6/8.7.3/AOL-2.0.0)
	  id WAA11156 for sfraves@hyperreal.com;
	  Sun, 23 Feb 1997 22:56:58 -0500 (EST)
Date: Sun, 23 Feb 1997 22:56:58 -0500 (EST)
Message-ID: <970223225658_379226126@emout02.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: PNY review
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

WOW
that was my first massive experience.
I haven't read any of the other reviews, because i didn't want their feeling
to influence mine.
It was definitely different.
I felt a negative vibe the whole night, except for when I was outside with
all of my friends.  and i met so many of you!!!!! Hello to all.  I can't
remember your names without the faces, but you are all in my heart (well, i
do remember most of your names, but i don't want to leave anyone out.)
I was so happy when i saw lara because I drove up by myself, hoping to see
her there.  I wandered around Home Base for about an hour before I found her
though.  She took me outside to where everyone was hanging out. I had the
best time outside talking to all of you people... that is one reason I love
being sober... I remember who you are better... I remeber your names... and
your faces too :).
Inside, the vibe was so bad... People were so rude, they would run into you
at full force and not even turn to say sorry.  The worst part of the night,
though, was wwhen I was walking into the deep house room.  I was pushed out
to the side and I saw like 5 thug looking guys kicking something or someone
on the ground.  Noone did anything (fear is not always trivial I learned that
night) to help. the bad guys just dispersed into the crowd and got off free
of charge.  OUCH!!! That hurt.  I've been taught that the rave culture was
about love and friendship... PLUR...  But noone could help him because one
person is helpless, We need to join together stave this off.  
Therre were also so few 'ravers' there (I call ravers those who go to parties
to dance, make friends, meet friends, join together in a state of Peace Love
Unity and Respect.  Those that go to parties to keep the vibe up and promote
good karma... help out others in times of need... smiles!!!!!!:}) I'm used to
all 'ravers' all the time.  Where you can stop anyone and say, "why hello
there, how are you today?" and everyone is nice to you, for the most part.
 I'm spoiled. 
On a happier note, though... the drum and bass room was so phat!!!!!  best
vibes inside any of the rooms.  My favorite part of it was standing by the
speakers and feeling the little hairs sticking up from between my braids
vibrate.  HEE HEE HEE.  It was pretty cool.  
To all of you that I met... It was wonderful meeting  you!!!!! I hope to see
you at a party sometime in the near future.  To all of my old friends,  I
love you guys too!!!!!
A quick question... Why were their girls booty shakin'... why were there
girls gyrating on top of speakers getting egged on by calls of "hoochie mama"
(no seriusly, it happened!!) I mean, sure this girl had a kick ass body, but
respect yourself, please.
Maybe that's just a massive.  A lot of my friends said that not all massives
are this phony and negative, that i should try it again.  I don't know,
maybe, but if another one is as bad as this, you can bet i'm staying
underground for the rest of my life!!!!!
Much love
April :)

I was in a really good mood, and ended up running into a few old friends.
 The atmosphere in general was kinda.... weird.  But that's ok, I wasn't
really paying that much attention to it... Too much fun dancin and sittin
against the speakers. hee hee!

It sucked that they closed off the chill room hella early.  That and the fact
that the house lights kept getting turned on every so often.  And the
security guards with megaphones... And that ending hallway to nowhere... Oh,
and the fights... THAT was.... interesting (first rave something that big has
ever happened at for me).  Oh and that icky icky line/crowded raver
pasture... That sucked! Good thing that I'm not claustrophobic! My friend Val
said that there was a naked person there too... ??? ok.... To each his or her
own, I guess.

But hey, it was only $6, and I got to take my little brother to his first
rave. Through all the "little" annoyances, and that TERRIBLE weather, I still
somehow managed to have a really good time.  Looking forward to seeing
everyone at STAIRWAY TO HEADPHONES!!!

Rave on! 
Just another little raver girlie....

Subject: Kama Loca Review

IMHO

Well, there it is 11:30 and I'm at Kama Loca realizing I have no idea where
Maddness is but I digress. There were only about sixty people there and I
think I'm being kind of generous with that number. The bar area had Felix
spinning who was great. I never heard him before, but his sound just kicked.
The main room had Gavin who was better at Spundae. Sadly, I left about 1:30
since during the time very few people arrived and even fewer were dancing. It
just felt weird. 

So what do I do? I go to PNY since I just needed to dance. I thank the team
for putting on the party making up for the diaster. That is a touch of class.
Luckily, I just went there to dance since I knew I wouldn't know were to find
this community. The music was good in the main room, but it seemed that
everyone was going somewhere and few were just stopping to dance. Not happy
campers. So I just end up smiling and saying hello to people hoping to spread
some joy. There was one angel of the evening I would like to thank. She was
handing out ice and that was a cool relief from the heat. The rest is
articulated by others on this list.

peace and joy,
Carl

Message-ID: <Pine.BSD/.3.91.970224020724.5270C-100000@fish.hooked.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

that guy was the best...

we used to pile in his pad after every Basics/Gathering...yanno, there 
was once a time when massives were cool and had good energy, yanno.  
Yanno?  

Dave Sarlin had a neato house in Berkeley...we trippers would climb up 
the backyard, over the fence, and walahh! ( i know that's not the right 
spelling, who cares?  shoot me. )  

then we were in another world.  the rose garden at tilden regional park.  

he used to let us crash there all day, sometimes we'd all meet there 
before the full moon.  

he was funny to talk to.  used to kind of mumble his sentences and finish 
with a mumble and a laugh.  funny cause he had this unique way of 
projecting his intent so we never needed to know what he was saying, but 
it was still kinda oddly funny.  

ill never forget the time i went to the thai bbq with him.  at this 
buddist temple.  perfect type of food for after a rave.  

although there are lots of cool people in the SFR community...Dave Sarlin 
was one of the most giving intellectual people I ever knew.  For those of 
you that don't know who the hell this guy is, he died last year.  He will be 
surely missed.  But it's cool, though, every once in a while I call for 
his spirit, and he shows up.  I can't see him, but I can definitely feel 
him.  actually its more like seefeel.  oh. he's here right now.  gotta 
go!  ;]  

love deep  [or is it deep love?] 

?;''[-=?

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Feb 24 09:48:57 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id JAA16948; Mon, 24 Feb 1997 09:48:57 -0800 (PST)
Received: from minniemouse by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with SMTP id JAA16941; Mon, 24 Feb 1997 09:48:53 -0800 (PST)
Received: from Dtotah.cemax.com by minniemouse (5.0/SMI-SVR4)
	id AA12045; Mon, 24 Feb 1997 09:47:26 -0800
Message-Id: <9702241747.AA12045@minniemouse>
From: "Dennis Totah" <dtotah@minniemouse.cemax.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Mass in SLO - Reviews
Date: Mon, 24 Feb 1997 09:42:00 -0800
X-Msmail-Priority: Normal
X-Priority: 3
X-Mailer: Microsoft Internet Mail 4.70.1155
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I just came back from Mass, which was thrown in San Luis Obisbo.

I had one of the bombest weekends I've had in a long while.

I suggest that everyone try to get down to a party in SLO, Santa Barbara,
or in one of the smaller towns on the coast sometime soon. The party had
300+ people in two rooms. Everything at the party reminded me of the
parties I used to go to before the big bucks started being pored into the
scene, when the vibe was the thing that drew you to the party.

The beats were just right. Getting away from all of the big name DJs in SF
and hearing some new sounds made me feel like it was my first rave all over
again. I never realized how bored I was getting with regards to the sounds
in SF where many DJs really sound the same. (needless to say, I was *not*
extremely disappointed to miss Cool World). I went down there with DJs MODA
and Jazz-E who were obviously feeling the killer vibes too, who both played
excellent sets. Mike (I don't remember his DJ name) also dropped some
jungle which had me going. Needless to say, I haven't danced that hard for
years.

Sunday afternoon, Mass threw a beach party. The turnout wasn't huge, but
the smiles and energy were there. The friendliness that used to be an
integral part of the SF scene was very much alive and well in SLO.

Props to Austin, Mike, and the whole Mass crew.

I recommend that everyone try to get down there sometime soon. 

-dnns

to everyone that came out and supported the MADNESS event. Special thanks
must go out to The CLOUD FACTORY crew for the assist on lights, etc., GATEWAY

Hour, Alan Oldham aka DJ T-1000, for coming down and playing for an hour or
so.  For those that were there, you felt it. for those that missed it, you
can catch him tonight for the last time at MAD.  Thanks again!!
3 STRIKES

Qbert is a three-time world-champion freestyle DJ - a member of the Rock
Steady Crew and Zulu Nation.  On March 15 the Southern Exposure Gallery at
SFSU is presenting "DJ Qbert's Turntable Trickery Workshop" as part of this
gallery's vital Artists in Education program (set up to counter the lack of
art education for youth in public schools).  I'm not sure of price (free, I
think, but they need DONATIONS) or time.  Call the gallery for more info.
 Here's their address:

http://thecity.sfsu.edu/~soex/current.html

On Sat, 22 Feb 1997, Candy Raver Kermit (Matt) wrote:
> 
> Oh yea, Just one more thing I forgot to add, It takes a hell of allot of
> guts to admit that you went to a cool world event!!!!
> 
> 							Kermit

God, no kidding.  I've never liked cruel world, and I never thought I 
would see the day that I would go.  But I hang my head in embarassment as 
I confess: I went. I found out about Madness too late, as I promised my 
new boyfriend that I would go with him to cw. He hasn't been in the scene 
very long and doesn't know about the GOOD parties yet.  I am looking 
forward to showing him! ;) I went with him and he paid my way.  I ain't 
even gonna pay *$6* for a cw event.

It was as bad as the previous posts have indicated.  I wasn't saying 
anything, but I was giving my SO that look of "I told you so". The music 
was uninspiring, to say the least, as mentioned there were more people 
walking around than dancing, someone sprayed PEPPER spray into the air in 
the main room and I kept coughing, it was just WAAAAY too crowded - it 
took forever to get anywhere.  Mark was my only breath of fresh air: he 
brought a backpack FULL of different friut and candy to give away. What a 
sweetheart! ;)  

By 2:30 I could not take it anymore.  I had witnessed the 3rd fight of 
the evening and the entire atmosphere was just plain evil. I said to 
Mark, "I'm leaving and I am leaving NOW."  He did not object.  His words 
were: "That was not a rave or a party.  That was a social catastrophe!"  
Very well put.  He's going to let me pick the parties for awhile now. :):)   

I hope I have not lost any respect from my friends on this list for going 
to that....that.... that monstrosity.  My heart was at Madness. Really-it 
was!

love,
Amy

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: PNY Review (short)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey everyone,
	Firstly, "Club" Cool World was not a rave, it was a big club. The Thug
factor was one as I have never seen. I almost got punched by accident on
my way to the water counter. There was "tagging everywhere". I just felt
really uncomfortable (unlike the Love Affair massive).As for the girls
dancing on top of the speakers, I kinda licked...woops...I mean liked
it, but I felt one lady was being a bit provacative (sp?) when she
lifted her dress to show her undies and doing the freaky-freaky
dance. Then Guys started yelling "Take it off". I was just waiting for
someone to get violated because of this. 
	Secondly, The people I met from Sfraves, and their friends made
up for all the negativity. Lara,you are the bomb: thanks for making me
feel so accepted. Orson,you are the bomb: thanks for the laminates,they
are very cool. Anthony E, you are the bomb: how did you like the tape?
Pablo: even though I didn't get to really speak with you, you're still
the bomb. April, you are the bomb: welcome to the list and I still
love your Dalmation (sp?) Ace, you are the bomb: Thanks for whatching
out for everyone. Eric, Fernando, Christina, Arron, Maggie and anyone
else I may have missed: You all are the bomb!! 
	Lastly, I think I will be attending Omnisonic on Friday and
Stairway to Headphones on Sat. If any of you are going let me know so we
may meet. I should have more mixtapes and other stuff to give out.
				Peace
				Vertigo

Hey Dan,

Friday nights at DV8 in San Francisco is a hip hop/rap club...it's name 
escapes me, but I know a few people who go there regularly and seem to like 
it.  It is moving however, soon I think - but I don't know where.  Also, 
maybe Saturday nights at the Soundfactory I think...not sure.  There are 
rave type events that are dedicated to the rap/hip hop sound, but I honestly 
don't know where you could get hold of that type of information other than 
keep asking around...

Yeah I know about those places. Thanks for the info anyway. 

I would go to those places more often but the lines are soooo long. Also all 
the women think you are trying to pick up on them, the places are populated by 
thugs with bad attitudes and the cover charges are ridiculous.

I was really hoping to find a cool club or rave with a friendly and fun loving 
attitude with some killer dj's spinning the beat.  I may have to throw my own 
party(hmmm.)

-dan

Smiles,

Scott =)

Alll Right!!! Big Hugs and Thank Yous to everyone who came out to my very
first house party. It was great!! A few Christmas lights and Dave Q's disco
ball really made the living room. Along with Adam M. who supplied the
turntables and was my "Obi-Won" for Zen and the art of house parties. Big
thanks also to Deepfog, Andy W., and everyone else who spun! The dining
room was set-up as a great little chill area and it was such a great night
outside on the back deck!! And I had no idea that my house would close-in
the music so well. 

This was such a "no problems" party that I think it's definitely the
beginning of a trend... ;-)

-=Pengo=-

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Fri, 21 Feb 1997 11:41:16 +0000
From: Paul Grogan <rampant@earthlink.net>
To: name removed...
Subject: Re: poor recording

I'm sorry you don't like Brownie's Breakdown mix. For us to go thru the 
whole manufacturing process again and re-master this mix would cost 
about $2000. As yours is the only complaint we have received out of the 
1500 pressed and sold, it doesn't seem likely that we will be doing 
this. 
However, one technique used by some DJ's is to adjust the level of the 
bass frequencies on the mixer's eq.If this does't help why don't you try 
playing the other THREE mixes that you like so much and stop fucking 
moaning! 3 out of 4 isn't bad and is better than most record companies 
provide.

Your letter will be added to "Rampant's Cheekiest Letters Collection" 
and so far it ranks #1.

Paul Grogan

Received: from arau.ar.br.np.els-gms.att.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with SMTP id OAA26719; Mon, 24 Feb 1997 14:51:00 -0800 (PST)
Date: Mon, 24 Feb 1997 14:48:00 +0000
From: SFO2!SFO2PO!sgalloway@msatt.attmail.com (Galloway, Scott)
Received: from msatt by attmail; Mon Feb 24 22:49 GMT 1997
Subject: Re:Pretty as they wanna...
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (SFraves)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: Text/Plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Message-ID: <MS-MAILG-3.0-Note-msatt-sgalloway-0856824465>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I've been reading people's comments about the PNY party this weekend, the 
comments about the "booty girls" in particular, and quite frankly I'm 
disturbed...

Here's the thing - There is something that separates raving and ravers from 
the social masses.  What we all share is the ultimate freedom to be yourself 
no matter what that may be.  Our house is 100% culturally diverse.   Few 
other groupings of people can make such a claim, but here in our little rave 
world, we can say that, and mean it.  What this means is, that we will 
accept anyone for whatever their ideals as part of the greater whole.

Sometimes these people are just like us, glitter and lollipops, great big 
smiles and blinky lights, these people are the easiest of course to accept 
and make a connection with, and become our instant best friends.  Sometimes 
though, "just like us" means something entirely different, because "just 
like us" is taken from a different perspective than one you observe.  This 
does not make this other perspective wrong, it merely makes it different. 
 Variety is the spice of life, it opens our minds to new and wonderful 
possibilities.  Without people and experiences different than the ones we 
each currently know of, how will be able to learn or grow?  

It's possible that these people dancing on the stage, wiggling their behinds 
at everyone, look a bit too different for some to accept.  But they, with 
all of their preconceptions, seemed to be having a great time accepting all 
of us, so much in fact that they were able to dance however they wished. 
 Why can't we then in turn appreciate what these girls have to offer the 
world spiritually?

We all have prejudices, we all use stereotypes to fall back upon to protect 
us from the things we don't know about, and this is alright.  It's perfectly 
human to want to protect your ideals and way of life, but there is a fine 
balance between protecting what you believe, and insulting or hurting others 
to acheive that protection.

Here's a thought...what if one of those girls is on sfraves?  How do you 
think that she might feel being publicly called a sleezy, slutty tramp by 
the same people that she was so comfortable with and trusted only a couple 
days ago?

Granted, they might not quite "fit in" to our rave culture through looks or 
actions, but since we are so open minded, we will accept them no matter who 
they are...right?  It may be difficult at first, but I believe that we could 
be a whole lot more constructive in their learning about what raving means 
to them, than name calling and singling them out as a negative aspect to a 
positive thinking culture.

IMHO,

Scott =)

Here's my perspective on this whole thing:

Coming from a different musical and cultural background from most of y'all,
I can definitely see that there is such a thing as "rave culture".  While
it is a very kind and gentle culture, with smiles and lollipops and glowy
things, it is a culture nonetheless.  People in the scene make the mistake
of confusing gentility with acceptance, though.  Just like any other
'scene', there are those whose attitude meshes with the scene and those
whose doesn't.

It is only natural for people to defend a scene from what they feel is the
encroachment of others.  Who wouldn't?  When I was younger, and people
started listening to ska and dancehall and all of the stuff that I thought
was the private domain of me and my friends, I was scared as hell!!  I
thought that goonish jocks and teeny-bopper would start skanking, and that
would be it.... we had fights, hostility, all of that shit... all from a
scene that was originally based on individuality and respect.  Five years
later, real ska and dancehall culture is just starting to recover.

The point is this:  defend your scene from the intruders.  Do it with all
your heart. Do it with all your soul. Just do it using the tools that make
your scene great to begin with, not with your fists or with scathing
rhetoric.  If you show some class, and evangelize what is good about UG
culture, you will either scare off or prosteletyze (sp?) the booty-shakers.
And you will have retained your own dignity in the process.

D. Kolin Better
Client Development

"Always dream and shoot higher than you know you can do."
			(William Faulkner)

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.3.91.970224130031.12396A-100000@lettuce.salinas.net>

MIME-Version: 1.0

Precedence: bulk

> I'm sorry you don't like Brownie's Breakdown mix. For us to go thru the 
> whole manufacturing process again and re-master this mix would cost 
> about $2000. As yours is the only complaint we have received out of the 
> 1500 pressed and sold, it doesn't seem likely that we will be doing 
> this.

Well, he's got a point here.  It costs a lot to manufacture records and
they probably got a test press before ordering a full production run to
insure that it sounded ok.  So the Rampant guy may have thought, "Well,
the test press sounded ok, and no one else has complained, so maybe he
just got a defective copy..."

> However, one technique used by some DJ's is to adjust the level of the 
> bass frequencies on the mixer's eq.If this does't help why don't you try 
> playing the other THREE mixes that you like so much and stop fucking 
> moaning! 3 out of 4 isn't bad and is better than most record companies 
> provide.
> 
> Your letter will be added to "Rampant's Cheekiest Letters Collection" 
> and so far it ranks #1.

But this is just pure assholishness (nice word, eh :).  Even if he didn't
offer to send a replacement (which I do *not* think he is obligated to do,
btw), he could have explained that there are always bad units in a
production run of records.  When you put in an order to have something put
to vinyl, you are implicitly agreeing to a 10% overrun of records.  That
is, they press 10% more than you request to account for the fact that many
of them will skip, sound bad, etc.

	Sami

Brian Denny wrote:

> can we please stop making generalizations about prices of parties?
> 
> i've been to some GREAT $20 parties, and some @#$%^& ones.
> i've been to some AMAZING $5 parties too. and some not-so-good ones.
> ...
> point #2: "it was a 6 dollar party" is not an excuse for anything.

Brian is absolutely right about these points.

> point #1: you can't judge a party by its cover.

But I can't agree with this one.  If you read the whole cover, and
follow "Krusty's Rules" for parties, you *can* judge how a party will
*probably* go off.  To paraphrase my meager memory of the "Krusty's
Rules":

1. The larger and fancier the flyer, the worse it's going to be.  Small,
simple flyers are the best.

2. The more phone numbers, the worse it's going to be.  If it has more
than two numbers, there's a problem.

3. The more overpublicized a party is, the worse it's going to be.  When
I saw a party getting huge advertising in any form, I avoided it. 
There's going to be too many immature people looking for a public forum
in which to get baked and look mean.

4. And the most important rule: go with promoters with good reps.  My
faves were FnF, Gateway, and Harmony.  I've been to good parties by
other promoters, Nomad and FGE included, but NOTHING beat those three
promoters for consistently phat, vibey parties.

5. Actually, point 4 ties with point 5 for importance: go where other
ravers you know and love are going.  We all have been at some really
crappy party where the sound was awful, the lighting was nonexistant,
and there were just too many darn bodies packed in one place, but we
found some friends to party with and it turned out to be a killer night
after all.  The *people* make the party.

S

I've already received many responses to the Rampant Issue. Several
people have asked to see the original post, before making any
judgements. That makes complete sense to me... So, I emailed my
friend and asked him if he has the original. Unfortunately, he sent
the mail from a Netscape browser, as he was checking out the 
Rampant Web Site, and didn't CC: a copy to his account...

I have included some questions that I asked him while in a 'Talk'
session...

At the end of this post, you will find Brian's address. He is the one
who wrote to Rampant, and welcomes any email in his direction
as well. I'm sorry that neither of us has the original. You can obviously
choose whether or not you believe what he originally wrote. Regardless,
I believe it was in poor taste for Rampant to react the way they did.
Brian wasn't asking for a new copy of the record. He was just pointing
out that he wasn't completely satisfied with the recording quality...

-matt

At 05:49 PM 2/24/97 -0800, you wrote:
>
>Just wondering, how is "world-champion dj" judged?

Not that I've ever been to a "championship", but I would reckon that it's
based on (1)style (scratching, cuts, tricks like cueing with your toes), and
(2)record selection.  Hip-hop djing has more competitive aspects to it  than
rave type djing, where there are less show-offy type of things to do with
the records.

I have a record on Rampant, and I think that it is pressed very poorly.  I
have heard a lot of records on Rampant and they all seem to sound very poor,
with very distorted lows and highs that sound like shit.  I don't know why
that is, but I haven't bought anything from them since because I can never
really play it out due to the sound quality.

>...But this is just pure assholishness (nice word, eh :).  Even if he didn't
>offer to send a replacement (which I do *not* think he is obligated to do,
>btw), he could have explained that there are always bad units in a
>production run of records.  When you put in an order to have something put
>to vinyl, you are implicitly agreeing to a 10% overrun of records.  That
>is, they press 10% more than you request to account for the fact that many
>of them will skip, sound bad, etc.
>
>	Sami
>

it's not what the party makes of you..
it's what YOUR funky ass makes of the PARTY!
yes, the vibe SUCKED!
oh man april i am SO sorry that was your first massive experience, 
because dear, there are some good massives out there! i pomise!

anyway, i stood in line from 8:45-10:30, thanks to the people who all 
cut in front of me.. i LOVE YOU ALLin all seriousnesess, i hope you 
got the best out of that extra half hour you had in front of the 
JUNGLE speakers and not walking around causing shit. which i saw ALOT 
of going on. a really NICE cop ran into me while about 100 scary 
looking people rushed the hallway that runs to the chillroom.. he was 
like :i am SO  very sorry!" and ran after the crowd.. you know 
something's wrong when the ravers are meaner and scarier than the 
cops.. hemm not to talk bad about cops or anything :)
	SO! lesse.. lara got in her car and went to berkeley and picked 
up about 7 people in her car, then went to home base super early, 
hoping to have no line. WRONG! i guess $6 tyo get in really inspires ravers 
to arrive early an'shit.. anyway, it was great, meeting some of the 
people in line, sharing stickers, candy, bouncing around, dancing up and down 
the line.. good vibe, i was thinking, this MIGHT JUST BE OKAY!! 
but THEN we got in. wow i awlmost wanted to go back and stand in line again!
my smiles and pink feather boa that stariana let me borrow on, i 
walked into a packed room of tall all-dark-clothed-wearing people.. and ran 
straight outside!
	where my friends and i had planned to meet(we were there 
during love a-fair too) sadly, the outside was NOT as safe haven for us 
as it was last weekend.. my friend's backpack got stolen, another's 
camera got stolen.. right from under our noses.. and inside, well that was 
WORSE! my friend got his wallet stolen by some pricks pretending to

From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Reply-To: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Slave to the Beat (Weekend Review)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9702241750.A8902-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


(Long...as usual!)


Friday Night
After a tour of diverse SF bars, me and my woozy group hit 1015.  
Good-sized crowd, not too packed or empty (as Nikita usually vacillates 
between!).  

We got there at 1 and Jerry Bonham was already on the main 
floor - and was still on when we split 4 hours later!  He spun some hard 
progressive trance (I think I might have just invented that category, but 
that sums it up) - a little too out-there for the mostly mainstream 
crowd, I think.  Jerry kept paring the music down with minimal beats, 
building bridges to the next phase... a great technique for creating an 
intense trancey set... but whenever the music slowed, the entire crowd 
stopped, unsure how to dance to "just beats!"  I did the "raver sway" :).

People crowded the front (disco and hip-hop) room - but although it was 
the "clubber" crowd, the vibe was relaxed, without any unnecessary 
rudeness or ogling.  As usual, the shift in atmosphere at 2AM when the 
barpeople left was palpable.  And Nikita must know their clientele, 
because right at 2 they abandoned disco in the front room and moved to 
_much_ more underground sounds!

Had fun with my non-raver friends there... Seeing "Last Call" spelled out by 
the lasers and flashing along with trance was a little weird though!


Saturday Night
After a tour of diverse Berkeley parties, a woozy me and my ragtag raver 
group hit Madness.  Got there around 12:30, and at first I 
was disappointed... the party seemed so empty and decorations so sparse 
compared to the incredible Koinonea party in the same space a few weeks 
ago... but we decided to give it a shot... UG ravers must be a bunch of 
laggers, because by 1:30 the place was finally full of happy ravers and 
the energy was transformed!  Most of my group spent the night upstairs, 
but I (of course) planted myself on the dance floor and could not be torn 
away... a slave to the beat... 

Minor Minor was still on when we got there, playing harder, more minimal 
stuff then I've heard from him before (and it rocked), and then T-1000 
came on for a huge portion of the night - what a treat!  His music was as 
technical and robotic-sounding as his name... music expressing a 
nightmare of the industrial age... or maybe turning into melody what is 
seemingly devoid of humanity?  (just questions I wrestled with while 
dancing my ass off)... Serious Detroit, some of it sounding really 
experimental.  I couldn't keep still, and the expressive and joyous crowd 
on that teeny hot dancefloor kept my spirits skyhigh :).  

I've never enjoyed minimal techno in the past.  I actually had to leave a 
party once a while back that was Detroit all night long.  But I have been 
through some sort of rave metamorphesis... suddenly I am a child of the 
beat... if there is a beat, I can find the soul of the music and my body 
will move to it... Categories of trance or goa or house or minimal are 
meaning less to me, I can become absorbed into the throbbing rhythm and 
take off from there - it's a wonderful feeling!  I finally feel like a 
true dancer.

The partygoers dwindled around 3, leaving a small group of about 30 of us 
on the dancefloor, and that's when it got the most fun.  Room to move and 
breathe and smiling people and relentless beats...

We left at 5:30, when the party was on its last legs.  But a few of us 
were still raring to go, so we hit that refuge of the night, the End-Up.  

Four bucks seemed a bit steep, but in we went (too desperate to bitch).  
What a funny scene!  All the remnants of the partying world deposited 
there... from strutting queens (and I mean that in the most appreciative 
manner) to tweaking trendies to "suburbanites" to ravers... and we were 
_all_ gettin' down.  The music was house, ranging from deep to cheese, 
and it was all good.  We danced and danced until we could go on no more, 
and finally drove home in the crystal-clear light of Sunday morning.

A good weekend.
:)

I don't know who you are, "Candy Raver Kermit," but I know one thing for
sure: you don't know who *we* are.  

sfraves has never been the kind of place where people indulge in careless
talk about "getto children" and "bitches".  I think your appearance on this
list is a sign of how the times have changed.  This kind of rough language
is used by people to impress others with how tough they are, how superior
they are.  We are *not* impressed.  And though there may be some interest
in flaming right back, I suspect we're also going to get past that as well.

This kind of talk indicates either deep-seated racism (which is doubtful
among the people likely to be interested in this list and this scene)
or very shallow life experience.  Who are these "getto children" and where
do they come from?  I wonder if you've even given this two seconds of 
though, "Candy Raver Kermit."  If you ask *them*, I bet you'll find out
they come from anywhere between and including West Oakland and Blackhawk,
or any other two random points on this planet.  

If you judge any group based on their clothes, their way of talking or
their skin color, it's certainly a way to stir up discussion and yelling.
But this is what James Brown meant when he sang about "talking loud and
saying nothing."  

As our little underground dance music scene started spreading out into wider
society, we started seeing some of the superficial and negative attitudes
circulating in general society start creeping in as well.  

If we really believe in the ideals we expressed in the past under the banner
of the House Nation, we had better be prepared to deal with this whole ball
of wax.  

The party Saturday night was not a "getto children party," it was a Cool
World party.  The vibe at their parties is the vibe *they* develop.  It
has to do with motivation and perspective.  Enough said.

As for the "ghetto," let's do a little thought experiment.  Imagine that
the places people consider to be "ghettos" had never existed.  Those are
places where people, regular people just like us, grow up, live, have
families, work, play, smile, cry, conduct real lives under difficult
circumstances.  It's not just about people roughing each other up and worse
on the street.  That's a fact of that life, but not the only one.  

One other thing -- there music in the "ghetto" -- a LOT of it, it comes
straight from the heart under the most difficult circumstances.

Without the "ghetto" we would have:

- No jazz, born in New Orleans, Chicago, Kansas City, Harlem New York and LA.

- No rock'n'roll, born on the doo-wop streetcorners of Manhattan, Brooklyn
  and the Bronx.

- No disco, born in the gay underground clubs from New York to San Francisco.

- No hip hop, straight from the streets of Crooklyn.

- No house, from the heart of Chicago and New York.

- No techno, from the soul of Detroit.

- No jungle, from the polyglot sprawl of London.

- No reggae, from the hardest ghetto of all, Trench Town Kingston.

This is an important issue -- how we talk to each other and the terms we
use.  I don't think anyone here really condones this kind of abuse of the
language and sloppy thinking.  The question is, how do we deal with it?
Online "communities" are fragile and easily sidetracked and even destroyed
by carelessness, cluelessness and malice.

I apologize for going on and on like this, but I feel that the issue of
what our obligations are to deal with these superficial and messed-up
attitudes in the "kids" entering into this scene is a very important one.

We all have our residual prejudices.  The only shame is in not dealing with
them and using what we learn to help others.  It is not a nice process,
a happy process.  It is a necessary process.  There is much wisdom in the
statement: 
  
  Positive education always corrects error.

peace out
phred

I would have to disagree with some points...
my first party had a very played up flyer
(my first was only in mid oct...)
it was in Santa Cruz at the Su-Bud house, called Pure-X
it was a phat party. I didn't know vibes that well yet, but being my first
eeeee it was a fun experience... i do not recall any bad vibes.  I had a most
wonderful time.  
I love parties so much because of my fabulous first experience...
And the flyer had 3 numbers and was very big and colorful.
so, don't judge a book by its cover, it might suck, bbut then again it might
be bomb.
another point to make.. try to go to all party crew's parties and find out
what kind of party they throw.  If you like the vibe at they're party, keep
going, if you had an awful time, don't go to another (unless you believe in
2nd chances)
love april
