I feel myself easily intrigued by astrology and its characteristics. So 
for any others who may like to know more about their sign, just flip 
through what I've put together for you...


"The moon pulls the deep tides of our bodies, minds, and spirits. She is 
ever changing yet ever remaining, the reflection of our essence and 
powers, reminder of the quickening, waxing and waning of all things."

--> Essentially the zodiac is made up of a belt of stars which circle the 
earth's elliptical yearly path around the sun. "ages" are decided by the 
point where the elliptical path coincides with the vernal equinox.In 
calculating an individual astrological chart, the aspects are decided by 
positions of sun, moon, and planets as seen from earth, against the 
backdrop of the zodiacal belt of stars. The moon signs are decided by the 
moon's position on the monthly path.
 

* The Elements:

In astrology there is an elemental system of fire, air, earth, and water.

FIRE people are volatile, tempermental, aggressive
WATER people are sensitive, emotional, passive
EARTH people are solid, stable, and stubborn
AIR people are fragile, intelligent, and spacy

(Of course, consider these only basic characteristics in one sense or 
another)


* The Signs:

ARIES rules the head and is considered an intellectual, yet fiery sign. 
Aries people are often brilliant, sometimes to the point of genius. They 
are great starters or initiators of projects, but not always good at 
sustaining and completing, often relying on more earthy, stable people to 
take over, while they move on to further adventures. they are known to be 
impulsive, rebellious, aggressive, and active.

TAURUS are earthy people and are considered sturdy, practical and 
grounded. They are known to be persistent and capable, tending toward 
stubborness and materialism. taurus can however see the "spirit of the 
matter," in the sense that money is a reflection of loving abundance, or 
that practical matters can serve less visibleneeds. they can be most 
generous and loyal, providing a steadying influence to more other types.

GEMINI is a mutable air sign, ruled by Mercury, planet of movement and 
communication. gemini are head-trippers, overflowing with playful ideas 
and speedy thoughts. they can see many sides of aa question and provide a 
variety of points of view. however, this ability can take the negative 
form of con-artist in its detrimental aspects.

CANCER is a watery sign, loving and emotional. cancerians are protective 
and tender-haerted, easily concerned with the troubles of others, 
sometimes to the point of over-identification. they make great parents 
and often keep warm hearths.

LEO people are great performers and usually take the center of attention. 
all children are ruled by this fixed firey sign, as they require the 
center for their very survival. fixed fire is deep and steady warmth and 
makes leos loyal and devoted in relationships and projects. negative ego 
problems can make them obnoxiously show-offish, or repressed and shy; 
healthy egos make them good leaders and creative artists.

VIRGO are organizers of enviroments, information, etc. they can be 
extremely analytical and make good critics. a virgo keeps an efficient 
house or office, but can be picky to the point of irritation in their zeal 
to be perfect. virgos often understand the value of loving service.

LIBRA is the sign of balance and diplomacy and grace. librans always try 
to see the other person's point of view, hence are sometimes called the 
peacemakers. in detriment this can make them seem somewhat indecisive or 
two-faced, as they find themselves caught between opposing issues.

SCORPIO (this is me!) is the deepest and most passionate of signs, 
connecting with mysticism, sexuality and the secrets of life and death. 
it is symbolized by four emblems: the scorpion, serpent, eagle, and 
phoenix. each represent a stage of tranformation from the depths to the 
heights of conciosness. scorpio people are intense  and powerful, but can 
be overly tempermental and volatile if they have not tamed their egos.

SAGITTARIUS people are free-spirited, impulsive, and wise. they make 
great travelers on the inner and outer planes as free-wheeling gypsies or 
adventerous thinkers. they do not like to be tied down and sometimes are 
considered irresponsible by more committed friends, but they always bring 
a fresh and exciting air to whatever they do.

CAPRICORN are ambitious, far-seeing and great at organizing groups. They 
make good politicians and leaders, combining high ideals with step by 
step practicality. like the mountain goat which symbolizes them, they 
will acheive great heights because of their ability to climb precarious 
places with care.

AQAURIUS is often called the sign of universal brotherhood/sisterhoo. its 
native can be quite detached and are capable of an overview that gives 
them a valuable understanding of social trends. watery types may find 
them a bit dry and unemotional, but they are loyal to the truths they see.

PISCES is a mutable watery sign, and very emotional and mystical. 
pisceans are extremely sensitive and receptive, and make passionate 
lovers and parents. they are so sympathetic to others that they sometimes 
become victimized, and have to be careful to define their boundaries and 
protect themselves.


***** Happy Birthday, Everyone!!!!!!!! *****



				peace luv and hugs from S.C. ==> Ann







* info. for this post was from 
	Ariadne's Thread, by Shekhinah Mountainwater
	The Crossing Press, 1991.

Good Day my friends!

I would like to, on the behalf of aware enviornments and crew, invite you 
 and your friends to
                         	warmth

In the city of - san francisco -  on - saturday - march 1st.

Your party will conspire on 2 floors, one designed for joy, spontenuity, 
enlightenment and fevered passion, and the other designed for all those 
things but with an overal feeling of...chill. The fellas in the main dance 
hall will be:

macadio
deepfrog
anakin
micron
wizard
  + special guests

The cats spinning upstairs in the lounge will be:

boomerang fidget
matt
proto lab (ambient band and keyboard)
  +special guests

our night will begin at 9pm with an opening rythem meditation and 
celebration. We are going to raise the energy and vibration of the space 
with hand drums and rythem tools.  If you want to participate bing your 
drums, digeradoos, guitars, cow bells, incense, candls, spiritual tools, 
and whatever else you would like to use to personalize your party.  There 
will be alters that will need your individual touches and additions.  The 
opening meditation and rythem circle will bigin at 9pm, so be here at 
9pm if you want to participate, I certenly do encourage it. 
 
We are preparing for a beautiful, secure, and kind night.  To 
leave a party feeling like a better person for being there.  we are designing a 
space to foster community, communication, intelligencia, love and 
intensity.  

Our tix are limmited to 300 and will be available at:

capricorn music --- santa cruz
solid grooves --- san jose
drop beat --- oakland
get a clue --- sacramento
  
tickets will be $10
If you have any questions, suggestions, or messages please feel free to 
call the voice mail and let us know.

        	             415.339.8059

be happy and be warm
spencer K.

> walls, etc.  Our building was the music, arts and crafts specialty program

> :)

Yes, it was, and in spite of the hellhole we turned it into physically,
the "ghettodorm" was a bunch of the most loving, caring, close-knit
communal group of folks I've ever been with (except for you wonderful 
sfravers, of course =).  As a result of this experience, though, I don't
know if I would be the right person to consult, as far as the definition
of the word ghetto is concerned.  That year, for me, connects the word
"ghetto" with a very positive (if not chaotic) experience, and I'm not
sure that's necessarily true.  But then again, it's just a word, to be
wielded however one so chooses, just another symbol for communication.
After all, interpretation of definition is part of the intrinsic beauty of
language.  Anyways, I believe I'm beginning to ramble...

Plur, (because I like the term, no matter who puts a stigma on it)-
-=Joe H.=-

Date: Wed, 26 Feb 1997 23:58:24 -0800 (PST)
Subject: passion (nrr)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-id: <01IFW21F355U9S4NOS@SONOMA.EDU>
X-VMS-To: SMTP%"sfraves@hyperreal.com"
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I, as some of you know, have a book that I bring to parties for 
people to draw in, write in, and do whatever they please in. Last 
weekend, at Planet New Year's nonetheless, a person by the name of 
Chris wrote in my book (I believe he went to the college I attended 
for awhile). What he wrote struck my heart and I feel compelled to 
share it with you.. It goes something like this... 

If I were to tell you I loved you, what would you do? 
If I, 
upon the first time seeing you, said with gazing eyes, "Amazing." And 
you say "what?" and I say "You're absolutely beautiful," how would 
you feel?
Would you feel flattered, confused, frightened, loved? 
Would you embrace me? Would you trust me? Would you beleive me? Would I 
believe myself? 
Can a lone sole believe in instantaneous true passion? 
Can the entire world, or someone's entire heart change in the blink 
of an eye?
Is my need to beleive in such things tearing my insides out or 
putting them together or both?
There is a quote, by Jack Kerouac, which drives itself straight to 
the deepest point of my innards. "The attainment of enlightenment is 
to be considered neither a high state nor a low state, everybody 
equally attains it because everybody equally knows that lightening 
strikes in the blue sky."
I love you, though I hardly know you, though I've never kissed or 
embraced you. I love you because you are reading this, and hopefully 
you know what I love. You are seeing all my hopes and hearing the 
only advice I have to give, my only true wisdom.
Believe in passion, for that is all there is.

Love to you all,
Lara

 I don't know if that "Thanks" was meant sarcastically or not, but I
took it as a challenge! ( being a hopeless web search junkie ).

1. Used Alta-Vista Advanced Search ( does boolean logic )
   http://altavista.digital.com/cgi-bin/query?pg=aq&what=web

2. Used the search string "Prodigy AND techno AND british"

3. On the second page of the results, found
   http://www.nerdworld.com/users/dstein/nw1093.html

4. Which had a link to:
   http://oden.rsn.hk-r.se/prodigy/   
   which is a Prodigy fan page, which is mirrored on
   http://www.sn.no/~bvs/

 .. and that guy has a sub-page of Prodigy and other music links.

Analog for two reasons. First, there is going to be jungle. Second, my
friends really wanted to have a "massive" experience. Though there are
plenty of negative opinions about massives, I'm hoping for a positive
experience which will be more a function of our attitudes than anything
else.

not be as warm as say, Warmth. :)

pushed me over the edge... I don't have the time or the desire to delete
100+ messages a day, so good bye everyone!

I've had some great times meeting many of you, and I know I'll keep seeing
you at parties and such. (if I go to any soon... school is really taking a
toll on my sanity =P )

anyway, take care (and watch out for viberation =)
-m.

From: Adam Guevara <aguevara@rely.com>
To: "'Sfraves@hyperreal.com'" <Sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Wish Review...
Date: Thu, 27 Feb 1997 11:44:41 -0800
X-Mailer:  Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.994.63

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Ok, I'm not one to review Clubs, But....


I'd have to say Wish was one of the most vibey events I've been to
during the week...

The last time was when that other German DJ was @ Mos Isley (Anyone
remember that weekly?).

Arriving @ 10-or-so I whisked myself to the first available spot'o'floor
and gruvved to Kenneth Sol's set (Hey Kenneth!).   His set was a fine
blend of housey/techno, but I really appreciated his mixing style:
Scratches, drop outs and spinbacks galore.  Very detroit - east
coast'ish.  Fell into a small Caporea(sp.) circle (Now THAT was FUN!!!)
until the security became a lil worried, and if I saw a bunch peole
kicking each other, I'd get worried too...

The Bahia ( heh, like no one has been there before) was done up in it's
nice Wishy fashion.  Red laser beaming on the mulitcoloured screen.
Blacklights giving everyone the "glow teeth" look. Nice posters hanging
around.  Crowd rainged from cubbies, regulars, ravers (see- we CAN all
get along)... Even a face or two from Cool World (Yea, I WAS there).    

I took a break unitil that famillar trance style got me back to my feet,
and was that place PACKED!!!
Hardsequencer:  Well, he DJ'ed a Mayday-type set.  Mucho breakdowns in
case the crowd couldn't handle long intense sets (Come on Germany, have
some faith in SF... There is a hardtrance scene out here too...).
Vocals, which tripped me out (only used to words with deep house or
gabber sets).  The music selection was forigen to these ears, but
delightful.  I couldn't 'go off' due to the many breakdowns tho...  =(

Had to 'bail' @ 1AM (I hate pagers) becuz of a friend in need.  So I'm
sorry that I coudn't talk to those I was supposed to talk to...  But hey
I'll be @ Wish next week (F-8 night)...

BTW: For those that were 'In the Void',  I was the bouncy guy in the
black'n'grey _PUMA #7_ tshirt w/a sweater around my waist...

----_Adam (Was that Rave related???)

"Stay Connected"

Subject: Astral Matrix, girls in cages & GEMINIS
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com

Astral Matrix is my favorite live act.  Some times I find live music a
little dry, ohh boy, not his.  Check out his new tape, I think it's called
Live in Toronto, it'll make you bounce around the room!

I know the post about girls dancing provacitivley has bluured out but I want
you all to know my 2 pennies worth.

Our society seems to make it very hard for a girl to be sexy without
recieving negative attention.  Even just wearing a small t shirt evokes
raunchy cat calls from guys with hmmm, perhaps a smaller brain.  So it's
nice that girls feel comforitable in our world of raves to flaunt and gyrate
to their hearts desires.  What I particuarly DON"T LIKE is the feeling of
forced sexuality I get when a promoter purposley puts girls in cages or
skimpily clad girls on stage to dance. The debate has raged on these pages
about individual peoples motivation for raving; music, friendship, drugs.
But I've never read anyone who said "I go for the free sexy stage show"
correct me if I'm wrong about that.  There is no doubt that techno(and all
the diff genres below it) is sexy music. one of my friends says if a DJ
makes her think of sex at least once, it's a good set.  But not everyone is
turned on by females, and even people who like girls aren't nescesarily
turned on by the visual of a half naked one grooving to the music.
Putting a girl in a cage to skank away is objectifying women-turning them in
to merley sex objects- I think it then makes it harder for the girls on the
dance floor to dance sexually w/o becoming the target for horny young males
- there are better ways to revere the beauty of women.  Basically I think
promoters should allow us dancers to choose ourselves what we think is sexy
and if they still feel the need to put people up on display they should
cover more of the bases, like a chip n dales style danser, a dyke danser
blah blah all the other sexual stereotype styles, instead of assuming that
we all like buxum boobsum half dreesed women!

and to the one who wrote that Geminis don't go in for astrology...You're
such a gemini!!

Subject: Re: Drug Hypocrisy?
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

 
        I'm bored. Time to start a flame war.

        {:>

> I've heard of VERY few trancendental experiences associated with the
> average cup of coffee;

        True. I haven't heard of *any* cases of people losing lives,
	freedom, relationships or jobs because of coffee either.
        Could it be that it just ain't that strong a drug? Like
        it shouldn't even be considered in the same class as E
        or LSD? To me this is a no-brainer. I'd also put cigarettes
        in this category - cigarettes have definite long term
        health problems associated with their use, but short-term
        problems? Never heard of any.

> I tend to believe that caffeine and alcohol are the opiates of the masses.

        We've already thrown out caffeine (unless somebody can show me a
        "coffee casualty" somewhere) so now let's talk about alcohol.
        Alcohol should be as illegal as heroin. It definitely would be,
        if it weren't for one simple fact: it's just too damn easy to
        make it. All you have to do is take some orange or grape juice
        and leave it unrefrigerated for awhile. Fermentation is everywhere.

Subject: Re: Drug Hypocrisy?

Precedence: bulk


>         I'm bored. Time to start a flame war.

you got it.

>         True. I haven't heard of *any* cases of people losing lives,
> 	freedom, relationships or jobs because of coffee either.

most such negative effects of drug use are directly or indirectly related
to their illegality.

>         Could it be that it just ain't that strong a drug? Like
>         it shouldn't even be considered in the same class as E
>         or LSD? To me this is a no-brainer. I'd also put cigarettes
>         in this category - cigarettes have definite long term
>         health problems associated with their use, but short-term
>         problems? Never heard of any.

depends on how you define strong.  Caffeine and nicotine are _physically
addictive_-- after a short time taking them regularly, you NEED them in
order to feel as good as you USED to feel without them. i would call that
a short-term problem.

LSD is totally NON-physically-addictive, and one of the least
psychologically addictive substances i've ever encountered.  There are
also NO physical health risks associated with it, and the psychological
risks are virtually nil among people who are educated about the drug's
effects and risks.

Ecstasy is also not physically addictive, though i have found it to be
psychologically so.  Still, there is a big difference between physical and
psychological addiction (at least for me).  There may be some long-term
neuro-physiological ramifications of Ecstasy use, however the evidence is
not a fraction as conclusive as the evidence of the damage that nicotine
and alcohol do to body tissues.

Alcohol is not as addictive as nicotine, but Alcohol is more
incapacitating than most recreational drugs (which makes it particularly
dangerous when driving) and, unlike, pot, E, acid, shrooms, etc., alcohol
often brings out the belligerent / violent sides of people. 

When people talk about the risks and negative effects of drugs, they often
forget to compare the risks and negative effects of everyday activities.

Ever drive to work?  Better chance you'll get killed on the road than
taking E.  And you're polluting while you're at it.

Ever have sex?  I find it plenty psychologically addictive.  And god knows
what could happen to you. :)

I'm only half being tongue in cheek here.  My ability to expand my mind
with psychedelics is at least as important to me as my ability to get to
work at 60 mph.  AND i consider it less risky.

Love,

brian

Hmmm..... I've heard from a few sources that nicotine and caffeine were =
some of the most addictive substances around,  but people take such =
incredibly small doses in "normal" usage that it really is not dangerous =
at all.  Another kinda' fun fact:  If the amount of nicotine in an =
unburnt cigarette entered your bloodstream all at once, it would kill =
you. :)  Fortunately, most of the nicotine is either destroyed by the =
burning or just exhaled. =20

        problems? Never heard of any.

        if it weren't for one simple fact: it's just too damn easy to
        make it. All you have to do is take some orange or grape juice
        and leave it unrefrigerated for awhile. Fermentation is =
everywhere.

I scanned through my mailbox, and found FOUR variations of this message sent
in the last two weeks.  Isn't one time enough?  SFRaves is not an
advertising service.  When posting about your own event or product, it is
conventional to use the prefix (BSP) in the subject heading to denote
(blatant) self-promotion.  Please use this in the future, so that those of
us who do not wish to view advertisements can filter them.  

Thanks,
Seth

> most such negative effects of drug use are directly or indirectly related
> to their illegality.

	Alcohol is legal, and many people have lost lives, freedom, 
	relationships and jobs as a direct result of using alcohol. 
	There are so many stories about this they have become cliches.

> depends on how you define strong.  Caffeine and nicotine are _physically
> addictive_-- after a short time taking them regularly, you NEED them in
> order to feel as good as you USED to feel without them. i would call that
> a short-term problem.

	Granted, but the difference between how you feel with vs. without 
	caffeine is so minor that this doesn't become much of a problem
	for most people. Cigarettes are tougher, but still minor.

	Come on - are you *really* comparing the effects of LSD or E
	with a cup of coffee & a cigarette? Please!

> LSD is totally NON-physically-addictive, and one of the least
> psychologically addictive substances i've ever encountered.

	I disagree with your assesment of the psychological addictiveness
	of L. The intensity of the L experience makes it *very* psycho-
	logically addictive to people who are attracted to that *intensity*.
	Maybe you're not one of those people - in which case you're probably
	not doing L very often.

	Also, L does kill - the experience can detach you so far from
	reality that you do something fatal - like (cliche time) jump
	out the window because you think you can fly. Or maybe jump
	off a boat because you need to get away from the angry, 
	bad-vibey people who've been waiting too long on a cold dock
	and you're sure you can make it to shore somehow ...

> Ecstasy is also not physically addictive, though i have found it to be
> psychologically so.

	Aaah. So you're one of those who likes the warm fuzzies more
	than intense weirdness. Well, we all seem to find our favorite 
	poison...

	E is not as intense an experience as L, but it's still a hell of
	a lot more intense than caffeine or nicotine.

> Alcohol is not as addictive as nicotine ...

	Depends on what you mean. It's harder to get *physically* hooked
	on alcohol - but if you do get hooked this way the withdrawals
	are more likely to kill you than heroin withdrawals (alcohol
	is a typical barbituate in this respect). Psychologically,
	alcohol also has a strong pull for certain types of people...

> When people talk about the risks and negative effects of drugs, they often
> forget to compare the risks and negative effects of everyday activities.

	I agree. Deciding whether it's worth it to take these risks 
	is a quality of life issue, like deciding about your personal 
	relationship with cars or latex.

	I just wish people wouldn't spend so much time trying to
	decieve themselves about the very real risks. I call comparing
	E & L to caffeine & cigarettes an exercise in self-deception.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Feb 27 15:55:20 1997

Received: from [206.14.138.142] (k142.value.net [206.14.138.142]) by value.net (8.8.4/8.7.3) with SMTP id PAA23339; Thu, 27 Feb 1997 15:54:53 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <v02130500af3bca90cf3e@[206.14.138.27]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
X-mailer: Eudora Pro 2.1.3
Date: Thu, 27 Feb 1997 15:58:13 -0800
To: Rob Rayle <robertr@autodesk.com>
From: bri@value.net (Brian Denny)
Subject: Re: Drug Hypocrisy?
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>        Come on - are you *really* comparing the effects of LSD or E
>        with a cup of coffee & a cigarette? Please!

no, i'm contrasting them-- LSD and E give, granted, much stronger, but also
much more beneficial effects, without fostering dependence (at least i've
managed not to become dependent on them, which is something i couldn't say
for cigarettes).

>        I disagree with your assesment of the psychological addictiveness
>        of L. The intensity of the L experience makes it *very* psycho-
>        logically addictive to people who are attracted to that *intensity*.
>        Maybe you're not one of those people - in which case you're probably
>        not doing L very often.
...
>        Aaah. So you're one of those who likes the warm fuzzies more
>        than intense weirdness. Well, we all seem to find our favorite
>        poison...

actually-- and this is the interesting thing-- i like Acid more than E.  no
substance has ever benefitted me more than LSD. i always seem to gain
clarity and understanding from it.  and when i do take it, i go for the
weirdness-- i'm bored by low doses. however, if i take it more than a
couple times a month it loses its appeal. whereas with E, i went through a
phase of taking it more and more often, 'cuz i liked how it made me feel,
even though i wasn't really gaining anything from the drug anymore.  that's
why i find E more psychologically addictive than LSD.  but i suppose other
people might find the opposite, i don't know.

>
>        Also, L does kill - the experience can detach you so far from
>        reality that you do something fatal - like (cliche time) jump

if you are educated about the drug and plan your set and setting, etc.
before you take LSD, the risks are minimal. no one ever died or went crazy
taking LSD under the advice of a psychiatrist back when it was legal...
those psychiatrists didn't know anything about LSD that we don't know if we
do our research.  but people went and took LSD carelessly and fucked it up
for themselves and the responsible ones too... [Hofmann, _LSD, My Problem
Child_]


>        E is not as intense an experience as L, but it's still a hell of
>        a lot more intense than caffeine or nicotine.

true.  i agree on the intensity point.  but i think it's their subtlety
that makes nicotine and other physically addictive drugs particularly
insidious.

i'm aware of the risks of the drugs i take, and generally play as safe as i
can.  to _me_, use of certain drugs is important.  use of others (mainly
the physically addictive ones) is scary.  i certainly advocate that
everyone become familiar with the effects and risks of a drug before
consuming it.


Love,

brian

>         or LSD? To me this is a no-brainer. I'd also put cigarettes
>         in this category - cigarettes have definite long term
>         health problems associated with their use, but short-term
>         problems? Never heard of any.

the short-term effects aren't as overwhelmingly obvious as emphysema (sp?)
or lung cancer, but they do exist - smaller oxygen transfer capacity and 
generally shortness of breath, propensity for chest infections like
bronchitis i believe, and of course chronic anemia (iron deficiency).

smoking for a couple months might not give you cancer, but if you are and
athlete or somebody else who is very aware of your level of fitness (like
a _dancer_ maybe?) then you will notice the difference.  after all, you've
killed off all your lung cilia - how can there _not_ be a difference?
matt.

Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C.
       Electronic dance, noise, spoken word, world music and more. Beats
       for your head. Sounds for your soul. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night midnight-3am - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats,
       Breakz and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

Take notice that these are only my own thoughts and observations. They are
not authorized by either gateway or pacific, nor should they been taken as
coming from any part of either gateway or pacific, nor is it fair to use
my words to set expectations - or maybe it is, I dunno. This is just what
I feel on the subject of their make up party... 

On Thu, 27 Feb 1997 Tekno313@aol.com wrote:

> I'm sure that Claire, Rob and Jon Carel would be more than happy to answer
> any questions that you might have.

	I have an idea. The next time anyone bumps into them and they are
not busying tuning their sound system, setting it up, controlling lights,
or otherwise busy, why not ask them what they want to put together as the
makeup party, what they have already tried to line up, and maybe even tell
them want will do as a makeup party. If anyone does this, I will also
advise that you do not demand to know what they are doing for you, but
instead just try and find out what their plan is and has been (there is a
big difference on the other end because one puts me, atleastm in a 
defnsive position and the latter does not seem like I am being accused 
so much).
	I know they have been trying to put together what they feel would
be a sufficient make up party for the one people paid $20 for. Maybe if
you work with them and communicate what you would like in such a make up
party, it will happen sooner... I wasn't in SF, and therefore I wasn't at
their NYE party, so I really have no reference point on the party, the
need for a makeup party and the like. I think that if they are not
approached in an accusitory way, one is more likely to get some idea to
want they want to do and have been trying to do... 

The usual disclaimers about not being a part of the promotion group apply
here; I don't own stock, I don't get a cut. I just know what level they
like to do things to, but it may be a while before they can do things to
such a level unless someone has a 3 or 4 room space to do it in (that is my 
own insight again, and not one affliated with Gateway or Pacific for 
that matter)... 

dave

tonight i had dinner with an old friend from high school... i haven't
really talked to her in a couple of years.

so we were catching up on eachother's lives, and i say "i don't know if you
know anything about the rave scene..."

turns out back in 92-93 when we were juniors in highschool (back when i was
anti-drug and had never _heard_ of raves) she was driving down to SF every
weekend with her sister or her boyfriend and going to raves.

she hasn't been in a couple of years, but she expressed interest in coming
to a party sometime.

:)

love,

brian

Hi all!  ]=)

 Well, as a very few of you may know or have noticed, I've been stressing 
like no tommorrow lately. With good reason to be sure, however it is 
still stress.

 I just wanted to say to all of you that the best drug in the world is 
friendship! I recieved two gifts (and another on just yesterday) from two 
very different people today and aww man have I been just flying! I feel 
soooo good!  =)

 Getting some gigs in the last week or so has helped. And I think I'm 
_starting_ to learn how to be truely grateful for the blessings in my 
life (like great music and amazing people to hang with).

 Big hugs to Martin Randall, Jess Burkson and Richard Sun. Big thanks 
also to Dagny and the LightSeed crew.

 Now of course this is just a happy peak and I'll slip back to my normal 
operative mode (which would be a blessing considering how I've been 
feeling lately!). But I think I've hit another platue (sp?). And I don't 
think I could have done it without all the shit I have gone through.

love you all,


Ran D.Dreams

People -

This monday (March 3rd) it's the return of the infamous Monday Night
Dinner.  This time it will be a pot luck at Natoma on the Lake (residence
of Sarah & Steve.)  Hoping to see some familiar faces, and maybe some new
ones too, eat yummy food (vegan, vegetarian or other :), drink lots of
chai (prepared by yours truly!) and have a great evening together. 

If we can talk him into it, there may be a live performance by Saturn5,
but regardless, we're a stone's throw from MAD at the Bahia Cabana - where
many ravers wind up after a long weekend.

E-mail myself (dlowe@saturn5.com) or Sarah Aberant (sarah@saturn5.com) for
directions and for ideas on what to bring food-wise. 

Sorry to those of you who get this twice :)

> 
> I scanned through my mailbox, and found FOUR variations of this message sent
> in the last two weeks.  Isn't one time enough?  SFRaves is not an
> advertising service.  When posting about your own event or product, it is
> conventional to use the prefix (BSP) in the subject heading to denote
> (blatant) self-promotion.  Please use this in the future, so that those of
> us who do not wish to view advertisements can filter them.  

Right.

Here's one more:

<from socal-raves>

Well, I went to the Ninja Tunes tour last night in Downtown
San Diego not really knowing what to expect.  I'd heard only
good things about them, so decided to check them out.

Bottom line:  HOLY SHIT CAN THOSE KIDS SPIN!

Their mixing skills defy hyperbole.  There are four of them
altogether.  DJ Food (actual DJ name Strictly Kev), DJ Vadim,
DJ Kid Koala, and I forget the fourth guy's name unfortunately.

DJ Kid Koala stole the show.  His average record stayed on the
turntable for about 30 seconds as he mixed, scratched, and
did various other ungodly things to those records without
ever missing a beat, WITHOUT WEARING HEADPHONES!  I'm still
not exactly sure how he did what he did, I think it might
have been magic.  I talked to him after the show, and he
is the most humble guy too.  (Real name Eric, he's from
Montreal, the rest are from England).  The flame that burns
twice as brightly burns half as long, so he probably only
spun for a total of 30-40 minutes, but man, he brought
everybody in the place to their feet screaming and yelling.

My only complaint would be music selection.  _Approximate_ breakdown:
60% hip hop
30% trip hop
5% electro/old school breakbeat
5% jungle

Far too much hip hop for my tastes, but their presentation of
it was certainly as good as it gets.

If there are tickets left for the Troubadour show, buy them
and go.

Jeff

Randy C Cone wrote:
> 
> Hi folks!  ]=)
> 
>  A few days ago someone stated that E had meth-amphetamine in it. I
> answered that I thought it was only related to amphetamines by the virtue
> of the last A in MDMA.
> 
>  Someone obviously thought I was way off base and sent back (in all upper
> case) that the MA in MDMA stood for meth-amphetamine.
> 
>  Well, I drug out (  ;)  ) my trusty Psychedelics Encyclopedia to see
> wha' s'up.
> 
>  from page III - 65
> 
> MDMA -- full name is N-methyl-3,4-mehylenedioxyphenylisopropylamine
> 
>  MDA is 3-4 methylendioxy-amphetamine or 3-4 methylendioxyphenylisopropylamine
> 
> from pages III-67 & 282 (I'm paraphrasing)
> 
>  Aminization (chemical conversion to amine form) makes MDA, MDMA and
> amphetamines, meth-amphetamines.

> > most such negative effects of drug use are directly or indirectly
related
> > to their illegality.
> 
> 	Alcohol is legal, and many people have lost lives, freedom, 
> 	relationships and jobs as a direct result of using alcohol. 
> 	There are so many stories about this they have become cliches.
> 
> > depends on how you define strong.  Caffeine and nicotine are
_physically
> > addictive_-- after a short time taking them regularly, you NEED them in
> > order to feel as good as you USED to feel without them. i would call
that
> > a short-term problem.
> 
> 	Granted, but the difference between how you feel with vs. without 
> 	caffeine is so minor that this doesn't become much of a problem
> 	for most people. Cigarettes are tougher, but still minor.
> 
> 	Come on - are you *really* comparing the effects of LSD or E
> 	with a cup of coffee & a cigarette? Please!
> 
> > LSD is totally NON-physically-addictive, and one of the least
> > psychologically addictive substances i've ever encountered.
> 
> 	I disagree with your assesment of the psychological addictiveness
> 	of L. The intensity of the L experience makes it *very* psycho-
> 	logically addictive to people who are attracted to that *intensity*.
> 	Maybe you're not one of those people - in which case you're probably
> 	not doing L very often.
> 
> 	Also, L does kill - the experience can detach you so far from
> 	reality that you do something fatal - like (cliche time) jump
> 	out the window because you think you can fly. Or maybe jump
> 	off a boat because you need to get away from the angry, 
> 	bad-vibey people who've been waiting too long on a cold dock
> 	and you're sure you can make it to shore somehow ...
> 
> > Ecstasy is also not physically addictive, though i have found it to be
> > psychologically so.
> 
> 	Aaah. So you're one of those who likes the warm fuzzies more
> 	than intense weirdness. Well, we all seem to find our favorite 
> 	poison...
> 
> 	E is not as intense an experience as L, but it's still a hell of
> 	a lot more intense than caffeine or nicotine.
> 
> > Alcohol is not as addictive as nicotine ...
> 
> 	Depends on what you mean. It's harder to get *physically* hooked
> 	on alcohol - but if you do get hooked this way the withdrawals
> 	are more likely to kill you than heroin withdrawals (alcohol
> 	is a typical barbituate in this respect). Psychologically,
> 	alcohol also has a strong pull for certain types of people...
> 
> > When people talk about the risks and negative effects of drugs, they
often
> > forget to compare the risks and negative effects of everyday
activities.
> 
> 	I agree. Deciding whether it's worth it to take these risks 
> 	is a quality of life issue, like deciding about your personal 
> 	relationship with cars or latex.
> 
> 	I just wish people wouldn't spend so much time trying to
> 	decieve themselves about the very real risks. I call comparing
> 	E & L to caffeine & cigarettes an exercise in self-deception.

if i maybe so bold.  

but that doesn't make us better than any of the other signs.  not at all.

in fact, it can even be a handicap.  one of the saddes things i see very 
often is a scorpio who isn't aware of their verry psychic connection. 
they usually are negative beyond belief.  watch out.  scorpios can be 
really positive or really negative.  im sure some of you have met some of 
those dark ones.  =\  but i also understand where they get trapped.  

in our physically oriented world (disgusting eating and sexual habits to 
boot), we are wired into our bodies somehow with a spirit connecting us 
to the "other side".  capricorns ( i know a lot of them, hi goat 
people!)  are usually wired up to "see" psychic energy (whatever that is) 
and scorpios sort of "feel" it.  feeling is a whole lot more intense 
than seeing.  that's why i think some scorpios have a lot of problems 
dealing and coping and end up destroying their bodies with drugs and 
alcohol, which usually have a higher tolerance to these substances.  how 
do i know all this?  experience.  i love meeting people, and i have a 
mental database.  i would never tell most of you to your face, because 
i've found that people don't like to be boxed and categorized.  

i don't know how many scorpios ive met that have said once we found out, 
they say (or I say)..."oh, no wonder!"  

anyway, off my soapbox.  it's time to hear from other scorpios, or other 
signs.  i think it's a pretty interesting discussion line, and is sort of 
rave related, because of it's spiritual nature.  

in closing, i would like to say that i believe there is a place where we 
are all pure energy and linked.  there is a place where we ALL understand 
where each other is coming from, and there is no need for discussion 
groups like SFR to grow, and drugs are not necessary for thought 
acceleration.  

there it doesn't matter what sign you are.  we're all linked.  

and theres a lot of love there.  a lot.  

love, :>

deep

hi, i just wrote this poem and i thought i'd share it with you all. if
you don't delete this right off the back or are one of those nrr
restricting fools, then tell me what you think. 

 Stupid is the boy who forgets how simple it is to tie his 
			shoes.
	Remember the rabbits, his sister tells him.
	  But, hes to busy thinking of his toys.
	Boys and their Toys, will they ever learn?
		Learn to spell your name,
		 his teacher tells him
	        Do you know what 2+2 is?
		   Or rather 1+1?
	But, he knows its not that simple.
	     Simplicity hides himself,
	  hes quite complicated to find.
       When looking for him close your eyes.
	  Imagination is your only guide.
		   Take my hand,
		dont take my hand?
	      Theres lots of touching
		Hes a big boy now.
	        "Why are you late?"
		 "Where were you?"
		    , He asks.
		    Questions?
	    The answers already there,
		    you know it.
	    "Dont look at me that way."
	    I wont look at you at all.
		     -But one-
		     plus one
	      its not that simple.
	     He keeps telling himself


-- 
strict-9(petrie)
e-male: ugm@earthlink.net
http://www.UGMadness.com

I was seriously thinking about all the way people were responding to
mean words and anything negative in any way. And i was thinking how did
all this come about and I saw that none of the negativity was there
until an advertisment about COOL WORLD's $6 make up. Then after it and
all the reviews were in about the event.
Which i think is good because when i don't go to a certain raves(whether
massive/underground/party) i wanna know how it was and about how food it
was and stuff.
We all do. right?
So right after the CW reviews people started posting sorta mean stuff.
Then it got meaner and meaner. Soon people jsut got tired about it and
stoped respoding to flames and falming people.
And I looked at all this and said? What caused all the negative posts.
What were they all getting at. What was the one unifying factor
envolving all thos negative posts? Do you know?
Yes, it was Planet New Year. And who brings you that? COOL WORLD.
So maybe there is some truth to what many people say about COOL WORLD
causing negativity among gererally happy good vibe ravers. And thats
what EVERYONE on this list is. You can't argue that point.
Well? What do you think? That's what I think.
Take a look at all the flames and negative postings. They all relate to
one thing...  COOL WORLD

Keep tha negativity and the flaming down.
We are all happy ravers in reality. Lets be the same in cyber-reality.
I am gonna be the first to start? Who will join me?

Peace.Love.Unity.Respect,
(anyone who filters those words confuses me)
Paul

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Feb 28 01:49:45 1997

To: "socal-raves@UCSD.EDU" <socal-raves@UCSD.EDU>
From: Marc Fathauer <marcus@technologik.com>
Subject: GHB Legal Status

        marcus@qnet.com, help@technologik.com

Precedence: bulk

For those in California who happen to have an interest in legal actions

regarding drugs, there are bills pending to change the scheduling of 
GHB

to schedule 1. There are lots of pro's and cons to the use of this

substance but I for one don't believe that this drug has near the abuse

potential of other schedule 1 (most dangerous) drugs. Schedule 1 drugs

are specifically classified as such because of their abuse potential 
and

total lack of medicinal use (oddly, Marijuana is still schedule 1).

Although there is potential for abuse, there is a wealth of positive

applications. Check out some of these sites:


http://www.ceri.com/feature.htm

http://www.erowid.com/entheogens/ghb/ghb.shtml

http://www.lycaeum.org/drugs/synthetics/ghb/

http://www.nepenthes.com/Drugs/GHB/


It's interesting that GHB is being targeted and to date, flunitrazepam

or Rohypnol-"roofies" which seems to be the real "date rape drug" is 
not

being attacked. I wonder if the fact that Rohypnol is made by a huge

chemical co.-Hoffman-La Roche, and GHB can be made at home has anything

to do with this.


Interesting also is the fact that LA's liberal candidate-to-be-mayor,

Tom Hayden is co-author of the bill! 


Here's info on these bills. Something that is way cool is that you can

"subscribe" to a bill and you will be e-mailed automatically when any

activity occurs:


http://www.leginfo.ca.gov/bilinfo.html


the bills are SB54 (state senate), AB6 (state assembly and identical to

SB56) and SB3 which looks identical to SB54 but who knows?


Let's do something about this now. I'll try to pass on anything I hear

to those interested. Once bad laws get passed they are a real pain in

the ass to change. MDMA has been schedule 1 for over 20 years and just

now are researchers being given a reasonable chance to prove that E has

great therapudic potential (something that shrinks knew all along) and

that it is reasonably safe. It will still be years before E will be

rescheduled if at all.


I know. I know. It sounds like BS but write or E-mail your state 
senator

and state assemblyman and ask him to look into the other positive side

of GHB. refer them to:


http://www.ceri.com/feature.htm

The facts and truth are evident. We just need to let them be known.


It's easy to find out who your politicians are too. All you need is 
your

zip code.


Go to:     http://www.leginfo.ca.gov/yourleg.html


Most of them have home pages on the net as well. Let your voices be

heard. Attached is the letter that I'm sending.

Dear Assemblyman/Senator



RE: AB 6, SB54, SB3



Please take the time to look into the positive aspects of the drug GHB
before voting. The most damage is being done by lack of knowledge and
lack of proper regulation. This drug does not belong on schedule 1
amongst dangerous drugs of zero value. 


Rohypnol or flunitrazepam is the "date rape drug" that you should be
spending your time and efforts toward rescheduling. 

see the following from the DEA:

http://www.usdoj.gov/dea/pubs/rohypnol/rohypnol.htm


As to the positive effects of GHB here's a web site to look at:

http://www.ceri.com/feature.htm


Take the time to look into this. Upon inspection you will find that there
is tremendous potential in the use of this drug as a treatment for
alcoholism, as a tool for the management of heroin addiction withdrawal,
as a sleeping aid and even possibly as a novel form of anti-depressant.
We need to get it in the hands of those who can prescribe it and not bury
it deeper in the underground. One other note to mention: GHB is not, like
Rohypnol, sold through organized drug channels (see DEA rept). In other
areas of the world, it is even sold in health food stores!



We have a serious drug problem in California today. Let's focus our
attention where it belongs:


Alcohol and tobacco abuse especially by our youth.

Methamphetamine production and abuse.

Banning truly dangerous and useless drugs like Rohypnol

Overcrowding of jails with non-violent offenders.

   

Education Education Education Education

kids must KNOW why to say NO. They don't "just say no"



I've included the most recent action taken on one of the bills, Assembly
Bill 6.

Note the reference to "rave" parties. Also note that it is being reported
as a date rape drug.


<fontfamily><param>Courier New</param><bigger>                           
    BILL ANALYSIS                                                        
                                                                         
                                                                 




                                                          AB 6

                                                         Page 1


Date of Hearing:  February 25, 1997

Counsel:          Jerome McGuire



                ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE ON PUBLIC SAFETY

                    Robert M. Hertzberg, Chair


         AB 6 (Bowler) - As Introduced:  December 2, 1996



Urgency statute.  2/3 vote required.


 ISSUE:    SHOULD GAMMA-HYDROXYBUTYRATE (GHB) BE CLASSIFIED AS A  

SCHEDULE I DRUG UNDER HEALTH AND SAFETY CODE SECTION 11054,  

SUBDIVISION (E)?


 SUMMARY:  Adds gamma-hydroxybutyrate (GHB) to the list of Schedule  

I controlled depressant substances in Health and Safety Code  

Section 11054, Subdivision (e).


 EXISTING LAW: 


1) Classifies controlled substances in five schedules according to  

   their danger and potential for abuse.  Schedule I substances  

   are the most restricted and have no accepted medical use.   

   (Health and Safety Code Section 11054, Subdivision (a)-(f) -  

   Schedule I substances.)


2)  Places two depressant substances - mecloqualone and  

methoqualone - in Schedule I.  (Health and Safety Code Section  

11054, Subdivision (e).)


3)  Makes possession of a Schedule I depressant substance an  

alternate felony/misdemeanor, punishable by 16 months, 2 or 3  

years in the state prison or up to one year in the county jail;  

makes possession for sale a felony, punishable by 2, 3 or 4 years  

in state prison; and makes sale, furnishing or transportation a  

felony, punishable by 3, 4 or 5 years in state prison.  (Health  

and Safety Code Sections 11350, 11351 and 11352.)


 BACKGROUND:  


1)   Author's Statement.  According to the author:

   

       "AB 6 will add the new 'designer drug' Gamma Hydroxy  

       Butyrate (GHB) to California's list of controlled  

       substances.


       As was the case last session, with the 'date rape drug'  

       Rohypnol, GHB is not currently recognized by California law  

       and is therefore not illegal to possess or use.  AB 6 seeks  

       to rectify this situation and list GHB as a 'Schedule 1'  

       controlled substance, thus allowing law enforcement to  

       prosecute individuals for possession and use.


       <color><param>0000,0000,8080</param>Like Rohypnol, the growth in
the use of GHB has been  

       astronomical.  The drug has been linked to a number of  

       deaths, and the stories of young people overdosing on the  

       drug have been spreading across the state and country.  In  

       addition to the great dangers associated with personal use  

       of the drug, GHB has also been linked to a number of 

       sexual assaults, and is being used in a manner similar to  

       Rohypnol."

</color>

2)   Development and Original Medical Use.  Gamma-hydroxybutyrate  

(GHB) is a substance which naturally occurs in the body.  As such,  

GHB cannot be a patented substance.  GHB appears to act as a  

neurotransmitter in the brain.  GHB was synthesized in 1960 and  

developed for use as as an anesthetic.  GHB fell into disfavor as  

an anesthetic in England because it lacks analgesic - pain  

relieving - properties.  However, it appears that GHB is still  

used in Europe as a surgical anesthetic.  In its synthesized form,  

GHB is a central nervous system (CNS) depressant. 
<color><param>ffff,0000,0000</param>While GHB is  

not produced by any major pharmaceutical companies in the United  

States, GHB is legally available in the United States for the  

experimental treatment of narcolepsy, a sleeping disorder.  It is  

also used in the treatment of heroin addition, alcoholism, and  

other conditions.

</color>

3)  Reported Recreational Use and Effects.  In California, GHB is  

   produced in non-legitimate laboratories and is usually  

   distributed as a liquid, diluted with water.  Users of GHB  

   often mix the drug with alcohol and take it combination with  

   other drugs.  <color><param>ffff,0000,0000</param>GHB has reportedly
become popular at "rave"  

   parties in Los Angeles and the Bay Area. 

</color>

   The intended effect for recreational users of the drug is an  

   intense, euphoric "high" of about two-hours' duration which  

   includes the lowering of sexual inhibitions.  The drug  

   typically induces sedation and sleep after the "high".  Side  

   effects include nausea, respiratory depression and arrest, coma  

   and seizures.  


<color><param>ffff,0000,0000</param>4)  Medical and Agency Reports. 
Hospitals and poison control  

   centers have reported an increase in overdoses on GHB.  Deaths  

   have been attributed to the use of the drug.  However, a  

   warning about GHB written by the Federal Food and Drug  

   Administration (FDA) in the April 1991  Journal of the  American  

   Medical  Association stated that no deaths from the use of the  

   drug had been reported.  In December 1996, Federal Drug  

   Enforcement Administration reported that at least three deaths  

   had been associated with GHB use, although GHB could not be  

   considered the sole cause of these deaths, especially  

   considering that the combined use of alcohol and GHB produces a  

   more pronounced CNS depressant effect.

</color>

5)   Schedule Classification Issue.  Because it appears that there  

may be legitimate medical uses for GBH, the issue is raised  

whether the drug should be classified under Schedules II, III, or  

IV so that physicians may prescribe GHB under regulated  

procedures.



 ARGUMENTS IN SUPPORT:  None on file


 ARGUMENTS IN OPPOSITION:  The California Attorneys for Criminal  

Justice state,

"Using criminal penalties as a means to stop drug abuse is a  

strategy that has been tried and that has failed.  Rather than  

further extending the reach of our criminal laws, with little or  

no benefit to to public safety and at great expense to the state,  

we should be looking towards other ways to stop the abuse of drugs  

- offering treatment programs to those who want help, for example.  

 Adding one more substance to the long list of those the  

possession or use of which can land people in jail or prison will  

do nothing to make Californians safer and will eat up state  

resources better used otherwise."


 REGISTERED SUPPORT/OPPOSITION:


 Support:  


None on file


 Opposition:  


California Attorneys for Criminal Justice

here is an article from the LA Times, I know it's two months old, but I 
don't remember anyone posting it...


BY DESIGN
Baby's Night Out
With Blankies, Pacifiers and Hello Kitty Paraphernalia, Ravers Are 
Turning Dance Floors Into Playpens

By MARK EHRMAN, SPECIAL TO THE TIMES

Los Angeles Times   Thursday January 2, 1997
Home Edition
Life & Style, Page 2


Never mind the high-decibel techno music pounding away at 120 beats per 
second or the trippy, continually morphing fractal graphics projected 
onto giant screens or even the late hour. When it comes to how people 
dress for raves, they might as well be heading to "Romper Room."

   Lining up outside a "map point" recently (a location where ravers 
receive tickets and directions to underground raves), hundreds of girls 
with their hair in pigtails wait alongside guys with hands encased in 
puffy white Mickey Mouse gloves. Over at Magic Wednesdays--a weekly club 
based in the World in Hollywood that serves up rave music and ambience on 
a weekly basis--glo-stick-waving late-teen and twentysomethings gyrate on 
the dance floor decked out in candy-colored outfits, Dr. Seuss hats, Bert 
and Ernie backpacks, Hello Kitty paraphernalia and whistles. And just 
about everybody has a pacifier dangling from the neck on a string of 
plastic beads--when they're not sucking on it, that is. For most 
scenesters, retro-fashion may be the ultimate in regression, but ravers 
have gone beyond that. Way beyond. Over the years, raves may have grown 
and gone suburban, but the clothes have never left the crib. In these 
multimedia fantasy lands, baby wear rules.

   "When you were young, didn't you used to play with toys?" asks 
21-year-old Justin Pitter, who goes by the nom-de-rave Kryolon. Pitter 
has shown up at Magic Wednesdays (he also hits about two full-blown raves 
a week) sporting a Superman shirt and pants, a pacifier and a transparent 
plastic backpack with a can of Play-Doh hanging from the zipper and 
plenty of toys inside. "When you got older, your parents told you not to 
do that anymore. Now that we're grown up, why not go out and act like 
kids? It's colorful and it's happy and it's all about having a good time."

   "I'd say the kiddie crowd is the most visible crowd within the 
ravers," says Ken Lawrence of Pure Acid, a company that operates 
concession booths at raves and at clubs such as Magic Wednesdays.

   Pure Acid offers ravers not only CDs of popular DJ mixes, but 
pacifiers, whistles, toys, beads and the No. 1 rave refreshment, Charms 
Blow-Pops. "Raves and clubs like this pretty much give you an excuse to 
act more childlike than you usually do--all without hurting anybody. So 
people like to dress up like cartoon characters to add to the silly 
environment. It's a synergy of everybody coming together and making a 
strange environment. It makes it more fun."

   While that may be valid, it's also true that the pacifier--the most 
ubiquitous rave accessory and the item that probably served as the 
genesis for the baby wear craze--sometimes has a more practical purpose: 
It keeps ravers from grinding their teeth while high on the scene's drug 
of choice, Ecstasy.

   Pitter and his club companion, 22-year-old Aimee Macabeo, a.k.a. Star, 
say they never ingest anything more potent than water. But many other 
ravers privately admit the pacifier's ties to Ecstasy, although many also 
add that it has evolved away from its drug roots into a cute fashion 
accessory.

   "The whole scene is based on drugs," says Atousa, a veteran L.A. raver 
and designer of the clothing line A Liquid Affair. "But it's gone totally 
mainstream. It's a whole lifestyle for these kids now. You'll see kids 
sitting on the floor and they're playing with dolls and eating candy and 
you think you're back in kindergarten. I've even seen kids carrying
blankies."

   Atousa cruises the scene looking for inspiration for her designs. For 
instance, she recently created an opalescent jacket with a fur collar and 
hood. The effect, she says, "is to make you look like Snow Bunny."

   Nowadays, stores such as Ministry of Aesthetics, Pasty and Ultramarket 
sell rave wear by such designers as A Liquid Affair and carry plastic 
toys and trinkets, many with cartoon motifs imported from the capital of 
cute, Japan. Still, putting together a baby wear ensemble seldom 
translates into one-stop retail shopping. With raves typically costing 
about $20 a head, high-ticket clothing is rarely an option. So many 
ravers sew their own.

   "It's cheaper and you have the freedom to do anything you want," 
Pitter says. He and Macabeo, he says, often spend afternoons in the 
garment district hunting down fabrics to stitch into pants, shirts or 
dresses on their home sewing machines. Macabeo adds that only one brand 
inspires her to pay mall prices: the Hello Kitty stuff sold in such 
stores as San Rio Gift Gate in the Beverly Center. "I can't help it," she 
says. "I love Hello Kitty."

   *

   Those without design skills usually hit the thrift stores. While much 
of the vintage clothing in adult sizes has long since left the Salvation 
Army for the pricey racks of Melrose Avenue, such in-demand baby labels 
as Playskool and Sesame Street remain.

   "I put this whole thing together for less than $10," brags 19-year-old 
raver Theresa Lee, who hits about a rave a week draped in a plastic 
Minnie Mouse raincoat with plastic daisies in her hair, a Sesame Street 
pack on her back, toy watch on her wrist and, of course, a pacifier not 
far from her mouth.

   And, often you can find the best and funnest stuff without even 
leaving the house.

   "I would separate and save stuff that I loved even while I was a kid, 
so I still have it," says Macabeo as she prepares her wardrobe for the 
upcoming weekend's raves. "People would always tell me, 'Oh, grow up.' 
But I never really did."


Copyright, The Times Mirror Company; Los Angeles Times, 1997.

MARK EHRMAN, BY DESIGN; Baby's Night Out; With Blankies, Pacifiers and 
Hello Kitty Paraphernalia, Ravers Are Turning Dance Floors Into Playpens; 
Home Edition, Los Angeles Times,  2 Jan 1997, pp. E-2.

I completely agree.  I hold no malice towards the production entity known
as coolworld.  *People* make the party - if we have a problem with
massives, or bad vibe, it's the audience, not the promoters who are really
the source.  Same thing with negative posts... there's just no excuse for
throwing bad vibe over a third party (pun).. you can't blame them, we can
only blame ourselves.  I personally think the attendence of massives
includes a dark element that is certainly an issue to be aware of or maybe
even complain about, but I'll tell you I certainly had a good time at
almost every massive I've gone to because I love the music, and I love the
people I'm there with, and to me that's all that matters.  Max

>I completely agree.  I hold no malice towards the production entity known
>as coolworld.  *People* make the party - if we have a problem with
>massives, or bad vibe, it's the audience, not the promoters who are really

Whoa, wait a minute, listen to what you are saying...man I have to
*strongly* disagree with you.  The promoters of a party have a *lot* to do
with the vibe.  The party/rave/event/gala/whatever starts the moment the
idea was sparked in the promoters/organizers head.  The vibe starts right
there.  End of story.  If someone comes up with an idea, hey lets throw
this party we can make bank, I can tell you a little bit about what the
vibe might be like.  I don't care who shows up to the party, I can still
tell you what kind of vibe will be around the whole night.

If, I, as a particpant in planning parties thought that I didn't have
anything to do with the vibe, I wouldn't be doing what I'm doing.  I have a
lot to do with the vibe that is set at parties I help with, that's why I'm
there.

love drenalin

At 2:55 PM -0800 2/28/97, Paul Hayden wrote:
>When I went to LA for a rave.
>Everyone was decked out beyonh our comprehension.
>They have nothing but Candy Ravers there.
>It's amazingly cool.
>Love.Luck.Lollipops,
>Paul

I gotta agree to some degree with Paul on this one.  Reading that article I
was taken WAAAAAY back to when this stuff was just getting in the public
eye.  LA has it when it comes to rave fashion.  I remember the first cat in
the hat hat I saw, of course it was in LA.  Damn those kids could dress.

Yeah there was other fashions too, but the cartoon cahracter element was
the most fun part.  Seeing what people has put together, and they were
perfectly comfortable wering the stuff as everyday too.  Kinda cool IMO.

Now I ain't goin' to no candy rave, but I think the idea is cool.  And it's
cool that that element is surviving.  Sf gave up alot of the costumes
really quick, it's good too see that vibe still exists somewhere.  And that
people are still into that elment of dance.

There are few things better than getting completely out of your head
(flipping was my spot) and watching a living, breathing, organic cartoon
character dancing to beats.  Then again I do miss my bra-booty-betty's,
damn that shit was D_O_P_E!  More bounce to the ounce...those were the
days....

See y'all later...the weekend is nigh, and I got my original candy raver
for the weekend (my son).  Although he hates dance music, he's into hip-hop
& jungle.  He ain't 'bout no house...yet that is.

Out,
John

Subject: SFRaves, PLUR or .... (very long)

Precedence: bulk

Hey everybody!

Long time, no post, but I am sure this one will make up for it :).

	As many of you noticed, last few weeks SFR has been *different*...
I have been on the list for a year now, which is not that long, but I feel
like the list has lost a lot of it's appeal.  More than once in last few
weeks I thought about leaving the list, because I wouldn't have to deal
with unnecessary flaming, stupid posts, and basically 90% of the posts I
have to read every day that don't bring anything to my life (except
headache).  The reason I stayed is because I've meet some wonderful people
through this list (Leslie, Tim K., Nancy, Kirsten, Noah, Micron, Terry,
Patrick, Andy W., - to name the few I consider great people, and whom I
have met because of the list), and I would feel like maybe I would be
missing the opportunity to meet great people without being the part of the
list.  Maybe, I would also meet these people at parties, because we were
meant to run into each other at one point or another, but the list gave me
the opportunity to speed up this process.

	I also like finding out what different people did over the weekend,
their rave experiences, their views on issues that are related to the
community we share; somebody's first rave, and the thrill that goes with
it....  Sometimes I like reading *intelligent* flames (John S. Lee,
BlackAdder and Niels, Leslie etc.).  Cute, sappy posts :) about people
falling in love at a rave etc. can be fun as well.  But lately, it seems
like most of this charm has disappeared and people are just their to post
unnecessary posts most of the time, try to preach 'how to be a raver',
flame others in a bad way etc.

	Here is where my PLUR section begins.  PLUR is starting to be a
very meaningless word, and more I stay on the list, the word irritates me
more and more.  I am sure many of you heard the saying "A dog that barks
doesn't bite."  In many cases I have seen, people who *preach* PLUR, only
know the words it stands for, but they are so far from understanding the
meaning of some of those words.  Many of the examples are on the list.  The
once I have noticed:
Is it respectful?
- to call people names
- to try to find something in somebody's post, so FLAME can begin
- to post 10 meaningless messages a day
- to tell people what "real raver does" and if you don't do it you can't be
a "raver"
- to tell people which drugs are good and which are bad, and if you do bad
drugs they don't want to hang out with you
- to have no understanding of what others do, even after they try to explain it

	Anyway - these are few things I have noticed, and rarely I find
people who preach PLUR to follow it in real life as well.  So, I rather
find out what people are like, and start liking them for their qualities,
than for their loudness about PLUR and PLURiness they have.

	My thoughts on this subject - if you have any constructive input, I
would be more than interested in it - if not, please don't post stupid
things (flames for the sake of it) - we have enough of them as it is (you
can send them to me if you really need to).

*B*

P.S. see some of you at "Warmth"

This Saturday Gateway Systems invites you to SHINE with James Dee,
Ethan, Darin Marshall, Sutekh and John Carel.  Float on an ambient cloud
while groovin to Joe Rice, Consciousness Lab, Claire, and Rich.  Free
breakfast will be served in the A.M.  Feel free to bring didgeridoos,
drums, altar art or contibutions.  Tarot card readings, smoothies, and
food will also be present. Tickets will be on sale at a map point in SF
that night. 
For info. please call 415.536.9453.  Thank you....    Feel it-Love.


 For those who have tickets from New Years...
SHINE is not the make up party for the Gateway/Pacific New Years.
Together, Gateway and Pacific Sound Systems are currently working on
obtaining permits from the city of SF for a daytime festival in the
bandshell in Golden Gate park for a Saturday in April.  We will be
flying in live acts/DJ's tba, also performance art groups, and providing
free food and beverages.  We apologize for not being able to create a
make-up event sooner and appreciate your support and understanding.  The
co-production on New Years was our most elaborate and beautiful
production. We obtained all the insurance, space contracts, security,
etc. the city required and were denied permits a week before the event. 
The cities reason being "There are not enough police officers available
for the event." With all other city perameters met, we perhaps
mistakenly, decided to continue.  All of us with Gateway and Pacific put
in all our energy, time, money and resources to create a magical night
which sadly many of you of never got to experience.  Our intention is to
create a magical outdoor festival (with permits) to bring in a new
season and some new sounds. If you are dissappointed, angry, happy,
supportive or just want to give us some imput (please) direct it to this
e-mail address or leave a message at 415.536.9453 or the Sunset vm. Have
a positive weekend...

From: Leslie Ayres <Leslie.Ayres@ncal.kaiperm.org>

Subject: The Fairy Rave Mother Speaks...
MIME-Version: 1.0
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello, all you sweet SFRavers (and some pleasantly not-so-sweet).

Branka's wonderful post has prompted me to post as well.

Many of you know me, and many don't, since I've been off the list for a couple of months due to other time commitments. Last Monday, I subbed again just to see what was up. I was planning to unsub quietly again, but (are you surprised?) I would like to share some thoughts first.

SFRaves is different things to different people.   Young, old, different backgrounds, different perspectives. That's part of the pleasure and wonder of this list, that a diverse group of people can come together because we share something in common.. we love to dance all night.  We love the music and the scene.  The list has had its ups and downs, but has held together because of the common thread.

But, as Phred pointed out recently, it is a fragile thing.  And there are a few things that can poison it easily.  If you are committed to being a part of keeping this virtual "community" alive, there are some things you *must* remember.

1.  You're talking to REAL PEOPLE here!  This is more than just an internet group.  Most of the people on this list personally know at least a few others, and many of us have met *many* others.  That's because what holds us together is dancing together.... this is not an abstract, intellectual discussion group of faceless people, folks... this is the online connection to many people who you see every week out dancing.  Remember that.  There are faces attached to these (usually amazingly creative) email addies.  Meet as many as you can!

2.  WALK the WALK.  One of the premises of the rave scene is that, through dance and music, we can connect and transcend in new ways.  If you want to be part of the future, act it.  If you want to change the world, it has to start with you. That means becoming consciously aware of who you are and how your actions affect others.   You want to make the world a better place (and hopefully everyone does) ... then be a better person.  Let us set the example, which sometimes means catching ourselves in inappropriate behavior and *changing it*!

3.  THINK before you SPEAK.  Write your message, read it, read it again, and edit it, and do it again before you send it!  It's challenging to communicate in writing as clearly as you might in person, but learn to do it.  Half the problems on the list come from people misunderstanding other's intentions.... and that's usually because the messages were poorly thought through in the first place.  If you have something to say, it should be worth the time to compose your post so the reader will understand.  And personally, I think profanity is rarely appropriate.

4.  Be NICE.  How simple is that?  You don't have to like people, but treating people with respect is required if you want the same in return.

5.  Be HUMBLE.  I know sometimes we all think we have the magic answer and know the only way things should be, but that's not likely now, is it?   The arrogance of youth and the cynicism of age are the two most poisonous ingredients on this list... and both would probably be softened quite a bit if people took a minute to realize they don't know everything, and that other people see the world in a different way.  

5.  Don't fight in PUBLIC.  Personal arguments belong private.  Never cc your flame to the list.  We don't want to know.

6.  SPEAK UP, YOU LURKERS!   There are 450+ people on this list, and I know for a fact many of you silent ones have thoughtful and interesting things to say.  Please don't let the bullies scare you off, cuz this is your list too.

7.  Use your HEAD.  Don't post about illegal activities.  That's stupid.  You want information, fine, but avoid talking about personal actions that may reflect on you and the others around you in a negative way.  This is a PUBLIC forum.

8.  Wear more HATS!  OK, that's optional.  But always way more fun!   I'm feeling much more like myself lately, so it's probably time to pull out a crazy headpiece tomorrow night for Warmth.  Special hugs for all other hat-wearers!

I hope to see many of you out, and encourage you go come introduce yourselves to me if we haven't met.   And you better all be coming to the campout, hear?!?!?

Much love,
Leslie

Subject: Keepin' it fresh
Date: Sat, 01 Mar 1997 03:37:07 GMT
Message-ID: <3318a229.696549907@mail.wco.com>
X-Mailer: Forte Agent .99g/32.339
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I have been a raver for 5 or 6 years now and have often had to face
the possibility of burnout.  I am wondering how other people manage to
stay enthused with raving while others move on to other things(not
that that's necessarily bad).  One thing I like to do is have a unique
"theme" to meditate on while dancing at each party. When my mind
wanders I return to my "theme" in an attempt to gain insight into the
subject.  Here are some of the things I have thought of:

Helping out or putting on your own parties.  Very fun but it carries
its own burnout/disillusionment factor.

Traveling to other areas.  I have traveled around N. America and
England but don't have the resources to do so right now.  The recent
descriptions of LA sound enticing, however.

Trying out new scenes.  Been to a jungle or goa party?

Does anyone have any other suggestions?

*hugz*
David

*B* wrote:
 
>         As many of you noticed, last few weeks SFR has been *different*...
> I have been on the list for a year now, which is not that long, but I feel
> like the list has lost a lot of it's appeal.  More than once in last few
> weeks I thought about leaving the list, 

I know how u feel.  I've unsubscribed on and off during the last few months.
I've also known others who have done the same.  I seem to can't help coming 
back.  I don't go out as much anymore and have difficulty keeping up with the
high volume posts.  But I still seem to come back.  I find that I'm deleting
alot more these days, but here I am.
I still get facinated with some of the communication that goes on here.  Lurking 
on sfraves when I can, helps me stay connected to a "scene" that has given me
so much.
I'm not sure exactly why I decided to come out of lurk mode.  Maybe its because I 
relate to your post, and appreciate your willingness to express these feelings and
continue to be a part of the list and make an effort to keep sfraves as something
u find to be special.
For me I have to say that I appreciate (not as often as I use to) the feelings I get
from what I am able to see in others here and when I go out, the love for the music, 
that brings us together.  I love the high I feel, from that sense of sharing the music
with myself enjoying the feelings that I get to experience from it.  I love the high
I feel when I am able to sense  the sharing of the love of the music that brings us
all together.  I like being able to see this in our words, how we dance together, and
just seeing the expressions on peoples faces.  
I also really appreciate the differences that people are able to express, and see 
how many of us can enjoy and struggle with some of our differences.  
They always seem to be more tolerable and more beautiful when I can be in tune
with the "vibe".  
Sometimes the "vibe" is more obvious to me than other times, but I think it always
exists.  When we are sharing the vibe, we can share so much.

I hope I didn't ramble on for too much.  I guess I'm just feeling a little sentimental
about our list along with some mixed feelings.  Thank you to all of u who help keep
the vibe alive here on sfraves, by your expressions and relativity to raving.

:)
peter

>  due to some unfortunate cicumstances i am going to have to get another

anyone knew > whether E would show up or not?  it seems highly unlikely to
